A parent writes to praises the school's teachers, assistant principal, and parent coordinator but notes that "it is very difficult to speak to the principal -- she seems to be bothered or not really concerned" and that the PTA does not take an active role in improving the school. She also notes that there are few extracurricular activities.

"While the school is a great improvement in terms of class size from her last school in Queens (terribly over-crowded -- about 35-38 kids per class vs. 15-22 at PS 34) and the classes are airy, well-kept and seem to have great materials," writes parent, Elsia Miah-Almodovar. "I agree with the father who said that the Principal seems to focus so much on test scores that there's little time and focus on encouraging children's imaginations. Learning the basics are important, but there has to be some effort towards encouraging and motivating children to seek ways and learning tools outside of the classroom. There are no after-school activities except for tutoring for those children with low-test scores. The music teacher is amazing, but is so intent on making the music program work, that many children complain that there's no enjoying what they learn. My daughter had two absolutely wonderful and dedicated teachers in 5th and 6th grades. They responded to all my concerns and questions and kept in touch throughout the school year and summer. The principal, however, is very hard to reach and is not seen often interacting the students. The parent-teacher coordinator is responsive, very helpful. Also, because the school has students from Kindergarten through 8th grade, they need to keep a better watch on the older students' interactions with the younger ones. This past year my daughter's class was pen pals with older students from a school in the Bronx - they should've thought about doing something along those lines with the students in the school - perhaps pairing an 8th grade class with a 6th grade class and 7th grade class with 5th grade and so on. Actually all schools should create such programs. Overall, I am please with the school and hope it continues to improve."
This school will never improve especially with the people that work there changes should be made
Diana, a student, writes that she does not like the school's policy of requiring uniforms. She believes the dress code is not well enforced anyway.

This school is an amazing school because we have great teachers. Me and my friends are in fourth grade and our teachers are Ms. Trail, Ms. Goldman, and Ms. Faust. I love math and they teach a lot about multiplication, division, and word problems that are a little hard but not too hard. So, if you're looking for a school for your child I suggest this school. From a PS63 Star Academy kid. Jazlyn!

We love PS63! As a educator with 20 
years of private school, public school, Elementary, Middle and High 
School, rural and urban schools, I had a lot of knowledge about 
schooling from the inside, but was really nervous about choosing a 
school for my (then) three year old.

Initially 
looking for schools closer to home in Brooklyn, I olny discovered PS63 
with the help of a DOE Staffer. It was our top choice for the second 
round of Pre-K admissions and it was like hitting the 
jackpot! I could see when we came in to register that the staff was 
warm, astute and child-centered--incredible foreshadowing for the year 
to 
come.


In addition to welcoming us all the staff 
showed tremendous 
care and affirmation and appropriately challenged and guided my 
daughter. Her teacher quickly and easily read and understood my child; 
her communication 
with families was respectful, timely and concise; her teaching 
partnership with was a lovely balance and our conferences were fruitful,
 direct, realistic and 
practical.



Outside of her primary 
classroom, my daughter benefited from and still talks about classes from
 last year with her other teachers--PE, Music, Art, and Library (our 
second home)--who made 
fantastic recommendations to engage her, helped her to find joy, 
confidence and 
curiosity in creation and movement and gave her concrete tools for 
collaboration.


Finally,
 the collaboration with Notes in Motion (afterschool) was so great for my daughter!

My kid and I love this school. My child has been at Star since preK. I highly recommend this school especially if you are into a caring staff, close family environment, and a lovely school setting. A couple of years ago I had a health crisis and the way staff responded, in particular Ms. Ferrone, was nothing short of amazing. She treated my child with extra care and really looked out for him. These are some of the few wonderful things this school has to offer.

My daughter has attended this school for 5 years, and I couldn't be happier with my choice in elementary school.  The teachers are amazing, and very dedicated to the students. They do not teach for state tests instead they prepare the students for critical thinking. There are no text books, which I like since they create their own curriculum and are not limited to teach according to one textbook. In Math and ELA, students are broken out in groups based on their ability across the grades, but have specific focus to help them grow and develop.  The classes have two teachers and then one or two assistant teachers.  They are available to answer questions. And ClassDojo (a facebook for schools) is a great tool for teachers, parents, and staff to stay connected.  Teachers post videos with new math concepts to help parents understand (!!!!).  The staff is amazingly supportive. Ms. Cameron (p) and Ms. Friedman (vp) are always there to greet parents and guide students through the day.  Ms. Alice (the parent coordinator) is heart of the school!  It is a small school, but builds a great community and support for parents, students, teachers and staff.

The city has terminated its contract with the company that has been working on the construction project at PS 63. Health and safety concerns have arisen from parents as school administrators have been forced to clean human waste and syringes from school grounds. Parents are hopeful that conditions will improve with a new company, DNA Info reports.

A mural art project now adorns the outside of the building which has been heavily scaffolded for construction projects. Read more about the project, done in conjunction with the Inside Out Project, here.
Data showed that PS 63 reported no or low numbers of bullying for the 2013-14 school year. Read more here.
Principal Darlene Cameron thinks about opening a second pre-K class to increase student enrollment. Read more here

Public schools offering pre-K navigate two systems for providing supports like speech and physical therapy. Assistant Principal Jodi Friedman, who oversees P.S. 63 S.T.A.R. Academy’s pre-K class expresses concerns that having to use a separate process can present challenges for families and for the school. Read more here.
Principal Darlene Cameron applauds more time for teacher development as part of Mayor de Blasio's new labor contract deal with the UFT—although not everyone is convinced. Read more here.
A major renovation project on the building shared by STAR Academy and the Neighborhood School has gotten off to a slow start due to the snowy winter. Read more here.

I was a student at STAR Academy for several years in this school (since pre-k). I have never felt so loved and safe in this nurturing environment. Whenever I had a problem or was struggling in a family crisis, friendship drama, or academic struggles, the teachers and staff members were always there by my side. The way they realized when I needed help was just by looking at my actions, they would see a change in my behavior and they automatically knew something was wrong because, they knew me so well as an individual and my personality. And it wasn't one person who knew me well. It was every teacher there was in the building. I have decided to share my opinion publicly because after this year I will be attending high school. After watching what I have been through and successfully accomplishing goals, I want to say that I don't think I could have ever achieved things in such a small part of my life. I don't think I could ever have accomplished my goals if it wasn't for STAR Academy. Now I am a 8th grade student currently attending Tompkins Square Middle School and I am applying to high schools, while others are having a hard time applying and losing confidence in themselves. I am impatient and very excited to receive my acception letter. My younger sister is in her final year of attending this school, and she is very glad that she is able to spend her last year here in a STAR community.

Star Academy believes that teamwork is one way that makes our school and students successful.  My children shares happy events with me.  Very few moments are sad but they manage to turn it into a positive attitude.  PTA and SLT teams are strong.  Opportunities for parents are open and we are all well informed.  Academics is very important and also being well rounded students will prepare for happy and successful human beings.

I would like to say that this school has been nothing but great to my
 daughter since she entered the school in kindergarten. She is now in 
3rd grade and still loves the school as well as the staff. Granted the 
school in not perfect but what school is? But the staff goes above and 
beyond to make sure that us parents are well informed of everything that goes on with our children. Ms. Alice the parent coordinator has always been awesome and amazing to everyone. As parents we have to take responsibility for our children and their actions. We know our children better than anyone else, so Im sure we recognize what our children can bring to each environment, good and bad. Accidents happen ALL THE TIME for children, even with supervision present. When our children are hurt at home or we as parents make mistakes, do you immediately label our self as a bad parent? Of course not somethings just happen and with children things always 
happen.
 My daughter is extremely sensitize so I am extremely over protective with my her so I'm looking at all aspects of the school and I have no complaints. And whenever I have any issues they are addressed then handled by whoever I bring the issue to. Yes, she has been in the nurses office for minor injuries, yes she has cried because of something someone said but its always handled before the issue is brought to me. What stands out is when we walk in the building and all the staff address my daughter by name, the staff address me by first name, my daughter comes home sharing happy stories very often, she's eager to get to school to participate in school activities and explains why she loves the people that surround her. You are a parent and you feel things need to change? Ok, I'm sure there maybe tons of parents with concerns and that's what the PTA is for. Join and help make a difference in our school. The hours are flexible enough to meet the needs of working parents as well. Why not work as a TEAM to make the school better for our children instead of criticizing the ones that are a major part of our children's life? 

My opinion and my experience!
The playground at PS 63 could be partially shut down through 2015 due to construction. Read more here.

Students tested features of an "Recyclarium" that offers kids interactive games to teach the importance of reusing different materials. The chancellor said he chose PS 63 because of the school's composting project. 
Read more: http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20120801/east-village/city-use-converted-trailer-teach-kids-about-recycling#ixzz22PFsPXh2

I attended the Open House event last night and it was great. The teachers were warm and friendly, classroom work was very impressive, and as a felllow educator I was impressed by the curriculum, belief systems, and critieria for learning!

My child is currently enrolled in pre-k at P.S. 63 and I couldn't be happier.  He has progressed so much this year, it knocks my socks off.  His teacher, Ms. Hardaway is great with all of the children and they are all extremely happy and excited to go to school.  What stands out about the pre-k class versus the rest of the school is the amount of parent involvement.

I have been disappointed to see how little the parents are involved with the school and ensuring that it is a great place for your child to learn and grow.  I have a feeling that all of the parents who have complained below have never given an ounce of their time to make the school a better place, which is sad.  

PS 63 has a small student body, giving every child ample opportunity to have lots of individualized attention.  Moreover I find the staff to be incredibly dedicated to their craft and to each and every child.  If children are failing at this school it's because they're are not getting the support they need at home, not because the teachers aren't trying their hardest.

The extra-curricular teachers for art, music, gym and dance class are all incredible and Ms. Alice is a cornerstone of this institution.  In truth, I don't know much about the principle, I'm not wowed by her, but I feel at most schools the principals really aren't the one's who know what's going on, it's either the asst. principle or someone of that caliber underneath them.

Overall for this school to be the best it can be, it needs parents who are willing to dedicate their time to their child's education.

My child attends the school. I am very pleased with the staff and how far my child has grown both personally and scholastically. It is no surprise those who are complaining still have difficulty spelling. Accountability is not abuse. There are many challenges the school needs to address, but they are moving in the right direction. I applaud the faculty on achieving the distinction of "Top Performing School." Keep up the hard work!

Thank you insideschools.org for posting all the reivews NOT just the positive ones about this school from the staff. I feel secure knowing that the comments are for real. Other sites delete reviews that dont depict a glowing school and only leave the ones from the staff & teachers!

My child came home one day, and said to me that he has enough of the abuse from this school. This school picks favorite students and the rest are neglected. If a parent asks a question involving the curriculum, the child will be picked by the teacher. I never experience such a poor runned school. Even the aftersoon program, the teacher aid (parrent coordinator) embarasses the child. Is this right? YOu should never embarass a child. The child should be encouraged. My child was not the only victim here.His friends experience the same abuse. Teachers are inexperienced even though they teach for over 10 years. Experience comes with quidelines. Howeve the principal too does not have experience . SHe graduated from the principal colege and was given a job to be a principal. Look up her creditials. Teachers are protected bytheir union and the union repesentative treatens parents if the parents are concerned about  child or want answers to why a child was injured multiply times inschool or why wrong information was sent out. There is no accountability. I am glad that my child is at abetter school. I no longer have to deal with this undue stress. Please think twice about this school.

This is not true about PS63. The principal is the worst. There is no transperancy. They have a low enrollment because no one wants to send the children to this school. Who is to say that all of the injures were  reported to the state. I know when my child attended this school, he got hurt 5 times in a period of 2 months. Teachers do not supervise the children nor do the aides. They are too busy talking. Please parents send your childrent elsewear. It is for the good of your children. Also if you ask too many questions about the curiculum or why the teacher does not check the homework. (basically one question) then your are banned in bringing your child to school. You have to drop off the childr by the  security office. Is this right. remember it is  the principal's  scchool .  Ask the princcipal how many children were banned last year or the year before . Terrible staff. I experienced that the teachers , staff, and principal lies.  This school needs  better staff, teachers and  a  principal.

I would like to begin by saying congratulations on being a top performing school AND being removed from the persistently dangerous schools list!!!! Now to address so many "negative" reviews about PS 63. Being born/raised just a couple of blocks away, I have a long history with 63! Many of my family & friends (at one time or another) had attended 63--including myself for Kindergarten. My own children attended for a short time. I found the Principal to be totally and 100% clear and transparent for ALL! To demand nothing but 150% from her staff and basically this woman has changed 63 for the better! She will try to help parents out as much as possible WITHIN reason. No principal can agree to accommodate every single parental request--that is just insane! Anytime I wanted to speak with her, never had a problem! Now the staff! What can I say, as a parent and teacher I have never meet such dedicated individuals! These teachers are in the school from abt 7am till well past 4pm trying to give support to their students! Teachers know students and parents by first name! They are more then qualified and go above and beyond to offer support! Does the school have issues , yes, I found it to have but all schools do! If you go into expecting to find no problems in any school, you will be disappointed! Every parent has different expectations. Now why my children do not attend PS 63--it was a personal choice for my family. We want something different, our children lead different lives and as comfortable in different surroundings. That doesnt mean this school is lacking and people should run away. One size fits all doesnt work in education, hence, all the differnt types of schools and programs. I have met some wonderful teachers and I only wish the best for PS 63!

My child's teacher were always coming into the building at 8:30. They never pick up the kids until after 8:40. No supervised drop off. The kids run and run in the roof or cafeteria area. The teachers are not there past 3 o clock because they go to do the extended day therefore you can not talk to them. Don't know what time frame you are speaking of.

Wow. This must be a different place now because the time my kids went their, yes, teachers came down at exactly 8:30, sometimes 8:35...very rarely after that (our first year there) but no supervision at dropp off??? Ms Alice and Ms Nancy were always around! Ms Nancy made it a point to tell you to notifiy her NOT just leave your child and go so she is aware of who is there. The school security is right there all the time and believe you me, you may think she doesnt watch but she is totally aware of who is coming and going and if she didnt recongize you YOU WERE STOPPED! At pick up, children either came down with a teacher or para or you picked up in the classroom! During lunch I really dont know as I wasnt there but my kids always said tons of adults were around. I had different issues with the school but supervision at pick up and dropp off wasnt one of them.

Former Parent, nothing has changed since your great experience. I am a parent and the morning recess is supervised. Ms. Alice is still there and Ms. Rodriguez supervising the upper grades, Ms. Nancy is still with the lower grades. There is organization, but remember morning is really for breakfast, there are not a lot of adults who have hours during that time parents are supposed to stay with their children until pick up. There are a few adults because they know that now all parents can stay that long.  Teachers do have extended day, but that is a mandated program. I have all my teacher's emails, cell phones and they text or call me whenever there is something I need to know about my child. I can email, text or call and they always answer or respond promptly. 
Its a great school, but the school can't do everything. Parents need to be involved and accountable. As you can see the behavior problems have drastically improved and thats because of the new systems and the accountability. Some parents just dont like taking responsibility for their children's actions.

Good to hear! I have to agree in that some parents dont want to take responsibility in their child's behavior!! I never had a problem communicating with my child's teacher either! Ms Colon is the best! and a true asset to PS 63!!!

Sorry but I dont believe what you are indicating here at all. YES, I agree there are problems with this school , like in any school! However the teachers that I delt with were in the buildilng very early, (7am) and didnt leave until after 5pm as I would see them when I picked up at after school! I NEVER had an issue when I wanted to speak to a teacher or the principal! EVER! And believe me during my time there I had alot of issues. These teachers have to deal with a student body which is very diverse in every way and spend alot of time dealing with home issues which prevents them from moving forward. I dont think its fair to blame all the staff for clearly the issues you had with one or maybe two teachers!

Right now there are no teachers in the building past 3 o clock because they go to extended day. The kids are placed in after school. Perhaps you dealt with the old principal. This new principal does not greet the children or dismiss them. I am not the only parent that ran into this problem. I know of several parents that are complaining  of this issue. I am glad you had a positive image of PS 63. I dont see where it is rated the Top Performing Elementary School. I see that it is rated aveerage. Please share your website where this is listed.

Are you still a parent in 63??? I dont understand what you mean no teacher is in the building because they all go to exteneded day. Arent the teachers running extended day? After school cannot take every single enrolled child. they dont have the staff or funding. And how many principals greet the students coming into school everyday??? Not man. And 63 is one of the only schools in district one NOT to fall behind. They are a B school. I am not a parent there any longer but still follow as I am in the area. Everyone is entitled to their opinion!

Congratulations to The S.T.A.R Academy- PS 63 for being the "Top Performing Elementary School" in all of District 1. Check out the City-wide Progress Reports to see how all of the District 1 schools ranked.

But it is not the number 1. It is average. Parents look at the scores before you enter the worst school ever.  I know I was there. The emotional distress that the child goes through this school is terrible.
What is emotionally distressing at this school?  Why is the worst school ever?  Please elaborate.

I was at the District-wide School Leadership Meeting and flyers were put in every single school folder showing the rankings of the schools in that districts scores. PS 63 was at the top of that list.  Compare their grade on the Progress Report- learning environment survey, test scores, etc. I did my research.

I love this school, and even better, my son does too!  My son has attended this school since kindergarten and he's now in the fifth grade.  Small class sizes, great teachers - he's done extremely well.  He's reading well above his grade level, performed extremely well on the state exams and he absolutely loves going to school.  He participates in the enrichment program, student council, and has a "student job" that helps him learn leadership skills and responsibility.  At no time have I felt like this was a dangerous place to be.  The teachers and staff know all the kids by name and it's a very caring environment.  The communication with parents is great as well and there are numerous opportunities to be involved, even if you're a workig parent.  We've loved our years here and we will be sad to leave when he moves on to middle school next year.

I went to the first awards assembly. The kids had so much fun. I watched my student win an award. They have a lot (for attendance, for behavior, for reading). Then they did a presentation to show the kids all the jobs they could apply for (like the ones mentioned in above in your description). it was so much fun to see the kids get excited about being in the Cleaning Crew or the EveryBuddy (someone who is everyone's buddy at recess). This is a great school.

After 3 years of struggling to teach at a failing school that offered little in the way of support for a new teacher, I moved over to P.S. 63, planning to spend a year (2 at most!) working there before leaving the teaching profession for good. Well... I am now in my 5th year as a P.S. 63 teacher, and I can't imagine working anywhere else! The principal expects teachers to maintain a high level of academic rigor in our classrooms, and we are given ample professional development to improve our teaching practice. Parents might not be aware of how much learning the teachers are engaged in at P.S. 63, but their children are reaping the benefits. Having a small staff encourages collaboration and allows teachers take on leadership roles that enrich the school community outside of our own classrooms. For example, in response to parent feedback seeking a program for high-performing students who need some extra challenges, the principal has supported me in developing an enrichment program in Philosophy for advanced students in grades 3-5. I feel fortunate to work with brilliant colleagues at a school that asks us to be at our best, all for the kids' benefit.

PS 63 is an awesome small school. The class sizes are small and the amount of students in the whole school are small so many staff members know my child's name. The teachers are great and make an effort to communicate with parents often. My child is learning a ton and loves going to school (this is not how it was when he went to a different school).

You can change your name but its still the same nonsense!!!! My family wasted a year of education, not to mention social and emotional well being at PS 63. This school is over run with children who have long histories in violence and bullying behaviors. I sincerely regret every single day that my child stepped foot into PS 63
This School could do better. The teachers and principal don't care about its students. Look for another school.

PS 63 was one of the few schools NOT to fall behind and maintain a B rating. The principal, teachers and basically everyone in the school is wonderful. The curriculum is challenging and teachers are more than willing to alter it based on a students need. THerefore no child gets bored if they are advanced or left behind if they lack certain skills. The one and only draw back to this school and I am pretty sure to most District 1 schools is the relentless teasing and bullying that goes on which leads many of us parents to believe why 63 was placed on the most dangerous schools list. I am not sure what type of incidents get reported but the teasing and bullying is totally out of control. The administration tries its best to work with the students and families but unfortunately, many students come from such environments making very hard. Even the most well adjusted children who excell academically, become depressed in such a negative place.

The School has been removed from the list and has instituted many things to ensure the safety both emotionally and physically of all of the students. This school unlike most has a structured recess program. We utilize the Asphalt Green Recess Enhancement program. Also, the Guidance Counselor is at every recess period in order to ensure that every has a great recess, has people to play with, and can take care of any issue as soon as it happens. In addition, out school has student  jobs. One of them is the EveryBuddy. This is a job where kids sign up to be Everybody's buddy. This makes sure all kids have someone to play with! Go on a visit of your school. I guarantee you will not think twice about your child's safety. In addition, to support not only our students but our families as well, we have the Hudson Guild Family Outreach program. Through this program we can offer counseling services to both students and their families to support them in whatever they are going through. As many know, a person often bullies when they are going through something stressful in their life. This program, a long with all the others we have has had a huge impact on the mood and tone of our school. Come see for yourself by scheduling a school visit with our Parent Coordinator, Alice 212-674-3180..
What is considered a "violent incident"....this seems to be very vague?

For the second year in a row, P.S. 63 is on the state's list of Persistently Dangerous Schools under the federal No Child Left Behind Act (August 2010). To be removed from the list, school's must demonstrate "two consecutive years of progress in reducing violent incidents," among other criteria, according to the state. Find more information on the 2010/2011 list here.

I must admit I was very hesitant to enroll my 2 boys at PS 63 however after watching them suffer at a local catholic school and wasting my money, I did. ANd within weeks my children flourished. It was a difficult transition because catholic school is so closed off from reality but they made it. The teachers and principal are amazing. Yes there are some bullying in the older grades, but it is not tolerated! However this is reality and children need to learn how to deal with such things. I dont understand why this school isplace on a dangerous list as I have not seen ANYTHING close to dangerous. THe hallways are always calm and quiet and my children are safe - neither of them have reported any fights or such in school. The school has reading and writing programs with Col. Teachers College which are fabulous. I believe this school is just as good as any other public school, A or B!!
P.S. 63 has been added to the state's list of Persistently Dangerous Schools under the federal No Child Left Behind Act . Find more information on the 2009/2010 list here.

Someone who works at PS 63 writes that it's a "great school" but notes that it shares the building with the Neighborhood School, but "the schools have little interaction and it feels like segregation in this building."

"PS 63 was my school from 3rd grade on to 6th," writes a recent graduate. "I had a great time there. They taught me about English language arts and math. I like those subjects because it prepared me for junior high school. PS 63 was like my second home."

We just moved from District 22 in Brooklyn," writes a parent. "My daughter was in the gifted program called Eagle II and attend PS 194 and I must say even though this school doesn't have that kind of program, their academic strategies are wonderful. My daughter is still a straight A student. We need more schools like PS 63 around. The teachers are wonderful and are eager to assist in helping your child get the most out of their education. Thanks to all the faculty at PS 63 for making the transition for my daughter a wonderful one. Keep up the good work!"

A graduate whose mother, aunts and uncle also attended PS 63 writes, "All of the students and faculty were very close." She continues, "I have seen this school make many changes for the better. PS 63 has helped mold me into the college graduate that I am today. If and when I ever have a child of my own, I will be sure to enroll them there."

I remember when P.S. 64 was located between 9th and 10th Streets off of Ave. B.  There was a time when there  was a "Boys Side (9th St.) and Girls Side (10th St.)."  My father once attended there and my brothers later on.  I recall things 60 or so years later such as the subway that would rumble under the school before the bell rang to attend class upstairs; finding hundreds of 'steriopticons' and the films that went with them (dating from the 19th century) in the attic.  I lived in a tenement house on 8th St.  I just wanted to share with the students that if you apply yourself you can do much even despite setbacks.  I eventually attained a post graduate education in several areas and went from an enlisted man in the Army to retiring as a LTC (Lieutenant Colonel).   Persevere!  Education never stops either.
Love the story!
PS 64 Principal Hosang is one school leader pushing to return cursive handwriting instruction to the curriculum. Read more here.

A new report from CEC 1 found that more than a third of schools in the district do not have a gym or must share their gym with other schools. DNAinfo highlights PS 64 as an example of a school struggling with space issues; it shares its gym with two other schools that share the building. Read more here.
An aerosol can explosion at P.S. 64 sent six students to the hospital.Read more here.

PS 64 will get a new dance studio this year, as the school plans to convert an old shower room into a studio with floor-to-ceiling mirrors, spring flooring, ballet bars and a sound system. Read more here.

The Department of Education is investigating claims of "ethical misconduct" on the annual surveys filled out by parents and teachers at PS 64 and other schools. According to the Daily New, "Principal Marlon Hosang assured families that the school’s parent coordinator and members of the parent association would be 'stationed in the library to assist you' on filling out the surveys. 'Remember, we consider anything less than ‘strongly agree’ a failure,'” read a letter signed by Hosang and the assistant principal, Daniela D’Arcangelo." Read more: Seven ethical misconduct violations surface after Bronx principal is caught influencing student reviews of Harry S Truman High School.

Forget I was at that school from pre k to 5 Th grade best school ever I really recommend you send your kids here best principal cool teachers its a safe enviorment. 

Sincerely,Deont'e Singleton

"P.S. 64 Principal Marlon Hosang, who banned teachers from wearing flip-flops, gym clothes and other sloppy clothing, is among the growing number of principals citywide who are installing a compulsory uniform policy," according to DNAInfo.com. Read more:Principal Who Installed Dress Code for Teachers Now Has One for Students.

THE END RESULT...Today it was officially posted that Robert Simon school P.S. 64 Robert E. Simon (064) received a Progress Report Leter Grade of C.the Administrators are quick to blame the system and the formula the DOE uses. But like i said in the past, present and future..you made it your mission to exclude parents from being involved in the school. The staff is constantly chasing parents out of the school as to welcoming them. Perhaps this was your,"WAKE UP CALL"!!
Parents are no longer allowed to escort their children to their classes or be in school grounds?
Ooops..correction, Reason given is for teachers not to be disturbed.

I think it's perfectly reasonable to ask parents to  not be in the classroom in the morning after 8am. Some of these parents stroll in with their children after 8 and linger in the classroom. Teaching has to start at 8am, and parents lingering around are a distraction. For grades 3 to 5 in particular, it is crucial for the class to get through as miuch of the lessons during the day, because of the upcoming state tests. Some of the parents who complain about this policy are not thinking of what's best for their child's learning, and like to think that they can do whatever they want in the school premises. They even congregate in front of the school to bad mouth the prinicipal and what he has been doing to improve academic performance. How twisted is that? Some people have too much time on their hands and instead of supporting the school, they thrive on drama and gossip and do nothing to help build a stronger PTA.

Strong comment to make from PTA?
Unlike you, we are not puppets.
Once again, you've proven my point. All drama, no action.

Aww Mann I love PS 64, my first school:) I was there from Pre-K through 6th grade we were the last 6th grader to graduate the school. I was there from 1996-2006, it was one of my best time of my life:') and Mr. Hosang was really cool and Ms. Litrico was cool also. I still remember my first teacher in PS 64, Ms. Cheryl Sinple :') good memories. I also can't believe I'ma finish High School next year :D

P.S. 64, the Tompkins Square Middle School and the Earth School are proposing to build a green roof called the 5th Street Farm Project. The rooftop will be developed into a green deck with an edible organic garden. Read more: Rooftop ‘farm’ will soon be sprouting atop three schools.
Judge Denies Teachers Union Request To Stop City From Releasing Data Reports?.So...What?. DOE get a life! leave these Great Educators alone!

I LOVE P.S. 64! Principal Marlon Hosang, and Asst. Principal Daniela D'Arcangelo are such humble individuals. They welcomed my son with open arms, and went over and beyond to get him the help he needed. They have a wondeful, family-oriented staff who are awesome and very accommodating. Great school....PERIOD!!

"I have children in this school and 2 that attended. I would like to thank the principal, teachers and staff for their continued support in helping my children achieve their goals. This is a good school and friendly environment. I always feel welcomed and can express my concerns to personnel. I would also like to thank Mr. Hosang for all his respect, responsibility and caring that he shows to the students and parents. He has proven his ability to lead. I believe he would be the suitable person as Principal of PS64M. He would help the school community grow. For those who don't like him. First you have to get to know him and what he has done for the children and the school. I am very proud of all that the school and Mr. Hosang has accomplished. Keep up the good work!"

"I am still awaiting to here back on why the new principal did not have a trained fire responder on premises on Tuesday, 9/23/08. I am also awaiting answers as to why the principal did not call the Fire Dept. to respond to the alarm but instead authorized everyone to return into the building without fire dept. approval. It tok my call to get the Fire Dept. there. The principal then called me reckless for having called the Fire Dept as required by law. The principal has not yet turned over the Fire safety plan, staff training certification or other requested documents for my review, as per our last conversation during a face to face meeting. Instead, he has made himself unavailable to me. I am then perceived and portrayed as a trouble maker for excersising my parental rights as Guaranteed by Chancelors Reg. A-660, The Parents Bill of Rights, No Child Left Behind, parent involvement."

"I am incredibly disappointed with the leadership of principal Ms. Litrico, and think the school has really gotten worse over the past few years," writes a single parent with two children in the school. "The times I have come to the school I have seen kids running around in the halls out of control. I don't think my kids' teachers get the support and resources they need, and they feel frustrated. It seems like they are teaching just to get better test scores and not really so my kids learn. I have found Ms. Litrico to be hard to get in touch with, and the few interactions I have had with her she has been mean and did not seem to care much about my kids."

"As a former student at this school a lot of what nurtured me as a child was vividly brought back by Principal Litrico for my child to benefit from," writes parent Melissa Polanco. "He really has a passion for learning and we have certainly been blessed with the wonderful teachers here at PS 64. Their caring, concern and overall involvement definitely encourages single parents such as myself to continue to support our children. I agree that there is little to no parent involvement to support each other, the school and the community that serves our school overall."

"PS 64 has come a long way since Litrico came on board; our test scores each year are higher," writes parent Jeany Rios. "Our teachers are certified and experienced. They each bring the best out of every student."

Juliana Cope, who works for the Educational Alliance at PS 64 as director of the after-school program, coordinator of the Head Start program, and supervisor of the Family Programs at the school, writes: "If you visited the school this year, I believe you would notice a great increase in parent involvement as volunteers, attending workshops, and participating in leadership positions." She adds that the after-school program is run by Educational Alliance, a community-based organization. "We provide mental health, after-school, [and] community programs, [as well as] Head Start in collaboration with PS 64."
A parent complains that the school is "terrible." She writes, "The students are unruly, the curriculum is nothing to shout about, and parent involvement is almost nonexistent."
"There is great communication with the principal," said a parent. "She has an open-door policy."

PS 110 was among 277 of NYC’s highest achieving schools under ESSA’s new accountability measures. https://www.chalkbeat.org/posts/ny/2019/06/19/these-277-schools-are-nycs-highest-achieving-under-essas-new-accountability-measures/
My son just graduated from PS 110 and I have to say that overall, I am very pleased by the education he got there. We especially loved the supportive community of parents.
As part of Chalkbeat's "How I teach" segment, PS 110 teacher and 2017 New York State Teacher of the Year finalist Lauren Bakian Aaker describes how she engages her fourth graders.
I am considering PS110 for my daughter entering 2nd grade in the G&T program, any parents out there that are enrolled in the G&T that can offer some insight into the school and the program?

The school is small and diverse with a strong PTA, and it's definitely a tight community. The academics are accelerated and enriched versions of the one in GenEd. It really depends on the teacher. I believe your child's teacher will be Ms. Kim who, in my opinion, is one of the best teachers I have ever met.

My soon to be 4th grader has been in the G&T program since kindergarten, and his soon to be 1st grade sibling will be entering it this year. I have no complaints. All of my son's teachers from kindergarten all the way up to 3rd grade have been wonderful educators that I respect.

Principal Feuer was selected for Cahn Fellowship for distinguished principals at Teachers College at Columbia!!! My child has been attending PS 110 since the Fall of 2013 and we are very happy with our choice. The school administration is very organized and there is a well-rounded curriculum. 5 years ago this school was awarded the "Rising Star" Award for an elementary school by the Blackboard Awards...

Sad to say, but anyone who has had multiple students at this school can honestly say that the school has definitely changed. When my oldest son came to this school he was held back because his previous school was a joke. he went from being held back and barely reading to the accelerated class. I was always impressed with the teachers level of skill. I had never felt out of place I always felt welcomed. Ms. Quvus was an excellent principal, she was always respectful she always displayed a kind manner and was always dressed appropriately for the school environment.
There is no exaggeration, things have changed and not for good. I hear complaints from all parents however The concern should be for all students General Ed, students with IEP's and G&T. Every child deserves to have a quality education. The same level of concern should be geared toward all of the students but unfortunately there is a biased there is a group for change but only for their group. That's why being involved is discouraging to many, not because they do not want to be involved but mostly because it becomes more about "my group" and not about all. Everyone may not have the same level of education, abilities, or financing but everyone does have the same concern and that is at least I hope it is that ALL children have access to the same Quality Education.
The new principal has definitely added to the tension filled environment. To be a good leader you first have to learn to follow. From day one she chose to do her own thing. I still don't know what that is. All I see is a lot of negativity. I see how things have changed and I'm still in awe I can't believe what has happened to this school.
Does this school offer any foreign languages? My son will be in the g&t class here and I would love as much info as possible. I'm really not interested in hearing about the principal.

There is no foreign language component offerd at PS 110. I'm not sure that the budget allows for enough instruction to make it worthwhile at the moment. An afterschool class was started but not sure it worked out well. 

Typically K enrichment includes cycles of art and chess (oofered at all grade levels) along with music instruction, computers, and science on a weekly basis. As part of the K curriculum, the class also studies prehistoric animals culminating in a dig week. Everything you ever wanted to know about mammoths and macedons will be learned during kindergarten (in a good way).

In addition, heavy emphasis on reading and writing skills.  

Many parents supplement with outside classes at Henry Street (Art, Music, Theatre, Dance), Paul Taylor Dance (up the block from PS 110), LES Capoiera, SeaHorse swimming, etc. There is also an afterschool chess club that meets on Fridays.

Additional enrichment in 1-5 include the following:

NDI (1st, 4th)
Spring Enrichment Clusters (1-3, 4-5) 
Salvadori Architecture (3)
Theatre (Not Sure)
Afterschool Science Club (5th Grade)
etc.

It's not NEST or Anderson but I'm not sure you will too many complaints from G&T parents in the K class.
The school now has a Spanish program.
Is the Spanish program a dual language program or after school class or what?

PS 110 has a full-time Pre-K program not a half-time program as described above.

I am very confused now.  I've heard positive things about PS 110 and was ecstatic when my child passed the G&T exam.  I chose PS 110, as this was my only choice anyway.  I went on the school tour and was very pleased.  After reading the feed backs here, I am getting a bit worried.  Yes, there are mixed reviews.  I just don't want to make any mistakes.  My daughter has been accepted at MCS, but I was actually leaning towards PS 110. I have been comparing both schools.  PS110 is graded C and MCS has an A.  This should be a no-brainer, however MCS does not have a G&T class.

oh wow, I am so excited!  Did you Pre-Register with Millie already?  I'm going in this week :-)

The school progress report means nothing in my book. PS 110 scored only 4 out of 15 points on the school environment section because some of the teachers flat out did whatever they could to screw over the principal and thus the school. Also, PS 110 encourages all parents to fill out the survey and has an extremely high completion rate thus you have many parents filling it out that give honest feedback instead of just targeting parents who will give the school all outstandings. Gaining just 4 points in this section would have moved PS 110 to a B. 

My real test is based on what my child is doing at PS 110. From an A level reader to a K level. From barely reading words to writing full sentences. To gaining strong number sense and being able to do addition and subtraction with confidence. For kindergarten, thats not bad...

Choose the school you want to but all I know is that when I was choosing between MCS and PS 110, I chose PS 110 and have not regretted it for one second.

I find it interesting that people complain about the principal not being warm. Really? Who cares? When I was a child, I was not interested in a principal being my friend and I don't care about it as a parent. As a parent, I want my child to succeed academically. 

I've seen really horrible principals in crappy schools get A or B ratings. These rating systems are pretty useless, IMO. The real question is whether or not my child is in a safe learning environment that will help him realize his intellectual potential.

I am a PS 110 Parent and my child has been accepted to MCS also. I will be taking the seat at MCS as I know it would be a better learning environment for my child.

Yes there are very polarized opinions on here. But they are just that; subjective opinions. Always bear in mind that in order for a parent such as myself to be vocal about the current environment- a series of event must have occurred. 

I would be wise about the decision as once you give up the seat at MCS, you will not be able to reclaim it.

110 G&T is definitely the better choice over MCS. The G&T teachers are great and most if not all the G&T parents I've spoken with are very happy with the school. The principal hand-picked most of the G&T teachers so they are therefore in her favor. 

The poor grade the school received has a lot more to do with the strained relationship between the principal and her staff. The teachers panned Karen in their ratings because of her adversarial leadership style and underlying tensions she caused. 

You also have to bear in mind that there is a very wide disparity between the G&T students and the special needs students in the CTT classes who may have IEP's and may bring down the school's overall test scores. 

For a gifted student, 110 is hands-down a better choice than MCS. It is a safe school with an active parent and PTA community and a rising population of more affluent parents who are effecting more fund-raising toward programs that benefit all students at the school.

It is  responses like the one from the above parent that make for a tension filled environment at the school.

Let me be very clear, a school does not receive poor grades b/c of a principal's popularity.  It takes more than negative opinions from disgruntled teachers to give a school a bad grade.  If you want to know what goes into a school grade you should look at the DOE website.  

I have two children in the school, one of which is actually graduating this year.  It's very sad to say that when we first entered this school 7 years ago, the grade was an A. And let it be stated that through all those years the CTT & IEP students did not BRING THE SCHOOLS TEST SCORES DOWN!  The school maintained a high ranking for many years before the re-introduction of G&T. To blame children who may have learning disabilities is just ignorant and biased.

Make no mistake about it, the one thing that made this school awesome was it's community support. This community is larger than the *affluent parents* along grand street.  The school is flanked on both sides by NYCHA complexes. Coincidentally, District 1 is home to over 15 housing complexes. 4 of which have a high population of students that attend PS 110. That is the community that raised PS 110 to score so highly year upon year. 

@

I think you are confused. No one is blaming the children with learning disabilities for the decreasing scores. I am merely stating that the school's grade is misleading and that the school is actually much better than it appears on paper. I also agree that it was the NYCHA families and PREVIOUS PRINCIPAL that made 110 a rising star but I believe the current principal's focus is NOT with this community but with the "Grand St." G&T folks  - which has further divided the school. The G&T and CTT children are the focus and the regular general ed kids are getting lost in the shuffle with the least desirable teachers that Karen can't get rid of (but in the process of trying to get them out, she has created a seemingly permanent rift between herself and the teachers she's alienated and intimidated AND divided the parent populations further).
to Long Time Parent@110... my guess is that you are a Long Time Teacher...

PS 110 rocks!  I am an involved parent and always feel very welcome in the building.  I think the new principal is doing an excellent job and has made great progress raising the bar for all students regardless of whether they are in a gen ed, ICT or G&T classroom.  Ms. Feuer knows every single student in the school by name and she is actively involved in all aspects of daily life in the school -- from supervising lunch and encouraging kids to pick up an apple or salad to actually running with students who participate in Mighty Milers (a school-based running program) to visiting classroom publishing parties when parents are invited to see our children's written work to helping supervise kids in the yard during recess, drop off and pick up (regardless of the weather - a little rain never hurt anyone).  The teachers are wonderful, caring, and dedicated and so far my first grader has grown immensely (academically, socially and emotionally) since coming to P110 in Pre-K.  I give P110 a big thumbs up.

Parent Coordinator James Glenn writes: "I just wanted to let you know a few things that have changed for the better this year. If because of this success, we lost our Supplemental Education Services, we are still one of the only schools in the district that offers after school math and reading enrichment to all grades. We have portfolio classes for 8th graders interested in applying to specialized art high schools, and this spring, our 5th graders will be learning to sing and dance with Rosie's Broadway Kids. Amid financial woes, Shuang Wen's Mandarin Chinese after-school program will close this fall, officials said. Read more here.

Shuang Wen has always been a very tight knit, yet welcoming group of students and faculty members and has excelled because of its care and attentiveness towards students. 

As a student that graduated two years ago and now attends a top school in New York, I can proudly say that I have been taught and enriched with such a welcoming and knowledgeable staff. My years in Shuang Wen were nothing but growth and hard work, fortified by a relentless passion for learning that each teacher shared. 

Chinese was always a second language and I speak English mainly. However, I can write, read, and communicate fluently in Mandarin with teachers, family members, and relatives just because of a few classes, not because I was born Chinese. Therefore, the allegations that Shuang Wen is only for Asians and that any other race is doomed to fail in Shuang Wen is beyond absurd. I came into Shuang Wen knowing how to speak Cantonese, a whole other dialect that actually can negatively hinder the learning of Mandarin. That being said, ANYONE can attend Shuang Wen and successfully learn Mandarin, just like I did. The ability to perform and perfect is mainly on the student, as a true craftsman does not blame his tools for his imperfections. Every student is given the same attention and knowledge, and it is up to them to grasp and absorb. Even if they fail to, I do not know one teacher in Shuang Wen that was not willing to sit down in their free time to explain it again.

In addition, Shuang Wen isn't racist or racially exclusive to Asians. The school embraces anyone that comes with an open heart and an open mind that is willing to learn. Anyone that was part of the student body was part of the family that made the learning experience thorough and enjoyable. Attending Shuang Wen means accepting and willing to learn Chinese and all the knowledge that is offered, and does not mean being forced, unhappily to take on a Chinese class. 

Education is a virtue that everyone has a choice to take and to refuse. Do not blame the school or the teachers because you found it as a vice. I did not and am forever grateful for the skills and intellect that I was able to acquire over the years at Shuang Wen.

As a former graduate from this school, it is an extreme frustration to see so many false statements both in the website's review and the discussion section. Shuang Wen is truly an honorable school that I am utmost proud of for having been able to attend. As a new immigrant with no Mandarin background, I was able to become fluent in Mandarin with the help of both the daytime Chinese teachers, such as Ms. Tsao, and the afterschool Chinese teachers from SWAN. Despite the ignorance of those not having learned Chinese before, Chinese is an extremely challenging language that can only be learned if one is willing to put time and effort into learning it. I admit that I even considered dropping out because it was hard, but with the encouragement of my parents, I decided to continue. My fluency in Mandarin has allowed me to be considered for jobs over candidates who do not have this advantage. Every time I encounter a situation when Mandarin is used, I am reminded of how grateful I am to Shuang Wen and all the members of the Shuang Wen family for helping me be the successful person I am today. 
Visiting Shuang Wen now is a whole other story. Not only are a great number of teachers that have worked for numerous years in Shuang Wen been leaving, but the team spirit and the sense of community has slowly begun to drift apart.

What happened to this school came out of no where. It took not only the parents by surprise, but the kids there as well. I started at Shuang Wen as a kindergartener, and I can say that SWS was not just a place I went to everyday but school, but it was also my family. At Shuang Wen, I met my best friend, whom still is my best friend to this day. Shuang Wen prepared me as a well rounded person as I entered high school, and taught me responsibility and social manners. 
It's sad that a few parents feel that their child did not get the same experience that I have, but it's even worse to ruin other's education because of that reason. Many students transferred out of SWS when our old principal was forced to step down, and many teachers left as well. Our principal was the building block of SWS, and she created the community and environment of the school we all felt so safe in. To the parents that got her forcefully removed, was it really our school that made your child feel that way? Or was it just you that could not accept that a school like SWS with such a unique environment existed. 
There were many options that you could have taken, one being to remove your child from our school, and not ruin the educational experience of so many others. 
I sincerely hope these parents that caused these events to Shuang Wen realize the sadness they've brought to so many students, and realize that doing so, did not bring happiness to their own child. Think about all the friendships you've ruined for your child in the process, and think about the monstrous acts that you've taught your child for their future.

"A lot of people just assumed it was a private school," said one community leader, "because they saw limousines dropping kids off and mostly Asian kids going in."
P.S is clearly a public school. Where did you see "limousines" dropping kids off? Are you sure it wasn't just a Jeep? Stop hating on the Asians. The school offers both English and Chinese. If people in the neighborhood are reluctant to apply because they don't want to learn Chinese or because of the majority of Asian people there, then you cannot blame them (the kids attending the school) for it. 
Secondly, parents still have to pay for their children to attend the afterschool program. They are not being forced into it. And since students are paying to learn Chinese, why attempt to hinder learning by trying to replace afterschool classrooms with "free art classes"?

I have to point out that just because a child you see sitting in a classroom is Asian does NOT mean they are a native speaker of Mandarin. Some of the Chinese kids come from Cantonese speaking homes. A few are American born Chinese, with American born parents, and they speak primary English. There is a Korean-American kid, a few Japanese-Americans, a Burmese family. I don't have a precise ethnic/language breakdown for the school--and neither does the author of this post. Please don't assume all Asian are fluent in Mandarin! That's quite an assumption.

Amazing, there is one line about the ethnic make up of the school and this is the basis for 8 lines from the above writer. Yet, I don't see anything about the fact that English is being addressed because it was not earlier, nor do I see anything about grammar or the fact that many parents don't have their children attend SWAN anymore.  Is it because it is so superior in teaching Mandarin?  Why would these parents who have fought so hard to keep SWAN in the school abandon it?  The point is not the ethnic makeup of the Asians in the school the point is that the school is becoming better and with the change it will at some point have to rid itself of SWAN.  As I have pointed out my daughter attends New York Chinese and even when she attended full time it never cost $1,000.00. Yet we have a program that is in a public school, paid no rent during the tenure of Ms. Ling-Ling Chou and charged first $300, then $600, and now $1200.00 for Mandarin. It is also known that the vocabulary didn't prepare students for any Social Studies program in either Middle School or High School, which was proven by even native speaker students being unable to do the work in the Social Studies program as taught by Ms. Tsao. Yet, these comments with no proof, nor documentation are put forth as if written in the law.  There is a reason that the program stopped receiving funding, and it is not because it was such a wonderful program.  I find it interesting where does this writer live?  I guess someone will look you up on the web, as it seems that many people writing don't live in the district.

I am very glad that Inside schools has taken the time to do a new review of Shuang Wen and dealt with some of the issues it still faces.  I feel that S.W.A.N. should be removed as the school is supposedly still a Title 1 school why is it allowed to charge $1,200.00 dollars in a Low income area.  The D.O.E. needs to be taken to task to explain this as it is a Public School and is mandated to teach  Mandarin to all its students equally. I am glad that emphasis is being put on grammar and English skills as when my daughter went the English was sub par and this caused students to flounder when they reached High School.  I have recordings of S.L.T. meeting where this was discussed and teachers of upper grades were frustrated due to students returning and complaining that they couldn't do the work in English Language expected of them. It is also under very good leadership as Ms. Chiu has worked in another school where there were divisions and worked to bring about harmony among the students.  I feel that there should be more programs that respect all cultures and not just Asian culture (read Chinese) in the school to reflect the African and Latin roots of most of the community. I truly feel that any school that doesn't take into consideration the ethnic roots of the community it is in is being disrespectful and is doomed to failure.

This school...you can say it is hard but really fun.The teacher really care for the students.The teachers also make the classwork or homework fun and intersting.

This school blows away every other school in district one.  It is a shame on the other schools that score 30 to 50 in English that a school that teaches two languages including Mandarin which is a very hard language to learn, can still blow away English language schools in English (reading score 89) and in math (math score 98.6).  The school is blamed for selecting students but the selection comes from the fact that they teach Chinese and are located in Chinatown.  How many parents want their kids to have to struggle to learn Chinese?  It's outrageous how the principal of this school was investigated, he should have been given a prize.

The school is not located in Chinatown and in fact is in an area that is 70% Black and Latino and the former administrator made sure to discourage them from coming into the school.  I also question the English scores as I know half of the 8th grade students wrote very poorly

just because your child wrote poorly doesn't mean everyone in shuang wen wrote poorly. Sir, you should quit spending ur time on attacking shuang wen, and concentrate on your work or your kid. I would let you know that I know for a fact that a teacher asked my daughter to write a sentence and to keep it simple so her classmates could understand and read it. I find this discussion boring and your level or response the same as the ignorant parents I dealt with while at Shuang Wen. I created the account last year, as an eight grader. Second, why is an english teacher trying so hard to disgrace and insult a school and its students when she has nothing to do with it?

The school is not being insulted or disgraced, what is being done is that the truth is being written and the myth exposed. Shuang Wen was not great in English, nor was it even great in Mandarin.  The students didn't have the vocabulary to learn History in any High School that taught it in Mandarin.  The many students also didn't do very well in English, this is not an insult but fact. Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña convened a group of principals from schools that enroll a high percentage of homeless students for a conversation to share ideas and best practices, Politico reported.
A New York Times reporter goes behind the scenes at PS 188 and sees just how rocky the road can be for students who are homeless.

The Marquis Inclusion Program uses arts to connect students of all abilities from P94 (The Spectrum School) and PS 188. Read more here.

“Our core idea is that every child matters, every child is entitled to an opportunity,” said principal Suany Ramos. “Our community school is integrating social services because we know that a child living in poverty is starting from a severe disadvantage” Read more here.

PS 188 The Island School received $25,000 in federal grants to expand its dual language Spanish program beginning in September 2015. The program will begin in pre-kindergarten. Read more about the city's new and expanded dual language programs here.

PS 188 The Island School has been selected to participate in the Department of Education's Community Schools initiative, aimed at boosting attendance and achievement by bringing in community partners to provide support for students and families. PS 188's partner is Sports and Arts. Read more about the program here and see the full list of schools, their community partners and their proposed services here.

PS 188 The Island School has been selected to showcase their community school program in the inaugural year of Chancellor Carmen Fariña’s Showcase Schools Program. Schools that excel in a specific learning focus area will host educators from other schools to share their successful structures and strategies. Read more here.
Principal Fred Tudda is one of 11 winners of the New York Daily News's Hometown Heroes Award. Read more here.

The Daily News reports that PS 188 has a cutting-edge science program that teaches children robotics with legos: "They use the blocks to build robots controlled by laptops that can walk around, lift objects and put them back down, and recognize colors or other changes in the environment." "Other classes include lessons in rocketry where students launch air-powered projectiles and mock criminal investigations where they use crime-scene forensics to solve cases."

The Daily News reports that PS 188 is one of "at least 10 A-rated middle schools [that] failed to properly prepare their students for high school work."

The DOE has tabled a proposal to combine PS 34 with the East Village Community School, Chalkbeat reports, "after meeting stiff resistance from families at P.S. 34, who said a merger was tantamount to closing their school."

A new report from CEC 1 found that more than a third of schools in the district do not have a gym or must share their gym with other schools. DNAinfo highlights East Village Community School as an example of a school struggling with space issues; its gym is made of two converted classrooms and is only big enough for activities like yoga and dance. Read more here.

Currently EVCS students use the gym at the the neighborhood Boys Club for their classes as well as dance classes in the dance room with visiting dance companies and a newly renovated playground.  Schools need on-site gyms, but EVCS found a creative solution until we can get what children deserve.
Their website is not listed: www.evcsnyc.org
Thanks. We added it!

My daughter was graduated from EVCS last year, and she is now thriving in her middle school. This is unequivocally due to the wonderful teaching that goes on daily at EVCS. The principal, Robin, and Ass't Principal, Bradley, always offered their support--both academic and social-emotional--and guidance, and nurtured my daughter all along her path, from Pre-K to Grade 5. In addition, there are many programs in place at the school that help to cultivate community-building, inlcuding, for example, 'Reading Buddies' and Friday Electives. To the many dedicated and talented Educators and Counselors at EVCS, we say Thank You.

My son graduated from EVCS and is now in Middle School and I regret putting him in that school. They did not properly prepare him for Middle School. I thought my son was an isolated case until I began to speak to other parents that share my feelings about EVCS. As a side note; the school does not know how to address and meet the needs of children with special needs or are suspected to need services. This is one reason why EVCS are losing great teachers. They are frustrated with the lack of support they receive from Robin (Principal) and Bradley (Assistant Principal).

I agree, this school lacks structure we moved our daughter to a new school in 4th grade and noticed a huge improvement over EVCS. This school is not for every child. Socially it was great, my daughter made lots of friends but the atmosphere is too relaxed, This school does not properly prepare students for middle school.

Transitioning to middle school is a big change for every kid. Many have only known one school and have been there for as long as 7 years. A kid going into 6th grade in a new school is going to have to make a big adjustment no matter how well prepared they are. New school, new teachers and classmates, hormones kicking in, of course it's overwhelming. It's our job as parents to support them through the transition and that's a hard job.

What does it mean to be prepared for middle school? Academically, EVCS is one of the top ranking schools in the district based on the test results of the last couple of years, so you can't mean that! When I bump into last years' 5th graders and ask them how it's going they all wail about how much homework they have - but they all seem to be happy in the school of their choice and last years' 5th graders all were accepted into their first choice school. So are you saying we should increase the amount of homework our 4th and 5th graders get so they won't be so shocked by their workload in middle school? Try telling them that and then block your ears.

As to meeting the needs of children with special needs: EVCS has a higher than average number of children with IEP's - it's an environment that has always felt welcoming to families of children who don't fit the mold because the school's ideology is about embracing learning differences and supporting children who struggle in a traditional classroom environment.

Our family feels very lucky to have landed in this school. Our oldest child struggled so much in K-2 and with the support, encouragement and amazing commitment of his teachers is now performing above grade level with great test scores and a passion for learning.  What more can you ask from a public school?
Being top ranked in District 1 unfortunately doesn't mean much. All of the emphasis at EVCS on helping children with special needs leaves other children underserved.

As a professional in the field as well as a parent of a child with special needs, I must disagree with your assessment of EVCS.  My son has attended EVCS for 4 years during which time he struggled significantly in the areas of reading, writing, social skill development, and attention.  The administrators have shown tremendous good will toward our son, even when dealing with situations that would challenge the most experienced professionals.  We worked together with the administrators and (wonderful!) classroom teachers to develop a plan to support him and help him grow as a learner and member of the school community.  Last year, our son advanced 2 years in reading because of the efforts of the teachers.  The staff at EVCS focuses on the development of the whole child, which is unusual in NYC public schools, yet essential to the development of life skills and long-term happiness.  The teachers and administrators proactively develop new skills themselves in order to meet the needs of children.  We have never regretted our decision to join this school community, filled with enthusiastic, thoughtful and caring administrators, teachers, paras and families.

The PTA is paying $10,000 for historical drama workshops provided by the Phoenix Theater Company, to ensure that the school can keep the program. A Garden? Chess? PTAs Face Choices About How to Spend Parent Money.

I've come to feel that this school needs new leadership. The principal is very soft-spoken, unassertive. The vice principal is aloof, even haughty. They seem out-of-touch with what's actually happening in the classrooms and they seem to lack any vision of where the school needs to grow and develop. They let the PA do whatever it wants instead of harnessing its energy to do things like fix up the building, get a computer lab, restore the dedicated science teacher the school used to have. Some of the extras currently in place -- a gym teacher and an art teacher -- offer the same tired lessons over and over again. What is the school's mission? Where is its drive?

Concerned Parent:
The Parents Association works very closely with the administration and with the parents (who show up) to enhance our children's experience at EVCS. They don't "do whatever they want".They fund raise tirelessly in order to fill in the gaps in the ever diminishing school budget. It was the PA that brought in a salad bar and replaced styrofoam trays with bio-degradeable. It was the PA that replaced the playground equipment. We provide the income for our Theater Arts programs, Spanish instruction, and Music. Meatless Mondays. AfterSchool music and theater. It was the PA that funded, produced, and distributed a music CD of our kids that sold over one thousand copies, not only in our community, but all over the world. They organize the Fall Ball, the Jubilee, the Spring Fling. Auctions. The list goes on and on.
That's what the PA does. If you're in our school you're a member and an active participant, right?
See you at the next meeting...

We were concerned after the science cluster was replaced with a gym class but my daughter woke up this morning, enthused to go to school because they have been learning about "plants that eat bug and small animals" and today they were creating How-to books about them. My daughter is in her fourth year at the school and still comes home, excitedly sharing what she has created in Art. With regard to the leadership, I have been impressed with the principal's leadership in the issues we have dealt with this year with regard to space. Having spent quality time with her on various committees, I can attest that she always has our school community's best interests guiding her decisions. Both the principal and assistant principal are very accessible and proactive in their curriculum decisions.

I'm surprised by this parent's comment. Our principal has been a strong advocate for EVCS as we've pushed back against the DOE's suggestion that we move our students to an inappropriate building. (She may be soft-spoken, but that should not be confused with unassertive.) Our vice principal is intimately involved with curriculum changes as well as our after-school and in-class music programs (he often accompanies students' on his guitar). Our building is in need of repair ... and about to get it (but this is largely in the hands of the School Construction Authority). Our PA has concentrated on raising the money needed to maintain enhancement programs -- Spanish, music, drama -- that are critical to the school's mission and no longer funded by the DOE. Room for improvement? Of course, always ... and if this parent is concerned, he/she should come to our next PA meeting and contribute to that improvement.
