The PA is amazing, all the wonderful things they have done for our kids. To have the money for spanish, drama, etc. I feel we owe them a big thanks.

The Education Department put a stop to diversity-based admissions at schools on the Lower East Side in 2007. The result has been an influx of white and high-income parents, disturbing the socio-economic balance at the East Village Community School, parents say. The population of white students rose from 21 percent to 43 percent between 2004 and 2010. Read more: East Village Schools Split Along Racial Lines: http://www.dnainfo.com/20120130/lower-east-side-east-village/city-policy-segregates-east-village-schools-parents-say

My child attends EVCS and one issue we have with the school is boy-girl imbalance. There are now about 150 boys and 90 girls in the school. The first grade classes each have only 3 or 4 girls. What to do??

EVCS doesn't have a K/1 bridge class anymore. There was one last year because enrollment required it but there are no more bridge classes below 2nd grade. The 12:1:1 special education class is required in most schools by the DOE, and other CTT classes are opening up in all schools city-wide. Pretty soon all schools will have a large CTT program, and if it's done well and the teachers are well trained for it then all kids will benefit. Imagine having 2 teachers in every classroom!

"East Village has some lovely Pre-k teachers and a nice vibe, but I am concerned by some of their changes for the 2009-2010 school year. A major one being that they have added a 12-1 kindergarten classroom (this is a special education classroom). WHy would that be the focus or the one big change for the upcoming year since pretty much not one of the pre-k children this year require such services. Also I think it is far too "busy" to have a bridge class (k/1st) which is also a CTT (collaborative team teaching: 60% general ed students/40% special education). That seems to be too much going on in one classroom even for 2 teachers especially at such an important place in their learning development. I am hesitant about next year's classes and the new classroom developments that EVCS says will occur next year. If they are making inclusion of special education their major focus they will find less and less general education students joining their student body."

"Our child is enrolled in the pre-K program, and we have been very impressed with the high quality of education here. We are always well-informed about the school's activities and have a plenty of opportunities to participate. Our child loves school, especially the arts class and the clubs. She is learning letters, Spanish, and math concepts, among many other wonderful things that she previously had no interest in. The days are filled with creative activities to keep the kids truly occupied and interested. We love the philosophy at EVCS. Our child feels very comfortable here."

"This place is wonderful, they seriously go the extra mile to make students and parents feel welcome. We are so thankful to have had the opportunity to work closely with them. Absolutely NO negative thoughts or comments regarding this school, its the best! THANK YOU!"

"We just started our son in the CTT/Kindergarten class with Georga and Jeannine. It's only the second week, but so far so good. The teachers are great and it's a very caring, nurturing enviroment. EVCS definitely has a terrific mix of kids, parents and staff - everyone is warm and friendly. We are very pleased!"

"EVCS has changed over the years to become more traditional. Teachers are moving away from the school's core progressive philosophy," writes a parent. "The new principal does not have a progressive background and she has now ended bridge classes and has limited parent involvement. Bullying is a problem. It is not the school it used to be."

"There are some of the most amazing teachers at EVCS alongside some of the worst, and even though the unsuccessful teachers are eventually moved out of the classroom, the adminstration handles the process in a way that is extremely disruptive to the community setting," a parent writes.
A parent writes that the school has discontinued its combined PreK-K classes and now "has a science and technology room with all new equipment including 30 laptops for the kids to use."

A parent writes, "There are 180 students attending the East Village Community School and next year we should be at 200. Also, graduates over the last five years have attended: ICE, School of the Future, The Museum School, Crossroads, LaGuardia, East Side Community High and Thompkin Square Middle School."

East Village is not only more ethnically diverse and socially conscious than other district schools, it exudes a special warmth and friendliness, writes the mother of twins at the school. "My children are encouraged to learn, explore their world, and contribute to their community in an atmosphere of love and respect," she says. The school has active parent involvement and offers small class sizes and a lot of arts programming, including free violin lessons. "Students at EVCS receive one hour of performing and visual arts every day," she writes. This mother is impressed by a building block project in which first and second graders re-create their community. "The other 1st/2nd grade class has a teacher who concentrates on "acts of kindness." Older kids write and perform plays, and the 5th/6th graders built a spaceship as part of their science study. The school is housed in the same building as the Children's Workshop, and as part of that arrangement East Village kids use "the beautiful newly built library there," she says.

.

Our child goes to this school, now in the third year.  It is a great middle school.  The teachers care so much, everyone knows each other.  They really understand children, and the do not rush them to grow up.  The admin and principals are amazing.  Do not be put off by state testing scores which created the "low performing" designation.  These numbers are based on kids taking those tests who don't test well, due to a variety of learning disabilities.  There is great learning going on at this school.

This description doesn't capture the entire picture of UNMS at all. The state designation is very controversial (see https://www.measurethis.org) and it isn't fair to cite it as the main measurement for a school like this, which is actively serving a wide population of students at every level with humanity, caring and thoughtfulness. UNMS doesn't "cherry pick" their students like some other schools in the district, or make them go through a demeaning and confusing admissions process. Instead, it takes its mission of educating *every* child very seriously. My son started there this year, and I have found the school--contrary to how it is often depicted on sites like this--a supportive and warm place with small classes where he is thriving with lots of individual attention and help. They follow restorative justice practices and engage students in larger issues of social justice. It's true that math is one area that needs attention, but they are working at it and with the help of dedicated parents, it *will* get better. Meanwhile, the science, humanities, art, music and all else has been terrific! So please give UNMS a second look and look beyond arbitrary measurements.

University Neighborhood Middle School has landed on the state's list of low-performing schools.
https://www.chalkbeat.org/posts/ny/2019/01/17/struggling-schools-nyc-essa/

UNMS is a very special school with exceptional teachers and staff. The classes are small and challenge the students to their personal best. This school has taken my already high-acheiving son to a new level--challenging him in writing and math and providing him the skills that he will need to succeed in highschool. More importantly, he goes to school feeling loved by this community and hasn't suffered any of the angst that is so common in Middle School.
The Panel for Education Policy has approved plans to merge University Neighborhood Middle School with the Collaborative Academy and grades 6-8 of the Henry Street School, reports Chalkbeat.

University Neighborhood Middle School is on the state education department’s list of failing schools but it doesn’t qualify for the city’s renewal program to receive additional support. Read more here.

Manhattan Borough President Gale Brewer gave $10,000 in grants to MS 332 and MS 328 to start in-school art programs, specifically to address the needs of English language learners and special education students. She calls on the DOE to pay more attention to the arts programs offered—and not offered—at many city schools. Read more here.

I'm a middle school parent, and when my daughter entered middle school in September 2013 I was slightly worried. Middle school has changed since my eldest child attended...so I had my concerns. But...that all changed when I took notice of just how detail oriented UNMS is. I'm very happy that my daughter chose a great middle school for herself. Because I had no clue on which school would fit her personality...but I'm so happy that UNMS fits my daughter's personality. The staff is on top of everything, and I'm glad that if my daughter ever has any concerns. She has many leaders (principals, teachers & staff members) that she can discuss all any problems with. I'm glad that my daughter is safe in school, and that her education is top priority with her current educators. In all of my years of parenting I've never witnessed a school operated with such rich details. I love it, and I strongly suggest that many parents who children are about to enter middle school. Think about having their child attend UNMS...because education, thinking, and speaking for oneself is what sets UNMS apart from other schools. I receive all emails, and reminder calls from the parent coordinator about upcoming meetings, school events, and school closings. Keep up the EXCELLENT WORK UNMS....AS THE KIDS SAY SO VERY PROUDLY....UNMS ROCKS!

DNAinfo highlights University Neighborhood Middle School as an example of a school struggling with space issues; the school is in the process of making its schoolyard more "fitness-friendly." I am a teacher in District one, serving as an ATR.  In this position I have travelled to almost every middle school in the district and I can say that in my experience University Neighborhood Middle School is the nicest, most comfortable middle school we have to offer.  The one thing that stands out to me above all other schools is how happy and excited the staff is to be at work.  As a new teacher told me this week, "Of course I still wish it was Summer Vacation every week, but short of that, I love coming to work here."  It is evident in their interactions with the students and each other what a family the administration has created here.

My son just transferred to this wonderful school after a horrible
experience in a charter school. The staff is warm and wonderful and the kids are very friendly. According to my son ,"this is what school should be, quiet in the classrooms, noisy in the cafeteria". I am sorry that I did not discover this school before. I recommend that all parents take a tour and see for themselves what a great school University Neighborhood Middle School is!
Yay! I'm so happy it worked out for you guys.  I told you that he would love it!

All situations are dealt with before the problem escalates into a
fight. This school is very disciplinary, so disciplinary that at this school
you get a detention just for not wearing uniform. This school has a really good

can prepare for high school by having taking classes for the Specialized High
School Test and if you’re interested in applying for a performing arts school,
this afterschool programs help you with that as well. I find this school to be
a very helpful school. This school taught me about how to carry myself as a
young intelligent lady. This school has helped me expand my way of thinking and

I've been part of the UNMS community for 5 years and believe the school is very safe. The staff work together to hold children accountable for their actions and it has created a culture of respect. Students do not talk over teachers like they do in many other middle schools. They see class as an opportunity and are highly motivated to succeed. In the cases where students have a difficult time managing their own behaviors, support is given and consequences are enforced. We have very high expectations at this school and students are aware of them. Day in and day out they rise to the occasion. The teaching here is also exceptional. Your child will get an excellent education at this school.

Ha listen pal this is the best school its a safe place I do admit there are fights from here to there but there usually but the situation is handled and if you think this is a unsafe place maybe your kid was in the lower curriculum class to experience unsafe conditions

Basically, I challenge this type of blanket comment about UNMS.  Were you an active member of the school community?  How many times did you attend an SLT meeting?  A PTA meeting?  A parent workshop, trip or event?  Ultimately, creating a superlative school environment is every community members responsibility. Parents are not silent partners.  When parents and guardians attend SLT meeting, the annual school-wide retreat or PTA meetings, when families read the policies and procedures we regularly send to homes, they can develop working knowledge of the systems UNMS has in place to deal with safety, discipline and middle school adolescent issues that include self-esteem, image and negotiating peer relationships.  

I have been the parent coordinator at UNMS for 6 years.  I've been reaching out to build bridges with parents, and community, to support our students. Our motto is "Together We Make the Difference," a motto our principal instituted. Family participation is encouraged and valued.  What did you personally do to change the situation you describe?

"The educational philosophy of the University Neighborhood Middle School is rooted in the reality of the Lower East Side of Manhattan, an area that continues to be home to significant numbers of recent immigrants, as well as bilingual and bicultural families,"according to the school's mission statement. "At the University Neighborhood Middle School the specific instructional, social, and emotional needs of each student are recognized and native languages and cultures are viewed as valuable resources. The educational climate, based on "The Principles of Learning," empowers students to take responsiblity for their own learning and to set high expectations for themselves," the statement goes on to say, as posted on the Teach NYC website (https://www.nycenet.edu/TEACHNYC/NewSmallSchools/UNIVERSITYNEIGHBORHOODMIDDLESCHOOL.htm).

Her exact words were “black women threw themselves at white men” being eleven I thought it was odd especially because it was contrary to everything I was taught about slavery ,but growing up and thinking of that I realize how disgusting and volatile of a person you have to be to say that to a kid, to say that to someone PERIOD. That is the worst interaction I’ve had with staff at this school but theres been many I don’t think highlighted MLK’s message either. Six years in, i still can't figure out how this place is progressive. It is old fashioned, un-dynamic, and i think their motto is "because that's the way we've always done it." The theme (obsession) is Martin Luther King, so there's a lot of talk of peace and love, but there are a bunch of teachers who yell at and berate kids. Apparently, M.L. King's philosophy doesn't apply to staff. As for the academics, it becomes clear in the upper grades that there are few smart kids, and the work is way too easy. The school caters to low-income families, but doesn't provide resources (social workers, counselors, etc) to deal with the myriad problems associated with poverty, such as absent parents and violent behavior. The leadership is passive, ineffective, and not a creature of today.

Our children have attended CWS since 2011 and we couldn't be happier and more confident in our choice for elementary school. In all ways possible, our entire family has been made to feel like we are part of an extended family! The community at CWS is nothing I have seen before. Bravo to Maria and all the staff and teachers who set the vibe at our brilliant gem of a school.

My child is graduating from CWS this year after seven years at the school.  She is a year ahead in reading thanks to an early start with the reading recovery teacher in 1st grade (one of the few schools in NYC that has one.)    She got a four on her science common core and high threes in math and ELA.  The teachers are dedicated to making sure each child gets what is needed educationally, emotionally, and physically if special needs.  It is also one of the only schools with a dedicated science teacher and a dedicated art teacher.  The parents work very hard to fund music, yoga (no gym), arts, and music programs.  It is a true community and I am glad my daughter elementary school years were spent at this school.

My daughter has been a student at The Children's Workshop School since pre-k and is now a rising fourth grader--she's had five wonderful years and is very excited for fourth grade, especially the farm trip-4 nights at the Manhattan Country School's farm upstate (a longtime CWS tradition).  CWS is the perfect school for her:  excellent experienced teachers, a diverse student body (diversity in all ways:race/ethnicity, socio-economic, academic, family lifestyle), fun after school clubs like Sports, Hip Hop, Cupcake Baking, Karate, Robotics, the beautiful library she loves so much, the Friday morning Community Meetings that bring the whole school community together with songs and class performances.  She is happy, has great friends, loves learning and loves her school.

I am very impressed with how CWS guides her academic and personal development. The focus on Social Studies, Science, Math and the Arts with reading and writing integrated throughout develops her critical thinking skills and creativity while the school's ethos of collaboration, peace and social justice, as exemplified by the principles of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr, develops her compassion and sense of civic responsibility. Maria, our wonderful founder and principal of 20 years; Dorothy, our parent coordinator and librarian and all the teachers have created a strong web of learning, love and support that encourages all CWS children to thrive--I am grateful for their hard work and dedication!

Attended graduation today of friends who are two years ahead of my son, and  felt again, how warm and caring the teachers are, how much the kids have been thriving, and kids are always  on top of teachers and administrator's minds. 

I have a son in third grade. His k,1-2 and current teachers were all fantastic. They nurture the child's strengths. My son loves the school.  I was reminded again how much I love CWS and the families in our community.

Being a little nostalgic of when I toured the schools, CWS stood out with children who were happy, full of energy, very responsive to parents' questions as the group proceeded through the hallways. The nicely lit and bright classrooms,... The children make most of the space and environment they have. Yes there are space issues. But only parents make it an "issue". Children don't seem to mind, and the teachers and admin at CWS try to make most of what they have and the environment they are in. Also great reach out to the community. No gym, yet a great use of gym space in a community center across the street.  A grant to renovate the auditorium. Teachers and staff and parents form committees and have done hard work towards the school and every bit of the effort can be seen and felt.  

Am thankful for CWS! I ❤️CWS!

I LOVE this school!  I have a second grader and a child that graduated from C.W.S. and is now at I.C.E. in the sixth grade. My sixth grader is getting honors at I.C.E. so I know that she was well prepared by C.W.S.. I love the progressive approach to teaching that puts less importance on high-stakes testing and more importance
on the curriculum developed by the teachers and the Principal.
My child's second grade teacher is outstanding.  And both of my older child's teachers, in fourth and fifth grade, were exceptional.
I feel that C.W.S. is like a family.  The administration is extremely warm and welcoming.  The Principal, Maria Velez-Clarke, is a true visionary.  She has created a school that is beautifully diverse and lives by the principles of Martin Luther King. Gary, the art teacher is a hero.  He not only leads weekly community meetings but also does inspiring art projects with all of the children.   I can honestly say that my child is thriving at this school.  She has made great friends, loves her teachers, and loves what she’s learning.   As a parent, I feel part of a vibrant community of people who share similar ideas and approaches to parenting.  The school offers yoga, school band, and chorus.  There is also a great after-school program.  From my perspective it's a GREAT school.

I have been researching other types of school and I came across CWS. I understand the hands-on concept and I think it's a great idea but how are the children graded? if there aren't any test how does school keeps record of progress. I've worked at this school as a per diem sub on several occasions.  All the positive posts below are absolutely true.  This is a wonderful school.

I am a happy parent at CWS.  Maria (our Principal) has a clear vision for how our children should be educated and does an amazing job of delivering a progressive education despite drastic budget cuts, high-stakes testing, overcrowding, and an old building that needs major upgrades.  There is no doubt in my mind that Maria and her staff actually live the principles of peace, community and love that they teach to our children.  I doubt that such integrity and commitment exist at most schools.  As for the basics -- reading, writing, math -- the school bends over backwards to make sure that the children master these subjects within the progressive model.  Given the high-stakes testing, it becomes increasingly difficult to provide substantive art, dance, music and yes, even SCIENCE (not a subject on the primary school tests).  Children all learn in different ways and their intelligence and talents take different forms.  I believe that CWS strives to give all the children the chance to shine.

I taught at CWS for one year sixteen years ago. I had been teaching in a regular school in the same building, and had been bumped by somebody who had been bumped, etc., etc. I went back to pick up my belongings and to take one last walk through the corridors of CWS. I was going to miss the wonderful projects that children had made. I was lucky to be offered a half-time position by Maria, who was familiar with the many dance performances I had done for the other school. I ended up being shared by CWS and The Neighborhood School. What a wonderful beginning to my career as a teacher. My memories of the devoted teachers, progressive methods and enriched curricula still outshine anything I've experienced in the fifteen years since. It was at CWS that I was first exposed to wonderful programs from Teachers College and Bank Street College. Those programs arrived several years later in Millburn, NJ, where I've taught for the past ten years. So CWS was years ahead of what is considered the top school district in a very wealthy part of New Jersey.
      As for the 'laid back' atmosphere, what I experienced was the true integration of the arts and academia. Children worked independently and with friends, completely engrossed in their projects. I've never been in a school that succeeds in integrating the arts -- they are always somewhere on the periphery. 
      As for criticisms of Maria Velez-Clarke, my NJ school went through five principals in ten years. The fabulous ones rarely lasted more than a year, and only the ones that oozed obsequiously in front of parents managed to survive. They were the ones that knew little about educating children and cared less. Principals that give their energy and attention to the children, not to their parents, are focused on the most challenging job one can imagine. Sorry if they fall short on PR skills.
     As for standardized tests, I've prepared children for those tests for sixteen years, and I never cease to be horrified by how inappropriate they are. Rarely do the reading passages relate to any child's schema or life experience. So children can read them but they don't really 'get' the meaning. And math word problems are written to be confusing, often talking about things like stock options. Just reading a term like that makes a child give up. Judging a school by its students' test scores is really a mistake. One of my NJ principals did little more than teach to the test. Our scores were great, were heralded all over the school in banners that you had to duck under as you walked through the halls. That showed what he cared about!
     As for text books and workbooks, many elementary schools have moved away from them and for good reason. I've rarely seen an ELA textbook that is worth much, and workbooks, like those glossy phonics disposables, are primarily money-makers for the publishing companies. A good teacher can do so much better. Everyday Math is a terrific program and I would guess it is used at CWS. Homework creates tremendous stress for many families, and if you really want to help your children, read to them, engage them in the math involved in shopping and meal planning, etc. Homework frequently displaces these more intimate and meaningful activities.
     If I had known about CWS and been able to get my daughter in, I wouldn't have moved out of NYC. My daughter was in a gifted and talented program in the upper west side, and we moved to NJ because of the teacher's rigidity and complaints that my daughter, at six, wasn't a fluent reader. When I tried to discuss her homework with the teacher, I was told to 'mind my own business'. Top grades on five AP courses and three Dartmouth engineering degrees later, I look back at her rough start in the NYC public schools and wish I had known about The Children's Workshop School.

I am very happy with my daughter's progress at this school academically but more importantly personally.  She has mastered what you expect to learn at any school, reading, writing, and math.  She has also learned some things you can't learn at every school.  How to work with and live with and understand others who are different from her.  She has learned tolerance and compassion from being in an environment that embraces and celebrates diversity and creativity.  She will grow up and move on and get more homework and take lots of tests and encounter lots of different types of schools. parents, and kids.  But she will grow up having experienced a happy and safe primary environment as her first exposure to school.  CWS is a family under one sky and like any family it is far from perfect but it is full of loving and caring people who take care of the children in their family.

I'm sorry but am of the 'old school' where I feel that education is about Math and ELA not hugs... hugs I can do at home.

Our family has been a part of the Children's Workshop School "family" for 10 years. Our children, two of whom are shy, were nurtured, valued and challenged here. In general, the teachers are excellent—bright, energetic, organized and devoted. Our kids been so fortunate to have had Helen, Suma, Scott, Miriam and Jessica who are talented and dedicated. Yes, there are a few clunkers, but not as many as at my sister's kids' posh private school, or at the highly-rated schools I attended as a child. Someone mentioned that their child did not learn how to write—this is next to impossible at this school; there is a piece of personal information that that parent is withholding. People have criticized Maria Velez-Clark for being off-putting, but my feeling is that she is somewhat shy, and I know for a fact she is devoted to the children. The school was founded by Maria and another educator who moved to Finland—it is my understanding that she was the more outgoing spokesperson for the school. My kids have always felt that the could walk right into Maria's office to get a hug, display a lost tooth or share exciting news with Maria. In general, the parents who are most dissatisfied and angry are the parents of children who turn out to have special needs—and yes, the school does not do a great job of catering to kids with potential learning disabilities, especially if they're from a family that has the means to address it on their own. It's a small school with limited funds. The school was founded on the principles of Martin Luther King—peace (non-violence), integration of all races, ethnicities, and religions, and dedication to maintaining the freedoms that are our rights. If Martin Luther King came to the annual celebration that is named for him, and he saw the mix of Black, White, Asian, Hispanic, Muslim children standing onstage singing "We're All One Family Under One Sky" together, he would see the realization of his dream.

A 'shy' Principal is not a good start for any school.  The non-violent principals are fine as is the ethnic inclusions what I object to to the shoddy lack of concern that this school FAILS in student progress and all that seems to happen is that the kids are overloaded with homework and spend their days doing art and ballet when clearly there's a greater need for more engagement in Math and ELA.   I might be cute that the school is so casual in it's approach and 'we are one family' but it's one family that won't be sending many kids off to collage (unless its art school). I'm sorry but am of the 'old school' where I feel that education is about Math and ELA not hugs... hugs I can do at home.

You need to do a lot more at home than hugs judging from your atrocious spelling and grammar!  The Principal runs the school, whereas the MLK principles form the foundation of the school.  "It's" is the contraction of "it" and "is," whereas "its" (without an apostrophe) is the possessive form of "it."  If you wanted high test scores you should have gone to a school that teaches to the test.  Everyone knows that the progressive schools do not do so.
collage or college
if you are caught up in testing, then you shouldn't have chosen a progressive school for your child in the first place.

Please stay far away from this school. They are too laid back and it shows on their state report card. The Children's Workshop School received an F grade for Student Performance and an overall grade of a C. What on earth is the school prinicpal doing to fix this? The teachers rarely give any homework, and the students do not study from text books or workbooks at home. I have never seen a book in five months! It is literally up to the parents to create lessons on their own if you want your child to actually learn something. Of course, they do not even mention this to parents, as you have to figure it out on your own. The school secretary rarely answers the phone, rarely returns phone calls and the phone lines are down often. If you have a question or an issue, good luck getting through! If you want your child to learn in an extremely laid back environment which promotes laziness, by all means- send your child to this school! It gets worse and worse as your child moves up in grades. I am glad to say that this will be my child's last year attending! Unfortunately, my child just may need to repeat a grade at another school due to lack of an education. He is so far behind compared to his friends in other schools. Thank you, Children's Workshop?

This is a great school.  As the parent of 2 kids with 10 years of time at the school and a traditionalist at heart with a skeptical eye,  I advise that you don't be put off by a little bit of chaos at pickup time and the slow Friday morning community meetings. The teachers are all great (and I suspect they like the freedom that Maria's admittedly less than dynamic leadership provides).  In ten years we've had only 1 clunker teacher and they were replaced halfway through the year.  Your kid will get plenty of love and attention from the teachers.  The diversity among the students is outstanding (it's truly a melting pot) and the parent community is fantastic, a committed, creative group with a PTA that works overtime to address any deficiences.  A great place for your little global citizen to start their education!

We are very happy with Children's Workshop. It is the only one of the 4 progressive schools in the East Village that offers after-school clubs and does a weekly community meeting.  It is a small and sweet school with a focus on the arts and group learning that has been very beneficial for my daughter.  The library is lovely, the teachers are all caring and energetic, and the parents and kids all easy-going and friendly.  There is a wonderful atmosphere of cooperation and acceptance and every year gets better and better for my child here.

This school is NOT the same as it was a few years ago... steady decline due to poor Principal leadership and slant towards arts (Ballet Hispanico, yoga etc) when kids are clearly not progressing... Student Progresion on DOE was at an F Fail. There are a few good teachers but the Principal is rude and not understanding to parents needs.   The stress is on the children that they are failing as opposed to looking at the teaching an leadership inadequacies.   Cathy Black will be getting a letter from me about this school. Some drastic measures need to be taken if kids are to meet DOE standards.

All three of my children have attended Children's Workshop since we moved here 5 years ago, and overall, our experience has been extremely rewarding. The school really IS warm and welcoming, and kids definitely get the sense that they are cared for and respected. The teachers and administration do their very best to serve all of their children, under sometimes difficult circumstances, given the mixed backgrounds and incomes of families and the varying levels of participation among parents. But that diversity is another thing that makes this school so special, and there is an enormous emphasis on compassion, tolerance and kindness at this school - something that I've not seen elsewhere. My kids have LOVED their experience at CWS -- each of them has at some point expressed their desire to be teachers when they grow up so that they can go back and teach there! It's not always perfect, but then no school is. I think some of the parents who've written here about being dissatisfied have unrealistic expectations. If you want the faculty and administration to greet you personally when you enter the building, a private school may be a better choice for your family. I could care less about whether a teacher smiles at me in the hall. More important to me -- do the kids come home talking about what they've learned, sharing new information, and excited about their projects? That's been our experience.

To expect to be greeted by someone, anyone on the very first day of school, a five year olds first day ever at a public school...that is an unrealistic expectation???  Amid the chaos of a first day, not one person to acknowledge your existence is truly sad and left a lasting impression.  I disagree wholeheartedly with everything you said. You only know your experience - do not judge someone else's.  By the way, the parental body is not inclusive. It is actually quite segregated.  You must be in the majority.

I feel this school has totally failed my child  it is no suprise to see the stats online which are overall a C on a rapid decline. Go somewhere else! http://schools.nyc.gov/OA/SchoolReports/2009-10/Progress_Report_Overview_2010_EMS_M361.pdf

My son finished Children's Workshop after 6 very mixed years. My takeaway is that it's a good school that unfortunately failed him in several ways. He is still, in 7th grade, barely able to write. He loves to read and has great comprehension skills, but he has serious issues with writing that the "loose atmosphere" at CWS failed to recognize and treat. The school failed to support him when he was bullied. At the time I wanted to support the staff because I dislike over-empowered parents who always take their child's side, but in retrospect my child needed defending. I'm sad that I wasn't there for him  at that time.The teachers are either stunningly capable or stunningly inept, there was very little middle ground. My son's third grade was a hodgepodge that started out with a premature promotion of a teacher's assistant, then his removal and replacement with another rookie who could barely control the children. It was a disruptive year. Fourth grade was outstanding and my son thrived under a teacher who maintained order without screaming (one teacher was notorious for hollering). At the same time CWS should be praised for it's inclusiveness and the devotion of some staff. CWS has wild variations in parental support, from artist parents who contribute loads of support to parents in the projects who want better for their children but are stretched thin. It's hard to teach children when the home situations are so inconsistent. The schools success in this regard is praiseworthy.

My son is in Kindergarten at Children's Workshop. It's a great school with caring teachers, nice classrooms and a wonderful family environment. I would highly recommend this school especially for the little ones.

I would never recommend this school to anyone. Was completely disappointed from day one last September. We had high hopes but once we arrived on the first day of school, we felt something was off about this place. Totally chaotic and disorganized. None of the staff was there to greet us parents as we arrived. NOT ONE person greeted us. We didn't know where to go, what to do. All the while, I have an almost five year old who is clinging to us for dear life. This was not a good experience. This was the start of the bumpy ride at CWS. Principal Velez-Clarke is unapproachable. The office staff is rude and they basically run the show. Most teachers do not smile or acknowledge parents. Not all but most. And I have personally observed the staff yelling at the children (even the Kindergartners) more than once. That was the last straw. Not a good first experience for a 5 year old. I know there are many parents that feel this way and am surprised I don't see more comments here.

My daughter is in pre-k at Children's Workshop and we couldn't be happier with the school. True, the office staff can be a bit flaky at times but that is only because Dorothy and Joyce will drop everything to visit a classroom doing a special project or the like-their whole focus is on the students and making each child feel special. The pre-k teachers, Helen and Suma, are both fantastic and great communicators. The children go on field trips, do family visits, have reading buddies, learn school songs, have dance class thanks to one of the class moms, music class through Turtle Bay Music Schoolit's everything you want for your child in a school: learning through experiencing.
School has been totally unresponsive about school tours, which begin this Friday. Grade 'F' for communication with prospective parents.

"My daughter is in Pre-K this year and we are absolutely happy with the school. The teacher, staff and parents are warm and welcoming and there is a real sense of community at the school. My child knows other students by name, from all grades/classes. The older students look out for the younger ones and they make them feel special and cared for. My daughter has grown by leaps and bounds and I am very happy to have her attend Children's Workshop."

"My child has been at the Children's Workshop School from pre-K to 3rd grade. I am ever grateful to be a part of this community of teachers, administration and families who together create a great environment for my child to learn in. At CWS there is an emphasis on social studies, academics, art and music that I feel is laying a strong foundation for her education. The community aspect of the school can't be beat. From the weekly Community Meetings, to the annual Martin Luther King Jr. Celebration, the commitment to diversity, responsibility and good values abound."

"Children's Workshop has really turned out to be a great little school for my daughter," writes a parent. "The school has a very dedicated teaching staff. My daughter had had amazing warm,fun,smart teachers. There is a strong creative community of families from both the East Village and Brooklyn that attend the school. The school administration has a huge heart. It really is a diamond in the rough."
A parent writes that she and her husband love CWS because "it made us feel welcome since the first day of school."
"We have had a very positive education experience here," writes parent Jennifer Pouget. "The teachers are all very warm and helpful. The staff is very involved in what is going on in the school."

"CWS is a warm, nurturing school. From day one we have felt welcome by our school community," writes parent Sandy Kuball, whose son has attended the school for five years. "Every teacher we have had has been exceptional. The school has an amazing art program, and also works with Ballet Hispanico, Turtle Bay Music School, and now has its own school band."

"Teachers and administrators alike are energetic, talented, and deeply committed to the kids," writes a parent. "There is a clear policy: children are treated respectfully, gently, and lovingly, and yet expectations, both academic and social, are high." This parent praises the school's emphasis on group work, which takes place "in a creative, hands-on environment, and its celebration of diversity. This parent writes that a comment calling the parent coordinator "curt" is "baffling -- We are extremely fortunate to have Dorothy Cantwell as our parent coordinator. She is smart, competent, energetic, deeply committed, caring, and above all, kind."

"My children have both consistently had high quality, intelligent teachers, who are engaged with their students and the community as a whole," writes a parent with children in 6th and 2nd grades. "The parent body and children enjoy a sense of small town community, which is a great comfort in NYC. Through our years at the CWS, I have watched the school as a whole become more organized and more solid in its ability to educate."

"Both of my children have attended The Children's Workshop School since Pre-K and I continue to be amazed by the richness of their educational experience," writes a parent. "The teachers are experienced, gifted, insightful and are personally committed to each and every child. The classroom work is challenging and stimulating and the 'extras,' such as visual and performing arts, movement, Ballet Hispanico, Instrumental Instruction and Band, and now this year, Rosie's Broadway Kids, have broadened my children's experience and validated my decision to keep my family in NYC and send them to this school. The diversity, energy and creativity of the CWS community enrich our entire family."
A prospective parent complains that the parent coordinator was "curt" during her visit and that she observed the school office staff screening calls using an answering machine.

I am the parent of 2 students who are just finishing up the 6th and 7th grade at the School for Global Leaders, Dual Language Program. The teachers and staff are amazing; both diligent and nurturing. From my experience, Global Leaders is a small community who cares tremendously about the quality of education and relationships formed between us all (parents, teachers and students). The Dual Language Mandarin program happens to be a very instrumental part for us. I feel it offers versatility, diversity and an advantage for when the students prepare to enter High School. 
I want to give a special mention to Ms. Wang, my sons Mandarin teacher. She always go beyond what her duty entails and push my boys pass their comfort levels to ensure that they are at the top of their game and well prepared for the future.

-Dawn Magee

I have had the privilege of being a parent at Global Leaders since 2014. My middle son began school there in 2014 and now my youngest daughter is a 7th grader. I remember when SGL was "born" and I was skeptical. I had an older son enter the 6th grade that year and I was skeptical just because they were so new and I didn't take the leap. Five years later, I was sure SGL was the right choice for my younger son, with small class size and project based learning. And never have I been happier with a school! My son left Global Leader to attend an elite boarding school in Pennsylvania as an Oliver Scholar. As he was leaving the school to move forward in his success, my daughter was entering the school into their Dual Language Mandarin program. Unfortunately, the end of my daughter's elementary school experience was not a very good one and academically she was suffering. She had gone from scoring 3 and 4 on the statewide test to scoring low 2s. And with the tutelage and dedication of the teachers at SGL my daughter went from low 2s to 4s on BOTH state exams. I could not have been happier. The faculty and staff at SGL reinvigorated her love for learning and their dedication to her success reminded her that she could believe in herself and succeed. Both of my SGL students were not only academically challenged, but they have benefited from the plethora of extra curricular activities available to them, both being involved in the many varsity sports available, art, choral music and theater. My daughter this year participated in the school rendition of The Lion King Jr and IT WAS PHENOMENAL!

I have also spent most of the time as a parent at SGL serving on the Executive Board of the PTA. This year the PTA sponsored Career Day bringing 20 professionals from all walks of life and industries to share their work experience and educational experience with our students. Career Day was super successful enjoyed by teachers, students and presenters alike.

AT SGL, we are a true family and believe in educating and supporting the whole child. I am so glad that both my youngest children have had an opportunity to share in this community. It was definitely the BEST choice we could have made. My son was WELL prepared for his journey to high school. As my daughter rises to the 8th grade, I have no doubt she will be well prepare for whatever her high school journey will be.

Last year I was told that my daughters school was merging into Global Leader I was so worried. Miah is graduating this year and I have to say thanks to all the teachers in Global. Miah always had issues with math, in Global she actually learned her math and enjoyed it. When Miahs grades go down I reach out to her teachers and they are quick to offer help on how to get her grades back up. Special Thanks to Ms Rhoads for never giving up on Miah. 
School for Global Leaders is AWESOME

My son just Graduated from this amazing school last week. At first I was hesitant about him attending this school but I’m glad he did. The first year he struggled but because of the amazing teachers this school has he succeeded. 
Mrs Rhoads you have played an important role in my sons life and because of that I’m very greatful. You were always on top of his school work and attitude. If he wasn’t doing his work, you would personally send me an email and inform me of what was going on. 
I couldn’t thank you enough for all that you have done.

8th grade for me has been a blast of fun! I loved Being on the basketball team, football and also baseball. Thank you, Coach Nowak. My 3 years in Global has been the best thing that happened in my life. I made lots of friends and the teachers in my school don't really feel like teachers they feel like family- even though some teachers are hard on you they do this because they want us to work hard because in high school it's not going to be easy. Since the first day of SGL they wanted us to get ready for the real world and what we students are going to face. In 7th and 6th grade I did not really know as much but the teachers helped me get to where the spot i am at right now. I'm glad they did because if  they did not help me I would not be in the spot I'm at right now. SGL has my love and my heart and will always have it. P.S. the best teacher is miss rhodes.

Being a 8th grader at this school has been the best experience so far! I really enjoy the new addition of electives during 3rd period. It gives a fun little break in-between periods just to do what love. Plus the trips are amazing. The Six Flags trip was the most I've ever had there and the Camp Getaway trip was even better. Global may not seem like much if you don't know the school but they really have help with my learning. Thanks to their caring and patient teachers I finally enjoy reading...considering the fact that I would never pick up a book in 5th grade! I Hope the up coming 5th grader love this school as much as I did.

As a graduating 8th grader of 2018, I must say that this school was something that I didn't expect in a great way. The senior trip to Club Getaway was amazing, teachers are eager to help students in need and are always caring.  I had a great experience in the school overall and I recommend this school to next year's 5th graders.

Throughout the past two years at The School For Global Leaders it has allowed to hone my craft as an educator.  The administration, faculty, and staff have always been supportive and helpful!!! As a faculty member, it has been our mission to incorporate the following goals:  to ensure that students  will have multiple opportunities to make their thinking visible, help students improve content knowledge by reading in all subject areas.   Among the above goals SGL aims to provide a supportive environment and culture for the students, parents, staff, and faculty always ensuring the lines of communication open.

My son graduated last week from the School for Global Leaders...
I must say I'm happy to have picked this school.
He did very good and I'm forever grateful to all the teachers and staff .
Each and everyone of them played an important part in his 3 years there . From IPW week, Saturday school, sports , passing his  algebra regents exam and just keeping him focused over all.... All staff and teacher had an open door policy and it really felt like family. A special thanks to the parent  coordinator for all the calls, text and emails .
Thanks for all your help and support with my son .
Devin R. Garcia did it because you took time to show him how much you care for his education which made him appreciate learning from leaders who lead by example .
With love 
 Cylinda V. Otero

and also Ms Brandon for preparing the kids and getting them ready for high school and preparing them for all the paperwork that needed to be handed in time. and always being there for them when they needed you to be there thanks again.

I am a parent of 2 students one that has graduated back in 2014 and he has taken all that he has learned from the school for global leaders to high  school now thank to the school for global leaders he has been on the honor roll for 3 years now my daughter has now graduated Thursday and will be starting high school in the fall thanks to Ms Rios for all her hard work in keeping me in the loop of everything that would be happening in the school for global leaders. and Ms Damura for being very patient with my daughter i know my daughter was difficult at time but you knew exactly how to handle her and i appreciate all the hard work you have done to keep her in line and for that i thank you.and i also would like to thank Mr. Nowack for keeping her busy with sports  she needed to stay busy. i might be spelling the names wrong but i'm sorry thank you guys again for all your hard work and patients again.
 

Thank you global leaders again its been a great Journey for me to have you in my life for the past 6 years thanks for all your hard work and patients. keep up the good work.
通过一年的学习，我孩子成绩进步很快，我认为这和学校学习环境有很大的关系，教师的教学方式可以引导她在英文、数学、科学有很大的兴趣。我非常开心她选择了这个学校，而且我也很开心认识了她的老师和同学。
我的女儿在这个学校，进步很快，比如数学、科学和英文。我女儿也喜欢运动。学校小班老师能关照每个学生，看到他们都在很开心的学习。他们都很友好相互帮忙。学校也有很多奖励的郊游。
我的孩子目前在这个学校学习中文，在这一年当中孩子进步很大，现在他也会看些中文，写些中文也对中国文化有所了解。学校是小班制，可以照顾到每个孩子，我认为这是一所很不错的学校，值得考虑。
The Department of Education has announced that the School for Global Leaders will have a Chinese dual language program from the start of the 2016-2017 school year.

MS 267 principal Patricia King describes School for Global Leaders' principal Carry Chan as "a master principal in every sense of the word" in an opinion article in Chalkbeat about the Learning Leaders Program.

My son is currently in the 6th grade and he absolutely love the school. He was always an avid reader and loves Science. To be honest, my son was accepted to other middle schools , but I chose Global Leaders because of the unique curriculum and the caring staff. I was worried at first because the school shares the building with two other high schools. I had many friends' children who attended Global and said that the school is safe and is separated from the other school. My son loves the school!!!!!!
About 30 percent of students at School for Global Leaders said bullying was a regular occurrence at the school. Read more here.
School for Global Leaders, Marta Valle and LES Prep had to evacuate Friday due to a building fire. Read more here.
School for Global Leaders is used as an example by education leaders in New York of how schools can gather and use student data constantly. Read more here.
School for Global Leaders holds high school applications hostage as an incentive for parents to get involved with the application process. Read more here.

Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. School for Global Leaders was chosen to host The Urban Assembly for the Urban Environment and M.S. 267 Math, Science & Technology. Read more here.

I am a parent of a 7th grader. I completely disagree with you Danielle. My daughter absolutely loves her teachers and respects Mrs. Chan. I enrolled my child in this school because of her and the wonderful teachers. My daughter and I turned down other middle schools in D1 for this school. She loves English and Science especially IPW. It is an "A" school and the staff, students and parents should be very proud of it. I Every time I need to meet with the dean, or any school administrators, they were available. Ms. Chan is always willing to meet with me even when I don't have an appointment. She is dedicated and cares a lot about her students. When I email the teachers, they always respond back. Ms. Rios has always been polite and patient with my questions. If you don't like the school,  you should transfer your child out.

You're entitled to disagree with me Eva. I'm stating my personal experience. You stated that you enrolled your daughter into the school because of the wonderful teachers and Mrs. Chan. How did you get to know the staff WELL, or at all for that matter, before you enrolled her in SGL? One thing about my kid is that he never gets into trouble and is extremely respectful of his fellow peers and staff. I get praises about my son during Parent Teacher Conference. I can care less about the school being an "A" school. There are many "A" schools out there that have many unhappy parents and students and an extremely rude staff. I have two other kids that attend a "C" school and I absolutely LOVE the school as well as my kids do. My kids have had a solid education in that school and the staff is warm and extremely attentive. The school grading system has its pros and cons. Really dig into exactly how the grading system works to get a better understanding. Many parents see an "A" school grading and assume "GREAT"!... bad assumption. Go figure why Mayor Bill de Blasio is seeking to rid the grading system. Anyway, I'm glad all is working out for your daughter and NO, I'm not transferring my son to another school. He graduates this year. He has been accepted into a so-called wonderful school with a so-called great staff. I use the words "so-called" because he will be a new enrollee and I'd be lying if I told you that the principal was great and that I enrolled my son in there because of the wonderful staff, etc. After all, how would I know this personally?

At the end of his experience at this school, do you feel your son was well educated? 
Is he prepared for HS?

Hi. Yes, I do feel he was educated. Now how well...only time will tell. I will know once he enters high school. Every high school is different, and nobody really knows exactly what to expect. I'd like to note that I really liked the teachers @ SGL. They extended themselves greatly to the students and I really admired that. I just wasn't happy with the leadership.

There is a high rate of Teacher turn over and some Teachers have been let go beginning and mid season. Good Teachers have been let go and have been replaced by Teachers who now have to juggle and get to know all the kids in a short matter of time. This greatly affects the students tests and scores.

I chose SGL as a top choice back in 2011 for my son and he graduated in 2013. My Daughter is now set to graduate in a few months 2014. This school has gone to the pits. No order, no one is on the same page. Communication with parents is lacking . Countless of times I have turned in medical paper work and it doesn't go in the file. Messages are not given to the Teachers and no call backs.

PBS Newshour highlighted an eighth grade English class at Global Leaders as an example of how teachers are adapting their lessons to meet the Common Core Standards. Read more and watch a video clip here.

I'm a parent of a teen (daughter) that graduated last June 2011 VALEDICTORIAN with an average of 98.7, the highest scoring student, not just girl, student of the graduating class...I am proud to say that Ms. Hickey, Ms. Chan, Ms. Alvarez were amazing to not just my daughter but to all the kids,,,there are some behavior issues from a select few, naturally teens are going to be teens,,but the adults in the school TRULY care about the education, and that's what its supposed to be about,,unfortunately my daughter did not get into the HS she and I wanted, but she got into the third choice which is still not a bad choice,,,,if you are considering placing your child in School for Global Leaders,,,it will be a great choice,,,only really stay in touch with the staff so that you are most informed,,,what I did not like looking back, was that there were great exercise programs while my daughter was in the 6th grade that included taking the kids out to the track for running, etc...involvement in the 1, 5k races for charity,,,but during the 7th and 8th grade, i did not see much of those programs,,,also the social awareness trips were really fantastic in 6th grade, (mind you it was the very first year the school opened its doors) but the focus has been on other things,,like i said in a previous post, the afterschool program I wished was more involved,,,and the food, eh,,,,its a public school...but i loved the uniforms,,,the school truly acts and runs as a private school...i am blessed to have found Ms. Chan....oh and one more thing,,my daughter got a pc the first year for attending...m little cousin who came in the following year, and graduates this June did not get a pc...., the other grades i didnt get pc's as the school expanded,,,so yes just consistent perks would have been fantastik for the students coming in,,,,

Your child and the rest of the students may have been in a different school. They truly care? Sorry but as often as Teachers  getting let go and the disorganizations that happen at this school surely I see no evidence of such greatness.

Please change information on this school.There is no French or Spanish offered.  They may have formed partnerships with Columbia and other teaching organizations, but there is no evidence of this within the school. The school is staffed by young, dedicated teachers but are overwhelmed by disruptive students and this is not conducive to learning. Many students seems not to comly with school rules. Real science lab? - not until 2013/14. Computer lab?- doesn't exist.
YOU ARE RIGHT! WHAT HE'S TELLING YOU IS THE TRUTH. TRUST ME I WAS A STUDENT IN THAT SCHOOL, AND I KNOW WHAT'S THE TRUTH AND WHAT'S NOT!!!

We are proud parents of a sixth grader at global leaders. We chose to place our child in global leaders above the other schools our child was accepted to.  Global Leaders seemed, and has demonstrated, the ability to guide our child to perform at her best.  With a project based curriculum and more integrated projects, our son is in fact learning more while in the classroom than ever before. The administrative staff, especially the principal Ms. Chan, has communicated with us and been with us throughout the year.  Although our son does say Ms. Chan is strict,  I am extremely pleased to see that there are still people in the department of education that are willing to work with the parents and students to ensure the learning environment is effective.

Um I'm a senior at this school currently and this school is good. The strict curriculum by ms.chan keeps us in the line , yes homework consists of reading , a science question , math sheet with like 7 questions but our class work is very heavy and we learn a lot of material . I am a proud parent of one of the students that will be part of the first graduating class 2011. I was fortunate to have found out about the school's opening just in August of 2008 after my daughter was placed in a middle school that was not of my choosing. I chose to place my daughter at the MS 378, and feel blessed ever since.  My daughter has been on the principal's list several times as she has been one of the highest scoring students in her class. (6th, 7th and 8th grades) She scored a 94% average in the 7th grade.  Ms. Chan is a fantastic leader, and the teachers are highly dedicated and motivated to move students to their fullest potential. I would recommend any parent to tour the school, speak with the teachers and students to assist them in deciding wether to enroll their child.  Its a small school with a big heart. Afterschool is available in the building through the Beacon program.The only caveat is that the school shares the building with a HS but security is strategically placed to keep students separate and safe.

My son has also been very high performing at Global Leaders, and his grade average is over 98%. He has never been marked late for school there, and is only absent when he is sick or there is a very good reason. I find the school to have teachers that can sustain the interest of middle school students every day. I have found the principal to be passionate about her school, and the issues related to solving global problems. There is tolerance and inclusion, so some students are academically talented with some behavior issues that need to be addressed. This school demands that kids follow the rules.

East Side Community School's approach to the importance of books and reading is featured in a Showcase Schools video.

ECHS graduating seniors demonstrate subject mastery over through projects instead of tests. Former ECHS students say the assessment style, pioneered by the New York Performance Standards Consortium, helped better prepare them for college, Edweek reports.

ECHS eighth graders won a free trip to Universal Studios after collecting newspaper bar codes for three months and writing a joint essay in the New York Daily News' Universal Orlando Class Trip contest, the New York Daily News reports.

East Side Community School is one of 48 schools, which have permission to use projects for graduation instead of the state-mandated standardized tests known as the Regents. Read more here
East Village students walk out after DOE bans Eric Garner protest. Read more here.

Following the grand jury decision not to indict the police officer involved in the death of Staten Island man Eric Garner, the principal of East Side Community High School sent a personal letter to all students urging them to learn as much as they can about recent events, justice and respect. Read more here.
The principal of East Side Community HS invited the New York Civil Liberties Union to give a two-day training session last week on interacting with police. Read more here.

East Side Community School has been selected to showcase “teacher development through school culture” in the inaugural year of Chancellor Carmen Fariña’s Showcase Schools Program. The initiative is designed to promote collaboration and sharing of strong practices. Schools that excel in a specific learning focus area will host educators from other schools to share their successful structures and strategies. Read more here.
East Side teacher Nicole Dixon applauds changes to teacher evaluations, one of several changes to come with Mayor de Blasio's deal with the UFT. Read more here.

East Side Community Principal Mark Federman has come up with various tricks to help students cope with the stress of state exams, including “Super Smart Smiley Unstuck Stickers" for when students get stuck on a test. Read more here.

East Side Community's middle school chess team recently won Chess-in-the-Schools' Grand Prix tournament for New York City. In April, about a dozen students will go to a national chess competition in San Diego. Read more here.

A new report from CEC 1 found that more than a third of schools in the district do not have a gym or must share their gym with other schools. DNAinfo highlights East Side Community High School as an example of a school struggling with space issues; its gym is two classrooms with the dividing wall removed. Read more here.
East Side Community High school's Mark Federman is DNAinfo's Principal of The Week. Read full interview here.

A free Beacon program at East Side Community High School, called University Settlement, had to shut down its entire elementary summer program and slashed the number of spots for middle and high school students because they lost their federal funding. Read more here.
Buildiing repairs that have kept our school in two remote locations since late September are ahead of schedule and we are due back at East Side on 1/22/13!

Gothamschools reported that East Side Community is one of 52 city high schools that have developed advanced courses that are deemed "college prep" by the Ed Department, meaning students who pass the rigorous course are more likely to succeed in college. 

Read more: http://gothamschools.org/2012/11/30/evaluating-homegrown-courses-city-deems-some-college-prep/
NY1 reports that Education Department officials said in a letter to East Side Community School parents that it will be "months" before the school is safe for "reoccupation" again.

Update for prospective students and their families:  On 10/15/12, we learned from the DOE, DOB, and SCA  that repairs will not allow us to return to our building until late February, 2013.  In the meanwhile,  a committee of ESCHS parents, teachers, and administrators has formed to arrange informational tours to be held at some area D1 elementary schools (dates and locations TBA) as a substitute for physical tours, which will simply not be possible before the application deadline for middle school.  We will very shortly post a new newsletter for prospective families on our website.  Please keep referring back to our website at eschs.org for updates on these matters.  As for our continuing displacement, the principal, Mark Federman, and his amazing team will remain focused on maintaining the highest standards for our kids, fostering a community feeling, and restoring any programs  (academic, afterschool, and otherwise) that may have had to be tabled in the short term while dealing with this emergency.  Please note, East Side Middle recently received an A (again!) on its school progress report -- the same grade it's received in every year that grades have been assigned.  High School progress reports are not in yet, but that is likely to be an A (again!), as well.    PS: note that the photos here, above, of ESCHS are good images of our lovely school.

Officials knew about the structural problems at the building housing East Side Community School for a long time before the near collapse of a wall. Read more: Students Went To School In Building With Structural Problems For More Than A Year .

On 9/25/12, a routine weekly inspection of the building revealed the eastern wall was separated from the roof.  The building is closed for repairs but the SCHOOL is alive and well, with the high schoolers temporarily relocated to the Norman Thomas building on 33rd & Park.  As of 10/1/12, the middle schoolers are in PS 1 on Henry Street in Chinatown, a K-5 building that has generously made space available for us for the duration of our displacement.  Principal Mark Federman and the staff have done an amazing job of making the best of the situation, and the parent community has been effective in supporting the school leadership in this crisis.  My daughter is a high-achieving 7th grader at East Side who not only is challenged academically, but who is happy and has made a wonderful group of friends.  ESCHS was our first choice for her and we've never looked back.  She has no intention of leaving for another high school.  ESCHS will be at the D1 Middle School fair on Wednesday, 10/3/12 at PS 134.  Arrangements will be made for outreach to 5th grade parents.  This is the best middle school in District 1, and I daresay, one of the best in the city. A

i am one of the parents of an 11th grader that does attent east side community highschool and i for one was not notified about any meeting or any thing going on about the school i didnt know my child was relocated to another scool as this was taken place until finallly on wednesday sept 26th of this year recieved a text stating the relocation of students without detail i have yet to hear about a meetin or anything but recieved a trip paper and as usual recieved the notice of cell phones on friday about a truck person holding cells for $1 each catch was i recieved on sept 28 notice dated sept 29th on a saturday

Hi, Jeanette -- I'm a parent of a 7th grader and I'm sorry you felt uninformed.  The building issue was discovered on 9/24 and a note was sent home to parents directing their children to PS 19 on 9/25.  On 9/26 school was closed for Yom Kippur and that evening was the date of the first parent meeting.  By 9/27 high schoolers were reporting to Norman Thomas.  The school has done a good job of posting updates to eschs.org and also using automated mass phone messages (robo-calls) to keep parents informed of meetings, transportation info, etc etc.  If you have not received any robo-calls during this period, please contact your child's advisory teacher to make sure you are on the automated phone call list.

Because of improvements in its test scores, East Side Community High School was removed from the state's list of schools needing improvement and is now considered "in good standing" under No Child Left Behind.

Because of its improved test scores, East Side Community High School was removed from the state's list of schools needing improvement and is now considered "in good standing" under No Child Left Behind.

A former teacher writes: "East Side Community High School is a shining star in the nation for schools serving the commonly ill-perceived 'urban' youth. East Side cares about the students and their families and demands high expectations from all." She continues: "I [dispute] the statistic that it only graduates 65% [of its students]. This seems incorrect. As well, I take issue with the appraisal that kids calling out of turn or a teacher using incorrect grammar point to weakness in instruction. Educators vary in the way they monitor classroom discussion, and a real conversation among peers rarely involves hand-raising. As for the teachers use of incorrect grammar, my guess is that it may have been an attempt on the part of the teacher to appear non-threatening to his/her students or to intentionally honor a non-standard usage of English." She concludes: "I would send my own children to East Side. Also, the fact that East Side is exempt from city curriculum is most likely due to the fact that East Side's curriculum far exceeds that found in most schools nationwide. An above-average school filled with above average teachers and students. Test scores can not possibly measure what happens in schools like this one."

A graduate of the school who has moved on to college writes: "This school was very special to me. They showed me a lot thanks to the amazing teachers they have [there]. ... I had many wonderful experiences here and probably would not have had them if I attended a different high school." She adds that the principal's work is "a job well done."

"Kids feel like they are part of a community here," a teacher said. "Everybody who spoke at graduation talked about being part of a family and community," she said. Kids feel so comfortable at the school that they stick around after school, she said. "The bell rings and the building is still full of kids." She praised the principal's dedication: "He works a million hours a week."

Traveling in the hallways can be a hassle since middle and high schoolers are all on the third floor. It's easy to get used to the crowded hallways. Once you've been at NEST for a few months you'll definitely find ways to avoid the hallway traffic. Teachers are not harsh about being late to class because of the traffic.

S.S, I’m a parent of a student that’s considering NEST. It sounds like you’re from Queens. With your grades Townsend is an excellent choice. They have almost 300 seats versus the 130 seats in Nest. Nest just like Baccalaureate prioritizes admissions for continuing 8th graders so seats for outside applicants is limited. The commute to Nest from Queens is dreadful but I encourage you to try it like we did.

Hi, I've been a student at NEST for 9 years now. I also live in Forest Hills. The commute to school is pretty tough but it's definitely worth it. I wake up around 6 if I want to take my time but, I can wake up as late as 6:50 and still be on time to school. NEST is a great environment for students who prefer collaborative learning. It's a great option for prospective middle and high schoolers.

After the first week of school, Chalkbeat reports on the conflicting opinions NEST+M parents have about the mayor's proposal to eliminate gifted and talented schools across the city. While some parents are against the idea of eliminating the advanced programs, others recognize the lack of diversity at the school.

It shouldn't be an either-or decision. The chancellor's committee should have taken into account possible ways to increase diversity, including amending their bus and transportation policy. Most of the lack of diversity lies squarely with the DOE's own policies in terms of busing, program location, and admissions. There are plenty of things they could do on their end to increase diversity rather than resort to eliminating the programs.

We are looking at NEST for middle school. The rubric says "grades 90 and above" but many 4th graders in NYC are on a 1-4 scale. Does anyone have a sense of the 1-4 scale grades required for consideration for admission?
Thanks!

Our child was one of the lucky ones who got in for 6th grade. To give you an idea of what it took to earn a place there, The 4th grade report card had all 4s across the board, 0 absences, 5 lateness', a perfect State Math Score, I think 4.5?, and ELA score was 4.3 something (if recall. It was 3 points off a perfect score). We knew competition would be tough but our kid did the best they could. Good luck!

It would be so helpful for one of these sites to crowd source cutoffs like they do for SHSAT cutoffs.
So for e.g., for middle school 2019 app to NEST, my daughter had all 4, and 4.4 Math, and 4.2 ELA, 0 absences/lates, but did not get a spot at NEST, so now we have an idea of the cutoffs from last year.
I would love to hear about the High School. I believe the DOE stats include IEP and NEST middle school students (93 average), so it's hard to tell the real cutoffs for GenEd new kids. This would help parents set expectations and make better choices.

You must be proud that your child had great scores in 4th grade. Please understand there were no hard cutoff scores but rather 1 or 2 open seats for middle school for hundress of qualified applicants. Admissions priority goes to continuing 5th graders and most stay to avoid the stressful touring/application process and cause they love the school. A continuing 5th grader with a 3 average and 2 state test scores would have priority over an outsider with 4's across the board. Your child could easily have gotten into Salk, Lab, Clinton or other competitive MS which I am sure they did.
3.7 on a GPA scale is 90. So if your child is less than 3 then don't bother.
All 4s in academics, we will see. Thanks for the guidance.
Plenty of kids applying will have straight 4s. In terms of ranking, I'd guess the hairs will be split with the state tests--4.5 down to 4.?? will determine placement.
Attendance should be 10 or less lateness/absences

I love the school but would like to know why the principal, Mr. Berkowitz is so negative about the re-implementation of language for elementary school. If the mandarin program was not strong enough, the solution was not to get rid of languages but to make the program stronger. It does not have to be mandarin; it could be any language but the elementary level is when the kids should start taking languages, no later. Mr. Berkowitz has been asked several times at Coffee with the Principal and PTAs meetings why he took out languages and he is never been able to offer a clear response and does not even want to talk about it. And yes, there is friction between teachers and him, because like in the language case, his decisions are pretty arbitrary as he acts without considering suggestions and recommendations from the teachers, who are the ones who really have experience in many of the topics he is considering. I strongly suggests that he takes into account the opinions of others. NEST+m is a community and we all can contribute to make it a better place.
100% agree
