This is the typical one sided review of schools I see on this site and everywhere. When we started school we were told quite bluntly that the teacher we had for Kindergarten treated boys in a less than positive fashion. We were also told the school generally did not treat boys well. If you can't tell, I am being as politically correct as I can muster. Suffice it to say that I have lodged many complaints against our K and 2nd grade teacher. The schools support for these complaints was so lacking that I had to take it up to the District office. This is not just my complaint, I was warned by the parents who came before me and have continually have had it reinforced by the people who have had these teachers after us.

Yes, I have a tough kid. Yes, I did everything the school asked. But when the Principal agress a teacher's behavior crossed the line, and then does nothing, what are my family's rights? And what happens when 2 of this years 4th grade teachers announce they can no longer teach certain students? Sorry, the state guarantees my son an education. Protection of teachers who have the same complaints logged against them every year is not an acceptable way of doing business. Furthermore, the Principal is actually on record as beaking the law in denying a student an education. She wassued in arbittration.The parent signed papers saying she would not discuss the case, but the student remained at the school so I assume the Principal lost.
Instead of blaming the teachers, how about taking an honest look at how your kids behave and the general lack of respect some people's children have for adults?
"We were also told the school generally did not treat boys well. - absolutely CRAZY and UNTRUE, a blatant lie

I have a 2nd grader and 4th grader attending PS40.  This write up does an excellent job capturing the numerous reasons why PS40 is such a special school:  truly dedicated administrators, teachers and staff, open communication with parents, and a tight-knit community with a strong and welcoming PTA.  The net result is a lot of happy kids who value their school experience in and outside of the classroom. My husband and I have never felt more a part of a community in NYC until our children began attending PS40.

Over the years I have seen the math curriculum evolve for the better.  While TERC is used as an underpinning, I do feel that efficiency is being emphasized more strongly in each grade which is important, and that the school is doing a better job in educating parents about a math curriculum which is completely different from how we parents learned. This understanding has helped me accept and appreciate many elements of the math curriculum, and even view aspects as an improvement to when I was in school. The English Language Arts curriculum is very strong.

When thinking of the big picture, I am so grateful that my kids are getting a quality public education in a close-knit community, and that I don't live in the suburbs!

TERC is a very inefficient, slow way to learn math and it is no reflection on PS40. they are stuck with it. My kid entered 3rd grade from a fancy private school unable to read. Could not read. By the end of 3rd grade at PS 40, she can read. My 1st grader can also read. I have NO complaints, Susan Felder is a great educator.
How many kids from here usually go to Salk for middle school?
Alas, small class size at P.S. 40 is a thing of the past.

WNYC reports on school fundraising, noting that wealthier schools like PS 151, PS 10, PS 163 and PS 40 can raise more money for supplemental programs than schools with poorer students. Read more: For Some Schools, Tight Budgets Mean More from Parents.
another reason to ignore public radio

A former parent writes, "The small class size (18) that my son had when he entered kindergarten at PS 40 (I think there were 4 K sections) has become 5 classrooms of 25 each.  The grant for small class size no longer exists."

I said a tearful goodbye to PS 4o yesterday as my youngest of 4 children graduated.  Before leaving, however, I told the wonderful Principal, Susan Felder, that I wanted to share with her a conversation that i had had with several other PS 40 families both this year and last.  The conversation was about the fact that, although our children were not advanced for their age when they entered the school at age 4 or 5, --a funny thing had happened to them by the time they were ready to leave the school in fifth grade; they had become advanced.  they had grown so much in the nurturing garden of PS 40 that by the time they were ready to leave, they had secured seats in the city's most elite middle schools, alongside and in some cases instead of, their counterparts at the Gifted and Talented schools. Any decent school, it seems to me, can take a child who is advanced for their age starting out--and keep them advanced.  But it takes much, much more in a school to take kids who are not advanced--and to turn them into advanced students by the time they leave.  That remarkable achievement, I told Susan Felder, is the legacy, to me and to others--of the wonderful neighborhood school known as Public School 40.
How many of the graduates are going to Salk this year? What about Clinton?

Like many parents I am not a fan of TERC math (not many parents are) and have had to supplement with private tutors. That is just the way it is and something our family was prepared to do.  However, there are so many wonderful aspects to PS 40 from Principal Susan Felder (she knows just about if not every name of the students in the school and is very hands on) to the teaching staff and more importantly to the parents.  The PTA is very active, the parents involved, and the environment a strong and nuturing one.  Many who are on the fringes of District 2 zoning really want to be at PS 40 and with good reason, the school does provide a good education for the students and has many art and cultural programs funded through its PTA.  Are there areas that can be improved?  Of course (as with any public school). And it has been my experience that the administration does want to continue to ensure a quality education for the the students in all areas.  Yet all you have to do is turn on NY1 and hear the plight of parents in other NYC neighborhoods (not as fortunate as those living in the Peter Cooper/Stuy Town/Gramery park areas) on schools closing, below standard teaching, and not having many alternatives.

I attended P.S 40 until 4th grade, and my time there was nothing but good. As of now I am in 8th grade, taking ninth grade math, science, and foreign language. I will be in Honors Geometry, Honors Biology, Honors English, and Honors Spanish. I have also been accepted into two private boarding high schools on scholarship. My entire elementary experience was spent at P.S 40, and it gave me the solid foundation every child needs to succeed. I give them a great deal of credit in making me the well rounded individual I am right now, and I hope your child benefits from it as I did.

My child is a recent grad of PS 40.  The school is, for the most part, a well-administered school that works hard to communicate with parents.  It also offers a very nurturing atmosphere and parents are very involved. There are some very good, dedicated teachers, as well as some mediocre and sub-par ones.  Overall, it is a solid school; however, there are two problems at PS 40 that also apply to all District 2 elementary schools.   

1. The TERC math curriculum (which is mandated throughout District 2) leaves much to be desired.  It is strong on "strategizing" different ways to solve a problem, but does not emphasize basic calculation skills.  As a result, students can do elaborate diagrams that relate to a math problem, but take an inordinate amount of time to execute simple calculations.  We saw this shortcoming and sent our child to an afterschool math program that taught her multiplication and division.  Finally, after complaints from parents, a slight adjustment was made to the TERC curriculum and "math facts" began to be emphasized (in other words, items like multiplication tables!!).  I won't forget when parents were instructed at the end of third grade to teach the multiplication tables to our children over the summer because they would need to know them in the fall.   Guess they realized that these "math facts" were important after all and it was on us to fix the deficit they created!   We were lucky because we had the resources to send our child to an afterschool program and she was ahead of the rest of the kids when they made the curriculum shift.  But more adjustments in the curriculum still need to be made.  

2. Spelling skills do not receive much attention.  In fact, my child had two teachers who could not spell -- one of them proudly/defiiantly announced to parents that she could not spell during the first open-class visit of the year!  We tried to address the curriculum's shortcoming at home and a fifth grade teacher also made an effort after she realized that her class couldn't spell.  But you can't win the battle when -- until your child's last year in elementary school --  the "spelling is not all that important" message is being communicated in class.  My child is an excellent reader and is becoming an excellent writer with poor spelling.  A recent conference with my child's middle school Language Arts teacher revealed that most of the teacher's students (who come exclusively from District 2 elementary schools) are poor spellers.  She also said that spelling is not part of the middle school curriculum and therefore she is not working on building spelling skills and is only grading papers based upon content, paragraph structure, etc.  So, once again,  we will need to address in-school shortcomings via private tutoring.  Even in the world of spell-check, spelling is an important skill and PS 40 and all the other District 2 elementary schools need to recognize this fact and address it.

An afterschool class to learn multiplication and division?  A private tutor to learn how to spell?  These are things a parent can teach or if you are too busy, just go and buy a workbook at Barnes and Nobles.  No biggie.
really..isn't the whole point of sending your kids to school is so they are taught...why do parents have to "teach" their kids at home..why not just homeschool them then?  it is a "biggie"

Then why are we sending the kids to school if when they get home we have to hire someone or buy an instruction book to teach them the basics; which should have been taught in elementary school not very sensible and a little to elitist not all parents have the means to hire a tutor.

My comments indicated that we have worked with our child on basic math skills and spelling.  However, reinforcement from the classroom is invaluable.  And when necessary skills are not taught in the classroom and, in some instances, teachers are openly deficient in these basic skills, you are fighting an uphill battle that workbooks from Barnes and Noble cannot completely address.  Plus, many children will more readily accept academic intervention from adults other than their parents.  That's not an unusual phenomenon.

While I echo the comments of concerned dad - we too sent our children to a math afterschool program and worked with our kids on spelling , etc. - no school is perfect. Parents must be engaged in helping their kids with their education. The curriculum, TERC is mandated by the district so you will find this in all of the other district 2 schools. We saw a big change in the years we were at 40 from our older daughter to our younger daughter in which they started to stress mathematical computation practice in addition to the TERC math. My point being, at least they listened to us, the parents. And TERC, as an adjunct is a useful way to teach the mathematical concepts behind the computations. Both our children were well prepared for the excellent district 2 middle schools they attended. One is now flourishing in a specialized high school. You would be fortunate to be able to have your children attend PS 40 and be part of their wonderful community. The principle Susan Felder is a caring dedicated professional. The teachers are excellent, caring and nurturing. They collaborate and work together. They employ innovative and creative projects to engage children in all subjects. The music teacher, Mr. Churchill is also excellent. I would say in all our years there with our two children we had one teacher which I would say was 'marginal'.

Your comments are truly valuable. We are moving to the district and are trying to figure out what school to send our children to. I think (in particular since my husband and I are from non English speaking countries,) it is important to have teachers who are proficient in the subject they are teaching i.e. spelling...

I loved this place so much. The teachers were always really helpful, and always gave me, an overachiever, extra work so that I wouldn't have to be bored to death by homework that felt easy. They also worked hard to help students who were struggling. No one ever got left behind, and the staff seemed to genuinely care about every student equally, never picking favorites. The arts program was amazing, and we got loads of art, music and dance classes. Everyone had a talent, and even the non-artistic people were encouraged to work hard in these classes. Everyone was allowed to read and write at their own level, and I was seen carrying around massive Harry Potter books at six years old. Math was a bit more accelerated than other schools, but was always eased in with fun activities. I encourage all parents to look at this school, because it's a great place to send your kids.

A parent writes to praise PS 40's teachers, whose "passion for teaching is constantly evident" and who are "always available." She also praises the school's "rich" curriculum, through which her children created an i-movie, dressed as Thomas Paine as part of a Revolutionary War-era mock press conference, and "even got to pet a giant cockroach." This parent also calls the principal "caring, fair , and approachable" and notes the school's diversity.

"Academics are good and the school works hard (and with great success) to foster a strong sense of community among the kids," writes a parent, who adds that the school's emphasis on test preparation is excessive. "The stellar test scores come at no small price to the kids - huge amounts of time are spent on test-taking preparation, often bringing rushed instruction on subjects not yet covered in the final days leading up to the tests," this parent writes. "As the test dates approach in each grade, the pressure put on the kids to do well by the teachers is palpable."
National Dance Institute (NDI), a program founded by Jacques d'Amboise, offers dance instruction to all 5th graders, an NDI spokesman said.

A parent writes: "I toured many schools and chose this school for many reasons. PS 40 is an unpretentious, non-elitist, warm, and nurturing school where kids are adored and parents are welcome. It is housed in a beautiful and very clean old building where classrooms are bright and colorful and all of the children's work is displayed. Most of the teachers are enthusiastic and dedicated." She continues: "There is a large population of gifted children at 40, as there is not enough space in the super-selective schools to accommodate them all, and many parents choose 40 over the local gifted schools. ...The class-size is kept low; the teachers are really quick to identify the kids who need extra help or extra work. The expectations are high, yet the children are not bombarded with tons of homework. They do have some starting in Kindergarten, but they also have plenty of time for after-school activities, free-play, and family time. A child's life shouldn't be about schoolwork, and they understand that at 40. If it's scores you're looking for, the kids are doing very well on standardized tests." Finally, she adds: "There is a really nice mix of kids and many super-involved parents. The PTA is pro-active and raises a lot of money to pay for enrichment classes, supplies and teaching assistants. PS 40 is the kind of place where you want to be involved, and there are so many ways to be."

A parent writes: "It's interesting to read the comments on PS 40 from the perspectives of so many opinionated parents, myself included. If nothing else, it proves PS 40 has a genuinely concerned parent association that is eager to provide nothing short of the BEST education we can within the confines of a limited budget." She continues: "I would love to see the school fully embrace technology and the arts. The new integrated arts program is making a wonderful start and is already sparking the imaginations of many; the warm and inviting library has made great advances recently also, but it is clear that certain 21st century necessities" are necessary. Among the improvements she suggests are "an active PS 40 website, where parents and kids can exchange information and ideas, a computer class that teaches how to effectively use the web for research, and ... computers in each classroom that were online and networked." This parent also thinks the school needs "more cultural field trips, a drama program, a dance, movement or at least a more varied sports program and a well-thought out and healthy meal plan" and writes that "if every parent here paid the average of a tenth of a single NYC private school's tuition to support the PS 40 annual appeal, our kids could have all these programs and more." She adds: "The new principal is a refreshing change."

A parent writes: "Our new principal is terrific--she spends a lot of time in the classroom getting to know the kids and is very open to meeting with parents. Anyone with questions about our math program need only look at our fabulous 4th grade math scores to see how well it's working." She adds: "My son had trouble learning to read in first grade and received wonderful personal attention from an experienced reading teacher, and by second grade was reading on grade level. Many of the kids are reading way above grade level, and the personalized approach to teaching reading allows them to forge ahead at their own pace."

A parent writes that although her son enjoyed the pre-K program very much, he was one of the youngest students in his kindergarten class the next year, and it seemed like the teacher focused on the older children in the class. She also complains that her daughter, who was a 5th grader at the school, "learned very little due to the TERC math curriculum (where she had previously been recommended to the gifted program at another school) and her grades sunk. ... Punctuation and grammar were also overlooked in Language-Arts."

"I read a posting from a parent from January 2004. I can't believe she was talking about the same school," writes a parent. "Having two children, whom are very different from each other, at PS 40 I have seen a variety of teachers and learning styles. I have never found communication with faculty or administration to be difficult. A note in a teacher's mailbox will get you a response or a meeting if you desire. (Pick-up and Drop-off times are not times to discuss your child.) Most teachers offer their email addresses for communication. The principal's door is always open. See her secretary and make an appointment. She takes time for parents and knows just about every kid in the school. She may know more about your child as a learner than you think." She adds, "A parent recently commented on 'the inadequacy of TERC math and the writing curriculum.' TERC, and other constructivist math programs taught nationally have merit. Certainly the PS40 4th grade math scores from last year show TERC works. Those kids have only been taught TERC and did an outstanding job. Check the stats. The PS 40 spelling program covers grades K through 5. The SLT is hosting a Spelling Workshop at the next PTA meeting. Parents should come out and learn what is being taught at their school. PS 40 has a young dynamic faculty, which also includes enthusiastic veteran teachers. I don't know what one parent based her theory of 'potential for high turnover' on. Young teachers who go out on maternity leave come back to PS 40. There is a certain feeling to PS 40 that people aren't quick to leave. As for the comment that the PTA annual appeal donations are too steep ... PTA donations are not mandatory as in some schools. The PTA literature always seems to say 'give what you can...' The PTA is open to each and every parent/guardian at PS 40. The single parent who donates $25 is just much an equal member as the family who gets a matching corporate grant and gives a grand. It's true not all of us can afford the $400 the PTA asks for, but it is my belief that they understand and respect that. My friends with kids at 116, 234, and other public school all have annual appeals. These funds are used to support programs not funded by the Department of Education. It seems to me that the PTA is just trying to keep the halls alive with the sound of music. "

A parent complains about the lack of communication with her child's teacher and with the principal and the inadequacy of TERC math and the writing curriculum. She writes that kids are not taught enough spelling or grammar. "I find myself doing a lot of homeschooling." She goes on to say, "there are some marvelous young teachers but there is potential for high turnover. Kudos to the custodial staff! This is the cleanest, best-maintained, NYC public school I have ever seen." She writes, "The PTA also requests an annual donation that is beyond the reach of most single-parents such as myself. Basic school supplies are the responsibility of the parents. P40 is not without merit, but it is either over-rated or the majority of other public schools are grossly sub-standard."

Good academics but a "Lord of the Flies" emotional environment. Staff is utterly useless/dysfunctional regarding bullying/cruelty. Ours was not the only case--have heard of multiple other cases. Deeply regret having sent my child here. Be forewarned!
State law makers and PS 41 parents are pushing for new legislation in hopes it will deter speeding around the area, DNA info reports.
The Department of Education selected PS 41 Principal Kelly Shannon to mentor three new District 2 principals, DNAinfo reports.

Parents of students at PS 41 met with the NYPD about Sgt. Greg Abbott drawing his gun while facing the schoolyard, stating that some of the students saw the incident and were traumatized, DNAinfo reports.
PS 41's green roof is the model for a similar proposed project at a new middle school in the West Village. Read more here.

PS 41 Manhattan is one of 11 schools featured in the findings of a federal investigation that revealed 83% of New York City elementary schools are not "fully accessible" for students with disabilities. Read more here and see the report here.
PS 41 had the highest percentage of 4th-grade students pass the 2015 ELA exam of any school without a G&T program, DNAinfo reports.
PS 41's solar rooftop garden (installed in 2013) have inspired other schools to follow suit. Read more here.
PS 41 4th-graders were among the city's top performers on the 2014 English language arts exam, reports DNA.info, although doubts about the tests content remain. Read more here.
PS 41 has cut its elective music classes because of schedule changes forced by the new teachers' union contract. Read more here.

In the wake of a series of recent accidents and close calls, Principal Kelly Shannon and a group of PS 41 parents, Village residents and local businesses are urging the city to take measures to slow traffic near the school. Read more here.
The PTA at PS 41 raised $3.97 million between 2007 and 2012, according to the NY Daily News. Read more here.

What does it mean that a child who is turned away from lottery to "stay on a waiting list"? Does it mean that a child goes to another school until PS3 calls the parents that there is finally a spot for the child? OR does it mean that a child is being red-shirted?
If you've applied at ps3 you won't be on any wait list, ps3 doesn't have one. Ps41 does.

The way the lottery works is that each family ranks the two schools and seats are assigned by lottery. Typically 41 has more applicants than seats; those whose names are not chosen in the lottery are put on a wait list that moves once private and g&t acceptances are announced. At some point those who remain on the wait list are assigned to another school, either 3 or 11. No child who is eligible for K in 2013 is denied a spot at any school that year simply because his or her zoned school has a wait list.  A seat will be found at another school in the district. Hope that helps.

In an interview with DNAinfo, Principal Kelly Shannon explains how the school finds creative solutions to overcrowding and why she thinks the rezoning is necessary.P.S. 41 Principal Strives for Excellence Despite Overcrowding.
As of 2014, PS 41 will no longer share a zone with PS 3. The two schools will each have its own zone. Read more: Zone split O.K.'d for Village Schools; Reaction Split, Too.

The New York Times reports on the school's new rooftop garden, "which uses trays with four inches of soil to grow sedum, a drought-resistant perennial, as well as herbs and other native plants."

read more: http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/24/nyregion/schools-add-in-house-farms-as-teaching-tools-in-new-york-city.html?
In an interview with DNAinfo, Principal Kelly Shannon talks about overcrowding at PS 41.

The DOE proposed zone changes for the school and plans to open a new elementary school in the area by 2014, to ease crowding in the neighborhood schools. DNAinfo reports: "Under the plan, the northern part of the current P.S. 3/41 zone would be split between P.S. 11, which would expand its current Chelsea-based zone into the Village and the new Foundling School, which would be zoned roughly from Fourth Avenue to Eighth Avenue between West 12th and West 18th Streets."
Read more: http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20121010/chelsea/redrawn-school-zones-will-ease-crowding-chelsea-village-doe-says#ixzz297hNDPVX

The Villager reports that PS 41 will open a rooftop garden this summer or fall. The principal says the green roof was six years in the making and it will be integrated into the school's curriculum. Read more: http://www.thevillager.com/?p=4443

My daughter graduated from PS 41 two years ago and she had an exceptionally good grade school experience. My first impression  in 2004 --while on the NYC kindergarten circuit tour-- was the children at the school were thoroughly engaged in meaningful, developmentally appropriate curriculum in spacious, light classrooms and my initial impression bore the test of time. For 6 years, I was welcomed into my child's classroom at least once a month and often twice a month for hands-on math and language curriculum mornings. There is ample opportunity for parent involvement and the children feel safe at PS 41. Most parents and children lament it does not go to 8th grade!! As a working mother, I appreciate the school's awareness of timing and it really seemed to create a schedule where most of us were able to attend events. At the tender age of 12, my daughter thinks of 41 as some of the best periods of her life!! But in fact she is thriving and enjoying 7th grade because she received such a sound beginning cognitively, socially and emotionally at the Greenwich Village School which currently has 55 kindergarteners on a waitlist!

P.S. 41 is a participant in the Wellness in the Schools
Cook for Kids program, which replaces the traditional cafeteria menu with
a healthy menu based on scratch cooking and fresh ingredients. WITS
places a trained culinary profession in the school cafeteria to prepare fresh
meals from scratch, engage students, and educate families about the importance
of eating whole, unprocessed foods through interactive cooking demonstrations
called WITS Labs. You can find out more about programming from Wellness in the
Schools and see a list of participating schools online at www.wellnessintheschools.org
PS 41 was a 2012 notable runner-up for a US Education Department Green Schools award.

We moved from London to New York and were delighted when we discovered we lived in the zone for a great public school. We are very happy with the education our child is getting and the school community is fantastic too!

...A very happy former PS41 parent here. One complaint, though - wish besides TERC the children had a more solid exposure to the  "traditional" math methods and curriculum. My child is now in middle school and, in order for him to keep up with the 6th grade math we had to teach him the "old way" to divide and multiply. I feel these skills should have been taught in the 4th-5th grades as it is expected that they possess them by middle school. Other than that it was a very positive experience overall! Parent involvement is tremendous - those of us with full-time jobs and other commitments may feel inadequate as compared to the rest of the parent body that is able to dedicate alot of time to the school! :-)

My daughter transitioned to 6th grade at Columbia Grammar and Prep  and the school has very traditional curriculum. Her teachers were impressed with her math analytical ability and learning algorhytms was done without too much strife. She is in 7th grade math Olympic Club and never had a math tutor.
PS 41 is awesome. Your daughter is not alone. Most of the graduates go on to great schools and do very, very well.

My child also struggled with math when he got to middle school (Lab) after PS 41.  Kids from other schools were much faster and more accurate.  My PS41 4th grader now goes to Kumon (along with many of his classmates) to avoid the same problems.  Getting a 4 on the state tests doesn't mean that you'll be OK with the math in middle school
Great review, Insideschool! We are a very happy PS 41 family.  Our children are having a wonderful experience.

The CEC debated separating PS 3 and PS 41 into their own zones though they decided that the schools will remain in a shared zone for now. Read more: Zoning Plan Would Add Stability to Pair of Downtown Schools, Principals Say.

PS 41 is a fantastic school. I can't say enough good things. I have twins and can't imagine what a waste of money it would have been to have spent 60k/year on private school. The education here is top-notch and the teachers and administrators are extremely dedicated and caring. I disagree with Sybao that the math program is weak. I never had the need to get tutors or use Kumon for my kids and they both received 4s on the 4th grade math test. Also, the school just founded a math team for 4th and 5th graders, which both of my kids are enjoying, so there are certainly opportunities for math enrichment for those who desire it. My kids will be graduating this year, and we will always be grateful to PS41 for the amazing education they received.
No tutors?
Very nice review.  How will you handle the middle school process with twins? I hope they like the same schools.

Something really good to know about applying with twins: at least in District 2 (i don't know about the others), the district will not break up a set of twins in middle school. If a school accepts one twin, they are legally required to accept the other. Apparently, last year at 41 one twin was accepted at Battery Park City and the other at Baruch S.P. The parents wanted both kids at Battery Park City. Thus, the district head called up Battery Park City School and told them they had to accept other other child. My kids have very similar grades and scores and did like the same schools, but it is still reassuring to know that they will definitely end up at the same place because of this rule.
They are discussint this on Urban Baby right now. They say it only works if you want both to go to a non-competitive school. Forget about this working with ESMS, Salk or Lab.

I got this straight from the guidance counselor at PS 41 who has been spearheading the middle school process there for 20 years. My kids are applying to competitive schools such as LAB and Baruch SP and he said that the same holds true at these schools. That being said, for sure my kids do have very similar scores and grades.

He has some information that is dead wrong. That's been the case for years. I don't know how or why, but I have finally learned not to take his opinion very seriously on any topic regarding the DOE and middle school.
There are going to be a lot of unhappy 5th grade parents who took his advice to apply to a certain school this year.
How many twin pairs are there in 41's graduating class? TMI if you ask me.

Your kids are similar, so this is probably true. However, I would caution parents with children who have dissimilar abilities. I don't think that competitive schools will accept a twin who doesn't meet their criteria (ex. 85 average, high 3-4). I'm not sure that the guidance counselor was talking about this type of situation. People in that situation should really speak directly to the schools they want.
I believe you. Those women on Urbanbaby are crazy when it comes to school stuff.
That's great to hear. Good luck with everything.

Best school environment, cheery and clean, great test scores, wonderful teachers, amazing parent coordinator, tireless PTA, hardworking principal, lovely children.  Only complaint is that they use YMCA for afterschool and there are better programs out there. Othewise, if you are zoned for 41 consider yourself blessed.
PS 41 is most likely the best elementary school in Manhattan. If you can afford to live in this zone you are very lucky.  You can skip private school, because this school is a gem.
In  Robert De Nero's biography it states that he attended PS 41. It was built in 1958 when he would have been at least 16 years old.  What grade does it up too ?
The NEW PS 41 was built in 1958. When I attended during the 40's/50's it went up to grade 6.
It goes up to 5th grade and in the past it may have gone up to 6th grade. Maybe there is an error in when it was built. As an aside, Scarlett Johanson attended when she was younger.

I attended PS 41 between 1948 and 1953, when the school was on Greenwich Avenue. I don't think we had a choice of where we went; it just depended on your place of residence. It was a wonderful education, and I still remember most of the teachers who taught me. Music appreciation was taught in assembly each week, and those moments are firmly embedded in my mind. I also remember Ms. Kreuser (sp?) the Kindergarten teacher, Ms. Poirier in 6th and Mr. Cunningham in 4th. It was Mrs. Wordenschlag (sp.) in 1st grade who provided the magical moment when the light bulb went on and  I realized that I could read. In those days we didn't learn reading in Kindergarten, only in 1st grade. Who can forget wearing red ties with white middy blouses and blue skirts to Friday assemblies. I also think fondly of that tomato soup we got with the school lunch, even though at the time I thought it was horrid. Those were simpler times. I'm happy to see that PS 41 has kept its reputation for quality. BTW, is PS 3 the same school that used to be Southerland Junior High?

Hi. I attended PS 41 from 1946 to 1952 before I attended PS 3 (then a Junior High school) on Hudson Ave. I was probably a year ahead of you. I was in Miss Poirier's class. I have many fine memories of her. I remember when the radio in the auditorium would not work she would reverse the electrical plug because the school was at that time on the DC distribution system.
I would like to know can I get my K-6 grade pictures in 1960-66
I started school there in 1965 I would like to know if you have any school pictures from K-6 grade my first teacher name was Kat
I was a student in 1953 what good memories ! Ms Sulivan was my first grade teacher. Those iron doors would scared me so much. I could still hear the sound of those iron doors. What a scary feeling.

I am searching for my 5th grade teacher from 1958, Miss Reading, she brings back such wonderful memories to me, she played the original score of the King & I to us, today I am seeing that show & remembering her, does anyone have any info on her?
P.S. 42 is number 8 on math proficiency (83.33%) in a high poverty school for 2014 city test scores. Read more here.

As city politicians consider making the Lunar New Year a NYC school holiday, on Friday (the Lunar New Year of 2014) PS 42 had one of the lowest attendance rates in the city, with an attendance rate of 37.17%. Read more here.
I went to this school in the 60's.  As an African American, I remember the diversity of races there. I have fond memories of this school and am very please to know that it is still teaching children.

I went to PS 42 in 1965 as an FOB from Hong Kong not speaking a word of english.  Can't really say that I have great memories of elementary school but it was a start to my life as the next wave of Chinese immigrants in the 60's.  I remember the school as a mix of hispanic (mostly Puerto Ricans) and Chinese immigrants here.  In fact what stood out was when we had a white kid join us in 3rd grade.  Parents were not involved (due to working 12 hr days in sweat shops or restaurants) and teachers were not all that interested in the kids.  Just allot of screaming since we did not speak english well.  So much for the good old days.  I hope with the gentrification of the LES (below Delancy Street) PS 42 is now a place where kids can be taught how to succeed.

Art  by PS 42 students is on view at the Guggenhiem Museum in the annual exhibition of the Learning Through The Arts program. http://broadwayworld.com/artic...   
                              
                                        Edit                  Reply
Parents are outraged at a pornographic art exhibit on display near the school.  Read the story: Parents blast gallery featuring porn paintings near school.
"The teachers teach you the best way they can teach," a student writes, praising the fact that "some teachers are very flexible."

"The Benjamin Altman School or PS42 is the best school because they taught me a lot of new information that allowed me to pass a test," writes student Ivan. "Principal O'Day and Ms. Wong Lee have done a great job to help the school and I love it!"

A former student writes: "I [attended PS 42] since Kindergarten, and the school is really amazing, I really liked it cause the students there were nice and the teachers that I had were very nice. Although they might yell, we all know they did it for a reason, to help us learn. They were very understanding if we didn't understand anything, [and would] explain it 100 times if they had to or tell us to come up at lunch time if we wanted help on anything."

We have been in PS51 for 6 years -my older daughter entered as a K student and my son as PK. We picked this school immediately after a school tour out of all the schools we visited (include gift & talent programs) because we loved the building and had a very positive feeling about the teachers and staff here. And we were right- everyone CARES so much for the students in this school! Principal Lukas has been here only 2 years but she has made so many great improvements to the School and to the students's academic life. For examples- she knows every single student's name after a year(!); and that she brought in the STEM program to the entire school this year after parents raised the points that our school lacks a good STEM program in the past. Every teachers my kids have has been phenomenal -some were tough or old fashion but they just love and care so much for their students -you can just tell by the ways they interact with your children in and out of classes, or they make special effort to individual student who may a little attention or help. All the supporting staff, even the security guards, know and watch out for your children  in every corner of  this school so they are in a very safe and lovely environment. Currently my daughter is in 5th grade and I am very proud to say that she plays 4 musical instruments (all from school), has all 4's in state tests,  also joins the Fashion Club and Girls Who Code clubs. My son is only in first grade but he is already showing exceptional talents in math, art and dance. I am not bragging but just wanted to show you that an average normal kid can strive and benefit from this exceptional amazing loving school!

We transferred to PS 51 from a local charter school when my girls were entering 4th and 2nd grades. It was the most terrifying decision I had made in a very long time.  I had one child with multiple learning disabilities although she was very bright and capable and both were struggling with their self-esteem. We had already gone through so many academic struggles that I wasn't sure if entering into a new academic environment would help or hurt. It turned out to be the best decision I could have made. I watched both of their self-esteems skyrocket. They were welcomed into the school like old friends and the teachers and administration were truly welcoming and supportive. The biggest up side for us was the numerous performing arts, STEM and other arts-based instructions that are embedded in the school day that finally gave my kids the balance they desperately needed vs. nonstop academic pressure. Today, my older one is flourishing thanks to amazing support from the SETTS teacher, guidance counselor and her teachers and my 3rd grader has really taken off academically and behaviorally and has an absolutely fabulous teacher. Coming from a highly structured, competitive academic environment, there are some very different academic approaches that took me time to get used to but once I spent time learning about their approach and the thought-process behind it I've been able to embrace it and really leverage the different learning programs. My now 5th grader earned 4s on all of her state exams last year which was very important to us for middle school applications. The principal is absolutely amazing. She is extremely present throughout the day, deeply involved in the curriculum, highly available to her teachers and parents and just genuinely and profoundly cares about the children at every level. The teachers are incredibly compassionate and work together to help children succeed and when there is need for discipline it is done with compassion and understanding while still achieving the needed disciplinary results. The school has done a terrific job of ramping up their communications, now incorporating weekly emails, texts when needed, regular updates on their FB page, an APP and most classroom teachers (I believe all but not sure) use the Remind App to communicate directly with parents which is phenomenal and was a goal of the PTA and principal last year. Finally, the PTA is wonderful and work incredibly hard to bring the "extras" to the schools that are actually part of the foundation that makes PS 51 what it is. Monthly PTA meetings where your feedback and suggestions are actually valued and incorporated whenever possible is fantastic and the principal, vice principal and parent coordinator actually attend the meetings, speak and take questions. PS  51 is an absolute gem of a school. While I don't regret our time in a charter school because of the choices we had at the time, if I had the choice of a school like PS 51 for Kindergarten, I wouldn't have even hesitated.

My child came to PS 51 in 4th grade.  We were welcomed by a genuine teacher, principal and entire staff who cared about our family.  The staff listens to the families and does everything possible to ensure that children are happy and safe.  The school is beautiful.  It has 2 gyms.  Besides the FANTASTIC music instructor, there is also a dance teacher on staff.  There are many after school programs.  One of note is the Fashion Club, taught by the school art teacher who went to FIT.  At the end of 5th grade, the kids put on a HUGE Project Runway type show.  It is phenomenal.  The recorder club, chorus club, science and coding clubs are also phenomenal.  They also have a rooftop garden.  Science classes use the space sometimes in their curriculum.  My child will miss this school I know when she goes on to middle school.  And I will too! Oh and my child was performing below grade level at another school in 3rd grade.  Now at PS 51 she is on grade level in every class and sometimes above grade level.  She has a real interest in learning at this school.

After 4 years at PS51, we are strong advocates for families in our community taking advantage of this fantastic school. The PTA and parent-body are active, warm and strong advocates for our children. They work well with the Administration to ensure that our children experience excellent educational curriculum in a supportive environment. The needs of each child are valued.

The Science program has a great lab, and the Arts programs are top notch. Art and Music boast two of the best teachers in the City. In addition to a Physical Education teacher, they also have a dance teacher! I love the emphasis on the WHOLE child - academic enrichment and creative endeavors.

Now, let's talk about the facilities: Ten Stars! It's a new building, with a VERY protected play yard. Plus, there's a rooftop garden where the children get to plant and harvest. 

And the After School Care options? Loads. We participate in the program that uses the school building after school. That program brings in a reading specialist for those who are struggling, in addition to their programming which includes homework help, chess, tennis, art clubs, music lessons (violin and piano for my child), and so much more.

Final Analysis: This school is a neighborhood gem. Don't miss your opportunity to be part of the community.

My daughter is currently enrolled in PreK at PS51.  She can't wait to go to school every day - her teacher is brilliant, kind, and always has a fun activity happening in the class.  The school itself is very organized and clean and full of friendly smiles every day.  There is a private outdoor recess area that the kids use every day weather permitting.  The art, music and dance programs that the kids are involved with every week are very impressive.  Parents are encouraged to participate in different activities all year long.  I only have experience in the PreK program that my daughter attends - but I highly recommend it.

i am extremely happy that my child is part of the warm and caring school environment. I am also  happy about all the services that my child is receiving.in this school. Full school based support team-including full time guidance  counselor/social workers .This school is very Diversity

After transiting from another school my child adjusted very well at P.S.51. He loves his school! There is lots of diversity, test prep is offered before/after school for grades 3-5. Definatly recommed Ps51

my son was very closed in befoe joining this school. since being at PS51 he has opened up, meeting new friends using his imagination and just blossming smoothly. the school is very welcoming and nurturing. i cant wait to see what next year brings!!!

I have a daughter in first grade here at 51 I am a huge fan of this school the way the teachers and staff are so involved with the safety and education of my daughter the principle ms lukas is the best her open door policy for every parent and student is a comfortable feeling she is never too busy to listen and help if needed

My daughter has been a student at PS 51 since kindergarten and is currently a fourth grader.  We have been so pleased with what a wonderful, positive, and enriching atmosphere the school provides.  My daughter absolutely LOVES going to school, and really feels as if it is her extended family!  What more could a parent ask for!  The school offers many arts, science, music, and dance opportunities, and strives to provide unique programs, field trips, and community activities. In particular, the art and music teachers are beyond amazing, and I wish I had them when I was in school.  My daughter also has an IEP, and I have been very pleased with how her services has been fulfilled.  They also have ICT classes which means one class in the grade has a special education teacher and a typical teacher who work in tandem.  The class is split between children who have an IEP and those who don't.  Its a fantastic grouping, and who doesn't want two teachers in the classroom!!  They have a wonderful roof top garden that the children learn, plant herbs, and  trees and learn about the growth cycle.  The science teacher  is a huge driving force in educating the children on environmental issues, recycling, and we even have a hydroponics station!!  Lastly, the teachers are fabulous, and every year my daughter mourns moving on to the next grade:)  Check us out.  You won't be disappointed!

Fabulous school with great academics, stellar teachers, and warm and truly nurturing environment. Art, music, dance and science programs are all fantastic. So happy that we found this school. Kids plant seeds in science class and then grow them on the roof. The science teacher is really phenomenal. He is growing fruit trees and all kinds of greens on the roof and the kids get to help. Art and music programs are extraordinary. Teachers and principal are encouraging and supportive of everyone -- whether behind or ahead or somewhere in between. A great environment!

any additional staff /teachers or funds to help the school out. The PTA does a wonderful job raising money, due to the dedicated parents who have full time jobs else where. Test prep more time for all students with also a math curriculum that teaches how m=numbers work not just how to use a formula. More learning through body movement, extra partnership to help teachers, para's and staff to learn and teach the children other forms of mind body learning through movement, for all grades.

My kid has been in this school for 3 years. Amazing school compared to other public schools. The arts program is stronger than most private schools. We are very disappointed that we lost the former Midtown West principal Ryan Bourke. He brought life and energy to P.S. 51 in ways I've never seen before. Really transformed the overall feel of the community. The teachers are great and most parents are involved.

We pulled our kid out of Success Academy in the middle of his kindergarten year because he  started crying on Sundays from the thought of school the next day. We brought him to Elias Howe.  Wow.  Just... Wow.  Within a month his reading skills jumped two grades. By the time he was in 1st grade, they were sending him up to the 2nd grade class at reading time to continue to challenge him. We resumed the violin lessons at home which we had to cancel because Success Academy had ruled our days and left no time. 

Today he is in the 4th grade and taking this years most important State evaluations, on which he scored all "4s" last year.  If he does the same, he should have his choice of Middle Schools next year.  We have added drum lessons to the continuing violin at home.  At school he loves science club and thanks to weekly lessons (available to all students and led by quite possibly the single-most amazing music teacher in the city), he is now adept at playing the ukulele, guitar, recorder, a plethora of percussion instruments and is developing his below-average singing voice in the weekly chorus..The previous principal who was inspiring, nurturing and progressive has sadly retired and been replaced by another who is inspiring, nurturing, progressive, innovative, open-minded, efficient and seemingly boundless in what he is able to accomplish in every 24 hours he shreds.  My child now LOVES to go to school and has rediscovered his natural curiosities and desire to learn. What more could we want from an Elementary school?  Yeah, we kinda like Elias Howe.

Our sons attend pre-K in Mrs Rivas' class. She is INCREDIBLE - patient, caring, loving, creative, and somehow finds time to truly impact every one of her students. The school is brand new and well-equipped. The teachers are passionate and the parents are getting involved (average PTA meeting has 50+ attendees). And the new principal (Ryan Bourke) was previously at the very well-regarded PS 212: Midtown West and is bringing the same great ideas and community focus to PS 51. 

We did a ton of research online and learned that some of the national ranking websites are not accurate. My recommendation is GO VISIT THE SCHOOL. Ask for a tour. Meet the principal and teachers and decide for yourself what's best for your family. Good luck!

We really like this school. Our son is in 3rd grade and daughter in K. The teachers are warm, motivated and dedicated to the school and the principal is great.  In the 2 years we’ve been here, the teachers have always been approachable and available to discuss any issues we’ve had.  The PTA is very active and focuses on community building as part of their fundraising. We love the school’s small size, diversity, spacious modern building and the wonderful art and music teachers. We have experience with two other elementary schools in the neighborhood and PS 51 is the best fit for us.

PS 51 is the crown jewel of Hell's Kitchen. A beautiful building, a worldly student body, brilliant & loving teachers, a terrific principal. The art and music programs are truly spectacular. My daughter's first two years there (K & 1) have been wonderful and I am so happy this is our neighborhood school. Just seeing the way the kids embrace each other in the playgrounds tells you what a special place it is. I wish they had more money for PE and language programs, but with a super-active PTA, that could still happen. The academic programs are uniquely designed to meet each student's needs. I can't say enough good things about PS 51.

P.S.51 is a unique small school in the heart of Manhattan, characterized by its diversity, motivated by the ideal of a holistic education that integrates the arts into the process of learning, allowing the students to excel academically as well as creatively and emotionally. This focus on arts education would not be possible without the strong commitment and leadership of Principal Nancy Sing-Bock. P.S.51 was recognized by the Department of Education as having a stellar arts education program. P.S.51 was also named an Outstanding School by The Blackboard Awards, achievements that show how much we are all committed to the success of each student at our school. My oldest daughter has already graduated from PS51 and my youngest daughter will be attending 4th grade in September. This is by far the best primary public school in our neighborhood. 
Lorena Camacho, Emilia Urcola (11) and Camila Urcola (9).

I am a very happy parent at PS51. We chose to send our son to PS51 last year for Kindergarten and it was one of the best decisions we could have made. I was nervous as all his friends went elsewhere but I had such a good feeling about 51 that I stuck to my guns and I am thrilled that I did.

My son did so well in that class and excelled in all his subjects. I love that he gets an all round experience in this school ( social,emotional and educational ) with a lot of outstanding (and award winning)  art and music. However for those who worry about academics, he was reading two levels above his grade level by Spring and they always kept him challenged and excited about reading. He enjoyed 'shopping' for books in Grade2! He started K only knowing a few words so this was their doing with a little help from him :) They differentiate the teaching to an amazing standard so that there are always at least 3-4 different level groups in maths and English. Even the homework is differentiated and the kids come home with different homework packets depending on their own personal level. What I like most about this, is the children don't even realize they are in different leveled groups. There is none of this 'I'm in the top group' rubbish that we had as kids.

They had a lovely activity in K where a kids name was picked out of a hat, they got to sit in the special chair and their peers were encouraged to give them compliments about what they did well in class and/or for each other. Children are really encouraged to love and help each other at 51 and you can really feel that throughout the school. This is modeled so well by the staff who you can clearly see love their children and want the very best out of them.

You can see above what a wonderful review inside schools gave them, but they also have recently won many fantastic awards for which they so deserve.

Please take time to visit the school ( I went to at least 3 tours !). Try to also make one of the open house sessions, the next one is 22 December 2015. The teachers get to explain what they do and why and you can ask lots of questions.

I have had nothing but good experiences with the Principal and Vice Principal. They are very open and responsive to anything I have suggested which is a great plus for the school. 

I don't think anyone will tell you that their school is perfect, there is always room for improvement, but I know PS51 in my opinion is brilliant. I look forward to sending my 2nd child there next year.

Feel free to contact me to chat further.

Elaine

Mum to two boys 4/6years.

I decided to put my daughters in PS 51 three years ago.  They were in catholic school. Everyone in my family beginning with my grandparents down to my parents, myself and my daughters all went to the same Catholic school. This is all I knew.  I heard so many wonderful things about PS 51. What really caught our attention were the arts and music programs. I was very nervous but I am happy to say it was the best decision that we made. My oldest daughter was only here for one year. She graduated in the fifth grade and is now in middle school in the seventh grade. She still says that she wishes she could go back. With in one school year she experienced so many wonderful things. I never saw her so happy to go to school. The faculty welcomed us and made us so comfortable. My daughter is in the second grade and my son started this year in Pre K this year. I'm happy to send my children off to school knowing that they are happy and that they are taken care of by teachers who love seeing them every day!

PS 51 is a great school!  My daughter started there in Kindergarten and is now in third grade.  She is happy there and making great strides every year.  She is challenged in reading, writing and math as well as exposed to all of the arts. The teachers are really wonderful - loving and VERY well trained. Two exceptional stand outs are the art teacher Ms. Perez and the music teacher Ms. Traxler.  They work so hard and go above and beyond.  They dedicate their lives to making this school a place where the arts can flourish.  My daughter gets tap every year! This year she is learning to play the recorder:)  This is not to say that her classroom teachers do not also work very hard on the academics. They do. I've been very satisfied every year with her classroom teachers. I recently watched a reading workshop where the children were learning how to discuss the essence of a story with each other - guided beautifully by Ms. Guttwillig. These are the beginnings of the skills needed to succeed in a  literature class in college. This is a well rounded school where children can learn to be well rounded adults.
PS 51 visual arts teacher Shani Perez is a recipient of the 2015 Big Apple Award for excellence in teaching. Read more here.
PS 51 is named outstanding school by Blackboard Awards 2014!! We are proud of our school!

I think P.S 51 is a great school. This will be my sons second year at the school, and we are both very happy! The teachers have always been  available to talk about any concerns  that I have about academics,and have given me suggestions on what I can do at home to help him. My son is thriving at this school. We came from a school that the teachers did not want to communicate with parents at all. I had know idea how my son was doing at the other school until I got his report card. I was treated like a crazy overbearing mother for wanting to be involved with my sons education. P.S 51 is like a breath of fresh air. I feel very welcomed, and  included in my sons education,and that gives me peace of mind.

Which school did your son come from? We toured this school and loved it. However, I am concerned that the kids at the top are not challenged. Do you find that? Is this school mainly for kids who will stop their education at high school, or for strong learners who eventually go on to college? Thanks!

I would not recommend P.S. 51 to another parent. The school is not academically challenging.  Students do not learn the skills they need to be successful outside the lax parameters promoted within this school.  If you want your child to be challenged or motivated to do work beyond the low expectations of the classroom, you should look elsewhere.  Parents' concerns about academics are challenged or brushed aside.  There is much focus on social-emotional learning at the expense of a coherent instructional plan for students.  The school does have wonderful art and music programs.

We live near this school, and are considering it, pending a tour. Does anyone have insight as to what schools many students attend after graduating this one? Is it challenging enough for studious children?
Angela Beckham from P.S. 51 was honored at the Harvard Club by Education Update as an Outstanding Teacher of 2014. Read more here.

I am curious to know how many applicants for pre-k VS how many get in as well as how many seats are available for this coming school year in 2014 and are applicants taken from outside the zone? I am in district 2 but outside of the zone map provided for this school specifically.

Over the past few years I've had the good fortune of getting to know P.S. 51 through an arts partnership. Working with students, faculty, and administrators in the old building, the temporary location and now its new home.  During this time, P.S. 51 has shown me it exists beyond its location. It's a spirit; difficult to articulate, some extraordinary mix of positive focused learning energy with real care toward the students and each other. That is an amazing accomplishment. GO P.S.51!

We are extremely fortunate to have our daughter in PS 51. I can truly say that our daughter gets the best education in math, reading and writing as well as is dance, art and music! The teachers are amazing, they work very hard, they know every child`s abilities and inspire and encourage them to grow. The environment is warm and including, which is highly important to us. Our daughter loves the teachers and the new school building, and so do we!! She has a lot of friends, and participates in several after school programs, like chess. I would also emphasize how important it is to have a strong, wise and inspiring principal like Nancy Sing-Bock. When you meet the staff and the teachers you can see they appreciate their work, and want to do their best for the kids. PS 51 is also a place where we meet good neighbors!

I enrolled my three daughters in PS 51 this year.  We are new to New York and I feel like finding this school has been a huge blessing.  I could not be happier!  My children each have excellent teachers who go out of their way to make sure all their needs are being met - educationally, socially, artistically.   I am very impressed with the arts in education that PS 51 provides as well as the focus on academics.

As a teacher at PS 51, I can speak to the wonderful work being done to create a rigorous curriculum based on the common core where each child is challenged to grow academically, artistically, and socially. Students are engaged in a multitude of learning strategies to help them enjoy their work while challenging their abilities in order to move them to the next level. They are encouraged and supported in a warm and positive learning environment. Teachers are caring and approachable to their students and work diligently to approach difficult situations head-on with effective behavior management strategies. They differentiate lessons so that high-achieving students are challenged to utilize their talents to the fullest extent and lower-performing students get the appropriate support they deserve to achieve growth. All students train as artists and musicians and develop a multitude of techniques and skills throughout their 6 years at the school. All students study tap, ballet, music theater, and ballroom dancing through our many partnerships, and also participate in many exciting physical education activities during their daily recess period. PS 51 has it all- and now we have it all in a brand new building that our students LOVE and DESERVE! Come and visit our school! Come and join our family of learners! We would love to have you!

An excellent school - staff know each child by name, the students treat each other with respect and the music and arts programs are excellent!
The school has a large immigrant population from all over the world and therefore has to adapt to its' students diverse needs. The teachers and administration are also very attentive to the needs of children with IEPs and try their best to ensure that each child gets the support he/she deserves

From a teacher- thanks! It is nice to know that our hard work is appreciated. We love our unique and beautiful student population and try to incorporate every child's culture into our lessons throughout the year.

Review PS 51 Manhattan

Shame on me. I should have written this review long ago I didn’t because I am not the review writing type but someone has to let the world know about thie awesome jewel of a school. I hope and pray that my writing and experienc at PS 51 in manhattan can do it Justice and attract the right families to our community. 

We have been at PS 51 since Kindergaten. We chose this school after visiting all the pubic schools in our District and applying to ten private schools.

We are an African Amrican hetero married middle class family living in Hell’s Kitchen with only one child. We own a small business and are artistic. I believe in specifics so the reader might understand my POV.

We chose PS 51 over the other schools because it was more diverse and for its educational approach. I liked that there were several cultures celebrated in the school as well as discipline. I like to see kids walking in a line quietly. I am raising a black son and I want him to recognize times of learning and play as different. I need him to recognize and respect authority. Findimg the balance of his own power and strength and voice inside of the structure of the adult world is what I think is right for childhood. I find that at PS 51.

I am so proud of the development of his social skills that he got last year in special groups with the guidance councler. The compassion he developed brings tears to my eyes. This year he was invited onto the pier mediation team. Last year he got in trouble for some bad behavior that hurt other students. Can you imagine?! Now he’s so popular and involved. The teachers, staff, principal, my husband and I all worked together. It took a village. Here we are.

So the attention to Social development at PS 51 is outstanding even when your child is “I’m not perfect, Mommy” as he’s fond of saying.

As a side note,the kid who’s feelings he hurt so badly is one of his best friends now. They just came in last together in the 400 relay without tears or blame. I hope somebody out there can feel this journey.      

He also worked his way from special education to the top reading levels. From the CT class to no support at all. I am so proud.

I attribute the academic success to the emphasis on curriculum by the principal because she does not play, all the teachers are nose to the grindstone educators. Dedication to the concept of ‘family of learners’ is taken to heart. There is parent involvement & communication. We have workshops and support to help us, help our kids. It pays off, our kids are doing awesome look at our grades! And there are several languages spoken at PS 51.

Let’s talk arts partners and programs and computers. We have as many as the private schools. I know because we applied to 9 of them. We don’t have the sports teams, that’s it though, the only difference. Coleman involved in developing an iphone app using his recorder last year, after two days of working with the musicians and programmers he was on stage explaining to the adults how the app worked. Yes, We are wired for the 21st Century. In 3rd grade my son gave me a keynote for Chrismas. He also has he own (secret) website. Skills learned at PS 51. 

This year he’s learning to play guitar as well as continuing with the recorder and have signed Maurice continues in tap class. Yeah more programs too numerous to name. All spelled out on the PS 51 website.

I think the school is awesome because of the dedication of the staff, and teachers, led by the principal Nancy Sing-Bock. I hope that there will be more families that join us in our new state of the art building. 

Yes we have a brand-new library with $250,000 worth of books. A science lab. A rooftop playground, a ground-floor playground, I can’t name all the stuff that’s in there, you got to see it. Come for a tour.

Hooray! A review that really captures the essence of our school. I've read this three times because it just feels good to know our teachers are making such a difference! That is how it happens... one student at a time. Thank you for choosing PS 51!
Parents, students and educators officially opened the new PS 51 building, where students have started of the school year. Read more and watch the NY1 story here.

PS 51 kicked off the new school year at its new location in Hell's Kitchen. While some parents are concerned about the ongoing construction around the school, most are happy about the new location. Read more here.
When is the school moving back to Hell's Kitchen? Is there a school bus from the zoned neighborhood up to E 91st? Where is the new building exactly?
Here are some pictures from the book fair with the PTA and teachers and staff.

This school is awesome.  The best kept secret on the west side of Manhattan. Our big shiny school building will probably change that. We are a small tight community.  Very diverse.  The teachers are young and passionate.  We have wonderful arts programs.  We are led by Nancy Singbock.  She is a tireless educator who has faught hard for every student in our school.  We have wonderful support staff and all the opportunities we need for the school to thrive. visit the school and you will see students working hard to excel as a family of learners.

I would like to know why this school hasn't been reviewed since 2003?? Also, I've heard a lot of not so good things with this school from the principal to the teachers. Can anyone give me any insight on how this school is?

Hope you found my comments helpful.  We had an excellent China fair in the third grade.  It's test prep time so it's not as fun now but the kids are going to do awesome. happy to talk about my own experiences. If you have any questions. Oh and our website is packed with information on the website. Www.ps551mahattan.com
DNAinfo reports PS 51 will return to Hell's Kitchen in September. http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20130116/hells-kitchen-clinton/ps-51-return-hells-kitchen-september

Dear Ms Sing Bock,

I live across from your school and have noticed that the
lights in the building are frequently left on. They have been on in the first floor
since last Friday and they will, most likely, be on until Tuesday Jan 22nd.
That is four nights and four days of energy waste.

About 10 days ago I spoke to your building manager and
informed him that the lights in the whole building had been left on two nights
on a row that week and two nights on a row the previous week. Many instances of
lights being left on also happened during 2012. In fact, towards the end of the
year my wife was there in person to draw attention to that fact.

Each time I look out my window and see that waste of
energy I think of the   schools and citizens in the city that have not
yet recovered from damages brought upon by Storm Sandy and still lack
electricity. I find this hard to understand.

I trust this situation will be corrected and I thank you
in advance. Sincerely, Carlos Narvaez

A buddy program helps change student behavior at PS 51. See the WNYC report: <a
href="http://www.nytimes.com/schoolbook/2012/06/27/to-change-behavior-students-walk-in-teachers-shoes/">To Change Behavior, Students Act as Teachers.

Children take tap-dancing lessons at PS 51, the New York Times reports.  

http://www.nytimes.com/schoolbook/2012/05/25/students-tap-tribute-to-bojangles/

After parent protests and talk of students being moved to other schools, PS 51 will move into Our Lady of Good Counsel church on East 91st St. by the start of the 2011-12 school year to get away from the construction around West 45th st. The school will likely remain in the church for two or three years. Read more: PS 51 parents and staff applaud Education Department for moving them out of construction zone.

A parent writes that the school taught her son how to love reading. "He was not reading at the appropriate level, and his self-confidence was suffering," she writes. "In a matter of 6 months, his teacher had him reading at level M and N (much higher levels). My son is now so much more outgoing and he loves to read."
Hi, I don't see a website for PS 59, can anyone explain whats the process to register for an open house for this school?
Chalkbeat reports that PS 59 Beekman Hill International School was named a 2019 National Blue Ribbon School.

Anna Bennett, 5th grade teacher at P.S. 59 Beekman Hill International, is one of the 17 recipients of the 2016 Big Apple Award. The Big Apple Award is a citywide recognition program that celebrates the incredible work of New York City public school teachers. Read more here.

My family would like to relocate to NYC this summer.  i would love my child (2nd grade, fall 2014) to attend this school.  Is there presently a wait list for fall 2014 - we would like to focus our home search on the zone for this school but would like to know enrollment status beforehand.  Any advice on how to proceed?
P.S. Beekman Hill receives Blackboard award for Outstanding Principal.

We have been thrilled with our daughter's kindergarten experience.  It almost feels like we're somehow cheating the system -- she has dedicated music, art, science and gym classes (in specialized classrooms), plus the K class did two 8 week cycles of latin american music run by the Turtle Bay Music School and several short cycles of computers (there is a mobile laptop cart).   All of this comes at a cost, of course.  K and 1st grade self-funds the assistant teacher and there is constant fund raising for other programs.  At the end of the year, we will have probably donated $2000 or so to the school and done so gladly. Construction finally began May 21, 2010  on the new PS 59 building at 250 East 57th Street. Paired with High School of Art and Design, the two new schools will frame andopen courtyard for recreational space.  Projected date for completion is September, 2012.  The site includes a residential building and commercial space.
The DOE reports that PS 59 is the city's first green school.
"The staff is the best," writes parent Josselyne Saccio. "The teachers are like family and provide a passion for learning that is contagious."

Parents say the children from different countries bring a richness to the school community. "My kids don't think Omar and Fatma and Mohammed are weird names," says Miriam Schneider, whose twin girls attend PS 59. "My daughters went to one birthday party at the Libyan mission and one at the Swedish mission."

Parent Alex Papayannis writes: "I love PS 59 and more importantly my son (pre-K-3rd grade) loves the school and all his teachers. This school is a wonderful environment for children. Just walking through its bright, colorful hallways, full of the children's creations, is inspiring and uplifting. The breadth of work is displayed everywhere; from art to math and science to writing and more. There are always parents around to lend a hand or an ear and the PTA is full of committed and hardworking parents." This parent adds: "More than this, we are lucky to have some bright, pleasant, and extremely dedicated teachers at all grades. The hard work with the children and many hours they put into their classes speak volumes and is evident in the faces of the students. This school is full of smiling, happy kids. ... Finally, the administration, led by Adele Schroeter, is brilliant, dedicated, and always advocates strongly for each and every student. I can't speak highly enough about this school; I enjoy being part of this family."

Parent Stephanie Orenstein writes: "My oldest has been at PS 59 for 3 years and I am so proud to be part of the PS 59 family. One week before first grade began we decided to put our son in public school -- our friends gasped! IT WAS THE BEST DECISION WE EVER MADE. What makes this school so special is the commitment of the teachers, Adele Schroeder (our principal) and our strong parent and PTA involvement. We may not have a gym, but we make use of every inch of our building and terrace. As for an auditorium, the high school is kind enough to let us use their auditorium for shows. The cafeteria doubles as a gym / multipurpose room -- so we me make do and have a lot of heart too!"

Lower Lab fifth-grader Vale Esposito took home top honors during the first day of the Daily News spelling bee Tuesday, despite being one of the youngest contestants on stage, the NY Post reports. He clinched the victory after correctly spelling “vanda," a tropical flower, and will go on to compete in the Scripps National Spelling Bee this May in Washington, DC.

Hello all. We're taking a time out from posting on this page. Criticism is OK, but we've noticed that there are some folks who are posting multiple negative comments under different names. That's not helpful. Our advice, visit the school and ask lots of questions.

“Folks” posting negative comments under different names are doing so most likely for fear of retribution from administration as has been the case for the past five years in various capacities. Our advice to insideschools.org, please don’t filter/restrict/censor comments solely on the fact that they reflect negatively on the poor decision-making of leadership in recent years. Keep your platform democratic for the ability to voice opinions of dissent.

Thank you for your comments. We don't have a problem with negative comments or even anonymous ones. We only resort to shutting down comments when it becomes out of control and full of personal attacks--not just towards the school but also fellow parents posting comments. Also, we don't approve of someone posting under different anonymous names to give the false appearance that the comments are being posted by more than one person.
