Parents at PS 116 have voiced safety concerns over early election voting at their children's school, CBS reports. "Of the 61 early voting sites in the city, 33 are New York City public schools, including eight of the nine sites in Manhattan. Early voting locations will be open for 10 days leading up to Nov. 5, allowing public voters to enter the school while students are there and classes are in session. That’s an uncomfortable thought for parents when children at Public School 116 are as young as 4."

My daughter has thrived at PS 116.  She is currently in 1st grade; reads and writes well, and they are building a strong math foundation.  She particularly loves performing arts and music.  
The PTA is very active and contributes largely to the school community.  Throughout the year there are many activities; Boo bash, book fair, spring fair, dance-a-thon, etc.  There are TAs for 1/2 day in both kindergarten and 1st grade, this is funded through the PTA.  
There are multiple opportunities to be in your child's classroom.  Families as buddies happens twice a month, there is also open school day in the early fall.  
I definitely recommend this school to other families, and plan to send my son for Pre-k in the fall.

My daughter has been at PS 116 for two years and we are very happy with her education and emotional/social development.  The school has a real community feel.  My daughter comes home from school excited to tell me about her day and ready for the next.  The no homework policy was  surprising to me at first but when I did my research, it all made sense.  Honestly, she IS doing work at home that she must complete but it isn't ditto sheets, it's learning through experiences.   The PTA does a great job working to fill holes left by the DOE.

My sons are in pre-k and 1st grade and we've had a wonderful experience so far. Our teachers have been fantastic. Our current Pre-K teacher takes the Reggio Emilia approach to her teaching (meeting the students where they are at, allowing them to drive the content of the curriculum based on common interests, etc).  My first grader loves the specialties - music and performing arts especially - and can't wait to learn to read music next year in second grade.  He's also become a chess player because of 116. I appreciate how involved the families are.  There is a wonderful group called Parents for the Arts who feel as passionately as I do and are committed to making sure our children are exposed to an engaging and dynamic art curriculum. Personally, one of the reasons I wanted to be in 116 over the River School was because of their decision to adopt PDF (Playtime, Downtime, Family Time) in lieu of homework.  My first grader reads every night (I can't get him to stop), fills out his reading log and makes smart choices for his PDF.  He is reading above grade level and enjoys doing math activities at night (by choice).  The school has woven SEL/mindfulness (the importance of breathing, meditation, etc) into all their classes.  The principal hosted a PD last week for thirty other AP's to teach how to do it successfully.  Overall, it feels great to be a part of such a warm, diverse, community and to know that the administration and teaching staff are committed to creating a school that values process, play, and internal well being as much as academics.

As a parent of a PreK student, I can only say that we have been very pleased with the school.  The PreK teachers and aides are excellent.  My daughter has changed in a positive way so quickly - she has learned routines, talks about being a scientist, has become more independent and taking more responsibilities to be helpful.  She was always good at home, but has now shown a greater maturity in her thinking and behavior.  I am impressed every time I go to "buddy day" and see how she is learning through experience to write her name or read.  The PreK teacher also posts class photos and videos to a blog for parents to update us on activities.  Parents are also encouraged to come to class to teach lessons - I went in Fall to teach her classmates about Divali, a Hindu holiday.
I've seen that there is a strong group of parents that are part of the PTA and you can make a difference if you get involved.  The leadership team has been available and I feel informed about what is happening at the school through emails, PTA, and the website. I even emailed the Principal on a weekend with some concerns and she replied immediately! I feel that it is what you want to make of it - if you get involved and talk to teachers, parents and staff you can make the school part of your community and hopefully a better place for everyone.  I am excited to continue in the school as I learn about amazing programs being offered - such as a partnership with Studio in a School, Jazz at Lincoln Center, Ballroom Dancing lessons, and chess & running clubs. There are many community building events and great opportunities to participate in the school as a parent. Yes, this is a public school and there is always a need for funding.  If you want to learn more about the character of the school, I would encourage you to go to the Spring Fling Street fair in the spring and talk to people.
Can any current parents please share their experiences with the school? We are considering moving into the area and would love to find out more. The last comment looks to be two years old. TIA!

My dc just finished kindergarten, and me and my husband have been very impressed with the school. Academics are really strong, and the school has a wonderful nurturing learning environment. I was nervous for my dc to start public school, but she was very happy, and always looking forward to go to school in the morning. We love the reading/math buddies every other week- great way to be connected to what is going on in the classroom. Chess program is fantastic. 
We were considering moving to G&T, but  we don't think it's worth it- So far our experience at PS 116 has been fantastic!
PS 116 has decided to abandon traditional homework so students can have more time to play and spend time with their families. Read more here.

I hate this school!!!!! Academics are fine, but their administrative staff and security guards are rude and unhelpful. Their procedure to enter the school if you are late is totally absurd and inefficient. I am not against procedures to encourage students to arrive on time to school, but making you to walk one extra block with streets covered with ice and slush and then to wait for 10 minutes (under icy rain) until the second is open is not funny. Seriously??? As if it was not hard enough trying to get to school pushing a stroller and holding the hand of a 5 year old. 
I hope next year my son is admitted to PS281, where I have heard all the staff is warm and friendly!!!!!

I just read the horrible news about this school. 

http://nypost.com/2014/10/29/pervy-school-janitor-peeks-on-neighbors-plays-with-his-pickle/
This is about one creepy man, not "about this school." If this guy was looking in your home's window, would it be "About your house" or about this guy?

This guy works in many different schools. Not just this one. This guy was just a temporary fill-in.  Also the horrible news is not about the school, it's about a creepy guy. PS116 is a wonderful school.
True not specific about school. Ca happen to any school in NYC.  however if I am researching about the elementary school something I wanted to know about it.  Since it is the fact not what I think.

My son is now 5th grade of this school. There are great teachers, and there are also teachers lack of experience or motivation.  One of the thing my son always complained about is boys room. According to him, it is only cleaned once a week only when requested by teacher.  Meaning is some extremely messy situation occur. He said that custodian does not clean or check bathroom periodically.  Cafeteria is Ok, relative to bathroom. Gym is under renovation right now. School yard recently re-paved and now has a cute Japanese garden.  

PTA is good and strong.   But, definitely the school has  issues for size. Simply there are too many kids and diversity.  Some kids come from very tough family situation and these few kids tend to turn the class room as chaos.

PS116 is a great school.  I am a parent of two kids at PS116, i am a former teacher, and have a masters degree in Education.  The school encourages parent involvement. The admin staff works very hard to make everything work.  The new pre-k program launched without a hitch (three classes) where some schools had to delay starting on the first day.  

As is the case with every school, the more involved with it, the better you will appreciate its character.  I know this school boasts an amazing after school program, that is offered by a former parent turned non-profit.  Chess is taught to everyone and the after school program is great.  The arts classes, music, painting, and dance are fantastic.  The teachers are excellent.

My child was bullied in PS116 and the teachers did nothing about it. He was beaten in front of the staff many times and no one said anything. He was hit by a boy in front of me and they could not deny it. It is a very bad school. Known only for lice and bullies. I am very disappointed with this school and I am going to have to investigate this abuse. Parents, if you really care about your children-DO NOT ENROLL THEM in PS 116. Unless you teach them how to fight very well (girls too) and please be prepared for the lice. No none cares about students in this school.

Wish I could have sent my child to this school as we live so close by. Luckily, I ended up sending my child to a a smaller more nurturing school from a different neighborhood. I felt this school was too big and did not like the tour and presentation at all. The administration was too cold. The parent coordinator and principal are just something else, for lack of a better description. Guess they are not worried they do not feel about losing their jobs at all. They seem as they don't give a d*mn. I got yelled at by a gym teacher with a loud megaphone when I entered the yard for the tour. The school seemed too big and chaotic. I don't get why the parents on the this board think everything describes this school as "GREAT"!!! Can you please elaborate beyond "GREAT"? I totally did not see it.
The Department of Education has approved two full-day pre-K sections at PS 116. Read more here.

Fewer kindergartners than expected registered in 2013, leading to budget cuts, DNAinfo reports. http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20140211/murray-hill/murray-hill-school-loses-100k-after-fewer-students-enroll-than-expected

I live very close to the school and was looking forward to sending my child there for Kindergarden, but I attended the orientation and tour and was sad to see how little "choice time" the students had, it seemed very "locked - down", and not at all creative. I chose to send my child to Ella Baker, a small progressive school that anyone can attend, it's on 67th and 3rd ave (It's a City Wide School).  It's a great school with a very warm and personal touch. I offer this as a suggestion to any parents who are unhappy with 116, I also recognize that many people like the school and I am glad that it works for them.

PS 116 is a wonderful school community - great families, great kids, great teachers and administrators and most importantly great academic results.

116ers have some of the best test scores in the district and across the city and the school was just recognized as one of only 7 "reward" schools in our district by NY State.

The school is one of the few that still offers a full array of specialty classes including art, music, computers, science, gym, dance, etc.

Also 116 has a close relationship with NYChess Kids - so kids get chess in the classroom as part of the curriculum.

Anyway - for our family this is a GREAT school - with GREAT values.  One of my favorites is the peer mediation program that lets kids help each other solve problems...also check out the beautiful school yard and soon to be renovated gym.
I think Principal Hsu is a fantastic academic leader for the school - I am happy to have a school leader that focuses on students, academics and teacher development before "community relations"
Far too many teachers start at 116 as student teachers and stay. They should get training elsewhere!

The school's progress report comes out around the end of September. Even with so many students doing so poorly on the tests, it is highly likely that 116 scored yet another "D" on progress, which, hopefully, will accelerate the process of a new principal at 116.


It is a fair statement that roughly 50% of parents could do a better job than the current principal. That's not saying they would do a slam-dunk job; rather, they would do 'less poorly' than the current 'leader'.

School progress reports are a tool of DOE - the best schools in the city gets Cs and Ds while schools with less than 25 percent at grade level get As.  Take a look at the academic performance section and you will see how well 116 fares

My 1st child enrolled in the Fall of 2005; our youngest has 3 years left. There has not been a single bit of communication with the Parent Coordinator. I am active in the PTA and know many families. 

Not one has ever said anything different. The principal ignores parents and has what amounts to a bolted shut door. 

The education is good but I wouldn't recommend ever disagreeing with the principal on anything. As for making an appointment to see her? 
Good Luck

Wow! This has been our experience as well.  The Parent Coordinator does not coordinate anything, but being a gatekeeper for The Principal.  The Principal will not meet with Parents, and avoids them like the plague.

My older child attends a school outside of the zone, but I registered my younger child at 116 as a backup for next year. At my older child's school the principal makes a point of meeting every single incoming family at K registration. When my son and I were in the main office to register at 116, the principal, who was in the office, couldn't even be bothered to say hello.
Is anyone excited by this school? I hear so little about this school.

No. There are good teachers but far too many inexperienced ones, and the administration is unwiling to listen to complaints regarding teacher quality. To them, every teacher is the best that could possibly be found.

A very good PTA, very involved parents for the most part, but an 
Indescribably poor and off-limits principal who, having been in her position for as long as she has, should have developed a modicum of people skills, but lacks even the most basic abilities to relate to parents on any level.

I've been connected to this school for longer than nearly any current parent.
The administration has a reputation for being inaccessible, but it is a lovely community and the kids get a good education.
Was very true. After 2009-2010, however, not true
Does anyone have any updated information about the overcrowding issue and the potential opening of PS 281? All the info I have found is a year old. Thanks.

It is a shame that this information isn't publicised better.

PS 281 will be opening in fall 2013. The DOE and the district 2 Community Education Counsel (CEC) just completed the last of 3 public hearings to gather feedback on the new zone lines proposed for 116 and 281. You can go to the CEC's website to veiw the proposal and if you have any thoughts you can still email them with your opinion.  The website is cecd2.net.
Parents are concerned about overcrowding, urged the city to expedite the opening of a new school. Read more: City Rejects Pleas to Expedite New School in Murray Hill.
Students spent Columbus Day at Zuccotti Park for Occupy Wall Street. Read more: Children Spend a Day at Protesters’ Encampment.

My daughter went here three years ago. Good school overall, but I want to address one issue that has been a real problem and that's the way they teach math. I tried to like it and accept it, but be warned that your child will have lots of trouble in the future because they learn ridiculous ways of doing division and even subtraction. I finally buckled down (don't ask me why it took so long) and taught her how to do division by rote so she can deal with division of large numbers---because I was amazed to find that she still has trouble and takes too long to do division, thus screwing up her chances of finishing tests with complex word problems. This is a student who is actually good at math overall and learned what I taught her in about 15 minutes, much to her relief.  I've posted a similar message twice and it keeps disappearing. Don't accept the TERC nonsense, because that's what it is. I agree with the comments about the principal. She needs a serious lesson in social skills. But overall the school is good.

I'm sitting here going over some math problems for the SHSAT with my daughter and I discover once again that she CAN'T DO LONG DIVISION WITH LARGE NUMBERS! Why? Because of the ridiculous way it was taught at this school. Get off this TERC nonsense, please. It's SO frustrating and stupid. Aside from that and a cold as ice principal, PS 116 was a good experience.

In response to the budget questions, a financial review is included in every PTA meeting and clearly delineates where the monies raised are spent. Furthermore, the breakdown of expenses was printed in the first newsletter of the year since it is such an issue due to the budget cuts. All this information is also available on the school's website. 6% of the budget is allotted to teacher development so it does not represent a significant expense overall.

Having the playground redone in the fall is a major inconvenience to all the children (& parents at drop off/pick up) however the finished product will be a major asset to the children and as another parent already mentioned, the poor timing can be blamed on the School construction authority.

There are 20 parents who serve on the PTA and we are only zombies when it is boo bash. We manage to organize well over 20 events throughout the year and raise over $400,000 to support the school's programs.We have also many parent volunteers who donate their time (not just money). Without their help and a PTA board to coordinate, PS 116 would certainly not be as special of a school.

Overcrowding is a concern indeed and one which affects NYC as a whole.  Due to the concerted efforts of a few people 2 weeks ago, kindergarten classes were capped off at 26.

If you want your voice heard, attend PTA meetings - the next one is at 6:30pm on October 19 as it is every other month in order to accommodate working parents. 

And as you mentioned, your child has a wonderful education... And is that not the most important?

i had two children go through 116 and felt, as some below did, that there was a serious deterioration after mrs. carillo left. ms hsu may seem friendly and warm on the outside, but i can tell you after two years of significant problems with my child that that warm exterior belies a chilly interior. and she is someone who will definitely shut parents out.

i served on the pta for 8 years, and i was most certainly not a pet.

after two years of significant bullying, nothing was done. i called and emailed the guidance counselor every week for months, and got no response. when i brought this to the attention of both mr. shevell and ms. hsu, nothing was done. i was shocked.

i really wish there were a way for parents to evaluate the principals in as much as the teachers are evaluated. i have been thrilled with most of the teachers, but the principal is, i think, incompetent. she has a great facade, but there's no there there, as gertrude stein said.

The only reason PS 116 is considered a "gem" is because its the only public school in a 25-30 block radius north and south bound of the schools location. Not only does the PTA ask for lots of money the after school program runned by them is ridiculously priced as well. And if the school continues to become more overcrowded with less teachers to teach, I doubt very much our children will learn.

That's incorrect.  Within the "25-30 block radius" there is PS 59 and PS 40.  It is not the only school within the area.  However, it is the only school that is zoned for much of the low income housing area near 28th street and the homeless shelter in the area.  For what it's worth, with what it's given, PS 116 does a lot.  It caters to a population that many other "well known" schools do not.  That is what I love about it, my child is around such a diverse group of classmates!
I never aspired to having my children be friends with kids in homeless shelters. You are a nicer person than I am.
...and I never aspired to have my children be friends with such judgmental people.  Your comment about kids in homeless shelters is sickening.

This is a normal answer. People like their 'own kind'. We marry up not down. The new school takes some of 'these' children away from 116, but the bottom line remains the same. 

OUR CHILDREN DO NOT PROGRESS TO THE SAME DEGREE THAT CHILDREN IN SIMILAR SCHOOLS ADVANCE. 

I think the PTA should ignore the principal's monetary requests and, instead, work for her dismissal.
You sound completely ignorant.

PS 116 is a great neighborhood school - an often overlooked gem in Manhattan.  My child has been there since kindergarten and is now entering 2nd grade.  The PTA is strong and a lot of parents give a lot of money so the school can continue have extras in the face of budget cuts.  For example the PTA funds teaching assistants for K and first grade and now 2nd grade.  

The teachers are great and the instruction is very structured and effective.  The focus (in the first 2 grades at least) is very much on reading level, basic writing, and counting and math.  All the kids no matter the level they enter at seem to progress significantly in these skills over the year.  

Other great things about the school:  Diversity of nations - many UN families attend PS 116 so children from many countries are part of the community - natives of China, Japan, Africa, Middle East, are among the classmates of my child. 
The special classes  are very good - they have wonderful art and music and science teachers who've been at the school a long time and all the kids love. However, due to crowding these specials are only 1/2 the year for most kids (except science)   Other specials include Library, computer, gym, classroom chess, (run by NYChess Kids) and Lincoln Center - a performing and visual arts unit run by Lincoln Center.  In Lincoln Center my child has had a unit on Dance, Blue Grass Music, Visual arts.

Yes, there are problems with overcrowding but that's happening everywhere and so far it hasn't impacted my child's learning n too much.  However, the budget cuts hit hard this year and 5 (not 6 as mentioned below) 2nd grades had to be combined into 4 with an estimated 29 kids per class.  This was a big shock because in first grade last year most classes had around 20 students- an amazing gift! Also one of the gym teachers was let go.I can't imagine why all these people complain so much about Ms. Jane (not Katherine) Hsu.  She seems very nice, attends every PTA meeting, and is very visible day-to-day in the yard and in the classrooms.  She communicated to the parents regularly.  She worked this year with the local police precinct to get crossing guards added at 2 places near the school.  I suppose you can criticize her choices of what to cut, but in my opinion -it does not seem that there is any fat in the budget, so what ever you choose to cut is going to hurt. This a great option for NYC families not opting for private.  Don't let the carping below fool you.

I meant to say, that 6 first grade classes from last year, have now been squeezed into 4 second grade classes.

AND, FWIW, the money to re-do the yard, did not come from the PTA.
Excuse me, correction on the post below, but went from 6 first grade classes to 4 second grade classes, with the same amount of students.  I apologize, but this is an emotionally charged post.

Attended this school in 76 and now my daughter attends this highly prestigious academic enriched school...the principal is hands on and there NO bullying tolerated within the school. Safety is priority as the many cameras can attest... It promotes diversity and enables immigrants with a support staff versed in Mandarin, Cantonese and Fokinese to aid in translation..the rigors of classroom instruction is balanced with creative outlets in art, dance, robotics and after school programs...Highly revered teachers in the class engages and motivates an open instruction format....Kudos to Ms. Chow !!!! Tech lab and outside science trips gives a well balanced cirriculm to each child. My blessings to a school with an outstanding reputation !! Big thanks to all the cluster teachers and classroom teachers !!!
hey i was in one of those photos we r not 4th graders we were 5th graders >:(
Only one family at PS 124 has ever opted out of state tests, reports The New York Times.
P.S. 124 is number 8 on reading proficiency (60.07%) and number 10 in math proficiency (78.80%) in a high poverty school for 2014 city test scores. Read more here.

In response to parents' concerns over traffic safety, the city is installing speed bumps near three downtown schools, including in front of Chinatown's PS 124 on Division Street, between Bowery and Market Street. Read more here.
The Department of Education has approved an additional full-day pre-K section at PS 124. Read more here.

As city politicians consider making the Lunar New Year a NYC school holiday, on Friday (the Lunar New Year of 2014) PS 124 had one of the lowest attendance rates in the city, with an attendance rate of 32.17%. Read more here.

At schools like PS 124 in Chinatown, about half of the students and teachers will probably be absent for the Lunar New Year. Read more in this New York Times story: Half of Class Takes Holiday Off? Soon Whole City May.

This school is awesome! Great, caring, smart teachers with lots of classroom experience. In addition to strong academics, a commitment to arts. Dedicated art, science and music teachers. A well-organized library with a part-time librarian and lots of parent volunteers. My child went here for pre-k (alas, not our zoned school) and had a wonderful year. Highlights included lion dancers at the Chinese New Year Celebration, and a field trip to the Big Apple Circus. I toured several schools in the past year, and this is as good as any of them.

This school is a great school because I come here to learn! The teachers, office, P.T.A , staff, and everybody else helps you with everything.They make sure you understand everything so we are ready for the state wide tests when they come. Every teacher in the school has their special talents. Everybody is treated fairly. The school staff also makes very fun fundraisers, events, and activities! I have this school year and next year which is fifth grade I really want to make these years count because I really LOVE coming to this school!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! This is why P.S. 124 is a great school to me and why people should understand that!
Can anyone comment on how many G&T classes per grade there are and how the school integrates the G&T kids with other children?

There is only one gifted and talented class per grade and the students in the class learn similar things, but they are more challenged. You could say that being in the gifted and talented class is just a status thing cause some people are in regular classes and are equally smart. Hope this helps!
the chess team at this school is awesome!!!!
i go to this school like now. um well after reading all the comments i realized that Ms.Hom works really hard to help us. good job Ms.Hom!

I think that P.S124 ia a wonderful school,even I just in P.S 124 for one year,but I learn so much things from P.S 124,and teachers in so great,when I come in P.S 124,I didn't know any English,but when I graduation from P.S 124,my English is well as the kids that same age to me, so I love P.S 124 yung wing school
Teacher Juhyung Harold Lee talks about the importance of teacher training. Read more:Coaching, Not 'Moneyball,' Will Improve Teaching.
The Panda Pawns earned top honors in a high school level national chess tournament in Nashville, Tennessee. Read more: The Panda Pawns of PS 124 Win Top Honors At National USCF Tournament.

My daughter loves this school and is thriving here. Her first grade class is now just 25 students, which is much smaller than I had expected. Her teachers in the past three years have been very supportive and are truly interested in her well being. The principal has always been responsive to all my concerns and inquiries. Unlike a prior post, I found that the PTA room is open every morning for parents and I have not had any problems entering the school.

First year teacher, Chloe Waldman, was profiled on a website by graduate students at Columbia Journalism School. The new media project, "Coping in New York," profiled several city residents, focusing on how they are getting by during the recession.

Principal Alice Hom received a 2009 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor an aspiring principal while continuing to serve as principal at their school.
Principal Alice Hom received a Time Warner Principals of Excellence Award, given to five public school principals who display "the same leadership skills that are so valued" at Time Warner.

"I never dislike any of my great teachers and I feel proud to be in this school. They teach me quite a lot and I became smarter by the minute I come to class. I really don't want to graduate but I know that after all the help from my teachers and the support of my great friends I will have a miracle in my middle school like in my time in PS 124!" writes student Byron, who adds that even though he doesn't have gym classes anymore, he can get exercise during lunchtime.
"I think this school is the best," writes student Winnie. "I have never had any other teachers other than the ones in P.S.124 that are so nice and encouraging."
National Dance Institute (NDI), a program founded by Jacques d'Amboise, offers dance instruction to all 5th graders, and a special education class an NDI spokesman said.
"Thanks to this school, I developed great work ethics and skills to get into better schools," writes former student Laura Phung.

Ellen, a former student, writes: "This school is seriously a wonderful school. You can't go wrong in a school like 124. It might need some work on the diversity side but that can't be changed too much being as it's built in Chinatown. The teachers are devoted and eager to help. Both my brother and I have attended the school and we are proud to say that it's given us the foundation we needed to move on to junior high school and high school."

A 5th-grader at the school writes: "When I came here in 2nd grade, I felt lonely, but now that a lot of people know me and I have made many friends, I'm proud of this school. ... The teachers are also really nice and our new principal--Ms.Hom--is very neat and nice."

A parent writes, "PS 124's biggest strengths are the generally exceptional teaching staff and the strong family life of the students. Teachers are very dedicated, with at least one teacher spending his entire 20-year career there. We also found teachers and some administrators to be genuinely caring, with efforts to bring extra help for students with problems." However, he complains that the new administration has been "a significant letdown" and writes that the new school leadership "seems to be overly concerned with security and order to the point where parents don't feel as welcome in the school, and lose out on a crucial opportunity for daily contact with teachers. This in a school that is already the very definition of order. Parents are literally not allowed in the building at drop-off or pick-up, which has the effect of shutting out the vast majority of working parents." He says these new policies are "a stark contrast to previous years when parents had limited access at pickup, a time when they could discuss class activities with other parents, or count on a chance encounter with one of the cluster teachers."

"This school vigorously prepares students for the standardized tests," a parent writes. " My son is currently in the 4th grade, with the state math test coming in a few days. The teachers are attentive and concerned not only with their students' academic performance and social growth, but also with their lives outside of school, understanding that difficulties can impact their academic work." She also notes, "The new principal, Alice Hom, is wonderfully efficient and very pleasant. Although the school has over 1000 students, it is well organized. The PTA is well-run and monthly meetings allow parents to learn about upcoming events, including fund raisers, schedule changes and standardized tests."

MAT has really made me explore the world more. What I love most is their sports program. For people who love sports but also want to maintain their academics, this is a nice school to balance the two things. You can be a kid like me who didn't know anything about volleyball and will end up coming out of MAT knowing lots about volleyball and playing it too. In sixth grade, it is more of getting to know the whole grade while in 7th, you are trying to find your friend group and in 8th, you learn to appreciate and treasure the people around you. Teachers are extremely nice as well as teaching you loads of information that will be super helpful in the future. Three years fly by and it seems short. We went overnight trip, Medieval Times, senior trip. I recommend everyone putting MAT as one of their top choices. This school is amazing and I can't forget it. It is sad to not experience this kind of environment.

I just graduated from MAT a few months ago and all I can say is that it's a small but amazing school where you can easily create close bonds with classmates, teachers and staff. Loved my experience at MAT.
this school is great

PS 126 Principal Jacqui Getz will be principal of a new District 2 middle school 75 Morton for the 2017-2018 school year. Morton says parents will not have to rank the school first to be accepted, DNAinfo reports.
Do they take entering 7th graders? What are the chances of accepting a student not from the district?

Jacqui Getz, currently the principal of PS 126, has been announced as the principal for the new middle school in District 2. The school, MS 297, will welcome its first class of students in September 2017. Read the full story here.
Historic walks through the Lower East Side neighborhood which is home to MS 126 have become a key part of one history teacher's curriculum. Read more here.
Do most of the students at 126 stay on for the middle school?  How many spots are usually available to students from other elementary schools?

I don't know exactly how many students stay, but the trend is for that number to get bigger each year as Middle School admissions gets more and more competitive and people opt to avoid the scramble and stay in an excellent school.
Um... I go to MAT, and all of you that say that it is an amazing school, you should be proud of yourself, because you are right.

P.S.126/MAT need YOUR help to make sure that the shelves are stocked 
with the books that our childrenwant to read, and those that our 
teachers need to expand the children's horizons - to give them more to 
dream about.  This will not be possible without your contribution!http://www.funds4books.com/fundraiser.aspx?pincode=b8e4
Some NYC schools are making exercise a priority. Read more: Fitting In Exercise, Between Math and English.
SchoolBook features Principal Jacqui Getz. Read the article: The Secrets of a Principal Who Makes Things Work.
MAT has a fabulous middle school. Great article.

Given how much I rely on this website, I'm writing to perhaps encourage other families to choose P.S. 126. Our son got into the pre-K program and we decided to transfer our other son (who had been going to a school on the east side for four years) so that they could both attend the same school. That's been the best thing we did as parents for our third grader. He has an extremely capable and caring teacher. The class sizes are amazing for a public school. Both our children love their gym, music and art teachers. There's a brand new school library with a very helpful librarian. Our older child loves his science teacher. There's a chess program, also with very caring chess teachers. The kids can join band and other athletic teams from 4th grade I believe. I think P.S. 126 is really a top notch school that is better than many public schools in better neighborhoods and even better than many private schools in the city. It's far from the train station but worth the commute!

wow, this is great to hear, thanks for your reply in case you come back here. My son just got into this pre-K program and was excited because I expected he got no admission anywhere at all. Really glad to see your review though, going to register him on Monday:) Thanks again!
"The teachers are great," writes student Janet Rodriguez. "I haven't met one teacher in that school that is mean."

My three girls have all attended since they were in Pre K (starting over 8 years ago). "The school has improved dramatically," writes parent Anna Cardinali. "Academically I could not be more pleased. I must highlight the music program, which is exceptional! The music teacher Mr. Ruddy is the best of the best. He plays multiple instruments and encourages these kids to excel in what many people feel is extracurricular. His music events always get high attendance and you can see how much he enjoys his interaction with the kids." She adds: "All of our teachers are extremely involved in the activities after school and holidays. You can always find them at events that they are not required to attend and participating with the kids as well."

A teacher writes: "Prospective families should know that, while the name MAT remains, the school bears no resemblance to the original Manhattan Academy of Technology. The original MAT's vision of progressive teaching, strong student-teacher relationships, and attention to the whole-child are not the core focus now. Only one teacher remains from the MAT that was housed at PS 2. The old descriptions and ratings prior to September 2003 just do not apply. But as another former teacher noted, the change in leadership (as of June '04) may turn out to be a really good thing."

A former teacher writes that our review seems "to portray a much better school than the one I worked at. To be fair to the review, I suspect that the school changed greatly last year [2003-04]. Yes, the school was very pretty- lots of sun, a great art teacher who went above and beyond the call of duty when it came to decorating, and a good janitorial staff." He writes that there were "lots of physical resources" at the school and that he did have professional development. Still, he writes that at least 9 teachers left the school last year, which he attributes to problems with the administration. He writes that the administration was ineffective in handling discipline issues. In addition, he complains that, as a teacher, he was not given guidance for how to meet the special needs of struggling students with individualized education plans (IEPs). "I had a great number of students wanting to come hang out in my classroom during lunch because they felt unsafe in the lunchroom," he writes. The two principals that were in the building in 2003-04 are no longer there, he notes. This, he suggests could bode well for the school.

A student who will graduate this year writes, "The school is a wonderful place to be. The teachers are caring." She says she hopes that a recent change in leadership won't change the school too much.

I am extremely pleased with the creativity of the TAG program. As a parent, I do not feel comfortable with rote assignments that reflect volume only. In my opinion, rigor is not defined by volume but by quality instruction which is reflective of MULTIPLE intelligences in the classroom.  The STEM projects, inspired critical thinking by way of Socratic methodology and progressive teaching strategies are the very definition of quality learning. Our children are as close to receiving a private school education in a public school as it gets. I always feel seen and heard by not only the teacher, but by administration. I'm truly disheartened that some parents, rather than voice their concerns face to face, are taking to a public forum to soil the outstanding reputation of our beloved school and its teachers. I feel extremely lucky that my child gets to attend this wonderful school. Private school is always an option for the dissatisfied. If you are a parent  looking for a public school that promotes creative arts, multiple intelligences, social emotional learning, and rigorous instruction- PS 130 is for you!

I was all with you until the part of private school education in a public school.  I am not sure if it was your intend to belittle the public school system but both the private and public system have their pros and cons.  I think the other parents are just voicing their opinion just like you.  And if you read their comments, some of them did tried to bring up their concerns with the administration but was ignored.  I personally think PS 130 is a great school but it might not be the right school for those parents and kids.

Let me start by saying that my child is also in this 4th grade TAG class.  Some background info: There are two 4th Grade TAG classes.  Last year, a majority of our class's parents inquired with administration about the child-to-class assignment process.  We did so after finding out that parents from the other class lobbied to the principal to be assigned the more experienced teacher. 

We sent in a long letter with a majority of the class parents signatures to get a response of "See you in September" from the principal himself.  We requested for another meeting to get the response of "I do not think there is anything more to talk about".  Administration also promised that they would make sure that the two TAG classes run on the same pace. 

The two classes are completely off pace from each other.  The workload and output of the other TAG class is what we expect from a blue ribbon school.  The workload and output of our TAG class is what they were able to produce in their 3rd grade TAG class.  Not only this, we have 32 kids in our class while the other class has 28.  

Dont get me wrong, I do not at all blame the teacher.  Administration is 100% at fault for not providing a solution to this inevitable problem.  This problem was identified a year ago, and nothing was done to prevent it.  It is simply disappointing that parents concerns are pushed aside and not addressed.

I am actually very impressed that the 4th grade teacher you refer to saw a teaching moment to attend the beautiful movie called Wonder. My child is getting a well-rounded education in that class, because they are prepared academically as well as working on STEM projects. That's not entertainment! I'm happy that they have a good amount of homework, but not overloaded with repetitive math problems. I love that the parents are involved in their classroom celebrations. The teacher responds immediately to any email I send, so if you have concerns it should be YOU as the parent to reach out. It actually sounds like you are the irresponsible one, not the teacher. That's so sad that your child has been so unhappy since September, but you kept them in the class. Shame on you.

Just curious - if you are concerned that this teacher’s effort and work’s lackluster as well as being very irresponsible, then why is your child still in this class? I would have taken my concerns directly to the teacher and voiced my concerns directly to administration immediately. Why wait until the end of February to air these concerns? You have every right to take your child out of the school if you are so dissatisfied with the quality of his/her education.

PS 130 used to be an outstanding school, but with my child this year the teacher is very irresponsible. Her effort and work’s lackluster and she misinforms the class students. My child current 4th grade teacher didn’t teach the students much and is too fond of entertainment. She rarely emails us in regards to academic or learning, but for the holidays she emailed us over and over for what food, drinks, and snacks to bring in to school. She brought the class into a trip to a movie theater and this trip was meant for 5th graders. Afterwards, there was NO writing assignment. In addition, her class is supposed to be on par with other class and we have been notified by admin that the teachers will work together to provide equal levels of education. This’s NOT the case. Our class trails far behind other class and has substandard education compared to other class. Her homework is in extremely small amounts. Homework from 2nd and 3rd grade is more plentiful than the amount she gives. Has the DOE curriculum changed? The other class has plentiful amounts of writing to prepare the classes for the upcoming ELA and Math classes. They have a writing assignment almost daily. A bit of fun and joy is acceptable, but my child class is overloaded with entertainment. The teacher does rarely gives feedback and the homework feedback is rushed. She spends too much time going to movies and partying than doing the job she is paid to do. She is irresponsible and unsuited for the job. She told the class that spelling isn’t important in ELA which is completely incorrect as poor spelling can drag your writing score down. As a parent how are we supposed to prep for the ELA and math tests that are upcoming? How is the class children supposed to excel in her class? Or is it because it is a Blue Ribbon school that the tests no longer important anymore?

The US Department of Education designated PS 130 a 2017 "Blue Ribbon" school for having test scores in the top 15 percent in the state, with students in all demographic groups scoring higher than at least 60 percent of students in their state, according to a US Department of Education press release.

I'm strongly disagreed with the administration allowed a small group of  parents going to classroom for Halloween trick-or-treating and take photograph with the child during class time. 

Now a lot parents have no choice but sending the children to tutoring center for extra curriculum so the children can  pass the ELA and Mathematics assessment test.

The US Department of Education designated PS 130 a "Blue Ribbon" school for having test scores in the top 15 percent in the state, with students in all demographic groups scoring higher than at least 60 percent of students in their state, Chalkbeat reports.

A comment from POPPYNYC:

Having just finished up our final year at PS 130, I thought it was a good time to post a review on InsideSchools. The website has been a
valuable tool for our family in the past (elementary, middle) and now as we begin our high schools search.  So, I thought best to post here and give back some. The DOE handbooks really don’t offer enough color to get the vibe of a school so I really like supporting websites like this.

Anyway, we put two kids through PS 130, in their TAG program, with our youngest graduating in 2017.  We couldn’t have been happier and it fact, we chose PS 130 over other “attractive” options closer to our home (upper east).  We chose PS 130 not only for its reputation and academic rigor but also for its spirit and for the diversity it offered over other neighborhoods.

No buts about it…PS 130 is a large school…about 1000 kids.   Our first impression that first day, drop off and pick-up, was like “WOW”..this is intense but then you realize that it is really quite organized and practiced.  The building itself is large so once the kids are in class, the layout
is quite comfortable throughout the day. The school runs smoothly under the Principal, Mr. Fong, and his APs, Ms. Pearsall and Ms. Thomas and in my eye, the transition from Lilly Woo and APs Epstein & Chin has been seamless.  Classrooms seem to be fairly typical with classrooms equipped with smart boards, AC’s and the kids get access to computers.  Rooms have high ceilings and the teachers can decorate their rooms turning monotone walls into something more cheerful.

The teachers we had were all excellent; academically sharp & capable, communicative, who really cared about the kids. 
Yes, there was a healthy amount of homework, even in the lower grades and a great deal of attention was
  spent on creating strong writers. Lots of book reports, essays, numerous drafts, etc. Other subjects were equally strong/rich including
science and music.   Our kids received an excellent education at PS 130 and both got into the middles schools of their
choice – Salk and East Side Middle.  Other kids in their class went on to Anderson, Hunter, and to many of the
other leading middle schools in Manhattan.  And though they were in the TAG program, I have no doubt that the non-TAG
teachers were just as strong.  It is worth noting that my older son, when he got to Salk, found that he was better academically prepared
than many of his peers.  Son #2 just started ESMS so I can’t really say yet.

At PS 130, there were lots of extra-curricular activities with some tied to Chinatown/Chinese culture which was very cool.  Both our kids were in the Lion Dance Club, marching (next to or under the Lion Costumes) in the annual Chinatown parade.  My kids also participated in the
Drum and Fife Corps, the video club, and more. They did not participate in the school’s two choruses but they are excellent clubs.   I saw that the Inside Schools review called out Rosie’s Kids, National Dance Institute and other programs…all wonderful.   Lots of Arts programs.  In 5th grade, my kids learned ballroom dancing with the best dancers in the school going on to compete against other
schools in the city.  At first, my kids were like “no way, ballroom dancing is silly” but then they loved it (as did
we, the parents) and they (and all the kids) performed beautifully while picking up some valuable social skills along the way.

The Parent’s Association is very strong and is quite adept in fund raising to bring nice programs into the school, in addition to providing extras
for the kids throughout the year. It’s an amazing cast of volunteers and staff who truly love the kids and vice versa. There is also the year-end Banquet held at a big dim-sum house in Chinatown which is a very impressive event with performances,
local dignitaries, auction and delicious food.   Parent Association meetings are conducted in both English and Chinese which I think is spot on.

Our family found PS 130 to be a very complete school; academically strong with tons of heart from administration, teachers, staff, parents and the
kids.   Not only that, it really was a fun school, and down-to earth, where our kids felt comfortable, safe, and 
academically challenged.  Plus, this all takes place in a culture-rich neighborhood.  We’re going to miss our PS 130 days…. in fact, we miss it already.  It goes by so fast!

Good luck!.

We came from a downtown Gen Ed public school with a beautiful campus for Kindergarten and were not happy with it. Too relaxed for us. It seemed to us like our child's teacher had a stigma against us and our child for the child being bright-ish and having a hunger to learn at an accelerated pace. We were lucky to get a G&T 1st grade spot at PS 130 with a youthful but absolutely spectacular and experienced teacher named Ms. Jessica Chan who actually graduated from PS 130 and was trained by the legendary Mrs. Woo. Our child went from being bored and restless to flourishing under Ms. Chan. There was some adjustment from our child's Kindergarten being 100% like Playgarden (downtown toddler and preschool activities place) to the intensity of Singapore Math and daily homework that was actually academic in nature. But we loved it and loved the teacher (Ms. Chan) who deftly had the right balance appropriate for high achieving first graders to learn at an accelerated pace, and warmly treating a kid like a kid. We still save Ms. Chan's famous, well organized Blue Book, as an artifact we want our child to look back on 10 and 20 years later for the teacher who made a seminal impact.  PS 130 frankly was not originally on our radar because of its location but we believe it is a hidden gem that is hugely under-marketed.  It is an outstanding school for parents who believe in academic achievement, and the enhancement programs are actually quite rich. We were so turned off by the Kindergarten experience in the other downtown public school, we were going to send our child to Packer in Brooklyn Heights for first grade, and thinking longer term about moving to the suburbs in high performing school districts. But we are happy keeping our child at PS 130

We had our son attend a Tribeca pre-school (Montessori School of Manhattan) for two years and were on the fence among having him continue there, go to the Pre-K at PS 130, or a place called Transfiguration. We decided on the Pre-K at PS 130 because we liked the young administration of PS 130, led by a caring, warm principal named Mr. Fong, and two youngish Assistant Principals who "showed well" as competent educators and administrators. The pre-K at PS130 was transformative for our son. He was always a shy reserved child, but the rich arts program at PS 130 transformed our son to be out of his bubble, where he now loves to sing, dance, recite "rhyming songs {rap} ", and crack jokes. We are very grateful to an extraordinary duo of teachers are son had, a very experienced, talented devoted one named Ms. Lai and her assistant, a new young teacher named Ms. Baker. Being in the bubble of Pre-K, we don't know about the rest of the school but it seems to be a pretty vibrant, well managed place

After Mrs Woo, Ms Chin and Mr Epstein retired PS130 is getting weaker by the day. Experienced, hard working, and talented teachers leaving this school. Brand new and inexperienced teachers are replacing all the teachers who have left resulting in a very young and unprepared staff.  Most of the time new teachers walk in and leaving the school same time as the students.The school is a safe and friendly environment for kids, but there are deeper problems being hidden by that facade.  Still some bright spots,such as some of the music and art teachers and the security are excellence. This NOT the school it used to be.
agreed

I have to respectfully disagree with the comments above about the current administration and inexperienced teachers.  
Our two children have been attending PS130 for a few years now and our experience has been wonderful.  With any new administration, there are bound to be changes but we have not seen any negative changes at all following Mrs. Woo’s (former principal) retirement.  Mr. Fong (current principal), Ms. Pearsall (AP) and Ms. Thomas (AP) always have the best interests of the children at heart and they have done an excellent job maintaining the quality and standards of the school.  The school continues to be a high performing school with an excellent academic program and wonderful enrichment activities.  

We believe the school has done a very thoughtful job at “succession planning” so there is not a “shock” to the system with the retirement/departure of any leader or teachers.  Take the transition of administration as an example, before Mrs. Woo retired, she had worked very closely with Mr. Fong (who was then an assistant principal and had been a teacher at the school for years) and Ms. Pearsall (who had been a teacher at the school for years as well) to ensure the “next generation” leaders could capably handle the new responsibilities when the time came for her to retire.  Even after she has retired, she still makes herself available to the new administration for any advice they need.  Ms. Chin (former AP) did the same thing.  The transition to the current administration could not have been more seamless! The same applies to the training and development of the teachers.  This is a school that is built to last and it is very impressive to see the administration and teachers all committed to sustaining excellence for generations to come.

In response to the specific comment about the teachers, it’s true that some experienced teachers have retired in recent years so there are newer teachers at the school, but the vast majority of the teachers are very experienced and have been with the school for years (some for decades!).  Note that these are retirement of older teachers and they did not leave the school for any other reasons - this is a very natural cycle of any organization – you cannot expect the “older generation” to stick around forever!  In the past few years, our children have had a good mix of highly experienced teachers (with one having taught at the school for almost 30 years!) and newer teachers and all of them have been excellent.  We think the administration has done a great job attracting teachers who believe in the school’s philosophy and culture of excellence and the teachers we have seen thus far are very committed and dedicated. There is also a very high level of collaboration among the teachers and they regularly exchange ideas and “best practices” among themselves.  From what we have observed, the more experienced teachers are very active in training and developing the newer teachers to ensure they maintain the same quality and standards of teaching across the school.  

The level of commitment and dedication of the administration and the teachers to the school and the children are really quite amazing.

You can disagree with me. But I'm sure a lot of parent agreed with me. I also have to respectfully disagree with you the teachers leaving PS130 are NOT OLD and they are NOT OLDER GENERATION. The teachers leaving PS130 to another school are all Hard-working, Intelligent,Energetic, Caring, Supports, Very committed and Dedicated..............  

Now a lot parents have no choice but sending the children to tutoring center for extra curriculum so the children can  pass the ELA and Mathematics assessment test. 

 I'm strongly disagreed with the administration allowed a small group of  parents going to classroom for Halloween trick-or-treating and take photograph with the child during class time.

Trying to decide between a downtown GenEd school (great facilities) and one of the closer district G&T schools (e.g. 33, 11, 130).  PS 130 is the closest of the district schools and I looked at the facilities at 33 and 11 and thought they were sub-par.  I haven't yet toured PS 130 but would love to hear from current parents about the G&T programs there.
PS 130 ranked ninth in District 2 on the 2015 math exam and 21st citywide, DNAinfo reports.

We have a child in the G&T program at PS130 and have been very pleased with it.  Our child switched from a well regarded GenEd school downtown and the academics at PS130 are way more advanced than her previous school.  It is a large school, however, it is not chaotic and dirty as stated by one of the posters below.  While the school is predominantly Chinese, there are also non-Chinese families who love the school.  The school is well run with very caring teachers and staff who really want to do the best for the children.

We just registered our kid. My friends told me the
principle, assistant principle and the teachers at PS130 are excellent. But
they also warned about some people in the school PTA love to gossiping. I saw
some PTA member stand out side of the school forced parents to buy raffle
tickets and make donations. The lady even pressing new parents to buy raffle
tickets inside the registration room. Just too aggressive and demanding. As
a new parent to the school this just make me felt very uncomfortable.

Considering where the school is situated and most of the parents are probably low income, I think the PA does an amazing job raising funds for the students and enrichment programs.  Not a lot of PA teams can put themselves out there to raise such funds.  The Funds go back to our children.

I think a part of the issue is that a new parent does not yet see everything that goes into the school.  To a new parent in the school, it might seem aggressive.  However, this PTA works above and beyond to support the school.  Many other District 2 schools have rich parents.  PS 130 does not, but they do not let the students suffer because of it.  Other schools ask for hundreds of dollars to raise money so they don't have to work on fundraising daily.  Our PTA works hard every single day to raise money, so they do not have to ask low income families for $500 or more that they might not have.  I have never seen a more hard-working PTA.  Every dime goes to the school and the kids.  The PTA raises money for new tech, dance, art, renovations, academic programs for the teachers and anything else that will help the school progress.  Even if they do ask me for a dollar here or there, I will comply because I see where it goes.

The PTA runs almost every event and fundraiser, so the teachers can focus on class.  Book fairs, picture day, parties, food drives, etc. - they are even involved in the day to day routine - keeping the drop offs and pick-ups orderly.   Every year, we walk in the Chinese new year parade with beautifully ornate dragons and an amazingly talented drum team.  At the annual banquet the 5th graders perform their best Latin dance routines.  My son takes music, movement, computer, and will be playing on a newly renovated rooftop playground.   Every GT class that he has been in has had two teachers.   The school can focus on the academics, while the PTA can help with the rest.  For the new parent, I ask you to give them a chance and maybe even volunteer.  Our family does and we would be proud to be demanding PS 130 PTA parents.

We pulled our child out of the 1st grade G&T class after almost 2 months. The school is large, chaotic, and DIRTY! G&T class is crowded with over 30 kids! The curriculum is not accelerated vs gen ed. Science class is none. We live in a great gen ed zone downtown. PS130 is not worth the daily schlep. Also the school is 97% Chinese, mostly new immigrants from all over the 5 boroughs. and lower east side (district 1). How can a district 2 G&T class full of kids who live in Brooklyn and Queens if it weren't for all the fake addresses? If you don't live in a great school zone or if you are newly immigrated Chinese, 130 is fine. Otherwise don't bother sending your child there.

The school is large, crowded, but not THAT dirty.  G&T class has the max # of students but the curriculum IS accelerated vs Gen Ed.  Science class is still none.  School is mainly Chinese because it IS located in Chinatown but not mostly new immigrants.  We all try to provide the best for our children and I do not think we should discriminate the new immigrants and we were all "new" immigrants at some point.  My child is in G&T class.  Again, the class is crowded but the teacher is able to keep the class under control.  If your child needs lots of attention, then it might not be a good school for him/her.  Best way to learn more about the school is to attend a school tour - ask all the questions you have in your mind and be observant.

Hello, everyone. We have had two kids at PS 130 since
2005, and we love this school so much, that we decided to add our input here, as our youngest child is now in the fifth grade, getting ready to graduate for middle school.   We enrolled our son in the first grade G+T program at PS 130 in 2005. He is currently entering the 7th grade at LAB Middle School and remains an A student, mostly because of the study habits he learned at PS 130 -- the most important of which is learning to internalize responsibility.   Back in 2005, our son had also been offered a spot at a terrific private school where our oldest child had attended, but we decided to check out the TAG programs in District Two, as well. Of all the District 2 elementary schools, we selected PS 130, because we were impressed at 1) the attentiveness and engagement of children in classrooms run by teachers who obviously enjoyed teaching; 2) the orderly, sunny switchover of almost 1,000 giggling, well behaved children between classes; 3) the aestheticism of a 27-million dollar renovation; 4) the impeccable cleanliness of the halls, classrooms, nurse’s office and cafeteria; 5) the quality of the children’s writing and work samples  displayed on the walls; 6) the quality, dedication and thorough attention to parents and children by the Parents Association—Lisa, Diane, Miriam, John, and other dedicated daily persons, and; 7) the principal herself, Mrs. Woo, who personally took the time to give the tour. Impressive. We cancelled our spot in private school.  

After going through both the private and the public school experience, we consider PS 130 an excellent and comparable choice on many levels: academic, psychological, and cultural. The educative style is a balance of traditional and progressive teaching, which means our son (and also our daughter, enrolled two years later) learned to be able to concentrate over long periods of time while enjoying themselves in school; to re-do work when it wasn’t good enough without feeling punished, but, rather, galvanized to be their best selves; to become  independent and able to prioritize and manage their own workloads; and to learn the rules of grammar, spelling, diction, math and the laws of logical thinking in essay writing, science experiments and chess to a level many others could not.   The school’s educative approach pleases me, as a British person, because it is similar to a British education in its discipline and academic practice. By the time our children graduated fourth grade, they could multiply and divide rapidly, in their heads. As my son grapples with complex math in Middle School, he never has to pause to check his basic arithmetic or use a calculator. The same is true of their spelling and grammar usage—the weekly word studies ensure that my children not only understand how to spell, but also how to define a word. My children automatically go deeper, searching for a more accurate, more complex word to use in an essay or everyday speech. They’ve learned that playing Scrabble with an open dictionary is fun, as are speed games in arithmetic and number sense.  

Though some may have noted that the school is dominantly Asian, we consider this an asset. Our kids experienced something wonderful, almost as if we had traveled elsewhere: they were steeped in another culture at an age young enough so that they were completely unconcerned with ethnic and cultural differences. As such, they have found listening to Mandarin and Cantonese to be natural and instinctive; they are as thrilled by Chinese New Year as they are by January 1. My son took great pride in being one of the drummers in his year for the Chinese Lion Dance club, and practiced after school every Friday afternoon for all of fifth grade, and participated in these dance displays on the streets of Chinatown on Chinese New Year, and on performance tours at private schools.  

The teachers have been there forever and are smart, engaged, quick to smile and care about the children. I only know the TAG teachers, but they are all gems: Ms. McConnell, Ms. Nicklas, Mr. Siu, Ms. Mieszkowski, Ms. Flagler, Ms. Pearsall, Mrs. Koa-Chan, Ms. Moncrief (now Mrs. Cho), Ms. Chen.   The school makes it a point to provide enrichment from fundraising. The science, library and music programs are all vibrant: my son participated in ballroom dancing, theater performance programs, debates, violin lessons, the drum and fife corps, chess, Young People’s Chorus, School Chorus, and the Lion Dance Club. The librarian responded with a bounty of ideas to my request for suggested books that would challenge our son, but not introduce themes that were inappropriate for his age level.   There is a collaborative art program with an art gallery space downtown, where the children work with an artist in class and have a culminating exhibition of their artwork at the gallery at the end of the residency. Field trips are fun and educational, from trips to restoration villages, Japanese tea ceremonies, or the Bronx Botanical Garden, the latter to learn about the life cycles of plants and trees in the context of learning to write a research paper.  

The aftercare program at PS 130 is an incredible value. Operating through a Community-based organization, the cost is less than $1,000 for 3-6 pm, Monday through Friday, September through mid June, with a teacher or tutor providing homework support and care. A full healthy meal is provided by Food Services each afternoon. There are also enrichment activities offered, for an additional modest fee, such as Mandarin, gymnastics, basketball, modern dance, piano and violin, depending on interest and enrollment. Whenever we picked  up our kids from school, we saw quiet groups of children reading, working together, tired but happy, with connected, caring adults all around.   Discipline and academics start in pre-K at PS 130; kids learn pencil grip, writing, leadership skills, switching tasks regularly without tantrums, sharing games together, and honing initial math and artistic skills. Mrs. Koa-Chan, the Pre-K teacher, is outstanding; humorous, warm, firm, organized. The three and four-year-olds are expected to sign in and out themselves(!) and by the time they graduate from Mrs. Koa-Chan’s class, they can.    At the start of first grade, our children were ready to write essays, read books and concentrate for hours at a time.   

When our daughter sat for the G+T exam during pre-K, the City had just steeply increased the standards. We sat with the PS 130 Guidance Counselor, Debbie Zaslow, to see if the non G+T classes would provide the same opportunities for our daughter to enter into fine middle schools, or if we should consider private schools, instead. Debbie showed us the impressive statistics for children exiting PS 130 Gen Ed classes into the best middle schools: Salk, ESM, LAB, NEST, Baruch, etc. We were convinced that we would be pleased with our daughter’s education in Gen Ed as much as in TAG.  

Because discipline is taught in a gentle, orderly way with kindly but high expectations, the children are unusually attentive and exhibit emotional fortitude and endurance, making the large class sizes non- threatening to the learning process. The years progress with quiet respect for the learning process, and enjoyment through collaboration, anticipation of reward through thrilling field trips, and the pleasure of pleasing a teacher who is devoted to you.   We were concerned about the infrequent outdoor recess, but neither our son or daughter had a real complaint about this in the end. At lunch, they ate with their friends and then played together—usually card games, or with toys brought from home. They learned to concentrate from 9-3, and play from 3-5. There are two great playgrounds a few blocks from the school, in Little Italy and Chinatown as well as some relatively inexpensive after school neighborhood athletic opportunities available, such as gymnastics, ballet, modern dance, swimming, Tae Kwon Do, soccer and basketball.  

Mrs. Woo is amazing. Not only is she the heartbeat and success story of PS 130, she makes a point to get to know you and your children from the opening tour to the day of graduation. I am not alone in knowing that her door is always open (literally, it is hard to walk to the office without catching her eye), she always answers her phone—often the school phone, actually—and knows the educative journey and personality of the children. When I was not sure which Middle School to send my son, she stayed on the phone and helped me for over 30 minutes weighing the pros and cons of his choices, against his personality, strengths and learning style. She gave  it her full attention, even using her own children’s experiences as examples.   When my son exhibited worrisome behavior in the third grade classroom, she called us in, and gathered together a team of educators, occupational therapists, a psychologist and herself to review my son’s behavior and test his concentration and coordination. I have never seen such swift, caring, and accurate evaluation of our children before or after PS 130. The graduates are loyal, and at the annual banquet or talent contest, I meet PS 130 alumni from all sorts of wonderful schools and universities who “just come back” because they love it.  

The school is greatly focused on moving the children toward good middle schools, namely, preparing for the defining fourth grade exams. The children work hard, and the rewards are earned.   Going to school in the heart of Chinatown has been an indelible experience for us. Our children, for the first ten years of their  lives, were not in the ethnic majority, an opportunity that we thought would enrich their perspective as adults. Many of their friends are bilingual, including Cantonese, Mandarin, Italian, French, Spanish, Russian, Farsi, Urdu and Romanian speakers. We regularly utilize the neighborhood as a resource as well, learning Mandarin at the Church of the Transfiguration on Mott Street; Tae Kwon Do and piano lessons at Confucius Plaza, all inexpensive, compared to elsewhere in the city. 
 As our son considers high school and our daughter prepares to interview for middle school, we feel they could not have received a better educated start in life than at PS 130. 

In August 2013, “The Economist” magazine published an article about how Finland, Poland and South Korea are topping the world in school standards. The winning formula, according to the article, is this: a strong focus on basic skills, respect for the role of teacher, and teachers themselves who embrace the idea that every child can succeed in understanding concepts if they are given the time and encouragement  to build the fortitude to stay with a problem. These qualities reminded us of the teaching style at PS 130.   We realize this is a lengthy paean to PS 130. We’re sad to say goodbye to this lovely place, and decided to set down on “paper” our family’s indelible experience at this unique, elementary school, with its intriguing sets of winning contradictions: large and intimate; progressive and traditional, Asian and European, immigrant and landed; tenured educators with the sparkle and energy of the newly hired; quintessentially New York.    Andrew and Jennie Dunn

Be aware their Gift and Talented program exceeds class size for such a program versus other G&T programs in other schools pushing 32-33 students here. The principal is very unwilling to allow any teaching help in classes even if parents are willing to pay for such. The extra class programs the schools says they offer of dance, music etc are never run weekly on a consistant basis. Overall the teachers are very attentive, nice and warm. Lunch time is limiting as half of the lunchtime children wait watching movies in the auditorium. Outdoor play is minimal don't expect much roof playground time for your child. In the winter they don't go out at all. Unfortunately I am very disappointed with this school and feel there is great room for improvement.

I'm sorry "alis jj" but this is just not true.  The G and T program, like all the classes at PS 130, is at capacity - because EVERYONE wants to be at this amazing school, and Mrs. Woo is too kind to turn folks away.  The amazing PS 130 teachers have no problems with their capacity classes; students all get individual attention, and the school culture is warm and friendly and caring.  
Of course Mrs. Woo does not want unqualified volunteers in the classroom, when she has highly qualified specialist teachers already doing a wonderful job with students (just check the statistics.) And by the way it is illegal for an individual to be teaching in a NY public school without both state and city certification, and fingerprint clearance.
The after-school classes ARE consistent, my children got piano, violin and dance classes regularly at a very reasonable rate, with highly qualified teachers, and the chance to present their skills in a delightful end of year recital.
Like all schools in New York, kids don't go out in the playground when the weather is bad.  (Duh!)  In many other schools children are sent out into a concrete yard with little supervision or play props.  At PS 130 when the children are on the roof they are given balls, hoops and supervised fun.  PS 130 boasts the most committed teaching staff - this is a school that no teacher would ever want to leave.  The children at this school are wonderful, their parents are committed, and the integration of the performing arts program boosts every child's self-esteem.
Seriously, if you have young children move to Chinatown to take advantage of this wonderful free school.
Jane Barrer

Mrs. Woo is just an incredible principal and she has built a wonderful staff. Most boys do better with daily physical activity and learn better when they can use movement and spatial mechanical   functioning and skills.  Recess and physical activity needs to be fully integrated into every schools' program.
