Hello, all,

My wife and I stopped by PS 130 last Friday, 3/2/12, to submit an out of district application for K admission on our daughters behalf.  What we thought was going to be a short visit to drop off paperwork turned out to be an extended, highly informative, and much welcomed discussion with the school's principal.   We stood at the main office counter, application in hand, asking our various questions, as one of the persons behind it joined in the conversation who, after a few moments, introduced herself as the school's principal.  Seizing the opportunity to barrage her with questions, and probably sensing our "schools-admission-are-we-doing-what's-best-for-our-child" anxiety, she invited us into her adjacent office where we sat down for what I estimate was an hour-long discussion.  We went over her history there, our hopes for our daughter's education, P.S. 130's mission, her experience raising and educating two children with very different learning styles - you name it, we covered it!  The larger point being we were more than a little impressed not only by Ms. Woo's willingness to have a spur of the moment, in-depth conversation with two nervous parents, who did not have an appointment, but also by her ability to address our concerns with ease, conviction, and empathy.  Aside from that, the physical plant itself, was lovely - clean - and the attitude from all the staff we came into contact with was warm and welcoming.  There is clearly a culture there that comes from the top down, and we hope to receive notification that our daughter is admitted.  If not, we most certainly will try again as we welcome the opportunity for our daughter to attend P.S. 130, especially after meeting Ms. Woo.

-Mark Lynch & Kirstin Allen

I have two girls in PS130, 1 in G&T 1st grade and 1 in regular Kindergarten.  I am truly amazed that there isn't a huge difference between the G&T and the regular class.  The teachers and staff are tremendously supportive and very responsive.  I work full time and drop off the kids in the AM, pick them up at an outside afterschool program, and I never had a problem communicating to the teacher via a note in the notebook(that is checked daily) or via email.  I can send email in the wee hours when I am just getting around to checking the kids homework or have a specific question.  By early next morning, even on weekends, the teacher responds, and I dont have to wait till parent teacher meeting or have to go and interrupt the teacher during the busy day.  The writing in my kindergarten class is absolutely amazing and astonishes me when  I compare it to the G&T class writing.  The G&T class is create because  it taught my daughter to think outside the box, ask detailed questions.  She went from not really knowing how to read right to level I.  I would highly recommend this school, the only down side is what happens after 5th grade :(. 
The principal is the heartbeat of the school.  She is absolutely amazing and warm.  You can see all that she has done.  All the love for arts and music isn't possible without her support or vision.
Oh I so agree Ms. Eng.  My kids both went on to specialized schools after PS130, but oh how I wish PS 130 was K-12!

I currently have a son at PS 130 and my daughter graduated from 130 and is now in high school.  My daughter was in a tag class, my son is not.  My children are both Latino and Asian (not chinese).  The school is an incredible place.  The principal and the teachers work incredibly hard, are extremly dedicated and are accessible.  Teachers have responded quickly to emails, set up meetings when requested and have been responsive to questions and concerns.  My son, who is not in a TAG class, has been challenged by his teachers and has been taught in exciting and creative ways.  I feel no hesitation walking into the main office or the principal's office if I need information or have questions or concerns.  For those who think that it's not a welcoming enviornment for non-Asian children, I can tell you, that's completely false.  We have never felt so welcomed at and connected to a school as we do at PS 130.  I do not live in the district and I chose to send my kids to this school.  I couldn't have chosen better.

Even if they don't, you can try to speak with Ms. Tam and she will definitely understand and try to talking to that teacher. -.-

This comment is not true. Ms.Tam respect all students in M.S.131 and welcomes them with smile and that includes the new immigrants. When students are not well behaved, teachers would give them chances to learn a lesson. If they mishave the 2nd or 3rd time, they would be send to the office and have a parent conference or lunch detention.
Ms. Tam is also, the best principal in M.S.131
I'm assuming that you're one of the teachers of 131. Does the name "Taylor" sound familiar to you?
False, after she took over 131, the grades started going downhill.
You claim to be a "parent" and yet seem to be a student. If you're a student, be honest about the strengths of MS 131. Don't be vengeful, and pretend to be someone you're not.

I have been here in ms131 for 3 years. i just graduated. I have learned a lot in this school ! The teachers are great. They teach you more then what we need to learn so we can rock the state tests! The principal & assistant principals care so much for us. I love the community service we do, as we give back to our neighborhood. They have prepared me to go to a strong high school and I was so happy when I was accepted.
What high school are you going to?
Since Ms. Tam has taken over, I have seen great change in school. My son knows that teachers there care. He is learning so many things that i know he would not get in others schools.

"My brother attended this school several years ago. He was often miserable after school because black and hispanic kids would pick on him, and picked fights with him and his friends, who also happen to be Asian Americans. I've heard It's improving but it things might move along faster if the rooms were equipped with security cameras, and if NYPD were staffed in/outside the school."

"MS131 is a great school that prepares students a lot for th high school. It has ESL and Bilingual programs that can help students who have been in America less than 2 years or having difficulties in English. The teachers are helping the students all the time on their homework and classwork. They help students with their reading and writing. Teachers teach students some reading strategies that they may use on the test. They guide students how to make their writing sounds mature. Students always work together in groups and help each other. In addition, teachers also plan a lot of fun trips for students, which help them with their learning. Moreover, MS131 has various of after school clubs for ESL students. These clubs help them practice with their speaking and communication skills. Once again, I wouldn't accomplish my dream of going to Baruch High School without MS131's help. MS131 is a great middle school."

"The school has been re-organized into three academies with distinct themes and activities: the Academy of Law, Society, and Technology, the Academy of Community and Technology, and the Academy of Leadership and Technology. Every student has a laptop. Almost every classroom has a Smart board. While the emphasis on a rigorous academic curriculum has been maintained, students are engaged in pursuing their choice of an art (dance, string instrument, music, theatre, and visual art) and an elective (something fun the teacher loves that fits the theme-examples: school newspaper, cooking, math and art, virtual portfolio, bass) several times a week. The halls are calmer. The layout is less confusing because each academy has its own floor and each grade has its own wing. Children are nurtured in small groups and meet with their advisors once a week. There are many engaging after school activities and extra academic help. Teachers plan collaboratively in twice weekly meetings."
A teacher reports that the gifted program is strong but that many other students transfer into the nearby Catholic school "because Sun Yat Sen is not doing what is needed."

A volunteer who worked with ESL teachers at the school writes, "What struck me was one teacher's use of music used as a means to teach language. The students described music, wrote about composers, learned about musical concepts, and went on field trips to listen to music. The teacher I worked with the most had a program with the Orchestra of St. Luke's and had visitng musicians who worked with her class. I also got the sense that the teachers are very sympathetic to the students' struggles with English and gave them some space by allowing some "Chinese" (I put this in quotes because there are so many dialects) in the classroom."

"I have to say that the school has calmed down a great deal from when I started there in the 6th grade," writes a former student. "When I first started at the school it was out of control like the staff had no control. Now everything seems under control."

"Although MS 131 is a safe school and most teachers are dedicated, there is no sense of community amongst the staff and families of students," writes an insideschools.org reader. "The staff is not communicating effectively with parents. Unfortunately, important information does not get through properly to parents who do not speak English, and there is a high level of stress and burn-out since it has been labeled a needs of improvement school."

The principal did not offer a response to the above comment.

A parent writes: "One of the most important issues that I would like to see corrected are the disciplinary problems. Kids are always fighting over the dumbest disputes and end up getting physical. Some people pick fights for apparently no reason." This parent feels that the staff does not respond appropriately to these fights.
Manhattan’s P.S. 150 will be allowed to continue occupying the bottom floors of a high-rise tower, at least until 2022, after pressure from city officials the WSJ reports.
Can current families comment on their experiences with the school (pros/cons)? Would like to hear whether the lack of traditional school facilities is a limitation.

The school's main strengths  are the sense of community that comes with a small school, the amazing families, and some pretty awesome teachers. The teachers are gifted and caring. The classrooms themselves are good-sized and the curriculum emphasizes project-based learning and creativity, which we appreciate. 

As for facilities, the younger grades eat lunch in the classrooms and older grades go to the multipurpose room (it doubles as the music room). The plaza serves as the recess yard, which has functioned pretty well for years until the current principal decided it was problematic. Previously, the recesses were as fine and normal and active as other schools, no incidents. But since 2013 the current principal enacted a ban on ball or play equipment, which frustrates families to no end. She cites safety but kids have played with balls and other playthings and managed to survive small conflicts and scrapes for decades before Jenny's arrival. It's easier for the recess monitors to not have to monitor active play and instead, the kids are left to run in circles (they do get tired of tag) or gossip about each other. 

The worst thing about the school is the fact that the administration (despite the intimacy of the school!) is almost handicapped in terms of ability to receive any kind of complaint or suggestion. The small front office takes every inquiry or interaction as an affront (like, how dare parents ask questions or raise concerns!). The principal (Jenny Bonnet) is an awful communicator and for unknown reasons, takes complaints as personal critiques. Often the response from the front office is "we're on it" (code for "shut up, go away") but there's little confidence in their decision-making process. Worse, parents feel personal retribution if they raise concerns that are unpopular or cause anyone to step out of their way or do any kind of hard thinking.  The PTA has been great for years but enthusiasm has dwindled since Jenny arrived. Sad to see the school decline due to poor leadership. Its reputation owes substantially to the strong foundation laid by the previous principal, Maggie, who is now at Peck Slip, and today, it is kind of on autopilot, meaning, of course, the school continues to exist and the kids learn and do well and the families make happy bonds with each other, etc.  But it could be so much more if it had better leadership.
PS 150 was one of six New York City schools that earned US Department of Education Blue Ribbon honors in 2014. Read more and see the full list of schools here.

This is our second year at PS150 for both of my children.  We are so happy to have found this gem of a school, where the academic curriculum is rigorous yet fun and well rounded.  Teachers and staff are friendly and supportive and the principal, Jenny Bonnet, is always available. 


Everyone knows everyone, which for us is a blessing and exactly what we wanted in a school, to really feel part of a tight-knit community.  However, this is probably not the school for families who want to blend into the background!  The PTA is very active and present, and every family is encouraged and expected to get involved, whether in the classroom, on field trips, or with school-wide initiatives and events.  


Important school events include bake sales, track meets, rummage sales, potlucks, musical "salon" evenings, the Halloween sing and disco, the Winter concert, a whole-school performance at the Tribeca Film Fest Family Day, the Spring Auction, and Taste of Tribeca, and the year culminates in the amazing, student-written and student-performed Arts Festival.
Schools Chancellor Carmen Fariña listened to downtown principals' concerns about kindergarten waitlists. PS 150 may take on another kindergarten class as part of the solution. Read more here.

This is our 3rd year as part of the warm, welcoming community of families at PS 150 and we feel very lucky to be here. The review above does not mention that the PTA pays for teacher assistants in every class so the large class size becomes much more manageable. The arts education is great, in particular we have an inspired music program and teacher (who doubles as the gym teacher too!) that are school treasures. The switch to Math in Focus (Singapore Math) is something that the parent body initiated and I am extremely happy with the vast improvement in the quality of math education over TERC. The second graders are routinely performing 3-digit addition and subtraction already, which is a year ahead of where they would be if they were still following the TERC curriculum. Writing and content studies are strong here as well. Our son seems excited by what he is learning (and singing) every day. I

It was a rocky time while it seemed as if the school might be moving out of the neighborhood. But now that things have settled down, we are again counting our lucky stars. This is not a school for people who are looking for state-of-the-art facilities. There's no gym and no cafeteria (though the school makes lemons into lemonades with "family-style" lunch and running clubs and dance classes). It's a school for families who are looking for high achievement in a warm environment where their children will not be able to get lost.

It has been 3 months since we joined the PS 150 community and  we can't say enough great things about this school. We are so lucky to have this as a choice for District 2. We weren't feeling the vibe at our zoned school in midtown east. When we were offered a spot at 150, it was an easy choice to make. We love the vibrant, passionate and active parent body. The class sizes can be large but the teachers, assistants and aides are fantastic at keeping it organized. The curriculum is very well-rounded (in both academics and arts). There is a social-emotional emphasis that is infused with the learning - something that most of the schools we toured didn't really address. Recently, there was a workshop on how parents can support some of the learnings from school based on the Responsive Classroom approach. I am happy that there was a switch to Math in Focus (Singapore Math) that most schools in District 2 do not offer. (Thank you Jenny and PTA) Technology is integrated as a tool for learning and communication. The kindergartener’s have been introduced to Tweeting and Twitter! Amazing. All these elements combined make me more confident that PS 150 is laying a strong foundation for our child's education and future.

I'm also from midtown east and considering PS 150 and would appreciate your experience with the commute.
How did it affect your child - socially and simply in terms of energy level and amount of "down time" he or she has. Please share.
Thank You,
Barbara

I hope you can join PS 150! The commute was not bad since we drove in the morning. Even with public transport, it was about 40 minutes each way.  I have to say though the "down time" is associated with the amount after school activities you may have you child enrolled more than the commute time to the school.  I had my child in about 2 days of after school activities the first year to start. In Kindergarten, my child was very tired the first few weeks but got used to the schedule. Children are very adaptable. Good luck!

While our school lunch is more than fine, I wouldn't list our "excellent nutrition program" as "What's special". 

Where to start? There is much to say...

PS 150
-hires assistant teachers in every class (paid for by parents)
-out runs track teams from bigger schools
-adopted Singapore math to address the Common Core (yea! no more TERC!)
-loves its strong community of volunteers and supportive parents
-sends 5th graders on two night trip to Frost Valley, PA
-shares Taste of Tribeca with PS 234 to raise money for arts & enrichment
-has a principal that really opens her door to parents
-sings on the steps for Halloween (yes, costumes for all)
-matches every new child with an upper grade buddy
-performs on the main stage at the Tribeca Film Festival Family Day (yes, we all fit)
-stresses recycling and runs the biggest rummage sale in Tribeca
-creates a new Broadway-like show every spring (Pre-K - 5th grade all dance & sing)
-performs well on state exams without teaching to the test 
-conducts monthly WHAM veggie taste tests (carrot vs. radish this month)

-has a PTA with close relationships to CB1, District 2's CEC and elected officials 

-hosts Science Day each year (new - hydroponics in Pre-K)
-stresses Responsive Classrooms and becoming G.R.E.A.T. citizens
-remembers those less fortunate during our food, toy & coin drives
-enjoys field trips and hands on learning in all 5 boroughs 

-embraces technology using MacBooks, iPads and SmartBoards
-orders latest books for well stocked library 
-brings well loved performer, Bill Gordh, for storytelling workshop each winter 
-consistently sends kids off to top middle schools
-5th graders leave our school knowing how to ballroom dance (see movie Mad Hot Ballroom)
-structures learning around content studies such as snakes, bridges & Greek mythology
-invites parents into class for regular publishing parties to share writing pieces with all
-loves food, pot luck gatherings and bake sales (with healthy treats included) of course!



If you are zoned for PS 89, PS 234, PS 276, Spruce or Peck Slip you can apply to our school with priority.  Don't forget to take a tour and list us #1 if you want a K seat at our amazing little school.

PS 150 is a diamond in the rough!  I have two children in the school and there is much more to love than the food.  This review paints a totally misleading picture.

The above review comments on the large class size feeling "unwieldy"--but it doesn't mention how we have assistant teachers which reduce the teacher-student ratio compared to other schools in the neighborhood.

The review says that Grades 3 - 5 visit the science lab 3 times a week.  But it should also be known that our K - 2 students have science each week as well.

And with regards to the switch to Math In Focus, the review talks about the perceived challenges for the kids.  There are new challenges with any new program that is implemented.  What the review fails to highlight is that the majority of parents wanted this math program and overall everyone is happy with the change.  

In addition, we have strong content studies in each grade as well as a great arts and music program.  These are tied together in an Arts Festival at the end of the school year in which all the grades participate.

My kids look forward to going to school and in part that is thanks to the support of the wonderful PS 150 community.

PS 150 in Tribeca is such a secret gem, one wonders whether to write about it all—but, it deserves to have it praises sung. 
Too small to be a zoned school, it's a "choice school," that is, anyone 
from District 2 can apply. Our zoned option in Chelsea did not feel like
 the right fit for us. In comparison, the small size (one class per 
grade) and progressive style (teacher's are called by first name) of PS 
150 seemed very attractive. Despite the legendary 'lottery' to get in, 
when we applied in June, there was space. Three months in, we feel lucky. Music, art, and animals in the classroom, outdoor play in the courtyard. It does have a definitive feel to it—and it's too small to fade into the background if you're not a participator. But if you do want to play a role in your child's education, here is a school where they listen.

The Department of Education dropped its controversial plan to move PS 150 to a new location in Chelsea after parents protested. Read more <a href="http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20130903/tribeca/doe-drops-controversial-plan-move-tribecas-ps-150-chelsea">here</a..
PS 150 will have additional kindergarten classes this fall to accommodate wait-listed students from the neighborhood. Read more here.

Principal Bonnet and the PS 150 PTA have opted to stop using the Invest­igations math program popular in many downtown elementary schools in favor of the more traditional Math in Focus program. Read more here.
School staff from PS 150 recently sent a letter to the school's parents explaining why most of them support the plans to move the school to Chelsea. Read the letter here.
PS 150 parents tell DOE officials they won't move to Chelsea. Read more: PS 150 Parents Tell DOE Officials They Won't Go to Chelsea.

Some parents at PS 150 are upset at DOE plans to move the school to a larger building that it would share with the new Foundling Elementary School in Chelsea beginning in September 2014. Read more here.
Students, staff and parents say they eat very well at PS 150. Read more: This Could Be the Foodiest School in New York.
PS 150 kindergartners learn to tweet. Read more: Tweet, Tweet Go the Kindergartners.
Downtown Express announces that Maggie Siena will become the principal of a new Peck Slip school in fall 2012. Read more: Peck Slip school gets new seats, new principal.
Students from the kindergarten class at PS 150 during 9/11 recall their experience: The kindergarten class of P.S. 150 remembers.
"I can know all the kids and I think I know most of them pretty well. This is like the little red schoolhouse - the kids they sit down with in kindergarten, they'll graduate 5th grade with."
“In this world of standardized testing and teaching, a lot of the curriculum is similar. Our school is doing a great job of making it an individualized experience for children.”
“The principal is absolutely accessible. Her door is open all the time.“
“We go on play dates to two room tenement apartments in Chinatown and to the most opulent house you can imagine. They really try to keep some diversity.”
"I love it. We're new to the school. We love this kind of a family school where everyone kind of knows your name eventually."

"PS 150 is a great school and the teachers keep you engaged," writes 5th grader Nicholas with his mother Rebecca. "They do stuff that is fun so that you won't get tired. They also motivate us so that we want to do more. The teachers are nice to the kids and they have great lunch and breakfast and a good after school program. They have so many sports. Science is also really interesting because we get to learn ahead. The school is great because it is small. Everyone gets the personal attention they need and deserve. When the recess people ban stuff like soccer it is good because we have to think of new games to play. Everybody will play the game and then we make new friends. The teachers have a funny side and then they are able to make kids get back in to what's going on. The school has good computers like laptops. I wish I had one. PS 150 is a very welcoming place. Even if you are new to the school they take care of you. P.S 150 is a great elementary school and it helps you prepare for middle school."

"TLC has been a warm, friendly, and welcoming school," writes student Lily, who has been at the school for seven years, since pre-kindergarten. "The principal always knows everybody's name and there is only one class per grade so you always know the people in your class. I am honored to have attended such a wonderful school and I am so sad to have to leave."

A parent writes: "PS 150 4th-graders earned the city's number-one ranking in mathematics for their school." She continues: "As my child's second year at this school comes to an end, I can say that you really can believe it when you hear that PS 150 is like a second family. The small size creates an intimate setting where parents are encouraged to get involved and be part of the community." In response to previous comments, she writes: "The lack of a jungle gym has no bearing since the children run around in an open plaza and have a ball doing so. PS 150 has been referred to as the hidden gem of Tribeca, and I am a believer!"

A parent of a pre-K student at the school writes: "Our experience at PS 150 has been 100% positive. This is a nurturing school with experienced teachers. The principal is hands-on and knows each child by name. The only drawback I can see so far is the lack of a gym, but the children play outside on the plaza when at all possible and the little ones go to the playground in Washington Market Park in good weather." She adds: "One of the very best things about PS 150 is the very active parent body. Parents are encouraged to participate in many areas of school life. The PTA raises funds for the 'extra' enrichment activities that make PS 150 a special place to go to school."

A parent writes, "Our son has been going to PS 150 since kindergarten (he's now in the fourth grade), and it's been a terrific experience for him. The school's small size means all the teachers and the principal know all the kids--their strengths, their needs, and their personalities. I very much appreciate the individualized attention the students receive, which is particularly important for a kid with ADHD. The parents are actively involved and help provide valuable resources to supplement the learning environment. Academically, the school excels; all the students in my son's fourth grade class just scored at Level 3 or 4 of the ELA. It's a very nurturing place, and we'll miss it when he graduates next year."

A parent writes, "Your review makes it sound like lunch is the best thing about this school. Not so." She continues, "there's no mention of the science class, which all students take once a week beginning in the 3rd grade. The computer room is brand-new. The kids play out on the plaza at recess, which at first may seem not as good as a playground, but actually it's good because kids need to use their imaginations to invent games to play. ... Often (maybe once or twice a week in the spring) the kids will be taken to the new playground at Washington Market Park." She says PS 150 is "a pretty good school" that puts "too much emphasis on testing," but adds that "that's probably a system-wide problem." She notes that "the parent body is pretty close-knit, and we have a good turnout at many fundraising events, such as the Taste of Tribeca and the annual auction."
Yorkville Community School's approach to building shared experiences is featured in a Showcase Schools video.

My son has been at the school since Kindergarten and is graduating this month. It's been a great experience. Like many of his classmates he will be moving on to East Side Middle School and we feel that the school did a terrific job at preparing him and his friends for what's to come. The teachers are nurturing but push the kids hard and really help them be the best they can be. The art and music programs at the school will also be missed. He was a member of the 4th and 5th grade band and the music he learned was very impressive, really helping to enhance and enrich his education. We will also miss the small class sizes and the intimate atmosphere. Anyway, we really highly recommend the school. Just learned that it has been designated a Showcase School for a second year in a row in a very competitive atmosphere, so...go YCS!!

My daughter joined the school in Kindergarten and is now in first grade. We couldn't be more pleased with this terrific school. The academics are top-notch and she is reading at third grade level. The class sizes are small - there were 18 kids in her Kindergarten and there are 21 in her first grade class. In addition, the facilities are exceptional. We have two yards and soon will have a rooftop playground and garden. The school also boasts a beautiful library, a computer lab, science lab,  music room and dance studio. I am also very impressed with the enrichment programs, generously funded by an active and passionate PTA. The children learn chess in the classroom, receive visual and performing arts instruction from the 92nd Street Y, and in the older grades, learn about the U.S. Constitution through an enrichment program called Constitution Works. While other public schools in the area are also reputable, none have the small class size that PS 151 has and most do not have the facilities that we do. I hope that as the school gets better known and all the new apartment building construction in the zone is completed, that it will become increasingly popular and admired. I think it's certainly on its way. I hope you consider this school!
"I developed this school taking all the passion and energy I have to offer something good to children" Principal Samatha Kaplan told DNAinfo. Read the full interview here.

This is an amazing school. My son graduated last year from YCS and doing great in his new middle school. YCS helps  students to become independent, curious, welcoming, intelligent and well rounded over all.
I currently have a 4th grader and she loves her school.
There is a strong sense of community and everyone takes pride in their school.
We have a very active parent body which is a gret thing. Our principal, A/P, administration, staff, and all the teachers put Kids first!!!
This is a great school overall.

Hello, I'm a current parent at YCS and on the PTA. Our school is a vibrant and diverse elementary school with an exceptional principal, great teachers and an engaged PTA. We have recently received "Showcase School" status by the DOE for our innovative practices and integrated thematic units. We also recently won $500,000 in city funds to build a rooftop garden. Thanks to the PTA and grants garnered by our principal, there are shared Chrome Books for every class, smart boards in every classroom, and laptops in the library. Enrichment programs funded by the PTA include: visual arts, dance, and drama through partnership with the 92nd Street Y, project-based building projects in STEM fields, mock trials and field trips to the Supreme Court with Constitution Works, hands-on learning with maps/art/artifacts to understand what shapes history with the NY Historical Society, and chess programs with ChessNYC. I couldn't be more happy to be part of this community. Join us in building something great together!
Hello, considering sending my daughter to this school.  Any further thoughts?  Is the curriculum rigorous?  Thank you.
We are considering moving to the area and would like parent opinions on ps 151.  I am a bit nervous about a new school that isn't fully functioning yet.  Thanks!
In it's new location on E. 88th Street, the school now has it's own outdoor play space, plus an on-site after-school program provided by Wingspan Arts.

WNYC reports on school fundraising, noting that wealthier schools like PS 151, PS 10, PS 163 and PS 40 can raise more money for supplemental programs than schools with poorer students. Read more: For Some Schools, Tight Budgets Mean More from Parents.

Does anyone know about the special ed program and the 12:1:1 program. I live nearby and I am thinking of moving my son in from a private school given that we live so close and that the school has such a good reputations.
I have a child in the special ed program and could not be happier.  The teacher and aides are great and the principal has made intergration as appropriate a priority.

I moved my son to YCS in first grade from a private school, that being said, I love the school. I have an older daughter in private school, 4th grade, and comparing the circulium it is the same.  It has a very warm feeling and it is wonderful to physically drop and pick up, directly to and from their teacher. The principal is there as well so any quick messages or feed back is always available.  I feel in a few years time, this will be the new hot school, given the buzz and it helps the classroom sizes are small, 19 kids and very motivated, educated and loving teachers
According to our state assemblyman and city councilwoman, ps 151 will be moving to a permanent home on E. 88th Street between 1st and York Ave in September 2011.
See the post about this on the InsideSCOOP: http://insideschools.org/blog/.../
Please update the article. Thanks.

My son joined PS 151 half way through the academic year when we moved to New York from overseas.  The principal took the time to talk to me extensively about the school and their vision.  Both Ms. Kaplan and my son's wonderful teachers were so supportive in what was a huge transition for him.  Coming from an educational system that was very different to the US my son went from not reading at all to reading above grade level within two months of attending PS 151.  This is an amazing school filled with talented and committed educators, engaged parents and happy kids.
If you're worried about children not expending energy during the day because there's no outside yard, don't. They get plenty of activity. By the end of the day they're happy and exhausted.

My son attends P.S. 151 and is thriving! He entered school knowing his ABC's and is now reading and writing them. We are thrilled with the principal, love the teachers and all the school offers. Chess, music, art EVERYDAY, physical education at Asphalt Green - there are days that we have to pinch ourselves - it really is too good to be true!

My son joined PS 151 half way through the academic year when we moved to New York from overseas. The principal took the time to talk to me extensively about the school and their vision. Both Ms. Kaplan and my son's wonderful teachers were so supportive in what was a huge transition for him. Coming from an educational system that was very different to the US my son went from not reading at all to reading above grade level within two months of attending PS 151. This is an amazing school filled with talented and committed educators, engaged parents and happy kids.
If you're worried about children not expending energy during the day because there's no outside yard, don't.  They get plenty of activity.  By the end of the day they're happy and exhausted.

My son attends P.S. 151 and is thriving! He entered school knowing his ABC's and is now reading and writing them. We are thrilled with the principal, love the teachers and all the school offers. Chess, music, art EVERYDAY, physical education at Asphalt Green - there are days that we have to pinch ourselves - it really is too good to be true!

It is EXTREMELY disturbing to me that this school is being praised for it's special education support!  This couldn't be further from the truth!!! This school a horrific place for special education as the school is basically intolerant of any child who learns differently! Ask 99% of the parents who have or have had special needs kids there! The school has a history of not only ignoring the needs of such children (and just pushing them through the system, etc.) but they've also caused tremendous damage to many, including my own kids! There really should be a class action suit against this horrible corrupt place...SO surprised that there hasn't been already!!!

Overall PS 158 is a fantastic school and my kid loves it.

Sure nothing is perfect (more below), but the school does a great job. I have a child at another elementary school school G&T. The schools are very different with extra things like arts and science, but the classroom work here is as good as and probably better than what is supposed to be the more advanced school.

Teachers are warm and  make the day fun while kids learn. There are many activities and outside the classroom things that the kids do like a great library and even a clown class for younger kids.

There is one BIG negative but mostly a problem for parents and not kids. The main office is AWFUL. It is run by a secretary who is totally rude to parents. It is very uncomfortable to go there if you have to pick up your kid early and even worse if you have a question to ask. She clearly has been given too much power and uses it to cast a shadow over the rest of the great people at the school.

My 2 kids have had a great experience at PS 158.  They have made many friends and flourished in particular as readers and writers.  The new principal (formerly the AP), Dina Ercolano, is giving the school a friendlier, more kid-centric vibe.  Dedicated teachers.

As a parent of two students at PS 158 (oldest in 4th grade), I can say that our experience has been fantastic here - both children have excelled educationally and socially and love going to school every day. We've found our teachers to be great at building a classroom community where our kids feel comfortable and learn often in small groups at the right pace for them.


This year is the first for the new principal, who was the assistant principal for many years before moving up. As a parent of PS 158 students herself, she already has shown that she is taking what was strong under the former principal (great teachers, strong academics) and adding a new feel to the school with things like school spirit days and a reduction on the focus of the state tests.


Overall, even though both kids qualified for G&T (like many of our friends' kids), we stayed at PS 158 because our kids LOVE it, they are getting smarter every day(!) and our experience with teachers has been great.

Look under Academics too.  Now compare some of the stats from 158 to other so-called "comparable" schools to 158-elememtary and middle schools.  

Happy Holidays to all!  Peace, love, health and joy!

Simply go to the INSIDE SCHOOLS-fact check on "School Vibe"-look at some of the numbers there.  This data begins to tell the story of the school.  This school has a FULL-TIME school social worker, school psychologist.  guidance counselor and assistant principal ( any one of these positions are craved by many NYC public schools! ) yet discipline matters are (most often) handled by the parent coordinator?!?  I stand by my claim that many of the teachers are inexperienced and not able to handle the behavior issues which arise in the classroom.  

(side note to Arlene- Please be reassured  I am neither  unhappy nor terribly insecure, just VERY disappointed with PS 158.  Children deserve a better "social emotional" experience than they can get at 158.)

This school symbolizes what is wrong with ranking systems!  So-they do well on State tests; what would the scores be if 99% of the students did not see outside private tutors or were "home schooled" by their pilot parents??!  The teaching staff-save for a few-are in constant turn-over.  The young woman are often immature and self-absorbed (check out Miss Teacher Chic-the instagram account of one of the "Master Teachers").  The teachers are often more consumed with wedding plans and showers than with the students in their classroom!  (IN fact, one year 3 or 4 took off on SCHOOL days to attend the destination bridal shower of another).  These are hardly professionals!  They are often overwhelmed by behavior yet seem only to notice when the rude outbursts are directed at them and not at other students.  For instance, the only time the FULL-TIME Social Worker (yes this school has a FT Social worker) came into a classroom was because one of the teachers felt disrespected by some students. As another student said to the social worker "why not come here when they disrespect us-why is this just about the teacher?".  All in all-not a child-centric school.

You are 100% right about the blind eye the administration and staff turn on student to student disrespect and behavior issues.  It is extremely disappointing and frustrating to many parents.  The school is breeding an environment that is harmful and inappropriate.  More parents need to get the Chancellor and DOE involved to make a change.
You and others should contact the Office of Youth Development and Safety at the DOE.
A PS 158 parent, along with others, voices concern over the NYPD's disbandment of its school emergency response unit. Read more here.

If it rains and the kids have to spend recess in the cafeteria, the cafeteria aide puts in a movie. The kids get to watch about 20 minutes of it. If it rains again the next day, the same woman puts in the same movie. She starts it from the beginning. The kids watch the same 20 minutes of it. If it rains yet again on the third day, again she pops the same movie in from the beginning and for the third time in a row, the kids spend their recess watching the first 20 minutes of the same movie. I bring this up because it's a metaphor for how the entire school is run. The Academics are strong and there are some very amazing teachers (yet that's inconsistent) and the administration runs it without much heart.

As the mother of a child who just finished K, I am happy with the teachers and the parents' association, and the education, but it is true that the principal is cold and uncommunicative.. She doesn't interact with the parents OR the students.

I am a PS 158 mom and have been extremely happy with the school K-2. Once the state testing begins though it's a completely different story. In the inside schools review above, it states that kids who need extra help are encouraged to come for test prep on Saturdays. That's not the case. Kids are required to attend test prep sessions either several days a week before class, after school or on Saturday mornings. If it isn't mandatory it certainly feels mandatory--for all children. Not just those who need extra help. And this is in addition to the 3-4 periods a day spent focusing on the test. I personally know of 5 children who have seen psychologists in 3rd or 4th grade due to anxiety or school refusal because PS 158 puts so much emphasis and focus on this test and the 8 year olds simply cannot handle it. A note was sent home the night before the ELA test began saying to the parents and kids "Eat a healthy breakfast, wear comfortable clothes, get a good night's rest, don't have them wear jewelry or hair accessories that could be distracting to other students, etc." It is very obvious that the teachers and/or Principal are incentivized based on the students' scores. Our teachers have been wonderful from K-2 but there is a big shift with regard to workload and just general warmth/compassion after the lower grades. Whereas in the earlier years, the teachers had webpages for the class and happily gave out their email addresses, that doesn't seem to be consistently true. Some teachers prefer to only be communicated with via the homework folder which not only feels cold but also makes it tough during extenuating circumstances.

All in all, I can't say that I wholeheartedly recommend this school.
Is this a zoned school? Can parents put their children in or are there no seats left for people outside the zone?
I don't believe there any district 2 schools that offer seats to unzoned students (not counting unzoned siblings).

Can a young boy or girl have a good education and a bad 'childhood' experience?
 I'm reading all about how the ADULTS feel about the school and their children getting good grades; what about a childhood experience? 
And, I see lots of lower grade parents comments where sure, a 4 or 5 year old is still having Pre K and K fun and, not experiencing the 3rd and 4th grade ELA pressure.

Can a child get good grades and still be a child? That is the challenge and, if you are willing to risk your kid's experience as a child, then go right ahead to PS 158. 
Speak to the children and you will learn many of them could not tell you where the Met or the Guggenheim are located. Ask them if they can run in the play yard. Ask them how often they go on a 'class trip' 1/2 block away to the park or to Central Park?

Sadly, tragically, some of them do not even know these things are important to experience. 
Parents, these things are important for kids to experience. 
And please stop being an apologist by stating that geez, there are 700 kids and grades are good so they must be doing a good job. It is a false choice. There are many shades of grey and a good, thoughtful leader always strives to maintain a balance between extremes.  

Congratulations to the school for its good scores. Keep in mind, it is the UES with high parent involvement and low poverty so, keep the scores in context.

The Department of Education recently confirmed that a new middle school planned for PS 158's empty space will admit students based on a controversial process that many parents have protested: DOE Approves Controversial Admissions Plan for New UES Middle School .
There is controversy over admissions and plans about placing a new middle school in the vacant space in PS 158: Controversy Lingers Over City's Admissions Criteria at New UES School.
After a challenging period of co-location with a charter school, parents of students at PS 158 say they do not want another charter school to be moved to their building. Read more here.

We are new to PS 158 with a child in kindergarten.  So far we are very pleased.  Communication coming from our child's teacher, the principal and the extremely committed Parents' Association is outstanding.  

We know that in the past others have spoken about the principal being cold, but we wanted to comment that this has not been our experience so far at all.  We knew this going in so have made a special point to be open-minded and take the chance to get to know her a little bit.  In fact, when we were registering in Spring 2012 she stopped and engaged us in conversation in the Main Office saying how pleased she was that we would be joining the school community.  She is always outside of her office at drop off, making sure everything is running smoothly and the children are going to their classrooms.  Obviously she has a lot of responsibility overseeing the physical plant, all of the teachers and staff and, above all else, the safety of our children.  In light of Hurricane Sandy and the terrible events in Newtown this fall, she has communicated with families multiple times about the school's emergency procedures and available resources (psychologists, etc.).  We feel that we could speak with her at any time.  She sent home a very warm letter after the holidays welcoming families back after break, mentioning a word about how she spent her own holidays and setting forth what was ahead in a number of areas.  She sends home notes in backpacks with the right regularity on relevant matters.  

Shortly we will meet with Darryl about the curriculum in kindergarten.  Unsolicited (as far as we know), she has set up this meeting for parents and requested questions in advance.  Our family finds her to be extremely inclusive.

Regarding our child's teacher, we love her.  She has a Master's in literacy (how perfect for kindergarten) and is just the best.  A seasoned professional who is proactive, engaged and loving (which in kindergarten is important as you want them to get the occasional hug or special word of encouragement), but she is very firm, too - in a good way as the little ones can from time to time squirm around, be impatient with friends, etc.  Just the right combination we feel for this age.  We are very happy.  

No experience yet with testing, but our view is that it is a fact of life and here to stay so why wouldn't the school devote resources so that students can perform at their best?  This is exactly the type of proactive environment we seek for our child.

There are numerous speciality classes, even in kindergarten - Spanish, art, music, science, library/media center, physical education, six weeks of chess in the late fall, etc.  Family reading and math mornings occur twice a month where you can spend 30 minutes with your child in the classroom.  On a separate parent observation morning we saw firsthand how our children spend their time.  It was a great glimpse into their learning.  Field trips are scheduled that relate to the curriculum (unfortunately two had to be cancelled in the wake of Hurricane Sandy, but two more have been held since).  Each class has I-Pads, a smart board and other state-of-the-art technology.  The library/media center is very impressive.  Library books are new and never have a ripped page or tear.  Plenty of books in the classroom.

No experience with Club 158, the after school program, but its offerings are extensive and impressive and from what we've heard families are very pleased.

We feel our child's education is off to a great start at 158.  Sure the school is big, but there is a large gym, a yard for recess and an auditorium (not all schools are able to devote space to these resources).  The school is spotless.  You never, ever see a speck of trash anywhere.  Certain areas were painted over the holidays (I thought it was fine beforehand!).

Obviously satisfaction really comes down to how happy one is year to year with the teachers and your child's progress.  So far, so good and we are very encouraged.  Clearly this school seems to be on a good path during challenging times.  We are glad that we didn't bus our child two or more hours a day to a downtown G&T program.  It was a hard choice for us, but we felt it would have been too much at least initially at such a young age for our particular child who tires easily (not commenting on anyone else's child or decision here).  If this is a decision you ultimately have to make, know from one family that four months into the year we can say we made the right decision for us.
The principal is cold and indifferent if you disagree with her policies
The principal is indifferent and cold if you happen to disagree with her policies.
http://www.nytimes.com/2002/09/29/nyregion/fingers-crossed.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm

I am delighted at the overall environment, high educational standards and the selection of after school activities that have been enriching her life at PS 158. My daughter has made numerous friends at the school in her kindergarten and 1st grade class. The kids are a cohesive group (in my experience), and the busy parents of my daughter's classmates stay quite involved to help ensure the success of their children

As a new parent of a child in Kindergarten at P.S. 158, I am pleasantly surprised and quite content with the school and how much my child has learned so far this year.  In fact my child has learned way more than my other child did who is in a private school.  I praise my child's teacher who displays consistent patience, warmth, kindness but with the right amount of discipline to earn her respect from all the children and parents of the class.  P.S. 158 offers numerous choices of after school activities, and the PA is outstanding. We hope that other families will consider P.S. 158 as a wonderful school for our children.

I am a proud 158 parent with two kids currently in the school.  I can not say enough wonderful things about the 158 environment.  My children always feel safe, loved and respected.  The teachers are incredibly devoted and also reachable.  The school has one of the most active P.A.'s.  The P.A. funds some of the most wonderful, diverse programs including Circus Arts and Ballroom dancing.  My kids are unquestionably getting a well rounded education in a very secure atmosphere.

I am a parent of 2 children at the school and can only say awful things about the principal who is running this school into the ground!  The P.A. is outstanding and the families of 158 have created a wonderful community for the children and parents combined.  This principal only cares about test scores and nothing will stand in her way - she will fire teachers, leave children back a grade and so on... all so her precious test scores do not suffer!  She is a liar and a vicious grudge-holding person who only serves to hurt the children at the school.  And her response to why she doesn't teach handwriting and spelling is that she feels they our children will be texting instead of writing anyway - ABSOLUTELY INEXCUSABLE for an educator.

you are so right..They don't pay attention to the children..And she does hold grudges..My kids are falling behind...And they are not doing anything about it..Other parents have complaint.and if you do complain ...they will keep your kids back..I live around the corner....

PS 158 is an amazing school and we are lucky and privileged to have our child in 1st grade there.  The principal runs the school as it should be run and that is why the school is so great...a testament to her skills and management style.  The curriculum is fantastic, there is plenty of help for kids that need it, and the school is filled with loving and intelligent teachers.  The administrative staff is wonderful, and the parent participation that this school allows is amazing...It's important to remember that this is FREE education for our kids and if we have been given the opportunity to send our kids to a fantastic FREE school, which saves us $30K/year, AND the kids are getting a great education, and love going to school every day,  then we should all be thankful for just how lucky we are.

While it is free, education is a right in this country and its quality should be high.  We are tainted by the fact that so many people choose to send their kids to private school and forget that education is a right.

I am a parent of 2 students at PS 158 and we LOVE the school.  The PreK teacher 
is warm and loving, manages the classroom well and differentiates instruction 
so that kids can be learning at their own level.  Kindergarten teacher was 
amazing in getting children to read and write, including creating their own 10 page booklets with table of contents and "about the author" pages.  The administration really focuses on each child to make sure that all are getting a great education.  My kids enjoy the art, science, music, world cultures and other specials at the school.  The families are down to earth and really nice, and the parents association has got to be among the best in the district.

I have NOTHING but positive comments for PS158 and the education my child is receiving under Darryl Alhadeff and her wonderful staff of teachers. Their test scores actually beat a gifted & talented school (lower Lab), have unrivaled enrichment (spanish in K, Circus Arts in 1st, Ballet Hispanico, etc, etc...) the intervention children receive as they need it, the incredible dedication the Principal and her staff have to the success of this school and students is amongst the best and tops many on the the UES.  For those complaining about a woman and her administration whose prime focus is on the STUDENTS, TEACHER enrichment & development,  may want to readjust their expectations of an elementary school experience and the results as they leave 5th grade.  I don't know how you are speaking to Prinicipal Alhadeff or what your demands are of her, but the parents and teachers I know respect her authority and find her quite smart, passionate and reasonable. Instead of writing  complaints in these blogs I suggest you contact her and request a meeting if there is something that needs her immediate attention.  Mrs Alhadeff is ALWAYS there; in her office, meetings, classrooms, fighting on our behalf.  I think the QUALITY OF THE TEACHERS, test scores, incredible parent involvement, enrichment, & facilities (not to mention the incredible new media center) are all a credit to Darryl Alhadeff and her staff.
Thank you for all the comments on the principal.  But what about the academics?  Extra curricula?  Is ps158 a viable public option?  Thanks!
just horrible
You should spell the Assistant Principal's name correctly, if you are going to make the claim that the school is weak in teaching spelling.  It is Ercolano.
Fair enough. Thanks for the tip. We've corrected the error.

I love the principal, is a woman who gives everything for the school, is very professional, and them extremely intelligent, maybe she is not understood as she deserves, at first I had a misconception of her, and I even thought that there was a favoritism in the school, but to see my child's academic growth, I know in my heart that behind excellent teachers must have an excellent principal and I understood that it is she who fight for our children reach high standards of education . I adore her, and I love that requires and is strictest, I hope the ministry of education hire more people like her.

Here's what I don't understand: the parents don't like the principal, correct? Why don't they boot her?  Why the heck would you feel comfortable sending your child to a school that is so poorly run?  Not only does the principal have terrible communication with the parents AND their children, but she is also thoroughly disliked by her staff because she shows irresponsibility with them, as well.  This woman was run out of P.S.87 because she was so awful; why let her run P.S.158? Get her out!

I agree.She literally lied to me when i confronted her regarding an incident with my son in the bathroom and kids were going under the bathroom stall looking at my sons privates...She keeps grudges..I had taken my daughter out before,and put her back in because of personal issues....She would not even listen to my concerns..Instead had teachers make false accusations..when I have a report telling my son that he is well mannered in school..She then threatened me...because I told her that what she is saying is false and I will report her and bring it to social the media or the board of ed..she flipped out and threatened me..

Because many parents are VERY happy with the state of the school.  Principal Alhedeff has her challenges but also many outstanding strengths, and most children are thriving in the school.  The teachers are wonderful, I feel it is an incredibly well run school that serves a diverse, 700 student population.  My gratitude is great to every person that goes to work at 158 each day.

It is such a big school and Principal Alhedeff is concerned with keeping the school open by keeping the test scores up. A lot of people don't understand that Alhedeff is mainly administrative now in function. She has been principal for so long that actual classroom specifics no longer concerns her. I think as the government changes its policies, you'll see changes in all of the school's priorities.

While this may seem unbelievable in this forum where parents are desperately trying to discredit Principal Alhedeff, I am going to compliment her. I have had to approach her on several occasions regarding school issues in general and my children's issues in particular. During each meeting she was cordial, professional and attended to my needs. Our meetings weren't filled with gratuitous niceties, but who cares? She is running a school of more than 700 children. Does she really have to be nice about whiny moms? 

These mothers think it is their god-given right to storm the principal's office and make demands. Their behavior and the disservice they do to their children - the marshmallow generation- is scary. It seems the ranting here comes from a group of ALPHA MOMS with a false sense of entitlement. They want to tell everyone how to do their jobs. If I were the Principal of PS 158 and had to contend with these mothers on a daily basis, I too would be a bit standoffish and grumpy. Why are we so concerned about her bed-side manner? Why are WOMEN expected to be cheery and smile all the time? We wouldn't dare demand the same of a male principal, would we? We parents should help where and when we can, support the school in any way possible and leave the administration to do their job. By the way, the Assistant Principal does a great job too!

I find these comments surprising.  We just moved to the school from out of state last year with children in two different grades.  We have had an exceptional experience.  Principal Alhedeff may not be the warmest, but she has managed to amass an very talented group of educators who deliver a comprehensive and challenging curriculum to over 700 students, and she happens to have said hello and smiled every time I have passed her in the halls.  The parent association is amazing and if you don't feel the warmth from the Principal, you will from the parents and the parent association.  I can't speak for anyone else, but we could not be more happy (and my children also love their school).

It is unfortunate that Principal Alhedeff has succeeded in destroying what was once a vibrant and excellent public elementary school.  Before she was officially hired,  a faction of the Executive Board of the Parents' Association tried to actively dispute her approval, but ultimately was overruled.  I was fortunate in that one child had graduated before she came and another only had to suffer through 1 year of her reign.  At graduation,  she did not seem to know any of the children personally.  It seems that the DOE has another casualty in PS 158.  Too bad...
Why is Principal Darryl Alhadeff allowed to remain after hundreds of complaints. It seems the vote againt her is unanimous.
lets vote..

Parent comment : Very defensive and unapproachable principal. Out of her element when interacting with parents and children. Seems this is the same given the teachers feedback. I wonder how she keeps her position, I guess that's what the teachers union is all about. My child has been in 158 for 4 yrs and I don't have any positive feedback to share on Alhadeff.

The PS 158 principal, Darryl Alhadeff, is an incompetent, nasty, terrorizing principal. She systematically chooses different teachers each year and begins a campaign of selective persecution to remove them from the school. This includes tenured and non-tenured teachers. She makes up her own truth and has ruined many careers for no reason other than the teacher's desire to be creative and teach to the child. She has created an atmosphere where teachers rat each other out and backstab each other in order to stay on her good side and the children are paying the price. The only content taught in this school is whatever is related to the state tests. For example, there is NO social studies taught above 2nd grade. The parents are terrified to make complaints because she has been known to be vindictive and take her anger toward parents on the children. DOE needs to investigate, get her out, and return this school back to the amazing school it once was. As long as she is principal you should only send your child to this school as a very last resort.
Please investigate this woman.this school...I am a victim so is my children...
Principal Alhedeff gets the students uncomfortable during the time of being introuble and im mot so happy about this

My daughter is in 7th grade at Wagner SP and she has had a great experience. The academics are strong and the teachers are so good. She has made new friends, and finds Wagner to feel like a safe and enjoyable school environment.

My son loves going to school everyday at Wagner, I feel like that never happens! We were initially nervous about it being such a big school, but it is so well run that it doesn't feel big to the kids. The grade specific AP, Dean, and guidance counselor helps provide a smaller school feel and I have always had my questions and needs met. The Wagner community is comprised of high caliber teachers and administrators who want the best for our kids, and understand how to relate to their developmental age. This amazingly caring staff is led by an incredible Principal. We are so happy at Wagner.

I have been so pleasantly surprised by Wagner. I was worried it was too big, heard some negative things, but for us it has been an incredibly positive middle school experience. Our daughter is thriving in band, track team and was transferred into honors math in 6th grade. She made friends, feels safe and loves her school. The principal knows all the kids names and makes the community feel small even tho' it is the largest public middle school in all 5 boroughs. Of course, things go wrong and nothings perfect, but we are thrilled that she is thriving in this community of caring teachers and administrators who want the best for our kids and give their all every single day.

I have had nothing but positive experience as a parent of a student who graduated in 2019 from Wagner Middle School.  My son had a great experience and education at Wagner as did his friends.  The administration is top notch and they are there every step of the way - for students and parents.  While no school is perfect - and you could find fault anywhere - Wagner is a great/safe NYC public school that I whole-heartedly recommend.
