In February, PS 165 hosted its first Math Night. Parents were given an overview of Common Core math, played math games with their children and teachers, and gave everyone a chance to connect outside of the regular school environment. We also raffled away tickets for four to the Museum of Mathematics! Thanks to all the parents, children, volunteers, teachers, and administration for making this event a success!

My daughter is a 2nd grader here and happy to go to school each day. After her last field trip to the Philharmonic she sang back the melodies played.  The best review of the Philharmonic ever.  She gave her teacher the credit for providing the tune, amazing.  There is a lot of dedicated people in that building. I for one am thankful.

This is our 3rd year at PS 165.  Prior to coming to this school, we researched and were put off by the negative comments we read on this site, however, we did our due diligence and toured the school, spoke to other families at the school and their children.  In 2011, we decided to enroll him and have not regretted our decision!  Our son has had wonderful teachers who nurture him, challenged him and keep him engaged.  He looks forward to going to school and misses his teachers and classmates during the school breaks. He is developing wonderfully!  As a plus, socially he has, and continues to, form friendships which we hope last long after our stay at PS 165.  That being said, the comments/complaints some parents have made on this site are not without merit.  PS 165, like so many other schools, can make improvements in certain areas.  However, you will be hard pressed to find any school that does not have their fair share of displeased parents, staff and students.  We know families that have left the school and are now regretting their decision.  So, we strongly encourage you to seek out parents with children in the school; speak to them about their experience and speak with the children if the parents allow it.  Tour the school and get a feel for what life inside PS 165 might be like. PS 165 has been a great fit for our son and for us.  He is learning a great deal and most importantly, he is happy.  There's no reason for us to want to leave; we are staying at PS 165!

My son is in Kindergarten this year at PS 165.  Although I was a bit nervous about the school at the beginning of the year, I am very glad that we stayed at 165.  My son's kindergarten teachers - for his K class, art and music are all top notch.  Caring and great at their respective specialty.  
My son was having a lot of trouble at the beginning of the year with his reading.  Although it was a team effort, it is mostly due to the dedication of his teachers that have made him into a great reader now!

Prospective parents: There will be one more school tour before the Kindergarten Connect deadline!


February 11, 2014, 8:45 AM


Come visit the school and bring your questions!

Having changed schools to move our daughter to PS165, we can honestly say that we are very happy we did. Our daughter is engaged and challenged at school. She has a wonderful teacher and a great group of classmates. The school is improving and will continue to do so thanks to the committed teachers at PS 165.

Prospective parents: please note there are two school tours this month:


Jan 14, 2014, 8:45 AM


Jan 28, 2014, 8:45 AM


Come visit the school and bring your questions!

We are new to this school, and I am happy to say that my child is also having a positive experience at PS 165.

PS/MS 165 has a strong dual-language program and a growing District G&T program. It also received an "A / Well-Developed" grade on its most recent report card, which is not easily earned.

In terms of enrichments, the school has a full time art teacher, FT gym teacher, and two FT music teachers. It has a partnership with the New Victory Theater, and there are five after-school programs.

The school is clean, the classrooms are much larger than new construction DOE buildings. The inner playground re-opened this fall.

The teachers are enthusiastic, and I have found the administration to be accessible and open to discussion for improvements. There is a core group of actively engaged parents working with the PTA and SLT, and we can use your help!

My daughter is having a positive experience at PS 165.  While most public schools have room for improvement, I see 165 heading in the right direction.  The teachers seem qualified and committed to the needs of their students.  The administration is making an effort to work with active parents and the new members of the PTA to make changes that will enhance the school.  The school's website is updated regularly with school info and events: psms165.org.

OK I will be more specific. I am currently not happy with the atmosphere at this school! I have custody of my niece and nephew that are enrolled in this school. As soon as I find a placement for them in another school I I am taking them out. Who is the principal at this school??? Who's in charge? The Dean act as if he runs the school. He thinks he can say what ever he wants to parents. But I was told he doesn't even have a license to work with children! It is something very strange about this school.

We are family with 2 children in PS. 165. One of our children used to be enrolled in a different school, so we have experience of different public schools and we are educators ourselves, albeit in higher education. We are disheartened to see personal attacks and non-constructive comments on the school's administration and principle here. As parents it is our responsibility to empower the school, so leaving anonymous comments, attacking the very people who are responsible for our children's education, care, and well-being, and threatening to abandon the school, is truly not in our children's best interest. We too share some (not all) of the concerns that are voiced here, but believe that pulling children out of the school and/or making damaging statements about their school principle/administration in an online forum is counterproductive. 

As many have already mentioned, the school's teachers are truly exceptional, highly educated, caring, and competent. The school has one of the best dual-language programs in the city. The building itself is beautiful, clean, spacious, and located in a wonderful neighborhood. Our own encounters with the principle have always been cordial and helpful. 

In our view, the few issues that do need immediate attention are as follows:

Solution for the busy and loud lunch-room: fewer classrooms in lunch-room at any given time. Different staff/method for keeping discipline in lunch-room.

One of the school yards, the one which is directly attached to the school has been under construction for far too long, which has not only deprived the kids from play there but has made pickup time rather unpleasant as one has to go to crowded, exceedingly loud gym to fetch the children instead. Please note that there is another school yard, a bigger one which has provided space for play but doesn't have direct access into the school. Solution: expedite the construction in school yard!

While school yard is still under construction, a handicap ramp/access MUST be installed for strollers (as currently entry into school is very arduous if not dangerous for those with strollers).

Having mentioned these few issues, that surely exist in most other schools, we are confident that with a positive frame of mind and a generosity of spirit, we can all help address them. So, instead of demoralizing the principle and her staff, we need to offer our confidence, our time, and our expertise to this exceptional school.

There are many involved parents at the school, and PTA leaders, who have been very vocal and open with the administration about their concerns. People have offered their time, expertise and labor and been rebuffed. Parents have also been communicating with District 3 leadership about their concerns with the administration. I don't want to be rude, but... I have never seen you at a PTA meeting or be involved in any way at the school overall during Ms. Castellano's tenure.

Parent leaders have tried to support the administration, rather than demoralize them, but IT DOES NOT WORK. I agree that an anonymous online forum is not the best way to handle things, but I assure you that the district is well aware of parent concerns expressed here.

We second the notion that the way to create the best learning environment for all is to be involved, along the lines of Albert O. Hirschman's "Exit, Voice, and Loyalty"-- If you care, use your voice and your labor, don't exit. GB (whom we've also not seen at PTA/SLT meetings or involved in other ways) has identified some crucial school needs (thank you), on which we've been working with the principal this past year.  We look forward to GB's "positive frame of mind and a generosity of spirit" -- what those of us who have been participating like to call "hard work"-- starting this summer and next year. Please introduce yourself at our next PTA and SLT meetings and we'll welcome your voice and loyalty.

We are moving our daughter from her current school to enter PS 165 G&T in 1st grade in the fall after turning down a spot there last year. We tried to do a lot of research and speak to a lot of people this year. We are moving to 165 because the G&T program seems GREAT and the G&T teachers seem great. The administration does seem problematic but that is true at many schools.

What's happening at the school is very sad.

PS 165 has: fantastic teachers (however much people will disagree about other stuff, everyone agrees about this); the best spanish dual language program in the district, if not the city; an attractive and growing G and T program; a great building with lots of space, windows and play areas; and is in a great location.

The building administration, however, is appalling: a lot of bravado, lack of professionalism and incompetence. It's not a good combination.

PS 165 has everything to be a truly great urban school, except effective leadership.

Wow, I's so surprised about what I'm reading about PS165.  I was a donor for that school many times. What ever happened to Mr. Gallini and Mr. Villegas?  I used to loved to come in and talked to them about future events.  They always were outside in the morning and dismissal. I can't believe all the comments about the administration.  That used to be one of the school strong session.  Let's hope things can change next year and they don't lose teachers.  Wow

My daughter is currently in the Gifted and Talented program at PS 165 and I feel that I need to find another option next year.  Initially I was thrilled that she were accepted into the program. The leadership under Principal Gallini was second to none. However, it's remarkable that the gains made under Gallini can be undone so quickly under the current administration. The teachers are absolutely top notch and in the classroom I feel she's getting a good education. However, outside the classroom the school is a mess. She fears eating lunch because there seems to be very little supervision in the lunch room. There seems to be very little discipline and interest in addressing the behavior of some of the rowdy students. When I addressed this matter with the principal, I didn't get a call back, email, or any acknowledgement of my concern. I've talked to other parents at the school and their experience is the same. While taking her out and putting her in private school is the last thing I want to do, I really feel I have no choice here. Please come back Principal Gallini

My son is acceped into G&T program in this school and I am trying to get as much information about it as possible. Can you, please tell more about G&T teashers, are they good? what are their names? I am facing 1 hour commute to this school, but I am wiiling to try.

Thank you!

The K G&T teacher Ms. Winnegar is fantastic, the 1/2 teacher Ms. Barret (it was blended this year and there will be separate 1 and 2nd grade classes next year) is also fantastic. Both are smart, committed, caring, and teach to different levels in the class. If you've seen their classrooms and heard them teach on one of the recent tours, you know what we mean.

Yes, I totally agree.  It's the principal and the overall administration, which is the issue. If the teachers leave, which wouldn't surprise me, there would be no reason to send your child to this school.

We have several children in the school and have had personal experience with a number of teachers. Every single teacher we've had for our kids at PS 165 has been excellent:  committed, diligent, caring, communicative, unbelievably hard working, smart, and more.They care deeply about the kids and when we ask other parents about the school, we ask, "Are your kids happy?" Ours invariably are and theirs usually are. We evaluate the school in 4 categories: teachers, parents, admin, physical plant. We rank it as follows: Teachers: A+ Admin: C (with some exceptions, see below); Parents: B (those involved are very much involved but there are many who are not involved because they are working and do not have the time); physical plant: B. The observations  below and of most parents, involved or not, are that the new administration: principal, some assistant principals (though not the AP for the middle school, who seems very good), and "dean" are mediocre. They don't exhibit the leadership, involvement, and abiliies that the parents want ,and they don't communicate or interact with parents well or enough.  That said, they are not horrible (see teacher feedback on principal of PS 87 for that) they are just overwhelmed, bureaucratic, and not that good. The question is how much weight you place on this problem? Clearly the admin should be there to support the great teachers, help them deal with the sickening DoE bureaucracy, and get them what they need to do their job. Currently, the teachers have to do much more with less support to get their job done than they should with a supportive administration. The way to fix this imbalance is for more parents to be involved and to move out this admiistration (which happened two principals ago and that person was really bad). In the private sector, they'd certainly be fired but it would take a review process. . So, we still love the school because we love the teachers and our kids are getting a great education in a truly NYC environment thanks to the teachers here.

One of the biggest mistakes I ever made was sending my daughter to this school. In the year that my daughter has attended this school I have seen the current Principal twice. The teachers are absolutely wonderful but it does not make up for the terrible administration.  I called 2-3 times to speak to the Principal and was hung up on and treated rudely by a lady that answered the phone.  I was calling in regards to an emergency concerning my child and they could care less.  It is a shame because the school has potential but the leadership is lacking. 

 I will be transferring my child out. She will start a new school in the Fall. I'm so disgusted with them that I'm signing her out of school 6 days early.  Do yourself a favor and avoid this school at all costs!

My children go to PS 165 but I have already registered them at another school for next year. The teachers are ALL (every single one I've encountered) top notch, they are not the problem. The real issues lie in the problems that are being trickled down like a domino effect to our children. The source of the problems we all know. The lack of efficient leadership. The principal, Ms. Castellano is no where to be seen or heard of. There's so much potential for this school. The school was at the brink of greatness just one year ago when Mr. Gallini was principal. This shows that all that PS 165 needs is a strong leader, or perhaps simply an efficient one for the school to thrive. The PTA is a small one (due to lack of administration support, many parents just give up), but it is dedicated to achieving greatness in the school. Parents and teachers at PS 165 do most of the heavy duty work, without complaint. We WANT the work of building an ideal educational environment. Once under effective leadership, PS 165 has shown it can stand on its own. Unfortunately, I fear the foundation and strength of the school will (if it isn't already) dismantle very soon. Parents such as myself can't afford to risk and gamble with our children's safety and future. I know the next and predictable outcome will be good teachers leaving. I would love to be able to keep my kids at PS 165, but I don't feel the school administration takes seriously A) the safety of my children and B) the fact that the school has excellent teachers in need of absolutely vital needs not being met. It's embarrassing but also deeply saddening for me. My kids will miss the community, the family that is PS 165.

I am one of a dozen parents I know personally who are pulling our children out of PS 165 because of our dissatisfaction with its principal and administrative staff. The teachers are fantastic, but the principal is distant and disorganized. The school has safety issues-- supervision at dismissal is lacking and and it is chaotic. The principal avoids contact with parents and rarely sees them. Same with her assistants, at least at the elementary level. Communication and scheduling is ridiculous-- events are advertised at the last minute, posters are put up advertising things after the fact, the phone blasts are riddled with errors. The PTA and the few active parents have a difficult time getting cooperation from the administration and there is a sense that the school is very closed off to families. People have complained directly to the principal and they have complained to the superintendent and to the person who is supposed to be our parent advocate. Nothing changes.

I have to say I am appalled by teachers bashing other staff members on this forum. My children go to PS165 and I can not believe some of the things being discussed here. It seems as if the negative comments are personal attacks that should not be on this forum. My children love The DEAN at PS165 the find the dean to be fair and someone who they could go to when they have an issue. My cousin also attended PS165 and remembers The dean as a substitue teacher. But the dean is not to be alone with students. He mentioned that all the kids loved the dean They feel that the dean is very approachable. I am a strong believer if you have something to say about someone you should confront the person and tell them how you feel. If your accusations are substantiated then why worry about a backlash. Lastly shouldn't this forum be encouraging to parents that are looking into this school for their children so why bash your workplace with your opinion. So to parents looking into having their child go to PS165 I have seen it be a very inviting school with wonderful caring teachers (with the exception of the basher who obviously is putting their personal feelings before the schools best interest). The staff goes beyond to make our children as comfortable and confident in their school. Btw Ms.Castellano was a teacher for many years (my cousin was in her class) so who would understand teachers better than a teacher and students best interest. Thank you for reading! Go PS165
When I said the dean is not to be alone I forgot the "??????" I was being sarcastic!
Could someone explain to me why the principal of this school keeps on pushing out GREAT teachers sometimes even in the middle of the year? Does not make sense to me.
Hateful

The New York Post reports that unused school supplies and books were found discarded outside of PS 166. A recycling advocate moved the materials so that others would be able to take them and alerted the school's principal, but soon found that they were put into a black garbage bag out on the curb again.
UPDATE:

As a current 4th grader, I do not have a problem with the school. The teachers are very good, they make you work hard. This has gotten me through the state testing. People easily fit in here, as I have. I really recommend this school to people who are thinking about coming, and to respond all the tension: 
There are no problems to be
seen. The principal is fine and black and Latino people are treated fairly. I
would know, since I am black myself.
 As I said, I really recommend this school and I hope this helped.

After neighborhood preservation group Landmark West joined a lawsuit to block the reconstruction of the 89 Playground, shared by PS 166 and the community, the school's PTA fights back. Read more here.
The battle over the playground adjacent to PS 166 is nearing an end. Read more here.

If some people think the cobblestones in the playground are suddenly a problem, after the design having been there for 60 years, maybe they should just remove them, and leave the overall design of the space alone.  Much cheaper and easier project.
Delays in building a new playground for PS 166 persist, leaving the timeline uncertain. Read more from DNAinfo.
Plans to renovate the "dangerous" playground at PS 166 have stalled again after the city's Public Design Commission removed the project from its August agenda. Read more here.
The plan to renovate the playground at PS 166 has been given the green light by Community Board 7 after weeks of debate amongst community members. Read more here.

Parents concerned about the safety of the playground at PS 166, known as Playground 89. lobbied the Parks Department to launch a $600,000 renovation. Other parents expressed concern that plans for the playground had not been made public. "Parks officials have decided to give the residents more notice before moving forward with removing all three-dimensional obstacles from the playground." Read more at http://observer.com/2013/07/cobblestoned-upper-west-side-parents-declare-war-over-sloped-surfaces/#ixzz2n172rwzM Follow us: @newyorkobserver on Twitter | newyorkobserver on Facebook: Cobblestoned: Upper West Side Parents Declare War Over Sloped Surfaces.

Parents at PS 166 have secured city approval to repair the injury-plagued playground at the school, but they are now facing opposition from other parents who want the new playground designs to undergo a lengthier approval process. Read more here.
Earlier this year, former PS 166 principal Richard Ronga was fired for ordering teachers and staff to fabricate teacher reviews, the NY Post reports.

All my boys are very happy at our local schools in District 14, but one of my sons, who loves to dance and perform, just tested into Citywide G & T and my research leads me to believe that 166 may have the enrichment programs he would love. This would be a very difficult commute for us, but we'd find some way to make it work, if this school could offer him something SPECIAL.  Can anyone who has or has had children in the G&T program offer any advice?  Assuming that there would be a spot for him, would it be worth our trouble to get him to the UWS, or should we keep him at his current school?  In other words, is the performance element of the school strong enough, special enough to take us way out of our neighborhood?
Performance is very strong at Ps 166, but it is not a citywide g&t school. They only accept g&t from district 3. Good luck.
DNAinfo reports that the Parks Department has promised to fix PS 166's playground this summer: Parks Dept Promises to Fix Dangerous PS 166 Playground this Summer

Our older child son went through the G&T program at 166 and we are planning on sending our youngest to the Gen Ed (non-G&T) program. The Gen Ed is very good now. Some of the school's best teachers are Gen Ed teachers and I promise you that the Gen Ed classes get the same resources as the G&T. The G&T system may be flawed (any program which relies on testing 4 year olds is probably flawed), but PS 166 does a good job making it work for all. Love this school!

"If you scream and yell and complain [about] the behavior in the class that they are currently in, it may get your child a seat in the 'gifted and talent program' provided the parents of these children don't find out."  Is this still being done?  I find it unacceptable that the G&T are blended with non-G&T kids. The whole idea is to make sure the G&T kids are not slowed down so that they are challenged.

The tone of your comment grates on me. I'm not sure what you mean by "slowed down" and how at the tender age of 4 you can be sure that it won't be your child who turns out to have the learning disability discovered in 2nd grade or have the sudden burst of Attitude when puberty begins in 5th grade. I am guessing "Finance_Fan" means you work in a profession where such things are kept at bay by sheer force of will and self-discipline and you wish to instill such competitive talents in your offspring, but not I'm guessing, the Achilles tendon of compassion. I can't comment on whether such things are self-earned or are the "gifts" of the gods into your life for the moment, but I can say that at PS166, both the G&T and Gen Ed programs are very strong. They are nearly equal in terms of the education your child would receive. The teachers sometimes rotate from G&T into gen ed and vice versa. The funding from the overactive PTA is spread evenly throughout the gen ed and G&T classrooms--teaching assistants, enrichment programs in the arts and sciences, after school activities. Generally kids from PS166 attend some of the finest middle schools in the city (Delta, Computer, MHII, Center), expect to have a good chance of attending Hunter and Anderson if they wish, and expect to attend the high schools of their choices. If this seems too slow for you and not sufficiently guaranteeing your toddler entry into one of the Ivies, may I suggest applying for private school? They do offer scholarships and I'm sure would welcome your spirit which seems competitive at all costs.

My daughter may be getting placed here in teh G&T program.  We are a latino family and got offered a placement.  I don't think the program has to do with race, but more with intellectual ability.  I personally don't think my daughter is anymore talented than any kid in the G&T program.  I believe that if you work with your children from a very early age they will develop their reasoning and logical skills at an earlier pace and that was our case. But not all children are the same and they don't all learn the same way; I don't know if my second daughter will be the same.  Perhaps she'll place in GenEd and I'll be fine with that too. I also found that many low income families, such as those in my daughters Head Start program, were not aware of such test and of the options available in the city.  I was shocked to see that some moms hadn't applied for any schools a few days before the deadline because they didn't "know".  Some parents are oblivious and just go with the flow, some feel that it's the schools job to educate while others are more pro-active.  I think this weighs heavily on the percentage of latinos that do well on the tests, but it's not definitive either.  As I mentioned before, no two kids learn the same.
I meant my daughter is not anymore talented or superior than the students in GedEd.   I only applied to escape my zoned school.

P.S. 166 is a participant in the Wellness in the Schools
Cook for Kids program, which replaces the traditional cafeteria menu with
a healthy menu based on scratch cooking and fresh ingredients. WITS
places a trained culinary profession in the school cafeteria to prepare fresh
meals from scratch, engage students, and educate families about the importance
of eating whole, unprocessed foods through interactive cooking demonstrations
called WITS Labs. You can find out more about programming from Wellness in the
Schools and see a list of participating schools online at www.wellnessintheschools.org

My children are not black or Hispanic and feel very comfortable in their "gen-ed" 2nd and 5th grade classrooms.  My 5th grader is writing every night and his teacher (the fantastic Mr G) actually gets my son excited about learning.  My daughter is in a 2nd grade gen-ed class that looks like a mini United Nations -  a representation of the city that we live in.  Their teacher is wonderful and does her best to create an inclusive environment while also celebrating individual heritage.  I think the divisions that many people site have more to do with the parents than with what is actually going on in the classrooms.  Yes, the PTA meetings are filled with mostly white parents of G & T kids, but my experience is that the money raised is equally shared throughout the classes and the new principal Ms Camiolio is actively working to ensure that all the students are getting what they need.

Add to that the great healthy school lunch program, huge play yard and big bright classrooms and you have a quality neighborhood public school for all children.

p.s.166 was my home away from home in the 50's.from k-6. All my teachers were caring. no matter if we were black,jew, or hispanic.. we were all treated the same. How sad that SOME parents are now allmost FIFTY years later want to change the true motto of thisschool. TRUE & FREE EDUCATION FOR --ALL'''. SAD SAD SAD
Can't wait to get out of this place! In all my travels never witnessed such separation. Revolting!

Whereas I'm sure this is a genuine feeling, I find this sort of comment difficult, because it remains the case that the school doesn't choose who attends which program. This is done at the DOE level. Second, this school has more programs to try to mix the G&T and gen ed groups than virtually any other school I've heard of. For instance, PS166 PTA shares money across all classes evenly, even though most money is raised by the G&T parents. The PTA pays for teaching assistants across all classes evenly. The school has several programs which combine the two groups--the dance festival; the music programs in the fall and winter; the afterschool program has scholarships to ensure that anyone with lower incomes (in other words ALL children from BOTH programs) can participate in the school play and the other amazing afterschool programs; parents, afterschool teachers, and regular teachers volunteer to teach for free (often) kids who need extra help academically and in the various arts programs; PTA money provides funding for underprivileged kids to attend the 4th grade trips and 5th grade graduation; all kids are welcome to attend the several other enrichment programs won by grants and other (mainly G&T) parent efforts, such as music lessons, robotics, chess, and the devoted science room, teacher, and curriculum; the school administration has reading programs which criss-cross both the two programs and grade levels, to ensure that mentorship takes place among the children; children switch classrooms (G&T to gen ed and vice versa) for certain classroom projects (such as a long-term writing project in 5th grade last year) then return to their regular teachers; G&T teachers rotate into gen ed classes for some years and vice versa, all but eliminating the differences in education between the two groups; many long-time PS166 families with several children matriculating there have opted to place their kids some in gen ed and some in G&T because the education in both are so similar and excellent. Because the two programs are so fully integrated at this school, there have been several calls to eliminate the G&T program entirely. This is why I find the charge levied at this school, that the programs are so separate to be almost non-nonsensical.
you must be a G&T Parent!!!!

My child is a 2nd grader at PS166 in the G&T program.  We have been very pleased with the teachers, the administration, the PTA--the list goes on.  The school has a very dedicated staff and the grand building is wonderful with high celings and big windows on every floor.  There is such an open feeling to the classrooms for the children.  The play yard provides a nice large space for recess and after school with a large structure for play.  There is a separate playground for Kindergarten which was just redone in the last few years.  As with most schools with a G&T program, the school does an excellent job of scheduling full grade time together for lunch and recess as well as field trips, so the children do not think in terms of G&T and Gen Ed.  There is a real sense of community among the children.

PS 166 's conservation efforts, including naming student "climate captains" to monitor energy use, caused the school to reduce its energy consumption by about 18 percent, and the school won the Green Cup Challenge. The school's efforts to champion environmentalism were featured in the August 2010 issue of Time Out New York Kids.

80`s-90`s, PS 166, was a full of blacks of Hispanic children, now they are full of whites, and now seems to be the only ones that can get into the G&T programs, it seems a little strange to me that race is what everyone talks about in this postings. If you look inside a class room for G&T every kid in that class is white, G,Ed class no so. What this says to me is all blacks and Hispanics are not as smart, are the whites, really! this programs need to be look into and see what is the problem, I have talked with some of the G&T kids some not Gifted or talented. Just a normal kid from the "UWS".

"RE: the previous few postsAlthough I have heard a few G&T parents voice the opinion that G&T should get preferential treatment, the majority of G&T parents do NOT feel this way and try very hard to make things equitable. Please do not let the voice of a few bad apples stand for G&T parents as a whole. Although the G&T is predominantly white, I have heard that this may be due to the fact that black and hispanic kids who score well on tests tend to get scholarships to private schools. PS 166 has a wonderful new principal this year in Debbie Hand and it is an amazing school."

"I half agree with 2009-04-01. I think most, not all, of the teachers treat the children fairly. But the "active" PTA parents in this school are nothing short of bullies. I remember sitting in a PTA meeting last year watching parents arguing for removing classroom assistants from the rooms of the classes whose parents did not pay the "suggested donation", specifically a kindergarten Special Ed class. The only time I was more horrified is at the beginning of the year when G&T parents normally protest General Ed kids being moved into G&T classes in order to balance class sizes. And yes, the General Ed kids are predominantly black and hispanic while the G&T program is predominantly white. It really becomes a throwback to the 1960s."
"teachers and many parents treat latinos and blacks students like second class citizen. I hate this place for my kids."

"I am a prospective parent and my observations are based on a tour. The building is great, very warm and seems to support a good sense of community. There is very good space for Art, Music, Gym and a well stocked Library. The parents I saw seemed helpful and very appreciative of the principal. Classes were smaller than usual, I counted no more than 23 in classes visited. The kids seemed happy. My group did not see any G+T classes on the tour. The sense I got was that there is a deliberate ethos of blurring the distinction between the Gen Ed and G+T classes. Reading the comments here about classes that look segregated this provides one context to understand this. As I did not see any G+T classes I don't know how accurate the comments are. Reflecting on this however, the Gen Ed classes I saw skewed slightly to non-white. Blurring the distinction is good just so long as ALL kids are being sufficiently challenged by the curriculum based on ability, including the kids on the G+T program."

Kindergarten teacher Julie Stone won West Side Spirit's 2008 Blackboard Award for "Best Public Elementary School Teacher of the Year." According to the newspaper, her class features a hands-on approach to education where students learn "inside and outside the classroom."

"All the children feel challenged to beat their personal academic best," one parent said of Stone's class.

"Yes, the classes do seem to be divided along racial lines, but no, this is not the fault of the school at all," writes a parent. "The school does NOT decide which kids get in--it is all zoned for general ed and the DOE places all of the G&T kids. The school would absolutely love to have more diverse G&T as well as Gen. Ed. classes--ask almost any parent at the school and the administration. PS 166 is very fair about offering extras such as classroom assistants and resources to ALL classrooms. There is a Community Building group at the school which helps parents of all backgrounds feel welcome. It is a great school--in large part to a very active parent body."

P.S. 166 is listed in the 2007 Blackboard Awards' honor roll list for "Support for the Arts and Creativity," "Overall Academic Rigor," and "Receptivity to Parent Involvement." Comments praise the active PTA and the"caring teachers" but note that teacher quality may vary. "There are some star teachers and some under-achievers," writes one.

"I have continued reading all the comments that parents, students, and 'anonymous' people have written about this wonderful school," writes graduate Alexis. "This whole argument about whether PS 166 is segregated or not is preposterous. PS 166 is a great school. There is no separation between races."

A parent writes to rebut criticisms that the school is segregated. "There are so many wonderful attributes to our school - partnerships, great teachers, art, music programs, a rich afterschool, to name a few," this parent writes. "The school is filled with hardworking middle-class families with many parents who spend many, many hours devouted to making public education the best it can be. Our parents raised money continuously for all kinds of improvements for ALL the children in the school." This parent also reminds Insideschools readers that decisions about acceptance into the gifted program are not made at the school level.
Alexis, who is now in 8th grade, writes, "This school is awesome. It definitely prepared me for junior high school."

Parent Ira Gershenhorn writes to disagree with comments that allege that the school favors some students over others. "The principals of PS 166 have never jumped through hoops for anyone. They've always considered the impact of agreeing to anything on their school and the management of the school. ... The current principal is a good listener and if a request is presented well and is in line with the workings of the school, there is a chance it will be acted on," he writes. He notes that all of the school's classes -- general, gifted and dual language -- get the same materials and have the same access to extra funding from the PTA.

"I was disappointed and embarrassed by the inequality that exists for African-American and Latino children at PS 166," writes a former student, who returned to visit the school for a few hours. "Under the guise of "Gifted and Talented," minority students are segregated and placed in classes with a greater number of disruptions and as a result less learning. The disparity was clear to me and to other visitors. As a Latina, who learned English in a bilingual class at P.S. 166, graduated from a private NY prep. school, and, later, graduated magna cum laude from an Ivy League college, I expect other minorities at P.S. 166 to have the same opportunity. Yet, at such an early age, students at P.S. 166 are being taught to live within the confines of their race and class and minorities are being presented with an education that is below standard and of low expectations. I commend the PTA parents for their active involvement in fundraising and in the education of their students. At the same time, you have created an injustice at P.S. 166."

The principal did not respond to the above comment.

An active parent and a PS 166 staff member writes to that in the 1980's the school received poor black and Hispanic children, because they were bused from the overcrowded District 6, not from nearby housing projects. The school's zone only encompasses one housing project, and "non G&T children form an ethnically integrated group as well."

"As an outgoing parent at PS166, I can honestly attest to the quality education my son received. A record number of students were accepted this year to some of the best middle schools within District 3," writes a parent. "Yes, lunchtime is hectic, but both the parent body and the administration worked together to try and eliminate the more serious issues and as a result there are more inside recess activities and the teaching assistants are also lunchtime assistants. The racial diversity that outside observers see has nothing to do with the quality of teaching the students receive. More parents are always needed and welcome to join the many committees on the PTA, especially from the non-G&T classes, to help maintain the quality education and services that all the children receive from the fund-raising activities. The PTA-sponsored after-school program is stellar and offers a wide variety of classes. On a minor downside, all classes could see better use of the wonderful library and art room."

A parent writes: "I have a son in the G&T program [at PS 166]. Because of what I'd heard and observed about the racial differences in the general ed. and G&T programs, I hesitated to send my son. ... No other school accepted my child, so I registered at PS 166 and vowed to work from within the school to end what I took, standing on the outside, to be obvious racial discrimination." However, she explains that once she began attending diversity committee meetings at the school, she realized the lack of diversity might not be because of racial discrimination, but because many parents do not display the extreme persistence necessary to navigate the school system's many hurdles. She continues: "As far as integrating the school, there are a number of places where the programs blend beautifully. One is the many musical performances. A second is the thriving and exciting after-school program."

A parent writes: "I must agree with the comments from other parents. If your child is not 'selected' for the gifted and talented program, they will be treated as second-class citizens. If you scream and yell and complain [about] the behavior in the class that they are currently in, it may get your child a seat in the 'gifted and talent program' provided the parents of these children don't find out. It's a shame, there is some much talent in these other children and PS 166 is missing out, because they prefer not to work with these kids and shortchange them."

A parent whose son is in kindergarten writes: "The racial disparity between general education classes and the G&T classes exists in all the schools offering G&T programs in neighborhoods where majority of residents are white. This issue is mostly manifested at the kindergarten level but in the higher grades the clash diminishes. The administration and the parent body are doing their best to move prospective G&T students from general education classes into the G&T ones." She adds: "PS 166 is situated in an architecturally beautiful, clean, and well kept building with a reading garden, offering great education, arts, dance, and music programs equipped with various musical instruments. The computer lab and all the classes are now equipped with state-of-the-art Macs and printers. The parents at each grade level raise money for fulltime classroom assistants for all the classes in their grade level collectively and not just their own class. PS 166 has a very active PTA dedicated to providing the children with as many amenities as the ones existent in private schools."

A parent writes: "I went on a tour of the school and was disturbed to see the disparity of ethnic background throughout the classes. The majority of the children in the G+T program were white while the mainstream classes consisted only of minority children (with one or two exceptions)...Residing in a city as diverse as New York, I am truly disappointed. The teachers seemed enthusiastic and attentive but I ask myself, should I send my son to PS 166?"
A parent writes that "our experiences with the school are very positive," but writes that his son "talks a lot about violence during recess."

My third child is now attending PS 180.  Our family has been at the school for 8 years.  Most teachers have been excellent.  My child who needed extra academic challenges was able to work on new exciting projects (escape room math problems, hands-on science projects.)  My child who needed extra academic support received it through daily reading intervention help and free after school tutoring.  And my child who sometimes got himself into trouble  was managed fairly - discipline with love.

The school has had two wonderful full-time librarians since we have been there.  This should not be a luxury, but it is!  Our family has also loved the in-class and after school chess program, the art experiences through Studio in a School.  When our kids were younger, they loved Ballet Hispanico and when they got to 3ed grade and beyond, they learned to play an instrument through the Midori music program.  The school's after school program, RTS, is also a wonderful resource.

Best of all, PS/IS 180 is a community that cares for one another.  Our family has created lasting friendships and connections through the school.  There is a lot to love about 180.

unwanted attention for PS180

The PS 180 community has produced a video "Young Gifted and Harlem" that highlights the diverse student body.

My son is now in 1st grade, and we've been there since PreK. He has had 3 wonderful classroom teachers and many wonderful specials teachers, especially the technology teacher! He is enrolled in the Dual Language Spanish program, and while I feel the school could do a better job holding teachers and students to higher rigor for Spanish literacy, the school more than makes up for it with the warm sense of community and the principal's commitment to Arts and Science in education. They have special programs like Studio in a School and Ballet Hispanico, but most of all it's the super caring, hard-working teachers that make it special. My son really loves his class and his school.
Construction has yet to begin on the garden "tranquility zone," for which PS 180 was awarded $325,000 in 2013, DNAinfo reports.

Our son attends dual language Kindergarten and we are very happy with the instruction in the classroom and overall community.  PS 180 is a great school that is working hard to continually improve its academic standing, programs and family engagement.  The school set out clear goals this year to improve NYS test scores, increase parent survey participation by 10%, improve school culture by improving safety at recess, improve instruction in mathematics, and move towards a progressive teaching model in all classrooms.  While test scores are not yet available, the rest of the goals have been met, or are on track for the year.  PS 180 offers an affordable afterschool program for grades K-2 through roads to success, as well as afterschool options for the upper grades.   The PTA sends weekly updates to the parent body and teachers use online software through to communicate to parents. I have found our teacher to be very accessible and responsive to any questions or concerns that we have about our son.  A recent parent/principal brunch with Ms Lana Fleming brought a sense of community to those who attended, and provided valuable information on the accomplishments and next steps for the school.    

The school has only three classes per grade for K-5 and classroom size is smaller than typical New York City classes, at 20 children per class.   No school is perfect, and certainly the experience that each family will have is dependent on their level of involvement with the school and the specific teachers interacting with their children.  Despite having exposure to the teachers for only one year, from what I have seen there is a deep level of commitment to educating children in the school on the part of most teachers as well as improving access to resources for all of the students in the school on the part of the administration.

My son has been a student at PS 180 for three years and he loves it. The teachers are hard working and knowledgeable. They take the time to make the kids feel special and valued. The class sizes are small so they are able to tailor and differentiate learning. The building is orderly and clean, with enough space for out of classroom teachers- like computers, music, science, and library- to have their own space. The music teacher is very talented and many teachers have won awards. The new principal has a great vision and works well with the PTA, which is very active. It's a true community of happy kids, dedicated teachers, and a well organized PTA. My son feels safe and loved. I would highly recommend PS 180!

He was replaced by Lana Fleming, a former assistant principal at the school. Read the letter he wrote to announce his new position on the school's website.

My daughter will be in the 5th grade at PS/IS 180. She has been a student there since Pre-K.  We love the school, the administration & the other parents/students. We are blessed to be surrounded by an exceptional team, lead by the Principal, Dr. Mac.  He runs a tight but
loving ship & has done an amazing job of ensuring our children are learning in a challenging yet supportive environment. We are also thankful that our child has been able to be active in many of the enrichment programs at the school – from chess and the Midori & Friends music program, to the after school program via Sports & Arts in Schools where she’s been exposed to everything from dance, drama, lacrosse & soccer.

Of course it’s helpful for all of our children when we as parents take an active role in the PTA to ensure our voices are heard, instead of mumbling in the halls to our peers (which I’m sure happens everywhere). Thankfully, most of the parents have our kids’ best interests at heart. We have a small but active PTA and we do hope it will continue to grow!

I am very happy that our daughter is a student at PS/IS 180!  And

My Grandson came to PS/IS 180 in 2004 and upon entering the lobby I immediately felt like I wanted to register/enroll him as a student.  The lobby is warm and inviting and very clean.  I notice that on the right wall in the lobby there are pictures and essays of students who were chosen for student of the month in academics and citizenship.  I was given the opportunity to meet and speak with Ms. Lambright who has now retired and she was instrumental in telling me what the school offer their students and what I would need to do as a grandparent meaning volunteering time in the school and making sure I attend the monthly PTA meeting.  She also gave me a tour of the PreK classes.  I am extremely overall please and satisfied with the education my grandchildren are getting.  Since my grandson enrollment his two sisters are now also students at PS 180 and, I must add they all are very happy and love their teachers.  Yes, there are challenges along the way but why not have some.  We need our children to be challenge to prepare them for the future.  Learning shouldn't be easy.  Our children need to learn to be thinkers and doers.  Also all students at PS/IS 180 has the opportunity to participate in sports, music, and its chess program. The school has Talent Tuesday whereby all students explore their choice of talents whether its jewelry making, dance, double dutch, etc. to keep them involve in extracurricular activities.  In Conclusion, in my opinion Dr. McFarlane mission is to ensure that all his students get the education they rightfully deserve to prepare them for the future regardless of ethnicity, economic status, race, or religion.  Thank you very much Dr. MacFarlane.

Grandparent

Our daughter is learning to read, cook, plant plants, build many different thigns, and is very well prepared for kindergarten. Her teacher (Ms Lee) is warm, affectionate, and understanding. My impression of the school, and the administration, was just wonderful. Don't dismiss an entire school because one staff member was having a bad day!"

As a parent searching for school for my child, she left me with very bad impression. Having good scores does not make up for being rude and being discourteous. I pass on this school."
Quandra Mach tells Insideschools.org: “This school is a gem. The community within the school, the way parents work with administrators and teachers, it’s the best school in Harlem.”

"P.S.180 is a GREAT school and im not just saying that I mean it. So i highly reccomend this school to hardworking dedicated students. Trust me you would fit right in."

"My daughter attends PS180 and we both love it. Not only the staff is nice, but the teachers are great. When my daughter first started K she was good by the end of the year she was GREAT. I love how dedicated everyone is towards the children and their education. The teachers care for their student. The sense of respect that you get as soon as you go in the school is fascinating. The principal of the school does not play with the children's education and future. He is in my own words" a tough cookie" but in a good way. He projects confidence and you see it in the students as well. The school is always clean and smelling fresh. I believe PS 180 has come a long way and will keep surprising us and shining in the years to come. I couldn't ask for a better school for my daughter. I always say that i want the best for her and i strongly believe that PS 180 is one if not the BEST school."

"I don't regret a minute of enrolling my children," writes a parent. "Dr. Mc, as he is known around the school, is genuine and supportive. Parent involvement is key to the success of our children. That is why the school is constantly appealing to parents in becoming more active in their child's education. I applaud all staff, faculty, and volunteers who put so much effort to enhance my children's experience."

Parent QuYahni Lewis calls Principal MacFarlane "touchable" and praises his presence in the school. "He's there to greet students and parents in the mornings, he always has an encouraging word, and he even goes about cleaning up spills and setting things in order," this parent writes. "He's the students greatest cheering section --- building their confidence and energy during test time and making sure they know they're all winners." This parent also notes that her daughter's teachers are "dedicated and patient" and that the school's music program is top-notch.

"PS 180 is definitely one of the more exciting schools in the district and an up and coming option," says Robin Aronow, founder of School Search NYC, a consulting firm that helps parents navigate the school system. "The combination of a dynamic principal, dedicated and mostly hand picked faculty, and renovated building makes for a winning combination. Dr. McFarlane is a character--sure of himself and opinionated--but he has lifted the morale and expectations in his school with his visions. While there is a sense of calm and order, especially in the halls, the classrooms have much energy," Aronow wrote after visiting the school.
The object is for all students to "view college as a viable and realistic goal," says Principal Peter McFarlane.

Our son is currently enrolled in PreK at RSMA / P.S. 191. He tells us that he’s happy with his classmates, loves his teachers and enjoys his lessons. He comes home with diversity in learning such as: singing songs learned in one week, bringing different types of artwork and discussing human nature. His homeroom teachers are wonderful – they instruct the children on a solid foundation of basic learning from the alphabet, numbers, analogy, etc. as well as guiding them in emotional development outside of their home. He had attended programs at Dwight, Mandell, Metropolitan Montessori and MetroKids - all from which he really benefited and thrived. My husband and I had researched as many schools possible - both private and public, in the UWS and Midtown area; and we’re happy with this academic program and close-knit community promoted. The enhancement teachers (music, movement and art) are wonderful and have connections with Juilliard, Laguardia HS, etc. Mandarin begins weekly this month for PreK and the lower grades. The after school program for PreK is Hudson Guild and pick up is by 6PM for about $400-500/month. Kindergarten-6th Grade after school is the YMCA until 5:45PM; and it’s free. The school was built around 3 years ago (the first “new” Manhattan school in about 30 years) and the classrooms are very large with lot of windows - each with their own bathroom and access to a private playground – it’s just as described on their website with state of the art technology from touch screen teaching monitors in every classroom (I’ve only seen that in charter schools so far), 3D printers, computers in every classroom and the library. The administration is very involved in the student body’s academic and social well-being. The interim principal, Mr. Stephen Hernon, is intelligent, friendly and respectful with the students, the teachers and administration team. The parent coordinator, Ms. Damaris Carrion, (she’s been there for about two decades) is the school conduit and has been instrumental in the transition of the school’s relocation and development. There are five PreK classes - many children enrolled are zoned for P.S. 199 or P.S. 452. I believe RSMA is the only public school for which the DOE provides the assistant PreK teacher for each class. Other area public schools’ PTAs/PAs raise funds to pay their assistant PreK teachers’ salaries. RSMA is the only area public school that currently has no suggested annual contribution minimum. I have been quoted at other public schools’ annual amounts from $300 to $2,400. Our PTA is a terrific group of parents and teachers who are effective as they are cooperative. They started the school’s first annual fundraiser party 3 years ago and it’s been very successful. The school has a progressive type of Gifted & Talented classes – the teachers elect students starting in 3rd Grade. We’re very thankful to RSMA / P.S. 191 too!

Our daughter joined the 6th grade this school year (Fall 2019). She is very happy. We visited the school during the middle school placement process and we were consistently impressed with the faculty and administration - and we remain so. We feel like we found a very special school where our daughter can grow, learn and thrive in a supportive and engaging environment. Homework is manageable, there are after school programs that are arts focused, academics seem exactly right with our daughter feeling some challenges and lots of successes too. Thank you RSMA/PS191!

This school is absolutely amazing! I'm a parent to a kindergartner who came from a tiny Montessori school. This school has been so welcoming, kind and understanding towards all my child's needs emotionally and academically. The staff, Parent coordinator Ms. Damaris, and teachers welcome families to participate in so many events and they encourage all family members to participate in the life of all events. My son takes so much joy in going to school every day and talks all about the exciting things hes done with his time in a school day. He has one amazing Kindergarten teacher Ms. Ariah, and a fantastic Music teacher Ms. D.J. who has filled his heart and soul with beautiful songs he sings as he does his homework every night. If you want your child to have an amazing public school experiance please enroll your child here.

I am so happy to be part of this community. My son's 1st grade teachers, Ms. Tarantino and Ms. Angelique, are so warm and nurturing. My son was so nervous about starting 1st grade but after day 1, he and I both knew he was in good hands. The book baggies and his homework assignments have proven to be a such a help with his academic progress.  Socially, he has grown so much as a result of the family he has built in school.  I am looking forward to my son's remaining years here. Thank you RSMA!

My daughter had an amazing first year at P.S. 191. The staff go above and beyond to create a warm environment, hosting several culturally themed events to ensure everyone feels represented. The G&T program offers a rigorous curriculum, which prepares students to perform well on the state exams. Yes, the test-prep is intense (one critique that I have), but schools must perform well to maintain student enrollment, and secure funding. In that regard, I understand the catch-22. The enrichment programs are an additional benefit, as students have access to the Juilliard music program, drama, and art (to name a few). The music teacher (Ms. DJ), who is largely (if not fully) responsible, for integrating the Juilliard program in this school, is phenomenal. She is so committed to ensuring her students are exposed to the arts, many of whom had little to no prior experience playing a musical instrument. Despite her student's novelty, she embraced them with open arms. The parent coordinator (Ms. Damaris) spends countless hours planning elaborate school events to strengthen the school community.  Lastly, the after-school YMCA program is amazing. Mr. Desmond (the coordinator), Ms. Jasmine (a counselor), and Mr. Jesus (a counselor) are so courteous and upbeat. They genuinely adore kids. What more could you ask for in a school? Staff members who genuinely love kids and enjoy what they do.  I must say, it saddens me that my daughter will be moving on from this school, as they have become family.

My daughter, Lya Trinidad has been in this school since Pre-k.  She is now in the 8th grade on her way to one of the best high schools. This school is horrible. It has on entrance for drop off and pick up making it a nightmare. Staff is horrible. We have attended for pre k but won’t be back.
