Hi, I’m wondering if anyone could offer any advice to me and my situation: My daughter and her father and I are going through the 6th grade admissions process, and what I am sensing is that there are mainly 2 kinds of public MS’ in district 3: those that are geared toward kids who can perform excellently on standardized tests, and those that are newer, more experimental, less racially/socio-ecomomically balanced and seem to consist of kids that, frankly, my daughter has little in common with and are in environments I’ve heard have had significant bullying problems.
I, myself, graduated from Anderson, before it was a “school” and was merely a “program” in the P.S.9 building (and right before they added a 6th grade, too!). I would love nothing more than for my daughter to have an experience such as the one I had in Anderson, at that time, with the diversity of race, different learning levels, etc, however, the fact is: my daughter simply doesn’t test as “well" as I did at her age and she learns and is inspired differently than myself academically, overall.
The ONLY school we have seen so far that seems a good match for her is MSC (M.S.333), but given that there are so few seats in the incoming 6th grade class coupled with its popularity, I am obv worried…
Can anyone give me any insight regarding what other schools may be comparable to MSC in the ways that it isn’t primarily a “test oriented” school and has a very diverse student body, etc?  

I really appreciate any info and advice any of you other parents are able to bless me with and thanks for reading!

this school is like any other school. is your like a student there like me you understnad that school is torturing me just because im differnt im harrased by different kids. it hurts and these lies that the school is"Briliant" id compeltly dispicable.
LIES what do you mean LIES I love the school and if you are getting bullied just ignore the kids and the spelling on the complaint is terrible

1. The comment you are replying to is eight years old. The situation was certainly different them from the way it is today. 

2. It is common for different people to have different experiences at school. Why would anybody want to lie about being bullied on an anonymous website? If somebody comes up and says that they're being harassed at your school, and you say that you've never seen this, then the answer is probably that you are both telling the truth. Your experience simply isn't universal.

3. "Just ignore the kids" is bad advice that never works. If a student is getting harassed at school then the school has a problem and needs to work to fix it. As an adult, I can tell you that I know multiple other adults who have severe anxiety, depression, or even PTSD related to being harassed at school and having staff refuse to handle the situation. If people have given YOU this advice then you need to know that these people do not have your best interests at heart.
4. You have no call to criticize another person's spelling while your own sense of punctuation is so deplorable. Take the beam out of your own eye before you look at the speck in another's.

I am truly sorry to read this. I hope you go to your advisor and conference the problem, or see Ms. Schwartz. I do understand what you are going though. My life in Jr. HS in Long Beach was about as much fun as being incarcerated
at Guantanamo Bay. I too was " different. " Vive la difference.

I'm an 8th grader at CS, and I can say for sure that it's full of nice people and fun classes like PE, Math, ELA, Science, Global Studies, Social Studies, Art, Enrichment, Spanish, and Music. The Computer School is a participant in the Wellness in the
Schools Cook for Kids program, which replaces the traditional cafeteria
menu with a healthy menu based on scratch cooking and fresh
ingredients. WITS places a trained culinary profession in the school cafeteria
to prepare fresh meals from scratch, engage students, and educate families
about the importance of eating whole, unprocessed foods through interactive
cooking demonstrations called WITS Labs. You can find out more about
programming from Wellness in the Schools and see a list of participating
schools online at www.wellnessintheschools.org

This is my last year at The Computer School and oh boy how am I going to miss it.  I have had some of the best times of my life here, and have made friends that I will have forever.  I know all of my teachers and some who don't teach me (the ones I know are certainty AWESOMELY AMAZING), they all seem to care about how others and I do.  Even when I've struggled because I didn't do my homework or didn't understand the material, teachers were always there to help.  A couple of them even made me stay after school, or during lunch to finish things.  That isn't to stay that I have never gone to my teachers voluntarily, I do so often.  In fact in my art class I was behind on the last project I had to complete, so I came back to school at 3:45 (the school day got out at 2:30) since there was a teachers meeting, to finish my art.  It's not like the teachers are trying to force you to do your work (I hope you understand what I mean) but they encourage you and make you want to do it.  Honestly I wish they would make The Computer School into a high school so I wouldn't have to leave.  The Computer has prepared me for all the state tests I've taken, me and four other students (who are currently in the eighth grade) actually managed to score in the top 2% out of all the students in NY who took the seventh grade ELA test.  I also got a high 4 on the MATH state test.  The 6/7 system with classes is great, I know it helped me get integrated into The Computer School and I hope I helped some of the sixth (now seventh) graders who were in my class last year become integrated into The Computer School.  We all learn from each other here, I know I help and have helped several of my teachers with technology, (not to say that they're bad with computers but a couple of teachers aren't the greatest with computers) I know I have learned so much here. (I'm really happy I didn't go to Delta)  The guidance counselors have helped me immensely with getting into a high school.  I was late 69 times last school year and I managed to get into a good high school. (I'm elated to say that I have been late 5 times this school year)  The classes are always engaging, the teachers are very good at doing that.  The teachers actually come up with lessons together a lot of the time which kind of makes it so no one class does better than other.  Thats not to say that teachers don't make accommodations for kids, they do. The Computer School is amazing and I'm going to miss so much, I kind of wish I didn't have to go, I know I'll come back and visit The Computer School and talk to my old teachers.  I know that if I need help in high school I can always email one of my teachers, this is an awesome school!

I am a 8th grader at the computer school. i think that it is a great school with great teachers. they help you with the assignments you do not understand. This school is very helpful and intresting. We take the rigeons in the 8th grade so that will help the students attending this school get into great high schools.
Can a learning disabled child with SETTS stand a chance? Grades are in the B- range

Yes. This is a school that take care of ALL of its students, not just the high fliers. I'm a mom with a kid like that. Computer School is a truly well-rounded school. Another school that really takes care of kids with SETTS and is smart like yours is Mott Hall II. They are amazing. Just read the comments for that school. (I have kids in both schools.)

Since you have kids in both Mott Hall II and Computer, can you give some insight as to which school you feel is stronger academically and is more structured.   Overall test scores and school description seem fairly similar, and we're trying to decide which MS my child should list first choice on MS application.  Our GC hasn't been much help!

It's very hard to compare the strength of the academics as both programs somewhat tailor to your child's strengths and weaknesses. They are both very strong. Both are progressive, in that they have projects that combine subject areas across disciplines. CS in 6th grade gives HW that doesn't just want regurgitation of facts. They purposefully stair step the thinking level from concrete to abstract. They want the kids to begin synthesizing new ideas from outside sources including their own brains. Some are able to do this right away. Some aren't. It's a developmental thing and CS is poised to capture this gently. Given that both schools are progressive, I would say MHII, though, is even more focused on creating cross-discipline projects, which are also rigorous and aimed at your kids' abilities. The summer homework for 7-8th grade was interesting in that they combined the math with literature. An 8th grade math project this year integrated making a ken ken puzzle (not just solving it) and then step by step the kids had to describe in words the thinking process of how they came up with the answer to each square. Incredibly good analytical skill-building! And fun.  The strength of the programs also depend on the needs of your child. If your child is ready for strong work--or isn't--MHII has several levels of choices, often within a single classroom. The idea is to reach and capture kids then pull them up. MHII is great with social-emotional too. I would say on the whole that the education that is focused more on the individual development of your child with the most flexibility is MHII, although CS has leveled education as well. I've been delighted with the care (not coddling!) of the MHII staff and principal. 2-3 minute parent teacher conferences at CS and as long as you need at MHII. Free parent entry at MHII, open hallways. CS is somewhat more restricted. Shiny and fresh looking school at CS, MHII seems to care more about its kids than how it looks, although it's very homey feeling.

As a parent of a 6th grader, this was the smoothest transition into middle school--or any school for that matter--I've yet experienced. I have an older child who goes to another school, also great, so I have several instances for comparison. So far, my daughter at Computer School adores her teachers, loves the kids, feels safe and comfortable even though she's physically small going through the hallways between classes with the hulking 8th graders. The parent coordinator must be the most upbeat person on the planet. The school has a great program in place so that the upper classmen/women take on mentoring roles with the younger students. The kids are also polite and care for each other when they step out of the school, on the buses home and going out for lunch. Everything about the experience so far seems to be carefully thought out to ensure that the kids feel safe and secure--and, crucially, organized! Much of the first "homework" was organizing the notebooks etc. to get the kids on track before the "real" homework begins. So far so good.

I am a 8th grader at the computer school and I absolutely love it! The teachers are so kind and helpful. I'm so upset that this is my last year. (if it were up to me i'd stay at that school until college!) We do have lockers, and the a decent size.
My child entered sixth grade this year and they do indeed have lockers.

My son is a new 6th grader at The Computer School and could not be happier! We are so pleased with the staff and administration, communication is excellent, and the teachers genuinely care about the kids. The children are bright and inquisitive, but do not try to achieve at the expense of others. Rather, there seems to be a spirit of cooperation among the student body. My son loves sharing subjects with 7th graders, enjoys his classes, and really seems to get on well with his teachers. Teachers are responsive and helpful with concerns and questions and seem to be an enthusiastic group. Our whole family agrees that the best decision we made was for our son to attend this wonderful school!

"This is an extremely well-rounded program. The school does not try to reinvent the wheel," writes a parent of an 8th grader. "They turn out really bright sucessful kids who can think 'out of the box' on a high level. They are very successful at motivating kids. The teachers and administrators want the kids to become accountable young adults and thus do hold them to their sometimes unpredictable preteen behavior. As a small school, Computer School enables the kids to grow and mature in a nurturing environment. The staff is amazing and completely committed! The electronic two-way communication system between school and parent/child is fantastic. There is a lot of homework, though, both nightly and long-term. There is not a lot of reference to standardized testing."

"I'm very pleased with the transition my 6th grader has made to middle school at the Computer School," writes a parent. "The teachers and administrators seem to understand that children are changing so much socially at this time. They really do seem to see the whole child and not treat the kids as test-taking automatons. I love that the children are all part of small advisory groups during which they can air their struggles or concerns. The teachers are creative and lively, and the school does a lot to foster community: dances, ice skating day, family potlucks and by the way, I think the whole eighth grade goes on an overnight to Montauk, not just one class, and the sixth grade already went to Philadelphia for the day fo finish their Colonial unit."

A parent of three children who have attended the Computer School, Jeanne Kurwin, said the relations with students attending MS 44 have improved markedly. Her oldest child, now in high school, was jumped outside the school when he was in middle school, but her younger children feel safe, she said. "The last two years have been almost incident-free," she said.

"It's a very democratic school," said English teacher Pamela Seuling. "All the teachers have a voice. Often decisions are made as a staff. It's a very supportive administration. [The students] are not all geniuses, but they are incredibly motivated."
Social studies teacher Jessica Shalom tells Insideschools: "We've really balanced the progressive philosophy with high-level thinking."

"I couldn't be happier with the Computer School. The faculty really seems to understand kids this age and they care about each individual child," writes a parent. "The computerized communication system is terrific. The school finds many different ways to interact with parents and to integrate new and returning kids. The curriculum is creative and challenging and homework is significant without being overwhelming. The first few days of drop off and pick up were somewhat chaotic and the other school in the complex is definitely a strong presence at dismissal. But overall, the challenges in the building seem to be less of an issue than previously. I am very pleased and my child is thriving."

"The school is in the midst of a renaissance since it was unified at one location on 77th Street," writes a parent. "The staff and students have an energy that is almost tangible. My son's 6th grade teachers seem to be motivated and highly qualified. They communicate with me promptly and frequently."

"The teachers really go out of their way to keep in touch with parents," writes a parent, who points to the fact that assignments are posted online as a particularly good system. This parent also writes that the school's relocation into the O'Shea Complex has been "positive" and "the tone within the building has changed dramatically."

City Council Member Gale Brewer reports: "The Computer School continues to provide a safe, quality middle school education to students in CSD3.  Although the O'Shea building, in which the Computer School is housed, has faced many challenges in recent years, reorganization and new leadership at MS 44 seem to be improving stability within the building and in the surrounding community."

"I view The Computer School as a big family," writes a student in his last year at the school. "We have some rivalries but the school isn't that cliquish. 6th and 7th graders tend to be more involved with each other because they have major classes together. Many of the 8th graders talk to the 7th graders though, because they were in the same classes the previous years. The teachers interact with the students a lot. You will see many students hanging out with the teachers during their lunch periods." He adds that security has improved and there are now fewer fights between schools in the building.

A dissatisfied former student writes: "I hated this school... There were all these cliques. It wasn't a diverse place." She describes the other schools in the building as "noisy" and "disruptive." This student also complains that although the school was well equipped, some of the teachers were disappointing.
A student complains that children at other schools in the building "always had fights and were loud." She also claims the school building is dirty and students tend to be cliquish.

"I'm a student of The Computer School and in my year there it a good school," writes Terrence D., a student. "There isn't any fights there. Not that many people get in trouble. And also we have a high-tech computer lab."

"The school provides a supportive, constructive environment to all," writes a parent. "Many of the teachers are good. But I feel that there are too many weak spots for a school of this size and that the way the school is structured, with two classes per grade at one site, and one class at the other, really leaves no options when there is a bad teacher/student combination. I also find the claims about technology integration highly overstated. It seems the school's technology edge has slipped away substantially while the school's administration fought other battles."

"The school is very good and handles students of different skill levels very well," writes a student. "The teachers are amazing and devoted." He also likes that the school "integrates computers into all the classes."

A 2002 graduate writes that The Computer School "helped me a lot. Because I was able to take high school math courses, I am in the 10th grade taking Pre-Calculus. I came into high school with 5 credits all because I was offered the classes in middle school. Computer School has helped me advance far in my school and I recommend this school to everyone."

I literally love this school. I came from Dominican Republic on 2015 when I was going to 8th grade, and I can say that this school was a miracle for me. They all helped me to improve my English and achieve all my goals that I had for myself and my family. The classes are ambitious but the teachers are always there to help you. I am pretty thankful to the school because it helped me and my family to go over the processes of change and learning. All the teachers were supportive and it was not as a normal school but a real community. The events that they organize and the trips that they take the students to are unforgettable. Ms. Caldwell was always trying to give her students anything they needed, she was supportive and she empathized with us, in the sense of knowing that we were "kids". The R.E.A.C.H. Values and Log, helps students to "involve" the essential values that they need to live a prosperous life (Responsibility & Respect, Enthusiasm, Achievement, Citizenship and Hard Work) and to lead students to behave in the best way. Also, the process for High School is easy and 
"informative"; they give you all the info you need about the process. The teachers take a time to talk about their experiences in High School and they call other students from the school that already graduated to talk about how High School is and to give students some advises. This school is the door to the world and prepare students for High School and for life in general.

MS 247 has been selected to showcase the focus area of English Language Learners in the inaugural year of Chancellor Carmen Fariña’s Showcase Schools Program. The initiative is designed to promote collaboration and sharing of strong practices. Schools that excel in a specific learning focus area will host educators from other schools to share their successful structures and strategies. Read more here.

Caitlin Caldwell has been named the Interim Acting Principal at MS 247. She will replace former principal Claudia Aguirre, who was promoted to serve as the new CEO of the Office of English Language Learners. Read more here.

I don't want to discount the positive experiences that students have had here. In fact I find it to be a testament to how hard working and caring the teachers are. I still stand by what I along with MANY teachers have taken the time to express here. This is a toxic work environment that should be avoided professionally. It is sad to see what the administration has done to countless good teachers. I felt helpless throughout my years there watching mistreatment, afraid to speak out in any way. In regards to students, if you as a parent have little concerns in regards to your student's behavior, I wouldn't advise against sending them here. If you have a student with even mild disciplinary issues, I disagreed with the way students were reprimanded and had no say in the process. This is a tricky time for students who are coming of age, and public chastising does little to teach a student a lesson. Rewarding and celebrating felt ingenuous and pulled nothing from teacher driven support. If you are a favorite of the administration, this can be a great place, for the many who are not (especially those arbitrarily so) the years quickly become countdowns until June. Of course what makes matters worse is that the same tactics are used upon teachers. Regardless, take the time to read into what has been written here. View the comments with the most LIKES and see the truth from teachers who know it from the inside. It has been years since I have been to the school, but as I have continued to keep in touch with staff members, am sad to say little has changed. It is a travesty what an unsupportive environment can do and how long lasting the effects can be. I write here only to protect others from the years I spent trapped and afraid rather than nurtured and guided.

I attend to this school i'm graduating this year. None of this is true. Haters need to stop it. Ms.Aguirre is not the best principal but she brings us to Broadway shows every years. We have great trips. From this school i got a scholarship to a dance school. They give you good opportunities. The teachers are on top of you making sure you do your homework. People say they make you stay till 7 but it is not true. I love this school, my teachers. Is going to be so sad living this school because it have give me good opportunities and have open the door to a great future. She might be mean but Ms. Aguirre do care about your future. All the staff care for you and know who you are. The good students are recognize. Stop with all this nonsense

The school is an extremely toxic environment run by a leader who has made it this way. Teachers are micromanaged and mistreated as many of these responses here have explained in detail. The principal is focused on maintaining the school’s image and not the emotional well-being of the students. She has no connection with her staff and even less a connection with the students. Despite what a progress report may show, students are still performing below average rather than at a high level. The high schools the students attend are disappointing compared to the way the principal describes the school to be. This is a school where the principal has learned how to work the system and destroys anyone or anything that gets in her way. Read through what teachers have written here to understand what type of a work environment this is, let alone what type of a school it would be for students. There is no soul left in this school and the leadership is to blame. It is a shame the DOE hasn't caught on to the atrocities that continue to occur to well meaning teachers here year after year. Read into the number of newly hired teachers each year. The lack of retention and constant hiring of completely new teachers is a sign. No experienced teacher would ever put up with the way this school is run. A great school should attract and retain qualified teachers rather than completely avoid them. A lot can be said about a school with so many new teachers year after year. Great schools nurture and develop talent rather than micromanage, abuse and undermine talent. Real leadership attracts talent and experience rather than avoiding it. Teachers I high advise avoiding this school regardless of how things may appear to you, just take the time to read further into the reviews posted by others. It is tragic that when kids should be the priority of a school, showmanship has become the focus at places like this.

The principal is crazy and annoying, she work by her self with no assistant principal and she don't know how to manage, I am agree with you that the kids they like is the one survive but the ones they don't like forget it, I think the principal has to go and do something different, the administration is horrible only 2 people are good which is Blanca Ortiz, parent coordinator and Counselor ms Rojas amazing person both of them, those two should be principal and assistant, if you think to put your child in this School read first the reviews and then decided if you going to send your child to hell..

M.S. 247 is a participant in the Wellness in the Schools Cook
for Kids program, which replaces the traditional cafeteria menu with a
healthy menu based on scratch cooking and fresh ingredients. WITS
places a trained culinary profession in the school cafeteria to prepare fresh
meals from scratch, engage students, and educate families about the importance
of eating whole, unprocessed foods through interactive cooking demonstrations
called WITS Labs. You can find out more about programming from Wellness in the
Schools and see a list of participating schools online at www.wellnessintheschools.org

I agree.  Thank you for posting the truth.  Thanks to all of you posting the truth here.  I left New York City after working for this monster.  I won't even teach middle school again.  

I have successfully been teaching high school since I left and have never met anyone in my admin as crazy as this lady- and I've seen A LOT of admin come and go over the years.  

If I tell colleagues now how this principal behaved, they either laugh their heads off or gasp, or both.  I have a lot of weird teaching stories from NYC, but I have never laughed about this nutjob.  That would be like laughing about a horried car wreck where you escaped permanently damaged.  This woman damaged my spirit.  I will never return to NYC or middle school because of her.  She stole something from me.

I learned that anyone can be a principal and thrive in NYC (this principal was a mere 32 yrs old the year I worked for her!! with no other school experience other than MS247).  She is a monster.  She should not be in a leadership position or anywhere near kids.

Warning to new teachers who choose to work at this school:

The commentary here is spot on.  You'll be working for a tyrant.  The principal is the only administrator running this tiny school.  There are no checks and balances with this person and she has a complete obsession with control.  She knows her rules and she knows your rights better than you do.  So it's easy for her to blame and discredit you using all or any obscure rules and regs she can pull up.  

This is easy to carry on with new teachers because there are a million things you won't know upfront.  She will sniff out individual minds she can't manipulate or control and target you for extinction via the rule book if she wants you out.  By this, I am saying that she doesn't necessarily pick on you due to incompetency.  And even if you are a weak teacher, the manner in which she will attack you is uncalled for and unprofessional.  I saw teachers crying here every week!!  But I hesitate to call any teacher here weak.  These are all new teachers who mostly need to be mentored and guided and nurtured.  Attacking them for their inexperience is simply one of her creepy war tactics.

This principal isn't about nurturing.  She missed her calling as a drill instructor and believes cruelty and abuse will either put you in line or break you down enough to leave the school.  If you don't get her approval, you won't have it from the others either. She convinces other staff that you are basically destroying her school and horrible for kids and turns the weak ones (who usually receive favoritism) against you.  And since she generally likes to work by the book and follows rules to a "T" no one ever suspects her of lying or twisting facts when she chooses to do so in order to bully and discredit you.  I found her personality frightening!!  Ethics and morality and compassion are only useful to her if they don't disturb her control.

When I worked here she kept the union rep on a tight leash and he was NOT there to protect or inform teachers.  I learned this prinicipal was a former union chair so you can bet she knows your rights better than you do.  But she only uses them to scare and manipulate you and prefers to keep you in the dark.  

Granted, if you are not in the middle of all this, I am going to sound like some disgruntled former employee.  She is fabulous about putting on a show for important visitors.  She is all about test scores and appearances.  That's what the higher ups and parents seem to be moved by and she knows this is how to manipulate what they see and understand about what happens at MS247. Even you will be fooled the first time you meet her.   

I see that she wants this school and students to be better but many of her efforts are misguided.  Interrogating kids in your class, or hiding outside your door to find out what you are *really* doing isn't professional.   She didn't use the eval/observation process to help you improve when I was there.  Asking you to work impossible hours without compensation or efforts of appreciation is just wrong (only her favorites get compliments).   Asking for all your assessments to review and making all your copies and rejecting things she doesn't approve of shows she has no faith or trust in you as a professional and you will feel like a child under her leadership.  Asking you teach classes or run clubs you are not trained for and then terrorizing you when you're not perfect is just twisted.  Watching your every move and blowing all things out of proportion when you don't do everything right is just stalkerish and overdramatic.  Reprimanding you in front of staff and students is demoraling and cruel.  Turning kids against you is just weird and gang-like.  She won't tolerate crying from students and she will think you are dirt when she makes you cry (and she will).  She actually suggested I had mental problems when I cried in front of her once.  ONCE.  She seems emotionally disconnected from the mental cruelty she imposes on you which is just.... sadistic.  She has no problem attacking you personally and this is harassment.

She fails to see the importance of anyone else's opinion, she will never admit she is wrong or makes bad decisions, and her obsession with control and perfection won't allow her to see that young teachers need to be appropriately mentored-- not abused because they don't do everything perfect.  

My heart goes out to the students and teachers she bullied.  I honestly felt I had PTSD after escaping this school because I had to put up with long term mental cruelty and emotional abuse. I tolerated so much more than I had to in retrospect because I didn't know my rights.  

If you work here and feel you are being treated unprofessionally, I urge you to document all of these principal's words and actions.  Get support from outside of this school from other union people and admin who can help.  It should help, but ultimately, I believe this principal is a product of the system and thrives here because it's almost impossible to prove how unprofessional she really is.  Most teachers she bullies simply leave to escape her.  

Do not trust your first impressions.  This admin and her school are not what they appear to be.  There is a lot of unseen emotional turmoil among this staff and definitely an atmposhere of terror.  Save yourself the grief of being bullied or the grief of helplessly watching your colleagues be bullied and work somewhere else.

Wow!!! This sounds like my school!!! It's unbelievable what Admin's are allowed to get away with in nyc schools today. Let me give you an example of Ms. Aguirre's management style.  We all agreed on the terms for sending students out of class at the start of the year.  The first time I sent a student to the office, some minutes later another student returned to my room, looked at me with disdain and shoved a post-it note at me from the principal.  It read, "REFLECT ON YOUR MANAGEMENT!!!  SEND WORK!!!"  What kind of "leader" does this to her staff?  Do you know what it's like to be reprimanded by the principal in the middle of class via post-it note and a 7th grader with attitude?  Unfortunately, this is Ms. Aguirre's bizarre and sadistic management style.  Nonsensical abuse.  If you tick her off, catch her in a bad mood, or if she decides you simply just don't fit in,  she turns kids against you and does absolutely anything it will take to sucker punch your morale.   This principal needs to reflect on her management and what it means to be a leader.  Sadly, I don't think even an interpersonal relationship course or a leadership course could help her.  She does as she pleases without consequence and knows she can get away with it because she's the only admin and teachers just leave to get away from her.   Absolutely no one but the teachers (and students) she picks on knows how damaging she is on the human spirit.

Students each lunch at 10:30am at this school.  It's too early.  When's breakfast? They're starving by the afternoon.  But it's a shared space with an elementary school and they have no control over this.  The setting is too small.  Some teachers haven't had their own rooms and run around all through the day and all week from room to room.  This affects stability and organization for teacher.  Classes have been held in the hallway.  Principal runs the school like a bootcamp.  Too many inexperienced teachers.
This is not true we don't eat lunch at 10:30 am. Stop lying!!
In DLMS we don't eat lunch at 10:30 am, we eat at one. So stop lying!!
This may not be true now but in its early days lunch really was that early in the morning.  It was just silly.

I was also there in the first years.  I forgot about that.  Lunch was wildly early at 10:30am and a couple of teachers did actually teach classes in the hallway.  Some didn't have rooms at all and wheeled a little board with supplies through the hallway all day long teaching wherever.  I recall one saying she changed rooms 10 times over the course of one week!!  It's a hard thing to forget as I've never heard of that since.  For everything we put up with and went through, we should have been treated better.  We worked our tails off and were scared all the time of being in trouble by this principal (Ms. Aguirre).  I have worse memories of teaching at this school than my actual middle school experience when I was a kid!!!!!

According to the Dept of Education's 2009-2010 NYC School Survey,  MS 247 has nearly 80% new teachers who have been teaching only 1-3 years.  Almost 25% less than one year!  Principal Claudia Aguirre has been the principal of this school since 2003 and has had little success keeping good, experienced staff.  When you chase that many staff out of your school year after year, you have to stop blaming teachers for absolutely everything and question the leadership and the overall professional climate.  It is a disservice to students to have so many new teachers in the classroom who are going to be in survival mode and learning the ropes every single year.  Good schools have teachers who never want to leave.  They stay and master their subjects.  Good schools nurture their teachers and support them and offer opportunities to grow and develop professionally.  Good leaders respect and inspire their staff and make them feel like part of a team.  If there was actual school-wide respect, support, and community at MS 247 generated by this principal then teachers wouldn't be quitting every year to escape the poor morale at this school.  This school suffers from poor leadership.
iknow we were told to say nice thinggs here but this school is like being at bootcamp.  you dont want to get in trouble here.  ms. Aguirre will make you cry.  She just keeps at it until you do

wow...very mature

Oh lord, thank you!! thank you!! to the teachers who have recently posted their honest thoughts and experiences with this school!  I taught here for one year and was completely traumatized by this principal.  And why?  Because she tried to cover up a poor decision on her behalf and set out to discredit me so she wouldn't look bad.  She hired me in my subject area and then when school started she told me I was to teach a very technical subject I was NOT trained to teach!!  I was not put in my subject area AT ALL.  As a new teacher to NYC I didn't know that I only had 48 hours to submit a grievance for being given a schedule 100% outside of your credentialed subject.  She exploited me.  I was not disrespectful but I expressed my discomfort to this principal, Claudia Aguirre.  Boy did this upset her.  She just doesn't accept complaints or resistance... you will do whatever she asks even if she has to shove it down your throat.  I was stuck in that uncomfortable position and she wrote me off from the start.  She literally stalked me all year and set out to discredit me at every turn.  She even made up lies.  I couldn't believe a principal could act this way.  She never, and I mean NEVER, had one kind word to say to me or one supportive thing to offer.  She just wanted me out.  It was the most bizarre experience I have ever had in teaching and to this day I have never seen a principal behave so cruelly and unethically.  You don't set teachers up to fail this way.  At the very least she could have helped me to be a better teacher in the subject I had ZERO training for.  Instead she was mean and vicious and put me down on many occasions in front of other teachers, office staff, and students.  I can't even begin to explain the injustice I experienced here.  And what did I do?  Nothing wrong.  Nothing... I did not deserve what she did to me that year.  I did my best to adapt but her abuse and constant attacks made it difficult to focus on teaching at all.  When I finally left it was like being rescued from HELL.  Literally.  She plays creepy mind games with her staff.  She always acts like you're in BIG TROUBLE walking around with a union rep who behaves like her henchman.  I can only say you have to be in it to understand how completely incompetent and unstable this principal is in the area of nurturing teachers.  It's like you ARE in middle school and the biggest bully around is after you.  Claudia... if you read this... SHAME ON YOU for what you did to me... to US ... ALL OF US.  So many staff quit that year... none of us could stand you and we were all terrified of you, even the kids.  Do not work here and do not send your kids here.  Kids are not emotionally safe here anymore than the teachers.
You're welcome.  No one deserves what we went through.  We survived.

As the saying goes, nothing good lasts forever.  The original founders of the school had the great concept that children should be proud of their heritage and then go on to incorporate the new culture in which they now live.  Also, to become proficient not only in their native language but as proficient in their second language. "El que sabe dos idiomas cuenta por dos."  Bilingualism in this world is a key to success.  That being said, a school is not a totalitarian state.  It "takes a village to raise a child", well it takes not only a good leader but good teachers.  Who are equally invested in having their students succeed.  Dual Language has and has had good teachers in the past.  However, teachers cannot function in an environment where they are harrassed, bullied and treated in an unprofessional manner.  Cooperation between the principal and the teachers needs to exist.  Yes, guidance can and should be provided by a principal, not confrontation and undermining of confidence.  After having worked there many years, I too saw many able teachers leave because of the work environment. No amount of supplies, computers, grants, and trips can compensate the support and encouragement needed by a teacher every day.  Even the most dedicated (and most try to stay and endure) get worn down by the ambiance. I wish the school well always.  I, like most of the teachers with whom I served loved and tried to do our best for the students.  I hope the principal forgets about stats and scores and remembers that it's the teachers, in their classrooms, on a daily basis that makes or breaks a school.  Undermining and abusing them cannot translate into good results for the students.

This is a principal (Claudia Aguirre) who divides her staff.  She hooks a few with favoritism who will do anything she asks, including post here.  Those who question anything are not treated well at all and will be discredited and ultimately chased out of her school.  I watched a lot of very competent teachers walk away from this school.  Unhappy, stressed out teachers is not a healthy environment for children.  I encourage you to let the facts speak for themselves.  Look at her teacher retention rate from year to year.  Look at her school scores and status as a school in need of improvement.  Do not be deceived if you tour this school and and are impressed by all the artistic visuals and the polite students and staff who meet with you.  They are all handpicked and coached to deal with you.  When I was there many of the teachers felt there was more of an emphasis on projects and pretty things that can hang on the walls to impress visitors than there is on reading and writing.  It's my belief that this principal has avoided a union movement against her because she keeps a tight leash on the union rep and tends to hire inexperienced teachers who don't know their right... and who usually run for the hills once they experience the abusive nature of this principal.  I do not recommend this school for students or any staff.  Do your homework and you will find the facts speak for themselves.

She did divide us.  I remember this well.  There was a pretty blond art teacher she treated like her little princess in those early days since she "beautified" her school.  Dressed up those walls.  Made it great for visitors.  And Claudia was all about appearances.  The rest of us were her trollish step children by comparison.  If you weren't doing something to make her look good, she had you tagged for extinction via harassment by the end of the year. So you had to come to her school with something to offer.  She was very good at vilifying certain teachers and making others feel like they were saving the school, esp by shunning those she vilified.  When really, she should have been mentoring us all to be better teachers and given us opportunities to contribute.

Whatever this principal is accomplishing is out of brute force and intense micromanaging.  Look at her history of retaining teachers.  It's terrible.  A good school has stability and retains teachers.    This is an emotionally unhealthy place to work and teachers leaving have nothing to do with their competence as she may conveniently blame.  Students and staff are terrorized by this principal and she misinterprets this fear as respect.  Moreover, this continues to be a failing school and in need of inprovement.  Her scores may be higher since before she was principal there, but after nearly 8 yrs she is STILL a failing school.  My grad program blacklisted her school and refused to send anymore of their teachers to her due to the widespread teacher abuse/lack of retention.
Principal has favoritism
Not true. People have a grand misconception on what it means to favor a child and what it means to acknowledge a student that is obviously working hard.
"I've been in the school for already three years and what I have to say about it is that I go to the best school in New York City," writes 8th grader Karina.
"I like it. There are a lot of opportunities. We went to the museum and we went to the movies," says one student.

A parent notes that DLMS was designated as "in need of improvement" because a few students in a particular demographic subgroup were not able to take the state tests. "This is a fabulous school with strong leadership, thoughtful and rigorous academics, and a caring community," this parent writes."

I finally graduated and it seems like it took forever but I finally did it. I think that the school needs a little updating. Teachers and staff are great and want you to succeed but some of the students who have behavior issues make it hard for others to learn.  Mr. Kehoe is amazing takes our learning to the next level. Our Counselor Ms. Perez is great she tries hard to help us and doesn't judge us.  We can come to her with any problem and she will listen and give us time to relax and refocus. Ms. Rodriguez and Ms. Medina are also amazing they are more than just ladies in the office they also listen to our problems when Ms. Perez isn't available.  I think that if you try hard and stay away from middle school drama you can succeed at West Side Collaborative. I will miss everyone.

I think the review above is somewhat out dated. It is not as progressive as it probably used to be. They do have small class sizes but I have not seen any project based learning except during I-explore week.The school is struggling with a difficult student body and I am not sure that the staff has quite a handle on it. We have seen and heard a lot of bullying. I agree with the student below on the noise level in the classrooms and Mr. Kehoe and Mr. Weissman being amazing. The staff is well meaning and I hope the school can attract more inspiring teachers.

Students in the school are very unintelligent, though I would say it's not the teachers' fault. Classes are often very noisy and it's hard to focus. Most teachers do a great job but some of the students are just ridiculous. But to be frankly there isn't any physical bullying inside the school. I am graduating WSC this year. Shout out to Mr. Kehoe and Mr. Weissman best teachers in the school.

Teachers at MS 250 West Side Collaborative are working to change the testing culture at the school, by using regular "check-ups" rather than relying just on high-stakes tests. Listen to the Schoolbook story here.
At West Side Collaborative, teachers urge students to talk about race and find the conversations far from simple. Read more here.

After a year that saw high-profile police shootings plus the deadly attack on a black church in South Carolina, middle school teacher, Ms. Caruso from West Side Collaborative told WNYC their classrooms were abuzz with personal and sometimes difficult conversations. Read more here.

West Side Collaborative will forge a partnership with the New York Historical Society as part of Teen Thursdays, a new after school initiative to offer middle schoolers the rich learning opportunities available through local cultural institutions. Read more here.
DNAinfo reports that West Side Collaborative's principal Jeanne Rotunda is retiring, effective February 24, 2014. A new principal has not yet been named.
West Side Collaborative receives Blackboard award for being the Rising Star of middle schools.

Responsible  use of internet and social media were the focus at WSC's  Digital Citizenship Day, meant to educate young people about the right ways to use the web.http://gothamschools.org/2012/10/05/students-weigh-ethics-of-facebook-at-west-side-collaborative/#more-92435

GothamSchools reported on Digital Citizenship day at the school. As part of the day's special programming, students discussed the ethics of Facebook, downloading music and digital copyright and more. Chancellor Dennis Walcott visited for the event. Read more: Student Weigh Ethics of Facebook at West Side Collaborative

iMatter day, a recent activity initiated by the  student council,    was described on the Department of Education website. The day featured student led workshops. Read about it at http://schools.nyc.gov/Home/InOurSchoolsToday/2011-2012/imatterdayatms250.htm

West Side Collaborative not only help me with the process of self discovery, but put me on a path to success. Collaborations with many different organizations not only allowed me to explore throughout the city but eventually helped me start on an international journey. When applying to West Side Collaborative as a 5th grader I didn't know I was taking a  step that would foster my future as a performer, singer, and conductor. I thank the staff and Ms. Rotunda for investing in me and helping me succeed not only as a student but as a human being.

Highly impressed with collabration with AMNH, Bronx Zoo, and Central Park Zoo into science curriculum. Wonderful to expose students to these wonderful experiences that many NYC students don't often get.

West Side Collaborative was able to get me into a great high school, a high school I would have never thought would be perfect for me. WSC has taught me to "think out side of the box". It has taught me many more, I can make a never ending list about the things I loved about WSC, but it wouldn't matter. What matters is how WSC still has an effect on my life after having graduated three years ago and where it has bought me in life today.

Going to West Side Collaborative was one of the best experiences in my life. WSC has always made me feel like I was at home. Coming back three years after I graduated all the teachers still remembered my name. Being a junior in high school I still use many of the things I was taught during my middle school years. All of my readers and writers classes have prepared me for high school. I still use the words I was taught in Mr.Rushing's 7th grade readers and writers. WSC did not only prepare me for my classes in high school but it also prepared me for the person I am in high school, it has taught me to be independent but also very out-going.

"As a School Counseling intern, I can tell you that this school is definitely an A+ School. The collaboration between all teachers and counselor is quite rare and this school is the exception. Students come to school and attend to their classes which they actually enjoy because the teachers have a wonderful technique that makes learning fun and enjoyable. The staff including the principal are all in communication with one another which makes learning and putting together great curriculum to teach the students easier. As a soon to be School Counselor I hope to find myself employed at a school just like WSC."

"As a recent graduate from west side I can say that west side was a good warm up for high school. At west side i learned several things that helped me in high school. For example in seventh grade readers and writers my teacher Mr. Rushing taught the class about vocabulary and how the words are like greek and latin words. Now in High School most of the words that he taught us and stuck in our heads are words that are given in my readers and writers quiz now. I can also say that west side shaped the person I am now. With West Side rules and activities they taught me how to be confident, smart, and intelligent."

"As a recent graduate of West Side Collaborative, I feel like I have grown so much. My experience in this school was great. I love it and enjoy coming back to visit. I loved PGL class, they talked about all the different things that teens go trough and it's just really fun. Ever since I came to this school I have came out of my shell. I was the really shy one but my teachers have taken me out of that shell and now I am the loud one. I will always remember the wonderful teachers that I had and all the great things we did."
"I feel safe and comfortable being in this school," writes student Alex. "It is a small school and warm and welcoming."

A math coach who has worked in the school writes, "I have worked in many schools during my long career and I find WSC one of the best. There are many things that set it apart--teachers, high academic standards, a dedicated, creative principal, and conscientious students, but what impresses me most is the tone. There is a quiet, comforting and comfortable feeling and students interact with each other and with the teachers in a respectful manner."

An 8th grader writes, "I think this school is a great environment and a safe place to be to learn so much. I am going to miss the teachers because once you get into the school it's like they are always going to be there and respect you. When you are in class you have to always be ready to do work with a pen or pencil ... I love the way we this school is with major events that are really cool like Halloween. I will always remember my greatness of this school ... it's like I never want to leave."

"When I first came to this school I was resistant because I went to PS 75 and I didn't want to be in the same building," writes Michelle, a student. "Then when I met the other kids I felt safe. Especially because I made very strong relationships with all of the teachers. It does get a little cramped but that's the only glitch."

"West Side Collaborative Middle School is indeed a very good school with a dedicated staff of teachers who use the portfolio method for educating its students," writes a parent. "The subjects overlap and are taught well. Often overlooked [by the] district 3 middle school fairs, it has much to offer and the graduation (2003) was the best non-traditional, student-focused ceremony I've attended in YEARS! They need better Parent Association and more pressure on local politicians and the Superintendent-this might help the overcrowding and resources issues."

Jhana M., a student, writes that while the school "may be cramped," it is "like a family." The school has a "great curriculum," she writes. "All I have to say is that all of the kids that haven't gone to this school deserve another chance to go to middle school because they don't have any idea what they are missing. "

Lafayette Academy won support from Community Board 7 on Tuesday to add grades 9-12 and start offering an International Baccalaureate diploma that will prepare students for high-paying international jobs. The expansion will require the DOE to find more space for the expanded grades, and would become the first dual language high school program located in District 3, Patch reports.

Just checking in to say we're on our second child to attend MS256 under Principal Zager, and things are getting better and better. The PTA is blossoming, and the teachers (by in large the same roster our first child learned from, starting five years ago, continue to be smart, hard-working, dedicated. Our 6th grader has a field trip to Philadelphia next week, which is traditional at MS256/Lafayette Academy. 



The chorus program under Mr. McKanstry is already amazing, and just keeps getting better. They have a performance of Lion King coming up, and even the previews were impressive, especially for a Middle School. The school has a soccer team this year for the first time, and their other athletic programs get better and better. It's still a "young" school, but we have been very pleased with the experience our kids have had here.


One of the most important things for us is the diversity of students and teachers, which has been mentioned by other parents here. Lafayette Academy stands for and delivers the kind of experience more NYC school children should be having. My kids have friends from many other countries and cultures--they learn to understand and help each other to be better people and to build better, more inclusive, more educated communities.

Parent "Six" writes:

Our daughter enrolled in MS256 last year as a Grade 7 student in the French dual-language program and has returned this year for Grade 8. We chose the school as she had come from a bilingual French elementary school program. The current principal, Brian Zager, is a very engaged and caring individual. He, along with a very dedicated group of teachers and administration, has moved the school in a very positive direction. Among many other examples, they introduced a multi-grade level Chorus program last year and the school was recently recognized by the French government for their dual language program and awarded the LabelFrancEduation. The class sizes are typical for NYC public schools but there are no disciplinary or bullying issues. The school is a mix of children from a ll ethnic backgrounds and I think could be a model for the integration that the NYC DOE is striving to achieve. It would be wonderful for the school if more parents discovered how improved it is, since the last reviews were posted on this site, and chose to send their children here so that it could continue to expand and develop for all current and potential students.
Can anyone comment on the vibe of the school in the past year? Has it changed?

My child has only been a student during the administration of the new Principal, Brian Zager, but that has been the last full two years. It seems that a lot of information about 256 is outdated on this site. We have had a great experience at 256: extremely involved teachers, no bullying on campus, a thriving dual-language French program (which is why we chose this school for our son), growing extracurricular activities, ever-increasing parental and community involvement and school spirit. 
There are a lot of comments here that say MS256 needs to change, and I truly believe that based on what I'm reading here, within the last two years, it has changed drastically, for the better.
Our son attended an outstanding elementary school, and I feel like MS256 has been an extension of his education there. Thoughtful cross-curriculum education, great field trips and in-school opportunities with community programs (photography, fundraisers for Wounded Warriors and schools in Africa), good parent-teacher interaction, etc. 
Obviously, no school is perfect, but I feel very happy with the quality of education and care our son has received the past two years at MS256, and he's having a good 8th grade year so far.

Also, this just in! The French government has awarded MS256 with LabelFrancÉducation, a rather prestigious certification awarded to French dual-language programs abroad. MS256 is one of only five middle school programs in the United States to receive this honor.
Does anybody in the French Dual Language program at MS 256 have any updates to share?

Candida Frith has been named the Interim Acting Principal at PS 256. She will replace former principal Jeffrey Perl, who resigned from his position at the start of the 2013-2014 school year. Read more here.

It is rather remarkable how many lies and falsehoods are presented as fact in the two posts below.  I could write a book detailing how wring these posters are, but what good would that serve?  The self-appointed representative of the "concerned teachers" ignores his or her own shortcomings (along with the colleagues he/she claims to represent) and blames everything on the principal and assistant principal.  In fact, many of these "concerned teachers" were far more focused on holding students accountable (code for punishing them) then with making sure they learned.  This is pretty accurately reflected in the Common Core test data - especially in 7th and 8th grade Math, where not one student scored above a Level 2. Literacy scores in Grades 7 and 8 weren't much better and, not surprisingly, the 7th and 8th grade math teachers both left the school (along with the 7th grade English teacher).  The school also didn't meet expectations on the 8th grade state Science exam and that teacher also left.  Noticing a trend?  Let's not forget that teachers taught those classes - not the principal or the assistant principal.  Did many teachers work hard and do their best?  Of course they did!  But their best wasn't good enough and the principal and assistant principal made them aware of this fact.  Apparently these people are in denial about their skills and are far better at giving criticism than receiving it. 


Did the principal put the needs of the students above the needs of the teachers?  Yes, I would say he did.  And he actually listened to what students had to say, as opposed to throwing everyone in detention all the time for the most minor of transgressions.  The principal thought his job was to make sure that students were learning and had a voice, not to make sure all the teachers were happy all the time and were allowed to do whatever they wanted without consequence.  It's true that there was no school-wide detention.  It's also true that I don't know one parent who considers this to be the most important service a school offers.  


Don't believe everything you read on this site as there are definitely two sides to this story.  And yes - many teachers and the principal did leave MS 256 at the end of the 2012-2013 school year, so anything you read here is now already out of date.  If you're considering MS 256 for your child, visit the school - talk to the new teachers (I hear they are amazing) and the ones who stuck around (quite a few did!), as well as the students and parents.  Most of them have nothing but good things to say about the school.  Then decide if it's a good fit for you.  I'm not making a recommendation one way or the other.  I just want you to be informed.


Oh - also take note that the French Dual Language Program did not launch this year due to low enrollment.  The new principal decided to wait until September 2014, pending more students.

I have a question Mr. or Ms. "In The Know at 256" how good can your best be if no one listens? How can you teach someone who doesn't wan't to learn? How can you teach a class when your voice can't be heard do to the fact that "some" students couldn't be quiet the whole class period day after day? Teachers can only do so much and It falls to the principal to do the rest and clearly she didn't do anything effective! With this in mind we shouldn't be pointing fingers, instead we should be looking for the answer to fix these issues going on in the school.

Dear 8th Grader - you make some very valid points.  Yes - teachers can only do so much.  In many ways, the same is true for the principal as well.  A principal (or assistant principal) can't teach all the classes for the teacher that is struggling.  Administrators can't write all the lessons and hold every individual student accountable for everything he or she does each period.  If the principal could do all this, then there'd be no need for teachers!  The principal does need to support and help teachers, do his or her best to make them better, and hold them accountable if they never show improvement.  You are 100% right, a class cannot be taught if students are unwilling to listen and focus.  The same is true for a teacher who is given strategies to use to help get the class to listen, but ignores them because he or she "knows better."  In an effective school, the teachers and the principal work together to solve problems and support one another.  Sadly, regardless of who has been the prinicpal at MS 256 over the last few years, this has not been the case.  This isn't to say the principals didn't try - I am sure they did, but the results weren't what they could have been,  You are correct that improvement should not be about pointing fingers, it should be about working together.  No one wants to fail.  I hope MS 256 is able to do this going forward.

I absolutely agree with your statement, "The same is true for a teacher who is given strategies to use to help get the class to listen, but ignores them because he or she "knows better."" However, I was there and I do not remember any of my teachers giving up on anyone. That was the saddest part of all because I had to sit there and watch my teachers get curse at for just trying to help students catch up. I had to sit there and listen to how students disrespected my instructors day after days.

The principal at 256 for 2012-13 (and years prior) did not "leave the school." The principal was forced to resign in exchange for their continued employment within the DOE. Failure to resign would have resulted in termination.  

What superintendent would fire a principal if they "put the needs of the students above the needs of the teachers?" Such a statement exposes an inherently divisive attitude. A good principal should not choose between the needs of the teachers or the students. Often the needs of the students and the needs of the teachers are one - structure, safety, and support. For years, the students and teachers of this school had none of those things. 

As for the 2013-14 year, the school is already in a better place because of the former principal's removal. Many hardworking teachers remain and with time the school will heal.

Perspective is a fascinating thing.  Clearly you harbor anger and hostility towards the former principal.  That's fine, but it's not really about reviewing the school. it's more about your personal issues.  The bottom line is the principal isn't there anymore.  (Though I should point out he wasn't fired - and this isn't really the forum to debate the how and why of his resignation).  Either way, the school is moving forward and we agree that there are hardworking teachers there.  I will point out that regardless of who the principal is, so we're clear - a "good" principal puts the needs of the students first.  Period.  When there is a conflict between what is in the best interests of the students and what is in the best interests of the teachers - I want a principal who is going to put my child's needs first.  End of discussion,  I could see how a teacher (who probably isn't a parent) might think otherwise.

The post below is largely accurate. At least 8 out of 16 teachers are leaving at the end of this school year. Many of these teachers (as well as those who are staying) are wonderful although not perfect, and they worked as a team to sustain and improve the school. This comes on the heels of another mass departure of teachers three years ago. Even the principal himself tried to leave by proposing this past spring to open his own new school in the city.

The school has no detention. There are no consistent consequences for bullying and aggressive behavior. Day in and day out students get away with conduct that interferes with classes and makes others feel unsafe and vulnerable. Students regularly curse at teachers and other students, students regularly cut class and come late to class and school, students regularly ignore requests to follow school rules, and nothing happens the same day or the next despite immediate documentation by teachers. Parents are rarely summoned except in the most egregious cases. Students learn the lesson that they can do what they want to adults and other students without fear of repercussions of any kind.

The principal and assistant principal spend most of their time in the office. They very rarely enter classrooms to work with teachers or students, and when they do the students tend to act even worse. They have little idea, even in general terms, what students are studying at any given point.

Co-taught ICT classes are often left with only one teacher to cover them. New teacher mentoring is a sham, used as cover to justify poor reviews given to newer teachers who understandably struggle. Teacher observation reports are regularly returned months after the observation is conducted, and they are riddled with falsehoods and misrepresentations that they hope the teachers will overlook.

The community partnerships listed above are not accurate. The school does not have a relationship with Morningside Center, ENACT, or the Schubert Arts Foundation. In 2012-13, the school had a part-time music teacher, bringing the joy of music education to students for the first time in years at the school. This teacher was not invited back for 2013-14. Money that would have supported the position will instead be used to pay for a full-time AP for the 165 student school. 

Read the DOE learning environment reports for the last three years. Read this past year’s report after it is released later in the summer (but do not believe that 95 percent of parents responded to the survey this past year; this is a fabrication).

It is worse than you can imagine, and the blame falls squarely on the principal and the AP. If your child is going to go here next year, prepare to be shocked at what they, and you, will see and hear.
Watch an interview with Principal Jeffrey S. Perl here

I know the ins and outs of this school. I know staff dynamics, teacher-student interactions, and the politics within the school. Due to the outdated and vague description of MS256, I take it as my moral responsibility to shed some truth to all the good-hearted, decent human beings out there who should never have to deal with the level of unprofessionalism in which this school is drowning. Whether you heed my warnings or take it as a grain of salt, if you choose to work at this school, I am confident that you’ll come to realize all that I have written here is true.

I shall start out by saying that the teachers are the ones who have poured their heart, blood, and sweat into improving this school. Ironically, the teachers are rarely recognized for their hard work. Instead, they are constantly undermined, ridiculed, or dismissed by the administration. Teaching is hard enough as it is, seeing how we are responsible for the academic future of all our students, but rather than receiving any support, teachers are left to fend for themselves. The only way you can possibly get support is if you compromise yourself and your pure-intentions of why you started teaching in the first place. There is a pungent unspoken agreement between these “compromisers” and administration. One of the mottos that seems to be running between them is: if you have my back, I have yours. And what about the teachers who stick to their pure-intentions and refuse to “drink the kool-aid”? Well, let me just say that currently, there is a mass exodus in this school. As the principal has said a couple of times this year, “I’m the principal, I make the decisions, and if you don’t like it, then you can leave!” 

The principal is quick to side with the students rather than ever giving teachers the benefit of the doubt. Thus, a message is sent to all the kids that they can do whatever they want. Oh, am I failing a class in Mr. X’s class? Well, I’m going to talk to Mr. Perl! And what happens as a result to this kid whining and complaining about failing Mr. X’s class because she refused to do any work or pay attention in class? Mr. Perl undermines the teacher by basically allowing this particular student to pass. This is just one in the multiple cases where he has done that. Thus, every student in this school knows that they can do whatever they want...which means they treat teachers with the utmost disrespect...and if the teacher addresses this to the principal, the principal dismisses it... 
I can write a 30 page paper detailing why teachers should not bother applying to this school, but I am going to end this post with this:

As said by Harvey in The Dark Knight, “You either die a hero or live long enough to see yourself become the villain.”

M.S 256 is a participant in the Wellness in the Schools Cook for
Kids program, which replaces the traditional cafeteria menu with a healthy
menu based on scratch cooking and fresh ingredients. WITS places a
trained culinary profession in the school cafeteria to prepare fresh meals from
scratch, engage students, and educate families about the importance of eating
whole, unprocessed foods through interactive cooking demonstrations called WITS
Labs. You can find out more about programming from Wellness in the Schools and
see a list of participating schools online at www.wellnessintheschools.org

For the second year in a row, M.S. 256 is on the state's list of Persistently Dangerous Schools under the federal No Child Left Behind Act (August 2010). To be removed from the list, school's must demonstrate "two consecutive years of progress in reducing violent incidents," among other criteria, according to the state. Find more information on the 2010/2011 list here.
