Were you a student of John Taylor Gatto?


If you were a student of his, I would like to reach out to you for 
participation in a "This is Your Life" styled project.  John had a 
stroke last year and is in his 70's. His mind is in great shape, but his
 body still faces challenges.  A group of us who admire John and his 
body of work have been making efforts to improve his condition.  We think it would be excellent for John's spirits if we could contact former students who would be willing to share with him how he has influenced your life. We will likely set up a meeting via skype for those outside of the New York City area where John now lives.  We would also like to reach out to you and offer you the opportunity to learn more about John's condition to see if you might be able to help him
 meet any needs he has that would help assist in his recovery.  If you 
were not a student, but know someone who was, please forward this to 
them. Thank you!


p.s. Please contact me on FB - Tristan J Carax, and I will have the 
person in charge of setting this stuff up, contact you. Thanks again.

I am a volunteer at Wadleigh, working as a tutor and as a member of the School Leadership Team.  As a member of First Corinthian Baptist Church, located two blocks from Wadleigh, I became involved as a result of Pastor Michael A. Walrond, Jr.'s focus on the injustices, such as school closings, co-locations, and budget cuts, that are being visited upon district schools in our community. Separate and UNEQUAL schools are the result.  Although I continue to fight against these unfair policies, I and other members of our congregation and the community are working with Principal Chin and his staff (conditions are turning around) and the rest of my comments will be in that vein.  

I agree that the arts programs at Wadleigh are top notch.  I've met most if not all of the arts teachers and many of the students.  Both teachers and students are passionate about their work which is apparent when you talk with them and see their output.  However, there are other positive occurrences in the environment which you might miss if you are here for just a short period of time or don't talk with other students and teachers who are just as passionate about their work.

For example, one of the Global Studies/ History teachers coaches a Mock Trial team where students are taught court room practices and strategies by attorneys who volunteer to work in the program which meets on Saturdays.  Last year, the team beat one of the most prestigious private schools in this city.   Can a Thurgood Marshall or a Sonia Sotomayor come out of Wadleigh?  Of course one can if you have a passion for the possible and work from that perspective, something Pastor Mike presses upon our congregation, and something I see in many students and teachers I meet here. 

I'd like to say something about a couple of other comments that you made.  I am in the school often at different times of the day and see the movement of students through the corridors.  There is very little, if any, loitering in the halls or in the stairwells, something I did see before Mr. Chin's arrival.  Also,  classroom desks are not arranged haphazardly but in a way that encourages small group cooperation.  It's one of the new, modern techniques of classroom management.

Finally, technology is being implemented in many exciting ways.  Several new Smart Boards and other technological devices, hardware  and software, have been added and a coach is training the staff in their use.   Not only will this facilitate teaching but also communication between staff, students, and their parents.

Is there room for continued improvement?  Of course, and we continue to push for that.  But a lot of positive change has happened since Mr. Chin's arrival less than a year ago and Wadleigh is on an upward swing.

I have had it up to my eyeballs with the negativity about Wadleigh.  People come in and take a snap shots and form and assessment of Wadleigh in one day (maybe 3) and put something in print and parents and students who can benefit from being in a community based school are turned off without doing their OWN legwork.  Enough!  IT takes a real man or woman to dig in and get dirty and meet the challenge of working for a school where the political and socioeconomic odds are stacked against you.  There are people who do it every day and ignore the pressure of the interlopers and people who offer nothing except criticism from an external standpoint.

Joshua Johnson was on Ellen, and had the initiative to tap dance his way through college.  Good for him!  He played Wadleigh Basketball too! Tune into the the NCAA and see athletes Johnathan Coleman, wide receiver (2014) Boston College, Josh Watkins PAC 10 (2012) University of Utah, Karim Rowson, 2010 grad, University of South Dakota, (2014) William Harrison, Quinnipiac and University of Bridgeport (2012) Wadleigh Class of 2008, Trivonte Bloodman Mississippi State class 2015 (Wadleigh 2010) and there are many, many more.  Do you want to know about something positive?  I have many more success stories that played sports and made a college career out of it from Wadleigh.  My point is this is an economically deprived community with a parent base that needs to step up to the plate and meet the educators half way.  CAthy Black had the courage to speak on parents who have kids and leave them for strangers to raise.  The most profound thing she contributed doomed her.

Tyee Chin is a good man and has pointed the staff in the right direction.  While it is not easy and there are no excuses when you take the job as an educator, I want to see who is willing to help this population out and not who can point out hairy moles and imperfections.  Wadleigh can work and with the right support can continue to be a viable educational outlet for all communities. Anyone who is cowardly enough to throw Wadleigh under the bus, know the good things that are going on and the lowest common denominator of any sport is sitting on the sidelines waiting for action to take place.  I'm making the action happen and I have sent over 40 kids to college on full rides from Wadleigh as student athletes.  Check us on MTV 2, MSG VArsity, ESPN New York or just Google or Bing us...Wadleigh Tigers Basketball.

Coach Crump
Tiger Life

Bill de Blasio tells teachers and students to fight sharing space with Harlem Success Academy next year. Read the full story: Public Advocate Tells Students, Teachers at Harlem School to Fight Co-Location Plan.

District 3 Presidents’ Council President, Michelle Ciulla Lipkin, wrote a letter to school chancellor Cathy Black to express their strong opposition to the moving Success Academy Charter School in the Brandeis High School building and to the proposal to expand Harlem Success Academy 1 into PS 149 and eventually into FDA II/Wadleigh High School, arguing that it will hurt District 3 public schools.  Below is an excerpt from the letter:

“Over the last few years, the District 3 community has worked tirelessly to address overcrowding in the district. We need our district school space to go to our district’s students.  We need to accommodate our growing population.  We need additional middle schools and high schools.  We cannot afford to lose any seats. 

The idea that the Upper West Success charter was approved without a site determined shows lack of planning and forethought. There was never room in District 3 for Upper West Success and we simply cannot accommodate this charter school. The District 3 Community Education Council, Community Board 7, Parent Associations from our District 3 schools, Assembly member Linda Rosenthal, Assembly member Danny O'Donnell, State Senator Tom Duane, State Senator Bill Perkins, Council member Gale Brewer, and Council member Melissa Mark-Viverito have all come together to express disagreement with this co-location. It is imperative that our voices are heard and that this co-location does not move forward.”

Many Harlem residents oppose the expansion of Harlem Success Academy including many public school parents. Read the full article: Public School Parents Protest Harlem Success Academy's Expansion Plans.

At the time that Karen Watts was named the city's first "executive principal," Wadleigh was under investigation by the State Education Department for allowing students to graduate based on inadequate work, according to an article in the New York Times. In the article, which focused on "credit recovery" programs, a state education official said she was looking into whether the graduation requirements at Wadleigh adhered to legal requirements. (April 2008)

"Principal Karen Watts is notorious for avoiding the parents," writes a teacher. "She allows the students to abuse teachers and refuses to discipline students herself. Parent Coordinator Ramona Garcia writes that in 2004 the school officially became an arts school, now called Wadleigh Secondary School for the Performing & Visual Arts. Arts programs include drama, instrumental and vocal music, TV and video production, dance, visual arts including ceramics, and the Wadleigh Express Magazine, among others. A.V.I.D., a college prep advanced placement program, is a new initiative for both middle and high school students. There are now two academic after-school programs, including one on Saturday and athletic teams include boys and girls basketball and track, as well as soccer, baseball and tennis.
" Wadleigh is a great school," write former student, Nadia Gibbs. "The staff is great. When I was sent to Wadleigh everyone talked of how bad it was, but when I got there it was way different."

My son graduated from West Prep last spring.  I have recommended this school to many people because I loved it and my son thrived there.  

I disagree about comments that say they don't care about parent's concerns.  Every one of his teachers throughout the three years that my son was there responded to me whenever I reached out to them (which was a LOT).  My son got personal attention and his academic performance improved over the course of the three years.  Both his math and ELA scored increased.  I am one of Principal Washington's biggest fans and every one of his teachers was excellent.

I get frustrated when I read about parents who complain about West Prep.  I was on the PA Exec Board for all three years that I was there.  The parent involvement at the school is very low, and it was discouraging.  If a parent at the school is unhappy about what is occurring, SHOW UP to the PA meetings and the Principal's breakfasts!!  I went to every meeting and my concerns were always heard.  I also met personally with every teacher and both the AP and Principal all three years. Further, I saw that the school needed support with the students and I volunteered to help out.  I realize that not every parent has a schedule that allows them to go to meetings but surely more parents could have been there than were.  

West Prep's motto is "With the Work of All".  I know that once parents get to middle school they are burned out with volunteering.  However, I truly believe that my son's success at West Prep was due to the efforts of all involved - the school, my son, and me as a parent.

As I said, that was 5 years ago but I trust in the people at the school that they are doing all they can to have the students thrive.

Is it customary to have students in classrooms with no air conditioning on a day when it is 87 degrees,but feels like 96 degrees? Is it true that the only units available are ones that the d.o.e. approve? Can't the schools use funding for kids' comfort? One small fan in the front of a classroom isn't healthy for a class size of approximately 24 plus the teacher! Shouldn't the school get prepared for next year,since it failed to make these students a priority this year.

Yes, many schools in NYC do not have air conditioning but have to keep school open nonetheless.  My daughter's elementary school has the same issue.

Yes, it is true that the only units available are ones that the DOE approves.  At my daughter's elementary school, we raised money specifically for air conditioners, but we could only use DOE approved units AND installers.

Unfortunately, the cost for air conditioners is often prohibitively high because not only do they have to get new AC units, but often the schools are not wired for electricity for AC, and that upgrade has to take place first.  Again, work must be done by DOE approved contractors. 

There is only a certain amount of money available for capital improvements each year.  With budget cuts, schools have to make hard choices about what to spend money on.

My own personal opinion is that school ends 3 weeks too late.  Not much learning happens in the last 2 weeks while teachers are cleaning up classrooms etc.  If it ended in early June, instead of late June, we would avoid the biggest chunk of hot days.

To Former Parent - well, it's been a few months, and I'm just as happy at the school now as I was 2 weeks into it.  I can't speak for the 7th and 8th grade teachers, but the 6th grade teachers are exceptional.  They promptly answer all my emails, have been very supportive of my son, and he is learning a lot.  They have a "super scholar" program where they recognize and reward kids who have acheived over 85% in a quarter, and he's been a super scholar for the first two quarters.  The homework is demanding but not overwhelming.  (I am not a parent who likes homework to begin with, but it's bearable to me.)  The staff is professional and approachable.  The facility is always clean and bright and I feel very welcomed.  If I were to fault anything it would be that the parent participation is low.  The parents I have met are very caring about the quality of the education but the PA meetings are sparsely attended.  I think this is to be expected of a "new" school that is a middle school - I know that many parents are tired after elementary school and don't want to volunteer any more.  Mr. Padilla has done an excellent job in his first full year and I am very pleased.

A parent writes: 
My child  just started kindergarten at PS 452 and we are really impressed with the school overall, with the principal, Scott Parker and with the teachers.  I'm very happy with what I hear from my child and I get a weekly newsletter from her teacher about what they did during the week and will do the upcoming week.   We love that it is a small and growing school.   Mr. Parker is a no nonsense very hands on principal who is super enthusiastic and clearly the leader in terms of the curriculum and the theory behind it, There is a significant expectation of parent involvement, but as a new school I'm not surprised and it's not uncomfortable.   
The specialists are great.  The gym teacher is a runner himself and all grades are part of Mighty Milers You can see their "mileage" online through a NYRR program...  He is also teaching them through many games good sportsmanship which is huge for young children who rarely like to lose!  She has gym 2x a week, music, art, movement, NDI comes once a week (same day as art) and Vital Theatre once a week (on one of the gym days).   
The kindergarten classes do a fall "park study" which rolls science, some math, reading, all together without them thinking about "science class" as something distinct which is neat.  On one of their park field trips they were super engaged --measuring trees, drawing/writing their observations of everything, etc., collecting things to study in the classroom. They came up with several questions about parks (as a class) when they started the "study" that they've been working on answering.  Of course there is uncertainty around test scores and all of those questions.  This is the first year there is a 3rd grade class.   No one seems to be stressed out about it.  The attitude I hear is that they knew common core was coming and the curriculum was designed with it in mind from day one and standards have always been high at the school.

You do understand, don't you, that kids with IEPs are often quite brilliant and could help your "normal" child--I mean beyond helping him/her gain depth of character simply by being near them? Someone with dyslexia, for example,  might be a genius. Some say that Leonardo Da Vinci was dyslexic. Or for another example, Stephen Hawking has physical disabilities, but might clue your lovely child in about how the universe works. He was an average person in school, btw, an almost disaster until he applied for college. Then there's Einstein who was "dull witted" in school. In fact a lot of people that we know as geniuses were rather bad fits for school. John Lennon (genius musician), Thomas Jefferson didn't read until he was nine, Christy Brown could only move his left foot and became a famous author, Itzhak Perlman had polio and he's a brilliant musician. In fact, people with genius characteristics can often develop asymmetrically, or despite great physical odds, so that they're amazingly good at one thing, while being delayed in another area, relative to the "normal" population. This makes school, which is geared for "normal" people challenging.

The comments for SMSHS are fairly quiet but. . . they shouldn't be. SMSHS has, at least for this family, been an absolutely wonderful educational experience, one of the very best we've experienced in NYC public schools. The academic program is, in some ways, even better than the music program. Classes are small, teachers are smart and engaged, the curriculum (especially given the necessary Common Core and Regents elements) is better than any other HS we've experienced, the kids are focused, and the standards are very high. Take a look at the work by kids hanging up in the classrooms when you visit. You don't see fluent essays, long reports in Spanish, articulate fiction, and so on in your average HS; the work holds its own or exceeds academic work done in the traditional specialized NYC high schools. The kids are, without exception, accomplished musicians and most of them apply the learning skills they have developed through their music training to their academic work. As with music, kids are expected to practice until they show mastery of a academic subject and then they move on to the next topic. Kids who excel at, say, math or a language, speed through the required work and move on to the next level, they are not held back. Classes are small enough to make this work. And the music education is superb, the best in the city by our (no doubt biased) estimation . . . the school is essentially a small college-level conservatory. Most of the kids pass the AP music test in _9th_ grade and then move on to more complex music theory and practice. Many of the kids play at a near-professional level and they all take their music very seriously. Perhaps half the school day is spent on music and the classes _start_ at basically a college level and move on from there. The school is tiny and yet the orchestra (which is sometimes fleshed out by kids just starting a second or third instrument) performs at a respectable college level. Many of the kids are so self-motivated that parents and teachers sometimes, wisely, encourage them to do a little _less_ work every day, to take time off to be a kid, to socialize, and so on. It's a wonderfully supportive atmosphere, top to bottom, and while not every kid is going to go on to a career in music, every kid seems to find a comfortable musical niche at SMS.

There are, yes, the usual HS issues at SMS . . . kids will be kids, some are more mature than others, some, maybe most, are still finding their place in the world and sometimes being a kid is painful but . . . things that are problems at many high schools, social cliques, fighting, discipline, apathy, and so on are rare at SMS. Compared to, say, LaGuardia or Stuyvesant, SMS is a low-drama place. Complications at the school are more along the lines of kids working _too hard_, having too many outside music commitments, aesthetic disputes, or career concerns. However, it's a tight-knit group and kids and parents who have concerns will find thoughtful, sympathetic, help. Perhaps the largest issue at the school is the physical space, being underground is a drag (the whole school is in a basement with no windows). Also, the large school complex that houses the school serves several other schools and, sadly, kids/teachers/visitors have to go through metal detectors and security lines. 

If you are looking for a school for a kid who takes their music _and_ their academic work seriously, SMS HS is worth a close look. It's not for everyone, kids who don't already get up before school to practice (or read) might not get it. Kids who want a school with a diffuse arts program might want to go elsewhere. Kids looking for a big high school with traditional programs will not like it. However, for kids who think string quartet practice, followed by reading Harry Potter out loud in Spanish, followed by a critique of a duet written by a fellow student, then a private piano lesson, and then on to math class . . . is _fun_, then SMS is perfect.

SMS is not for every kid, not even for every music-focused kid, but for kids who take all of their studies seriously and want to work on music for half of their school day and be surrounded by musicians, it's heaven. I wish the school wasn't in a basement. I wish the music program was more willing to take chances and/or focus a bit more on music by living composers. Sorry but you are wrong. The children accepted are the most potentially talented and also have the best concentration/focus. My child was admitted without my family knowing a single person at the school.

I agree that the school lacks transparency about the admissions testing. That is on purpose--if parents knew exactly what was on the test, they would engage in expensive test-prep to give their kids an advantage. NYC parents do this kind of thing all the time.

That said, if you want to give your pre-K child an advantage, enroll him or her in a Dalcroze class in the Lucy Moses School (same building as Special Music School). These are music and movement classes that I suspect are quite similar to the kinds of activities the kids do during their admissions tests. My child had Dalcroze classes and played an instrument for a year before the admissions test. It also doesn't hurt that my child grew up in a musical environment. My sister is a professional musician, and my spouse and I are serious amateur musicians.

A bigger problem, I think, is that the tests give older kids an advantage at the expense of the younger kids. There is a huge developmental difference between a child who has just turned 4 and one who is 4 3/4. I have noticed that almost all the children in my child's class have birthdays in January and February! This is not a coincidence (see Malcolm Gladwell's book "Outliers" for a fuller explanation of this phenomenon). In my opinion, the school should stagger their testing so that all of the students are almost exactly the same age when they are tested for musical aptitude.

Hello Mariela, congratulations! If you give me your e-mail address I'll get in touch. You should also connect with the PTA, if you haven't already done so. They are very helpful and engaged, and most of them are grammar school parents. The PTA facebook site: https://m.facebook.com/profile.php?id=1883523495260336&tsid=0.021778829737746697&source=result

I can also attest that I noticed no special preference and didn't know people at SMS before our kid was admitted. Also, at least from my point of view, the school seems generally quite transparent about admissions and responsive to polite inquiries of all kinds, much more responsive, in my experience, than most schools. Shady is not a word I associate with the school.

As for current parents commenting . . . well, hmmmm, I don't know a lot about SMS but ask away, I'll check this thread once in a while. The PTA at SMS, considering the size of the school, seems very active to me. Take a look at their website and you see lots and lots of teacher-parent-student communication of all kinds: http://smsparents.org/.

Hi - the assessments for K admission are music - based. Children participate in games and activities that assess their musical aptitude such as sense of rhythm and pitch. They are assigned scores based on their participation in these activities and based on those scores are either invited back for a second round or not. While nepotism or special preference may or may not exist - as it does everywhere in the world - I can at least speak for myself in saying that we did not know anyone or have any connection to the school when my child was accepted.
Hi- do you know what test test for second round?
Does the school give the students instruments or do we have to use our own?
This IS profile hasn't been updated to reflect that the High School meets in the Martin Luther King complex - which is one of the schools with scanners.
any info regarding the interview process for the student that have gone through the audition? (we are applying for 6th grade admission)
Kindergartners at PS 859 have read poems for WNYC's Schoolbook. Listen to them here.
Does anybody know how difficult are the auditions for the 3rd grade?

Parentsofnyteens parent writes: I'm the mother of a 14-year-old special needs teen. This is my son's first year in a mainstream school. It is a music school, so I figured the music classes would be of high quality (which they are). What I wasn't expecting was the extremely high quality of the academic classes. The teachers are not only there to teach, but they have truly inspired my son. In addition, the school is unusually supportive and sensitive to his special needs. Both the administrators and the teachers have demonstrated an exceptional atmosphere of caring and support. The students each have an advisor who touches base with them each week. What's more, I feel there has been excellent communication from each teacher, which helps to keep my son on track.

This sounds like a great school, but can someone tell me honestly, are these students well-rounded? Do they also study different cultures and art and science, or is it just music all the time? Is there really time for family and personal growth? I see the test scores are amazing, and the music integration is great, but I want to make sure they don't miss out on other important parts of growing up.

The children are quite extraordinary. While music is usually their main thing, many of the kids are very, very gifted in math, reading, science, art, dance, chess, sports... Most of the kids are bilingual (esp. Russian, Hebrew, Korean, and Chinese). My 8-year-old is reading a book about the Buddha right now. They have impromptu political debates at recess (I hear the majority are for Hillary, with a substantial minority supporting Bernie). Besides regular academics, there are special dance classes along with gym, art, and music theory. It is a very intense environment--more intense, I'd imagine, than most of the gifted and talented programs in the city. We practice so much (at least and hour every day) that it seems there's never enough time for just hanging out and being a kid. It is very different than the laid-back environment I grew up in.
One hundred percent of 4th-graders at the Special Music School who took the state English language arts exam this year passed, reports DNA.info. Read more here.
Special Music School is number 3 on reading proficiency (94.44)%) in 2014 city test scores and number 7 in math proficiency (96.43)%) Read more here.
question to 9th graders, how is it going? please give info on the school and the building. how is it going to school in the mlk jr ed complex?
how much homework does a 7th grader get? is it really intense and too much pressure?
any new comments from current parents and students? is it true the middle schooler have 3 hours of homework and 3 hours of practicing?

The Special Music School - where the kids go to public school andpractice per night?  Do most of the children participate in an after 
school music program where they get to practice their instrument?  It is
 hard to tell at age 4 whether my child will have the stamina for a 
program like this.  How were you able to tell that your individual child
 would be able to hack this level of commitment?  Also, is there any 
time left over in your child's life for sports, homework, friendships, 
etc.
I wonder what have you decided after all? I am in your same boat! my daughter is 4 and supposed to take the assessment next month. I'm a nervous wreck.

When the Special Music School opens its high school in the Martin Luther King building in 2013 with 50 9th grade students, pupils will study music management and technology along with performance. Read more:  New Note for Classical.
can we wear shoes or sneakers
FDA II is among the schools with the most improved 2017 state math test scores, Chalkbeat reports.
FDA2 is one of the renown schools in the vicinity of Harlem. In addition, all the teachers help you as like as their kids. By the way, I was so proud to be part of that school.

Frederick Douglass Academy II received 950 applications for 100 9th-grade seats this coming school year. School leaders are pointing to this uptick in interest to fight back against the plan to move a Success Academy into the FDA building. Read more here.
If plans to expand Success Academy Harlem West, which shares the West 114th Street building, go forward FDA II could lose its art room. Read more here.

"Over the course of the last two years, our school has made one of the 
more remarkable transformations within the city.  This is captured in 
our recently released 2012 middle school progress report and our soon to be released 2012  high school progress report," Principal Osei Owusu-Afriyie writes. 

"We offer Culinary Arts, Chess, Dance, Boxing and other electives to our 
Scholars.  We also have one of the highest, if not the highest, 18-month
 college persistence rate in the city.  Our team of Educators, Scholars 
and their families are working tirelessly to make FDA II one of the best
 schools in the city." .
A parent who chose FDA 2 for her child, said she was not informed when the school's grade and test scores had dropped. Read more: School Choice is no Cure-All, Harlem Finds.

Wadleigh Secondary School's notable librarian recruited Cornel West to speak to FDA II and Wadleigh students on Monday, December 6, 2011: Librarian recruits Cornel West to troubled school that may close
Cornel West spoke to students at Wadleigh and FDA II, saying he intends to fight for their school. Video of the speech on gothamschools.org.
This school has been placed on the list of schools that may close after earning an F on its Progress Report. Read more: City adds high schools, charter schools to possible closure list.
A teacher writes, "I am very impressed by the faculty at FDA II.  The other day at a meeting I looked around and was filled with gratitude to see such a dedicated, capable and hardworking bunch."

District 3 Presidents’ Council President, Michelle Ciulla Lipkin, wrote a letter to school chancellor Cathy Black to express their strong opposition to the moving Success Academy Charter School in the Brandeis High School building and to the proposal to expand Harlem Success Academy 1 into PS 149 and eventually into FDA II/Wadleigh High School, arguing that it will hurt District 3 public schools.  Below is an excerpt from the letter:

“Over the last few years, the District 3 community has worked tirelessly to address overcrowding in the district. We need our district school space to go to our district’s students.  We need to accommodate our growing population.  We need additional middle schools and high schools.  We cannot afford to lose any seats. 

The idea that the Upper West Success charter was approved without a site determined shows lack of planning and forethought. There was never room in District 3 for Upper West Success and we simply cannot accommodate this charter school. The District 3 Community Education Council, Community Board 7, Parent Associations from our District 3 schools, Assembly member Linda Rosenthal, Assembly member Danny O'Donnell, State Senator Tom Duane, State Senator Bill Perkins, Council member Gale Brewer, and Council member Melissa Mark-Viverito have all come together to express disagreement with this co-location. It is imperative that our voices are heard and that this co-location does not move forward.”

Many Harlem residents oppose the expansion of Harlem Success Academy including many public school parents. Read the full article: Public School Parents Protest Harlem Success Academy's Expansion Plans.

"All of the staff here play a part in each of the students lives," writes student Rebecca Hatcher. "Our principal, Ms.Greer is probably the most dedicated person I have ever known. She is involved in everything we did in the school. She is like the mother everyone likes and admires. She pushes her kids forward to move on to bigger and better things. She selects a few students to apply to a program for boarding school, which I received acceptance to. During my three years at FDA2 I have found such a strong support system to fall back on. All of the staff are willing to talk and truly care about you. This school is really one big family learning and working together."
"The school is warm and gives care to every child," said parent Kim Williams, who volunteers as a receptionist. "If Miss Greer was not here, we wouldn't be here, the school wouldn't be here."

"The teachers reach out and call parents if your child needs help, before the situation gets out of hand," said parent Linda Brown. "The principal gets involved in everything, including attending junior varsity basketball playoffs.

"When the location changed, so did the administration," writes parent Christine Spates. "Unfortunately, the new choice for principal was an inexperienced teacher. She either didn't know how to be an effective leader or she didn't have the much needed support to grow into a good leader; either way, the school lost its beautiful reputation and its 'flavor.' Nothing is as it was. There is no classical music in the hallways, children are roaming the halls, children are getting arrested in front of the school (it occupies the second floor of Wadleigh), and scores on state tests sank. Many children are frustrated and one can parents hear complaining left and right. Yet it seems as if nobody there wants to listen."  
Assistant Principal Rhode Octobre-Cooper responds to the comment above: "We have worked diligently in creating an atmosphere that is both academically challenging and supportive for our students. In our recent Quality Review our principal, Latasha Greer, is praised 'as a person of high standards and integrity, [who] has an exceptional commitment and passion for the school and especially for its students whom she knows and understands very well.' This statement speaks volume as to the character of our school leader. Moreover, in the eighth grade, our students take Regents exams. In the 2006-2007 school year, 93 percent of 8th graders passed the Math A Regents. Finally, we offer an environment where our parents are welcome and are able to voice their concerns. Again, our Quality Review shows that 'communication with parents are extremely clear and through, with strong liaison evident through the work of the parent coordinator.' This again proves the type of school that we have at FDA."

"FDA is a good school," writes student Christopher. "I have learned a lot of things. The teachers were always there for any problem you had. When we were scared to go home teachers walked you to the train station. They are always willing to help you after school."

A student said the school was "the best" under its former principal, Ms. Turner Campbell, but has suffered since then. "I have been in Frederick Douglass II for three years and every year we had a different principal," this student wrote. "The school has no kind of control over any of its students and there is a fight everyday."

Jasmine, an 8th-grader at FDA II, writes: "When I first came here [in 6th grade] I was like yes finally a school in Harlem that plays no games and doesn't waste any time. The population of the school was around 100-150 and it only went from 6th-8th grade." But Jasmine writes that in her 7th-grade year, everything changed. "Our principal had left the school ... the school was very unorganized, [and] we had new teachers that were not teaching us what we needed to know ... At this time the school was now going up to 9th grade and had a very small class. Later on in the year it was announced that we would be moving to a different location into a school with a bad reputation. Only that did not stop us." She writes that although she feels that her "classmates are not focused and serious as they should be," "all of our 8th grade teachers are extraordinary educators in my opinion except one. ... [and] we have the best acting principle in the world, Ms. Greer. She is like my mother in every way she plays no games when it comes to education. Our school now has 300-350 scholars, but size isn't anything but a number to her."

My daughter graduated from Mott Hall 2 this past June.  From 6th grade to 8th grade her time there was spent working hard, expanding her horizons, making new friends and having fun. I was amazed by their ability to take children of different races, ethnic backgrounds and academic levels and make this into one school family.  Parents and Staff work together for the betterment of all the children.  All the recent talk of integrating District 3 did not bother our school since Mott Hall 2 has been doing exactly what was proposed and doing it well from the schools inception.  I'm happy that they were given the opportunity to expand their space onto the 5th floor of the school. The additional space will help Mott Hall 2 to become even better.  I would advise all parents who children are currently in seventh grade to prepare them early for the high school process. Start looking at the NYC High School directory which can be found online, during the summer months and narrow down your child's choices. Go to each schools website and take note of all their instructions regarding admission. Many schools require that documents be dropped/mailed to them directly by the parents not the Guidance Counselor. If your child is interested in attending a Specialized H.S. get them tutoring the summer before they start 8th grade.  Keep track of deadlines, schedule tours and be realistic.  My daughter got into Beacon H.S.  Mott Hall's 2 Guidance Counselor is fantastic. My daughter's classmates got into various schools such as Beacon, Manhattan Hunter Science, Stuyvesant the list of fantastic schools is extensive.   A word of caution, only list high schools on the high school application that your child would be happy to go to no matter what.  I have heard horror stories from parents at other middle schools who put down a school their child did not really want to go to but ended up getting placed there by the DOE.  Wishing everyone the best!

Now that my child is in college, I look back at her academic development and we are so grateful she attended MH2. This is the school that shaped her as a diligent and conscientious student. You taught her how to learn, manage her time, and advocate for herself. She truly grew into a scholar at Mott Hall II. And is now an Ivy League sophomore. We can’t thank you enough for putting her on this trajectory.
Chalkbeat reports that parents at Mott Hall II are interested in how the admissions standards will be effected by the possible closure of PS 165 (the middle school it shares a building with.)
Mott Hall II has a (fairy loose) dress code but no uniform, in case you want to update your listing.
Curious about the special ed program

My child was in G&T classes in elementary school. It was my intention from the beginning to choose Mott Hall II for middle school. I have no regrets. My child is in 7th grade at Mott Hall 2.  My child is academically challenged but not to the point of being miserable.   

My child took the 6th Grade NYS  Math & ELA tests in Spring of  2016. My child told me afterwards that everything on the test had been taught by Mott Hall 2.  Mr. Lowe is a wonderful Principal with a fantastic staff. I'm constantly amazed at how organized and efficient the school is. The staff at Mott Hall 2 think out of the box. The school is proactive in regards to preparing the kids for their future. They have already started sending out e-mails and attachments regarding the high school process. I went through this with my oldest child but you forget after some years have passed. Mott Hall 2 offers a ton of clubs/school activities for your child to participate in. The PTA and the parents are very involved. We do what must be done to help our children and school.  

My advice to parents going through the Middle School process. Check the NYS scores, Tour the school and keep in mind that while scores and accolades of a school is good. The bottom line is what is best for your child. For me what was important was a school with good NYS ELA & Math scores, a rigorous curriculum, with a diverse student body and that they allowed the kids to have fun. Mott Hall 2 met all my requirements. They truly do care about the "whole" child.

Hi I am a graduate if Mott Hall 2 class of 2016. Mott Hall 2 is a great school accademically but students here disrespect each other on a daily basis. As well many teachers are bias when disciplining students. Unfair detention are given and different punshment to different people for the same thing. A friend of mine teying to stop a fight that broke out at a school dance was given afterschool detention because he was belived to have "joined the fight". As well another friend who messed up and opened the hotel room door during the senior trip lost his prom even though there were others who did the same thing but just lied to get out of trouble or recieved justa meer after school detention. The school is excellent but disipline is not.

This was truly one of the best things about our one year in NYC.  Both are kids went to MHII one in 6th and one in 8th.  I cannot believe how challenging the courses were and how both my kids could not wait to go to school each day.  Mr. Lowe is a fantastic principal the embodies every quality you would want in a leader.  He has the most motivated teachers working with him and together they create one fantastic environment.  We move quite frequently all over the United States and I can say that MHII has been the best school our kids have ever been to!

A wonderful small school with caring teachers. Our daughter is a 6th grader who is really enjoying all her classes and her new friends. The teachers have high expectations and are well versed in helping the 6th graders transition to the middle school environment. The guidance counselor, Ms. Robbins, is fantastic!
Principal Marlon Lowe of Mott Hall II describes the schools emphasis on transparency and engagement. Read more here.

This is my son's second year at the school. it really is a nurturing and diverse school. students here receive a rigorous education, but with  extreme care and individual support. the hands-on learning makes it more fun for the students. The teachers are always available to talk about your kid, and really know them. The principle Mr Lowe is a great inspirational force setting good examples for both students and teachers.
its unfortunate that the gym in the old building is not great, but MH2 can't do anything about it at this point.

This is our second year in this school and we love it. Administration and teachers inspire respect, love and trust. I feel that they truly care about children and provide optimal nurturing environment, which was a very important factor for us in choosing this school. Also another just as important factor was (and is) that children are taught to think for themselves and question everything, all the information: from commercials to what's happening in the world and more. I'm also happy with Math and Science curriculum. Science is very project oriented, children learn by doing how to conduct scientific research and deal with data. Mott Hall 2 absolutely lives up to its stated Mission and Vision and I'm very very grateful for it.
Congratulations to Mr. Lowe! I see that he's the new principal. He's an amazing leader and cares so much about education and every child. Well done, Mr. Lowe!

Hidden gem is indeed a great way to describe MHII.  Our child is currently in 7th grade and has been so happy and well adjusted at MHII.  The academics are rigorous and demanding without being overwhelming as they are at other schools.  The teachers care about and are able to meet the learning needs of the students whether struggling, advanced, or anything in between.  The most remarkable part of the school is the environment of inclusiveness and warmth.  Partly because it is a small school but mostly because of the culture of the school created by the students, teachers, and administrators altogether, MHII has a team feel to it with little to no bullying (our son says there isn't any bullying but I have a hard time believing there is ZERO at ANY middle school!).  It is also a wonderfully diverse student body. Students get to know each other across the grades through advisory and other activities, which adds to the positive community feel.  Our son has been excited about what he has been learning and even in subjects that are not his favorite he reports that the teachers are great and the activities are interesting.  We have been so pleased with our son's experience at Mott Hall II!

Mott Hall II is such a great school!! This is the first school I've seen where they not only concentrate on academics but they take a huge interest in the child as a whole. It's important to the teachers and Principle to have happy students. Being in middle school is one of the hardest things our children will go through and I am certain that at Mott Hall she will get through this process with all the support she needs.  Teachers are always available to help students after school and during lunch.  Mott Hall II is genuinely a great school.

Mott Hall II has welcomed my 6th grade son with open arms.  Teachers are thoughtful and attentive.  They work collaboratively to offer scholars skill-focused, hands-on learning opportunities in every class.  For example, in Science, the 6th graders started off the year learning about the scientific method and then jumped right in to design their own straw rockets.  Last week, they launched them and now they are writing up their first labs.  In ELA, scholars examined pieces from a radio show, "This I Believe," and then they wrote and recited their own pieces.  In Social Studies, students interviewed people about their decision to move and discussed the push and pull factors of migration.  They also mapped their city block and created their own countries after discussing borders, land forms, and climate.  My son is excited to go to school each day and raves about his teachers.  We are thrilled to be part of the Mott Hall II community.
My sincere condolences for the loss of your previous principal Ana E. Tornatore.
Ms. Ana was a gentle and kind leader. We will miss her tender and yet effective touch. She made a huge difference for the good in our lives. I will always be grateful for having known her.

I am a parent at MH2. If you are looking for a smaller school where students are challenged but never lost, where all the teachers know everyone's names and respond quickly to email concerns, and where the students and parents are diverse and social, you should seriously consider this school. 
Granted, the physical plant is not great, but if your main concerns are  rigorous academics with clear standards for success, collaborative work, and a nurturing environment with an eclectic student body, then this is the place. 
The teachers are invested in the well-being of the entire community and participate in school fundraisers and fun events. The administration is approachable, inclusive and creative.

The after school options are expanding yearly, and this year they are free. Yes, free, with a suggested contribution to support the programs. They include sports (basketball), model UN, music lessons (brass and strings, I believe), science, and more.
My son is very happy here.

Hi I am Kameron Gil (If you have any questions on the school just comment below and I will answer it honestly). I can honestly 100%  say that Mott Hall 2 was the best choice I have ever made. 
I am a 8th grader as of this year and its been a amazing 3 years. I am a very arts influenced student, I have been in the school rock band since the first year I was at the school and I played the music for our production of West Side Story and this year I am in our production of The Last Unicorn and I feel like arts wise the school has so much to offer. The school also has an award wining chess team, a boys and a girls track team, a boys and a girls basketball team and a co-ed flag football team. The School offers a variety of after school and in school classes, such as, Model United Nations and my elective on music and how it effects history and economy and have no fear, we all get all of our core and extra-curricular classes into our schedule every day (this being math, science, social studies, ELA, Art, and Physical Education). The thing I love about Mott Hall 2 is from my first day at this school I felt safe and at home and that's one of the many things I have always loved about the school. As I said before, if you have any questions just type them in the comments and I promise to answer them, have a nice day.

I am an eight grader and I have been here at Mott Hall II since sixth grade. I can tell you that this school is great academically and they offer so many enrichment/ after school classes and clubs that I have a really hard time choosing between them all. I currently participate in Model UN which is one of the many clubs our school has to offer. Every year we have a big meeting in the UN headquarters with other kids from all around the world. Each deligate represents a country and we must write a position paper and debate with the other kids. I am also taking regence science (Biology) and regence math (Algebra 1). These are two classes that most students take in high school. This means when I get to high school I will be able to move on ahead to the next course. Not many schools offer regence classes in the eight grade and the teachers make sure you are ready and capable for the class before you take it. The teachers are very good at their jobs and have a lot of experience. The teachers here have taught me things that I would never believe possible to learn. My teachers see potential in every one of there students and they have pushed me to become a great student but also a great person. Over my last three years here, my teachers have helped me reach goals that I never thought were possible for me. The students here at Mott Hall II are as great as the teachers. I know pretty much every student in the school including sixth graders. In this school we are not students who happen to be in the same classroom, we are family that are working together to be the best people we can be. The students help me learn as much as the teachers do and we all get along. Our school also offers sports such as basketball, volleyball, and fencing. My school has really prepared me well for high school and I feel ready to tackle new and exciting goals that lie ahead.

- Aidan Huntley

i love mhii nd it's my 3d year graduating :( the teachers and everyone is great and it's really great loving school and community. It makes you feel warm and everyone is like family and im going to miss and visit this school.

Hello there.  I am an eight grader at Mott Hall II.  My friend Matt and many others have, and will continue to post comments on how great the school is.  Personally, I rather enjoyed my 7th grade year (my first year after transferring), and the teachers are very skilled at their job and know how to make the students interested.  Being in 8th grade now has been okay.  I really enjoy the having trust of this school on the students.  Every day for 45 minutes, the eighth graders (and honor roll 7th graders) get to go outside and have lunch out.  Of course there are limits to how many blocks a student can go, but it's something like a mile down and up broadway, and Amsterdam to Riverside.  Most students don't go far from the school, and nothing bad has happened with lunch out.  No students have broken the rules, and that's fine, because we get to eat outside with our friends in places like 5-Guys, Subways, Absolute Bagels, Famiglia, Koronet, Hungarian Pastry Shop, and so many other places.

Hi, my name is Matt and I am an eighth grader at MHII. I was reading this review out of curiosity and could not help but write a comment. I love this school, the teachers really want everyone to succeed and help kids graduate. I feel like I have learned more than enough to gain entry to any high school and also do not feel like the school has in any way stifled my creativity. I am a lead in the school play, i am trying out for the band, and plan on participating in the talent show. All of these extracurricular activities have in no way stopped my academics, I still get honers. I feel challenged yet do not feel overwhelmed. Also, all of the faculty are so kind, I feel like this school is a second home where I learn things. I could not recommend this school any more.

Hi everyone, my name is Michael, a graduate of Mott Hall II's Class of 2012. I can tell you that I loved this school, and even now starting high school, I am still in touch with the amazing staff as well as some of my closest classmates. The teachers here are amazing, they make class fun, while making sure we learn everything we're supposed to. The teachers are devoted to success, and if your child has any academic or personal problems, most teachers offer help during lunch and if not lunch, after school. The students here are phenomenal. This is a school of about 320 students in total, so everyone in every grade is close to each other. At Mott Hall II, the students challenge each other as well as the teachers, with their thoughts on certain topics, which can only help. Everyone is up to the challenge which makes things even better. Mott Hall II is also known for sending students to top high schools such as Millennium, Beacon, Elanor Roosevelt, Stuyvesant, and many others. Right now I am currently going to Millennium High School, and because of the challenging but fun course I had with Mott Hall II, the transition from middle school to high school was not hard at all for me, as well as the students from this school who made it into Millennium with me.
Fantastic info... but how about a list of Elementary Schools gaining acceptance to MHII?

This is generally a District 3 school, so mainly kids living in or attending elementary schools in District 3. However, my son attended school with kids from District 5 and 6 too and some from District 2.
Does Mott Hall II have a strings program?

My son graduated from MHII today and there wasn't a dry eye in the auditorium. My 86 year old father was in tears and leaned over to me saying, " I am so struck and moved by the sense of community!!" Indeed. Community, hard work, optimism, connection.. THe boy my son was when he entered the school, to who he has become because of the staff- is just a revelation. I cannot rave about this school enough!!! THANK-YOU ALL! and please parents, when you're looking for a great middle school, you really really must check out MHII.

I go to mott hall ll and this is my last year here and i'm graduating in a few weeks and i think that it really heklped me grow as a person. I recommend this school because you get a chance to make really good friends and have really nice teachers and education. I'll never forget my three years at middleschool and i will visit this place a lot ! And miss it !

Mott Hall II will be EXTREMELY hard to leave once my son graduates in a couple of months. The school has been the personification of what middle school education should reflect. The staff are so deeply involved in the well being of all the students, from teachers to administrators, the students are known and pushed ( with compassion!) and told over and over again that they CAN succeed. They are given incredible opportunities both academically and socially. My son has grown into such an amazing kid, and in no small part due to the care and education he's received at school. The guidance counselor works hard in the 7th and 8th grade helping kids with the High school application process. The school goes to bat for your kid in a myriad of ways and it's an amazing collaborative experience between staff and parents/guardians. My son ( who struggled academically before Mott Hall II) has been accepted to a really great high school! Rest assured that if you send your child to MHII, that they will bring out the very best in your child. 12-14 years of age is such a rough time, and they handle the kids just masterfully. These people know what they are doing. You walk through the halls and see a lot of happy kids who embody tons of school pride and spirit. I can't say enough.

I COMPLETELY agree. My son started at MHII as a scared little 6th grader.  He's finishing a big, confident, happy young man. He's excited about attending his first-choice high school next fall, thanks to the efforts of everyone at MHII. He especially has enjoyed Mr. Lowe, who is fair, funny, and makes the school run like clockwork. He knows every child at the school, their ups and downs. He's amazing. Ms. De los Santos is so gentle and yet her leadership of the school is steady and clear. She gives the school its warm vibe and expects the most out of kids, and personally encourages them to grow. Each and every one of my son's teachers has been very different in temperament and style, and I can't think of a single one that was a klinker. They were all good. I've never seen such dedicated faculty. I wish I could thank every one of them over and over again. Ms. Gorman personally worked with each family to advise them about all of the options that were open to each child for high school admissions. She truly seems to love her job. Mott Hall II has been a blessing.
I go to Mott Hall II and I think it is the best school ever.

mott hall has been the haven both my children were fortunate enough to have attain.
this school has some very good teachers that are willing to assist the children during the school hours and after. the quality of learning  is superb. i have been a parent in the school for 5 years and truly i will be sad to have to leave, but im aware that the training and education my children take with them is untouchable. the work is rigorous, but they go on to great schools and very well prepared. if you are looking for a great school come take a tour and see all the possiblities the are here for your child, where they learn to be independant thinkers, where they learn grow emotionally, where they become young ladies and young men with a goal. this school's population is large enough to be diverse and small enough to and individual teachers and administration know on a personal term. come and see what we have to offer and i know you won't regret it.    a satisfied parent
Though it can be challenging which is good it is a good way to concentrate in your education. I love Mott Hall 2 for its teachers and classes.

This Is My Last Year At Mott Hall II And I Am Sad To Leave Because It Has Been A Very Amazing Time...I Love All My Teachers An I Love All My Class Mates. When I First Got To Mott Hall II I Thought that I Did Not Belong Cause It Was To Smart For Me But I am One Of Those Smart Kids Now And Thanks To Mott Hall II. I LOVE YOU MOTT HALL II. I Am Going To Miss You. By The Way MATH RULEZZ. =D
Math is the best. I am currently in the seventh grade and Ms. Rodriguez and Ms. Shewan taught me a lot.
Yes it does. Especially with Ms. Rodriguez, Ms. Schulten and of course Ms. Shewan.
