My brother's 4th grader, considering about attending here. He's serious with cello.
The students who attend here; Are most of the students who take Art/Music/etc. seriously(choosing their career as art, music, etc.)?

ME indeed attracts many students (possibly even a majority of students) who are serious about making their careers in the arts.  However, the bigger issue for your brother is that ME does not offer an intermediate classical strings program, altho in the past, it has offered elementary strings. ME does have an excellent jazz band, so if your brother would be willing to learn double bass, he could have a wonderful experience at the school.  In the past, ME has had students who came in as guitar, electric bass, or cello players who made the transition successfully to double bass.  Please note that all students accepted to ME pick an instrument suited for symphonic band, and learn to play that instrument.  The symphonic band is amazing!   My son came in as a guitar player and learned to play tenor sax at ME. He played in both the jazz band and symphonic band at ME, and was subsequently accepted to LaGuardia HS.  Generally, learning another instrument increases a student's overall musicianship.  Otherwise, if your brother's heart is set on cello, he would be better off trying to apply to middle schools that have an orchestra or strings program.  You are right to think about this early.  There are not many middle schools with decent instrumental music programs, and many are selective, so please encourage your brother to also do well on his state ELA and math exams.  Good luck ,and how nice of you to help your brother!
Thank you so much! It helped a lot. Sorry for late response, but your advice REALLY helped a lot. Thank you again!!

Hello all, my daughter is in 7th grade at Manhattan East. She loves it. The principal, staff and teachers are strong, work together, and maintain a solid atmosphere of support and inspiration for the kids. We have a wonderful music teacher, an amazing art teacher, we have a beautiful gym, and daily recess. The schools scores are strong. It is a diverse population, from all over the city. I would highly recommend any parent to seek out this hidden gem of a middle school.

The Big Apple Awards Nominations FAQ's:

Q. Who can nominate a teacher? 

A. Anyone – supervisors, colleagues, parents, students,
staff, and community members – can submit a nomination for a current New York City Department of Education (NYCDOE) teacher by March 13, 2013. 

Q. Can I nominate myself?

A. Yes, self-nominations will be accepted.
Beware

Manhattan East has been a wonderful experience for many families this year. The principal is readily available, the assistant principal answers emails the same day and the office staff have all been so supportive to my child. The teachers are enthusiastic and although demanding, treat each child with great care. My child has had access to his own computer in most classes, including ELA and Social Studies, and is challenged on an individual basis. The classes are small(approximately 18), and the students are getting a rigorous and well rounded education. They are learning well beyond their years in writing style and analysis, research credibility and complex writing styles. Writing is given across the curriculum, including Mathematics and Science, and classes correlate well in their projects and topics. The teachers' goals are not only to get their students ready for state exams, but to get them ready for their lives ahead of them. The school's focus is on producing independent thinkers who can meet any challenge, and the Socratic method is often used in class discussions. My child enjoys going to school every morning, and for the first time in years, comes home happy every day full of interesting information he loves to share. The teachers are patient in answering all questions parents ask of them, and are truly caring about each student's progress. This is a rare opportunity that every parent should evaluate seriously.

Hello @ parent! Although the small class size actually works to each student's advantage, I understand your point. The administration has been addressing your concern, and has been actively recruiting students since last year. My child accompanied the Assistant Principal and Manhattan East's very fine art instructor to one of those school fairs last year, of which there were many. Perhaps the program could have started a bit earlier, but it is in full swing and is being approached very seriously. Of course, it takes a while to see results from any program, but it is working and many parents in other boroughs are just not aware of this wonderful school. Manhattan East offers excellent teaching, in an environment that makes it easy on students to transition from elementary school into middle school. The school also has concerned and highly motivated parents, including a new treasurer who is in the financial field, working in every aspect of the school. To see it all in action is very different from hearing about it, and no one can fault you for that. As a parent, you have every right to information, but actual information...
not just what is being said in a given community. The Principal and Assistant Principal work very hard daily to make sure each student learns in a wonderful environment and always address individual concerns. Teachers also respond very quickly, and truly care about their students.

"The classes are small(approximately 18)..."  So by now you have probably realized that those 6th grade classes were really TOO small, related to the school's falling enrollment.  So now this year, the school lost two teachers.  Budgeting and leadership are important.  Why is the principal not addressing these issues?
I'm a Sixth grader this school is wonder full these teachers push to help us learn. This is a wonderful school no child should not want to go here ! I love it

Absolutely Manhattan East is a fantastic school.  My son went into high school with extra Regents credits from ME which were then averaged into his high school grades (giving him a big boost for his 1st year in high school); he also was placed into HS honors classes.  My son learned how to play tenor sax at ME, and learned how to read music well there.  He adored the excellent science classes, especially the Earth Science Regents class, and also the 11th grade US History Regents class -- which meant that he was able to take advanced science and social studies classes in HS.  And he grew greatly from ME's group advisory classes that all students particpate in, where teachers lead discussions in everything from organizational skills to how to deal with some of the common stresses of growing up.  He always felt well cared for at ME, and he developed close relationships with many teachers; he is still is in touch with some of them today.  The neighborhood is fine.  I frequently left the school after dark, or walked to it after dark, for events or meetings.  I took the subway, buses, etc. near the school.  No issues.  My son had no problems going home by subway, or going cross town via bus to get to music classes after school.  All in all, this is a terrific school for G&T kids with a strong interest in the arts.

Manhattan East is an amazing school. When my daughter graduated from there she went into high school with extra credits. She learned how to play the trumpet there, learned how to speak french, and enjoyed so many activities during her years there. This school definitely had a positive impact on her life. Do not let the neighborhood intimidate you. The children are safe in the building and the staff and faculty always have the children's best interest in my mind.

I am compelled to share my families very positive experiences at ME224. My daughter is in her 1st year of high school, she has shared with me that if it wasn't for the curriculum at ME224 she would not have been as prepared for high school as she is. ME not only offers a strong academic program, but a supportive teaching staff, and an administration that goes above and beyond to make sure that the students are getting all the resources they need to succeed in school. 
I am happy to have been a part of the Manhattan East family.

I'm an eighth grader at this school. It is a great school and the academics are definitely above average. Last year I took honors physics and algebra, and this year I'm taking high school math, social studies, and science. And as for my classmates, it's just like most there schools, some are nice and some not so much. However, last year when I became the victim of some violent bullying the assistant principal  Melissa Cancel, brought the two kids who made the problem to justice. So maybe Manhattan East isn't an A school, but I don't regret coming here in any way.

the Broadway musical just visited the school.
The school's scores are quite good actually but may be slightly lower than schools who focus primarily on testing.  This school has much more to offer.

My daughter was accepted here, scholars' academy ,mark twain and louis armstrong.We chose scholars'.This schools progress grade was a D this year!Their state scores are bad.I'm so glad that she didn't HAVE to go here.Not to mention the scary neighborhood,and scary kids from the other schools in the building.When we went to the open house,we were thoroughly unimpressed.

Its really not necessary to post such a mean comment on this page. It doesn't help anyone, and it doesn't pertain to this school at all. I just graduated from manhattan east and i loved it. go take your nasty comment somewhere else.

I wasn't trying to be nasty.People read these comments to decide whether or not to send their child here.The fact is that Manhattan East got a D on their progress report this year,and a C last year.Obviously something is going on the school that is negatively impacting the children's education there. The department of Education obviously thinks that there is a problem.It does help people to know these things. I would want to know. The kids are highly intelligent because they go through the interview,test and screening process. The problem must be with the administration.

But if you don't have a child in the school, is it really appropriate to comment? There are a number of well-documented issues with the school rating system, and at any rate, that is information we can all find on our own.

The administration at ME is readily available to parents of prospective students and is incredibly supportive to students matriculated in the school. It is easy to call up on any given day to speak with the principal directly, who is willing to discuss any concerns. The Assistant Principal answers all emails the same day. I'm sorry that mom1043 had a negative experience, but I can assure her and any parent thinking of sending their child to ME, the education is solid, the teachers actively teach their students(as opposed to only getting the students ready for state tests) and the students learn a great deal from hands on learning(projects and trips) in addition to rigorous lessons regarding writing techniques/analysis and research papers(as early as 6th Grade). The students are taught how to conduct research and each child has a computer to use in English and Social Studies classes(not including computer class). For parents who are looking for a school that only teaches its students how to take the state tests, this school is not the one. But for parents who are looking for a well rounded and challenging education, that includes the arts, music theory and rigorous academics, this is it. The students are safe and are given first priority in every decision the administration makes. The classes are small and each student is given individual attention. Within the small classes, students are also given challenging work according to their level. Teachers are enthusiastic while demanding the very best from their students. For the discerning parent who wants high quality education with individual attention, Manhattan East is the place to be.

We actively sought out this school. Pleased when our child made it in. 6th Grade was tough...a shock coming from elementary school. But we insisted our child dig deep and perform. She did.  Raising the bar is a good thing. Parents constantly complain...yet want their children to excel and attend top high schools and universities. Your child CAN do the work...stop making excuses.   Top schools don't want mediocrity...they demand excellence!  The Math teacher demanded excellence...she helped elevate students to do far and above anything they had ever done in Math before.  A lot of what you read here can be summed up as 'sour grapes'. No place is perfect. You get out of it what you put in.

A parent tells Insideschools: The school "just doesn't take care of problems unless you make an issue of them. They don't communicate well at all. A lot of teachers left and the new 7th grade teachers last year were very hard on the students, and gave them bad grades."
Parents need to step up and become actively involved and not just complain...nothing worth having is free.

"I am sure some students in the 7th grade create difficulty. However, that is only one grade.  The 6th grade and 8th grade are wonderful, I know this because I have children in both grades."

Wow!  How sad that this comment comes from a parent!  Ugh!  Willing to throw an entire GRADE of students under the bus!  One third of the school!  Where's the supportive small-school atmosphere of Manhattan East now???

I am a parent of a Manhattan East student and I would just like to commend the school for how great the block party was on Saturday.  There was a large student turn out as well as parents and the teachers. Much has changed in Esperanza including it's principal, the new principal does not have a handle on things as much as she boast. So far within the 2013-2014 school year the school has gone through three principals. The staff is constantly changing and there is no stability in anything. My child started their first year there in Sept 2013, since then my child has has had at least 5 science teachers, 4 ELA teachers, 3 Spanish teachers, and 2 technology teachers. When asking the the principal why this was happening, we were told these teachers were hired and then later let go or switched to other classrooms because they did not meet the standards that they were looking for. I'm confused why hire teachers that don't meet the school's standards? The teachers don't read IEP's for special education. I have to call constantly to have them read my child's IEP and have them follow it. I was assured that the school did cater to children with special needs and the truth is yes they accept special ed students but no they do not adhere to IEP's, nor care to unless you bring it up to them first and insist that they read them. There is also a big problem with discipline in this school. The children are out of control in the classroom and the teachers don't know how to handle them. The so called Deans of discipline just yell and intimidate the children, follow them as they walk from class to class, hand out detention, and claim to be the eyes and ears of the school. But under their watch my child was hurt and bullied by other classmates. And lastly my child is present at school every day and on time, yet I continuously receive phone calls saying my child was late or my child was absent. I sigh when I think of all these things hindering my child's education. I wish I had placed my child some where else. I'm looking into moving to another middle school.

Renaissance School of the Arts made significant gains in attendance, test scores and teacher training under the Renewal Schools program, and continued improvement is both necessary and possible as it becomes a Rise School, writes Partnership with Children executive director Margaret Crotty in the Gotham Gazette.
Renaissance School of the Arts Principal Brian Bradley lauded the city's Renewal School program for providing his new teachers with the support they needed in fall 2015, the New York Times Reports.
On the first day of school, Chancellor Carmen Fariña visited Renaissance School of the Arts, one of the city's 94 "Renewal Schools". Read more here.

Ninety-four low-performing schools are now called “Renewal Schools,”. They will receive increased funds designated for an hour of additional learning time, after-school and summer programs, and teacher training. The principals will also be under review. Read more here.

Renaissance School of the Arts is among 40 middle schools selected for an extended learning day pilot with 2.5 more learning hours in the school day for all students, and daily literacy tutoring for high needs students. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

"The school was designed by parents and educators," the school's founding principal, Tammy Pate-Spears, told Insideschools. "It's a school that will look at students as individuals, but it will also hold them accountable to high standards."

Central Park East I is "on a list of 76 schools — designated as “struggling” by the state — that are required to test third and sixth graders three times a year on their academic progress using the NWEA Measures of Academic Progress (MAP) Growth Assessments," Chalkbeat reports. These would be in addition to the state math and English tests each year that 70% of CPE 1 students opted out of last year. The school is adorable but if you don’t have a sibling already there and a spot in PreK, not worth applying. This year there were something like 35 PreK spots and only 27 K spots. So impossible to get it unless you’re extraordinarily lucky.

The "embroiled" atmosphere of the last two years was not caused by Garg, but by real concerns that parents at the school had and continue to have. The diversity and spirit of this school is great, but at the end of they day many parents found that their children were not learning fundamental skills in math and ELA. "How to do we resolve this?" was the lead question that was asked publicly by Garg and what led to much opposition. I honestly think that many parents keep things as is in order to weed out working class families who are looking for a good solid education, as you really need the resources of time and money to supplement a child's education that this school does not provide. 

PROSPECTIVE PARENTS BE WARNED: this school will require you as a parent to do a lot of your own teaching at home, or provide the extra-curricular studies and tutoring. There are ZERO assessments done at the school as far as fundamental skills building is concerned so assessments will have to be done on your own to find out if your child is meeting the skills for his or her grade level. Report cards are handwritten by teachers and really don't provide the practical feedback that parents need. There is an expectation from parents to much of the work in math and ELA fundamental skills building. For a full-time working parent this is tough. You are going to need to buy workbooks or enroll in online supplemental education sites (Khan Academy, etc.) or tutoring lessons and do this every day in order for your child not to fall behind and be ready for middle school.

My daughter  graduated from CPE 1 about 2 years ago. She is doing excellent ( yes- grades to!- 90+, Including 3.5-4.5 in state tests) in another public middle school. They love her approach, willingness and responsibility and love of learning. That credit goes to CPE 1. Its approach develops child not only academically but also socially and emotionally. We never put her in any tutoring classes.  NYC is city of choices. There are many schools who teaches to take tests. CPE 1 is one of the best kept secret. and  hope it continue to flourish for many years.

Monika Garg cut the budget line for these specialists and added in a budget line for a school secretary - a personal friend she brought in. This alone speaks volumes about her priorities.
Though CPE1 received enough to fill their seats, kindergarten applications are down after a tumultuous year at the East Harlem school, reports DNAinfo.
Dozens of students, parents and educators took part in a school walkout to protest the policies of Principal Monika Garg. Read more here.
The New York Times takes a close look at the battle over CPE I's leadership and progressive values.

This article does not accurately reflect the situation. I am an involved parent and here is the letter I wrote to the NY Times editor in response to the article: To the editor:

Re: "East Harlem School's Utopian Spirit Devolves into a War" (May 18): 

The article presents a false picture of the "war" at Central Park East 1. It is not a case of out-of-district parents trying to keep local families of color from the school. Rather, it is the overwhelming majority of a school community-- Black and Latino, White, Asian and Biracial, low-income and middle class, in district and out--joining together to preserve a progressive education that has been CPE 1's hallmark for four decades. 

Department of Education officials handpicked a principal, Monica Garg, who would break down that tradition, and after months of trying to work with the principal, parents decided we could no longer trust her with our children. The breaking point for many was when Ms. Garg spearheaded official investigations of longtime teachers, questioning children without notifying their parents. Seven-year-olds were asked about incidents that occurred two years prior and were told to keep their interviews secret. 

Seventy percent of CPE 1 students are children of color, who come from both inside and outside the district in order to attend a school as diverse, progressive, and quality as CPE1. That type of diverse, inclusive and progressive environment is what we are fighting to protect.
Principal Monika Garg has defended herself from parents' criticism, saying that the progressive school needs more structure, DNAinfo reports.
Parents at Central Park East I have launched a campaign to have Principal Monika Garg removed, saying she does not uphold the school's progressive values. See the website parents created here.

Principal Monika Garg is destroying our school community and does not respect the parents. Students are losing valuable instructional time due to being pulled into her investigations against teachers that she doesn't like. There is a petition on Change.org to have her immediately removed from our school. Please read the following article to learn about her detrimental effect on our beloved school: https://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20160413/east-harlem/new-principal-ruining-legendary-progressive-public-school-parents-say

Project Museum.  These two words exemplify what makes CPE1 standout among public elementary schools.  A unique aspect of the school is "project time".  Throughout the year, almost every day, students work on projects of their own choosing based on their own interests (or "genius").  They labor for months researching, writing, thinking, planning, processing, discussing & creating.  The children across the grades present their work to peers, staff and families.  The 4th & 5th grade classes call this the Project Museum and it is a spectacular display not only of what amazing and genuine scholars the students are, but also how phenomenal the teachers are!  The teachers go above and beyond to support each child in developing their ideas and projects.  Can you imagine what efforts teachers put into supporting the development of dozens of unique projects?  That is why the children of this school are excited to go to school each day.  That is why so many families opted out of the state testing.  We don't need poorly designed assessments to tell us how our children are learning or how "efficient" the teachers are!  When we walk through the classrooms and see all that they have created, that says it all!
The choir at Central Park East has performed for local senior citizens. Read more here.
Central Park East I receives Blackboard Award for Progressive education.

Girls from several Harlem high schools-including Central Park East- learn golf  and form a team with coaching from Teddy Griffith. Read more <a href="http://cityroom.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/11/03/golf-by-corey-kilgannon/?_r=1">here</a.>

Central Park East I & II may get a middle school in parents' desired location after all: on October 17th, 2013, the Education Department will hold a hearing to discuss the proposal expand CPE II to include a middle school, located in the same building as CPE I's elementary and high school. The public hearing will be held at 6 pm in Central Park East I's building at 1573 Madison Avenue in East Harlem. 

Read more about the CPE community's ongoing fight to open a middle school here: http://insideschools.org/blog/item/1000611-walcott-says-middle-school-in-cpes-future

I am very much interested in this school, but someone who went to college with my son recommended this also I have a cousin who had twins that went to this school. My grandson will be turning 4 in November and we are looking at schools that he will be able to meet his educational needs. I am very much interested in how we can make this happen
Central Park East I and II are struggling to find more space to expand to include a middle school. Read more here.
Students spent Columbus Day at Zuccotti Park for Occupy Wall Street. Read more: Children Spend a Day at Protesters’ Encampment.

Interested in touring Central Park East: You'll need to call for an appointment. This from the school:


 


We are a non-catchment area school and accept
students from throughout the city. CPE1 is now accepting applications and scheduling
parent tours. Interested families should call 212.860.5821 for an appointment.

My son transferred to CPE1 from a "progressive" private school that didn't live up to its hype.  At CPE, I have finally seen real progressive education at work.  The children learn community and collaboration.  Most important, they learn to love learning. Every time I visit, I am amazed by the way the children learn to respect and listen to one another, whether during work time, presenting projects they have developed together, or simply listening quietly and applauding their schoolmates at the school's concerts.  My son's reading, always strong, has grown by leaps and bounds.  This is truly a wonderful place.
Would you share where your son went? My son is at a "progressive" private school now and we are thinking of transferring him for many reasons - and are looking at CPE1. Thank you!

Parent coordinator Beth Wood has had three children attend the school. One transferred to a more structured environment that better served his needs, but the other two were well served at CPE. “Teachers really get to know kids and create ways they can focus better,” she said.
A father: “It’s a give and take. Do I want my child to be a good person or do I want a brainer? I like progressive ed. The kids can express themselves. Other things we can fill in with a tutor.”

We have had several wonderful years at CPE1. If you want progressive education, this is the place. Our children and their learning styles are very different- and the teachers have given each what they need, valued each for who they are. It is a caring and nurturing environment that allows children to find their passion and be responsible for their own work and behavior. The core of the school is helping children grow as people- academically, socially, emotionally, and as a member of a democratic community. Tests are not what is valued here. It is not a good school if you only want the early grades; early grades lay the groundwork for a pre-k(or k) through 5th experience. It is a small community that thrives on families coming and staying. Look elsewhere if you are looking for a school only for the early years. But for a full experience that helps children grow as people and as learners, this is a unique and vibrant place.

"I am the parent of a 4th grader and I actually think the students are generally very engaged. CPE's use of project-based work, driven by the students own interests and passions actually cultivates true scholars. Anyone who has ever had to work on a research paper, senior thesis or project, or better yet a dissertation can appreciate that it takes enormous discipline, engagement and focus to think up a project, research it, design a plan or procedure, and implement it over the course of months. And then the kids do an oral presentation on the project and the process! It's quite amazing, actually. It may not result in 4's on state tests, but students leave with invaluable skills that should carry them through to the highest levels of school and beyond."

"CPE 1 is a great school for K-2 or maybe 3rd after that you should transfer your child to a new school, I say that because the curriculum and teaching procedures is not the best for a 4th & 5th grader, things a child should be learning at that age they don't, there is no advance programs at the school and not enough to keep your child challenged and engaged in learning. I feel the kids in 4th & 5th grade are way behind in learning materials compare to other public & charter schools. They need to work on that."

My son has been at CPE 1 for about a month now. He transferred there after 4 years in a G&T class. The most important thing I can say about CPE is that he is truly happy there. He was not happy to be leaving his friends behind, but he soon changed his tune once he recognized the vast differences at CPE. For the first time since pre-school, he is invested in his work and actually enjoying it. He is thinking again, not just doing robotic test prep work. And now when I ask about his day, he is actually excited to talk about what he did and learned. I am equally happy. The teachers, parents, principal- everyone!- all feel very welcoming and invested in the kids. In my opinion, this is what school should be. A space where kids are respected and cherished, where kids' voices and ideas are equally valued. And best of all, they are genuinely learning and thinking.

"I am thrilled to have two children at CPE1," writes a parent. "CPE1 understands that children learn in many different ways and does not subscribe to the one-size-fits-all mentality. The school deemphasizes standardized testing and instead focuses on how to teach children to think for themselves with the idea that true thoughtfulness translates into increased interest and a greater appetite for learning in general. The thing that struck me the first time I toured CPE1 was the total engagement that I witnessed in both students and teachers. ... The teachers are phenomenal and have the highest level of dedication. The school's method of child-based learning requires that each teacher really understand the individual child - and they do. This small environment allows all the kids to know one another and it is a regular sight at CPE1 to see upper-grade children supporting the lower grade students in and outside of the classrooms. Parent involvement at the school is incredibly high. The school has true racial and ecomomic diversity and puts a very high emphasis on community/social events rather than focusing on fundraising. My whole family loves CPE1 and we feel we are making a difference and really doing something right in the NYC educational system by giving our full support to this wonderful school."

"I student-taught at CPE I in 1990, and knew when I first set my foot in the door that this was a school where I would love to work and send my kids. I feel the same way today," writes a parent who says she moved to Harlem to be closer to the school. "CPE I accepts children for who they are and helps them grow into the people they are meant to be. My son and daughter love the school, enjoy all the arts that are offered, are becoming solid readers and mathematicians, and maturing wonderfully. Parents are welcomed at the school and now we even have our own parent room with a play area for babies and toddlers! We have families from many backgrounds at the school, which makes the experience for our children very rich. It is a school filled with passionate children, parents, teachers, and even a passionate principal! Test scores and school grades cannot measure the depth of learning and growth that is happening at the school, and many parents who decide to come know from their first visit, like I did, that CPE I is a special place."

According to the city Department of Education Quality Review Report, "[Students] are particularly good at initiating ideas planning their projects, but a significant number are less effective at researching and developing their ideas to a suitable depth."

Julie Zuckerman, who became principal in fall 2005, was "hand-picked" by the staff and parents, writes Robin Aronow, founder of School Search NYC and a consulting firm that helps parents navigate school admissions. Zuckerman is "thoughtful, intelligent and sincere" and "committed to progressive education," Aronow writes. "There is a nice mix of experienced teachers who mentor the new younger teachers. The parent coordinator, Beth Woods, is also extremely helpful. The parent body is actively involved... The arts program is extremely strong at CPE 1: studio arts, drama, movement and music. Music encompasses choral music as well as instruments: violin, drums, guitar and recorder. Each Monday morning the school week starts with a whole school assembly where the students and families sing together for 1/2 hour...The students have less homework than most other schools even in the upper grades. Report cards are anecdotal and there are no grades or class tests," she writes, adding that it is difficult to find standardized test scores for the school. "However, for a family who would love to have its child educated in an environment that emphasizes individual growth over test prep, while promoting a nurturing community, CPE I may be your school. CPE 1 is a citywide option."

"My daughter, a first grader, is in her second year here and thriving," writes parent Wendy Harris. "Suddenly she's reading books on her own, writing in her journal, and seems to have a developing interest in math." This parent cites CPE1's small size, innovative arts program, personal attention given to students and families, and emphasis on "teaching the children to truly love learning" as its greatest strengths, and she notes that classrooms are orderly and calm because students are engaged in their work. Finally, she points out that the school's traditions, such as the weekly "All School Sing," and weekly field trips, as well as the free Opus 118 Violin Partnership, give students "a sense of belonging to the CPE1 community."

A parent writes: "[Central Park East] is a truly amazing school! We have two children attending this school and both are thriving. The teachers and staff are devoted, inspiring and committed to reaching every child. Parents are warmly welcomed and intimately involved in the school. Both of our children skip off to school and run home talking about their days. The visual arts, music and drama/movement are integrated into the curriculum, giving the children many outlets to explore and learn. Central Park is an extension of their classroom." This parent adds: "We could have gone to one of many good NYC schools, or to a G/T program, but in visiting 15 schools, I never saw one where the children were as engaged in and excited about their learning or where the curriculum was so humanistic in its content as CPE1. The children learn the academic material and just as importantly they learn how to be caring and socially responsible people in their classroom, school and community. CPE1 is a little gem for anyone who wants a warm, nurturing school experience for their child and family."

A parent writes in to let readers know that Central Park East 1 and 2, as well as River East, are considering merging to gain independent school status (since none of the schools have enough students to gain this status on their own). However, this parent believes the identities of the schools are very different and doesn't think a merger would work: "How could these three schools [merge] as one since these three has their own characters and ambitions and their own ways of approaching their goals in educating their children?" she asks.

"I disagree with your review about many children not obtaining basic skills," writes a parent. "Both of my children attended CPE 1 since pre-kindergarten and learned to read by 5 years of age. They also had no trouble mastering age-appropriate math concepts. CPE 1 uses assessments that measure kids progress over time. It is a wonderful school that is academically challenging and at the same time teaches children through a hands on curriculum. If your review was based on test scores alone then you missed the whole picture. My son is now an honors student at a parochial school in the Bronx. My daughter is in the third grade. She loves to read and write and I owe it all to CPE 1. "

PLEASE READ!!!!!!!!! LOTS to say about this one.. in all honesty please do not send your child here. firstly the grad rate. TYWLS loves to brag about our 100% graduation rate but it's actually a lie. I've spoken to former tywls students who HAVE been dropped. yes, dropped. TYWLS will find juniors who are not doing well their junior year and drop them from the school. This allows the rest of the juniors who are doing well to move on to senior year ensuring they will graduate. I'm not exactly sure if they help these students find new schools to transfer to or they just drop them without any direction butttttttt...... also to add on, my friend had told me once she had a meeting with Ms.Colleen about her grades (Drew is no longer our principal) and was essentially told to only focus on one class and fail the other she was struggling in because it would be too difficult to handle both. I know it sounds ridiculous and hard to believe but if you were a student you would understand. It's awful our staff don't encourage us to try our best when really all they care about is their reputation. Ms.Colleen is a bit lost and doesn't seem like a principal figure, really Ms.Vega (the vice principal) is the one who takes that role although she doesn't have the title. However Ms.Vega isn't the greatest either. She can be a bit mean here and there and sometimes seems to be too preoccupied to help students when they really need it or might need somebody to talk to. Now, the "sisterhood". TYWLS claims to be a supportive environment when in all honesty the staff don't really care about you. again, for them it's all about reputation. Girls aren't really nice to each other and lots of bullying takes place but it's also an all girl's school so i think bullying/mean girls is inevitable no matter what. Again, bringing back the word "reputation", we don't talk to ANY of our sister schools in the other boroughs AT ALL and tywls east harlem only really cares about themselves (aka NOT the other tywls schools in nyc) and their OWN (say it with me) r e p u t a t i o n!!! opportunities here and there which is one pro. Also academics is really all about the student i find it to be pretty easy while other's find it challenging. But teachers honestly can't grade and will hand out 70s all the time instead of actually grading fairly. However, ( i forget the name of these group of students) who have extra time and shorter tests, etc actually get easier work!! I'm in the normal track. and for example while everyone in the normal track might do bad on this one math test the other students with "shorter" but really easier tests often pass with flying colors!! I've seen one of my friend's grades who is part of this group and she has all 90's in her classes meanwhile I'm in the normal track struggling to bring my geomotry grade up to an 80! It's really unfair seeing kids on honor roll who really didn't earn that spot and seeing them all of a sudden act all cocky and treat me with sympathy as if i don't get the material. In the end though, will they really be prepared for college? In Conclusion, don't consider applying to this school https://media3.giphy.com/media/xUOxfb6Cgxx0n7tp1S/giphy.gif

Academic wise this school is known for producing scholars! They have a high college acceptance rate & the work prepares you for college. As far as Administration, they're terrible! My daughter has been getting bullied in and outside the school and the Principal and staff have done a terrible job at helping with this situation. First off their school phones have not "worked" for a yr already so you can never get through to anyone. No one responds to emails, they do not inform you when your child is pulled out of class. When meeting with the parents and staff the principal was completely unprofessional, yelling at us and even got in our faces!! My daughter is still dealing dealing with this issue and we have even brought it to the attention of the police. I am now filing a report with the DOE as well. I now feel like I have no choice but to remove her from this school and let these cowards rob her of a wonderful opportunity all because of a terrible principal and vice principal.
WHAT IS THE BELL SCHEDULE? when does school start and when does it end?? tell me it all n thanks
Any bullying?

My name is Javier Sepulveda, I am the proud father of three awesome girls. Madeline graduated from this school and is currently in her 3rd year at SUNY Purchase, She is on the Deans list with a 4.0 GPA. Michelle is on schedule to graduate this year with a high 90's average, and is excited about her college search. Melissa is on track to graduate next year and is exceeding in all courses. I would highly recommend this school to all families; who wish to give the best education to their daughter(s). As a low income, Puerto Rican, parent living in Harlem for the past 9 years I have struggled and hoped to give my girls a better life. This school is an Oasis in the big city. The teachers are awesome, their commitment to my girls education has always been evident. The principals, teachers, office staff, security officer, have always treated me and my girls with care and respect. My girls love the school and their attendance record reflex that. They do not wish to miss a day. They come home excited to tell my wife and I about their day in school. I TOTALLY RECOMMEND THIS SCHOOL AND STAFF.  I GIVE THEM HIGH PRAISE AND SINCERE THANKS FOR TAKING CARE OF AND EDUCATING MY GIRLS. I have watched them prosper into strong, intelligent, independent young women. I am grateful to this school and it's staff for helping my girls prepare to take on the world. I am proud of each one of them and of my decision to place them at The Young Women's Leadership School of East Harlem. This school should be your first choice for your daughter(s).

Also, recently, the school has added various benefits for seniors. Such as, when you are on time everyday of the week, you get to go out for lunch on Fridays. And, when going home, you get to skip the elevator line. I love TYWLS and especially TYWLS East Harlem because the co-directors, Drew and Colleen are truly the best in helping the future women leaders.

I'm a senior at TYWLS East Harlem and I came in 10th grade. TYWLS has been such an amazing school and I'm glad I have gotten the chance to attend (I wish I came in 6th grade!) The teachers are so supportive, and are there to tell you reality and push you to do your best. I remember having an issue with punctuality and the amount of support and care I received from my teachers that all came together to help me stop it was beyond heart warming. Also, the school has such a nice bond and spirit where we really do come together as sisters to get things done. For example, with the recent political climate and election, juniors and seniors organized a walkout protest to protest about the injustice happening. The amount of opportunities here are also great as we are a CBI (College Bound Initiative) school in which we have a college counselor who takes time to help us with the college process. For instance, I have college counseling class two times a week in my schedule (which is great because not a lot of schools have that). No school is perfect and so, there are some downsides. Such as how we have a small gym that is also our auditorium. But, we are still able to play sports and we do in fact have a joined sports team with two neighboring schools nearby in which we use one of the school's gym (so it kinda all works out!). Also, we do have to take the elevator to school and Mon-Thurs after school (as the lines might be long but...sometimes it comes in handy! because it could be pretty tiring to walk up nine flight up stairs). We do though, take the stairs for changing classrooms. As it is a small school, our school is located in an office building and so floors 7-11 are ours. TYWLS EH being a small school is a great advantage because you really get that one on one support from all the staff and teachers. I've never felt such a sense of community and love from a school that empowers women, our educational future, and what it truly means to be a leader and lead the way for our future and those to come after. I highly recommend TYWLS because as they say, girls really do learn and focus better when boys aren't around!
this school is the worst thing you could ever put yourself through, all the teachers care about is the schools reputation and act completely different once a visitor enters the classroom

Followup on the bullying issue: I was always under the impression that threats to kill students were taken very seriously and fell under the zero tolerance policy. I was disappointed today to find out that my daughter was threatened to be killed by the same student for the second time in a week. She not only threatened to kill her but that she would get to her by finding out where she lives by way of the 'blue card' that parents have to fill out and return to the school. This student has only received verbal  warnings first from a teacher and then today from the dean. I am in utter shock that this matter isn't receiving the attention it deserves in light of so many tragedies that have already occurred because of the lack of reaction. I am hoping that the next comment on here isn't another tragedy (Godforbid).
can you go out for lunch??
nope

Yesterday we were finally able to speak with Carlos, the dean.  I must say that i am very pleased with how quickly he handled the situation.  Today they weren't any uncomfortable moments my daughter had to face.  Many thanks to Carlos!  Hopefully, we can resolve the other issues.

Last year i was ecstatic to find out my daughter was accepted to one of the top schools in East Harlem! She was attending a small elementary school and i thought it would be a great transition. Unfortunately, i must say that i regret making the decision to even apply to TYWLS. I am incredibly disappointed with the support, management and the so called Violin program! 
1.The teachers want to treat the students like adults.  I think that should be expected by the end of the middle school years, not the first year coming from an elementary school. Most 11/12 year olds need as much support as possible while they're entering a new environment, encountering new policies and going through puberty.
Parent support: i must call the main office  212 289-7593about 6 times(maybe more) before i finally speak to someone. I've also emailed the teachers and one teacher responds half the time, the other teacher never responds.
2. Management: Finding a good school your child can attend through 12th grade is usually a positive for parents. We assume that the older students would set an example and the teachers can manage the students.  Well, not the case!  There is a student that bullies a lot of the other students. She steals from them, threatens, hits and verbally abuses them.  My daughter witnessed a fight in one class and saw the teacher turn her head to the opposite direction.  She doesn't feel safe, didn't want to go to school and feels like the teachers are too afraid to address the situation.
Elevator mgmt: students are required to be there by 8:40. She has to stand on line to wait for one of two elevators.  One time she was on line at 8:32, but since seniors have priority they get to skip the line.  Whenever this occurs, she is marked late.
3.Violin program: The question is what Violin program.  They hand a student a violin and they say practice.  In elementary school she met in a small group with a violin teacher twice a week and had beautiful concerts. She amazed so many.  Now her skills are regressing. In the beginning of the year she had her first TYWLS  concert.  I left work early, invited 4 family members and 1 friend.  Oh my goodness, how unbelievably embarrassed I was.  The "concert" lasted literally 3 minutes. I spent more time waiting for the concert to start.  Did i mention they had to dress up for this 3 min concert or they would recieve an F for music for that quarter. Then they had the nerves to announce that the so called concert was just to get parents in for a PTA meeting.  I was so furious and have not gone to one PTA meeting!  Deception is not the way to get parents involved.
4.My daughter really wants me to mention the food issue as well. It's public school lunch, so not much can be expected. However, cleaniness can and should be controled . She found a bug in her food one time.  The window guard above the food is dirty. The water containers are dirty. 
I have started to look into other schools.  This time I'm not letting reputation convince me and I will ask to speak to the new students.

I also have a 6th grader at TYWLS and I sympathize with some of your complaints.  Communication for me with teachers has been great, but not so much so with the administration.  I have e-mailed one of the principals and never received a response.  They generally give very short notice about events, changes to the schedule, etc.  I too was very upset about the "concert"/trick-parents-to-attend-the-PTA-meeting!  On top of that, some parents were lectured by a PTA dad when they decided not to stay for the PTA meeting.  I have attended some meetings and felt they were disorganized and a waste of my time.  My lunch complaint is that my daughter says they never have much time to eat.  She brings lunch from home, and even without having to wait in line, there is still little time.

I will say that my daughter has spoken to me about one particular 6th grade bully, but I know that when her adviser became aware of the situation, she thought of ways to intervene.  Although the girl is still having issues (not easily solved by teachers), it has not gotten so bad that my daughter didn't want to be there.  In fact, she wants to stay there through high school.  My daughter has teachers that she really, really likes and often comes home talking about exciting lessons both in class and in the after school program, Girls, Inc.  I feel that the teachers are genuinely invested in my daughter's education.  Girls, Inc has been a great way to spend the extended day.  My daughter has gotten to participate in some really interesting and engaging activities through them and I know that they are really looking to ensure her success in school.

As someone who sees firsthand what can go wrong in middle & high schools, I have to say that TYWLS is doing better than most.  There is definitely room for improvement, especially on the communication front (I hope the principals are reading this- you need to respond to parents, too!).  But overall, I think it's a good, safe learning environment where girls can thrive.

I'm glad you're not experiencing the same lack of communication with your daughter's teachers.  It becomes extremely frustrating when you're a working parent and aren't able to be present physically.  However, I am looking forward to parent teacher conference day.  Although, the teacher that I wanted to speak to the last time, regarding a stolen project, wasn't available.  
My daughter also says she doesn't have enough time to eat.  After waiting on two lines to get lunch she only had 5 minutes to eat one day.  On average,  she says she gets about 15 minutes to eat her lunch.

After 19 years of the federal government probing the Young Women's Leadership School due to complaints from the NYCLU and NYCRC, the Federal government found there was no violation of any civil rights. Read more here.
Michael Meyers, executive director of the New York Human Rights Coalition, explains why he believes that schools segregated by gender, such as TYWLS, violate city and federal law. Read more here.
TYWLS has inspired the creation of a new school in St. Louis, Hawthorn Leadership School for Girls, a STEM college preparatory school set to open in the fall of 2015. Read more here.

I entered TYWLS as a freshman. Admittedly, it was not my first or second choice, but my third. However, after spending three years at this institution I must say that I wouldn't trade it for any other school if given the choice. Many of the students are passionate and strong willed, which only pushed me to step out of my shell and develop a powerful voice myself. Leaving middle school, I was afraid that I'd be just another face in crowd, but the support and sense of camaraderie between the students, teachers, and staff eased all of my concerns. Most of the teachers make lessons engaging and are there for students for academic help, but they are also almost always ready to lend an ear and give us support on circumstances beyond the classroom walls. Of course no school is perfect and not all of the student body will have the same views as I do, but it is important to remember that the faculty and the administration are not solely responsible for giving each student a spectacular experience. We as students must also take initiative to make it the best four years    (or seven years if you are entering the school as a sixth grader) it could possibly be. We must take advantage of all the resources and support given to us. Thank you TYWLS for the last three years!

During open house the staff was polite and inviting. The school is small but that the only thing i can say that wasnt so great. But as for everything else it was great and the community talks very highly about this school. The girls attending are also happy to be there.

I'm currently a senior in TYWLS, I've been in TYWLS since I was in 7th grade. I think academically the school is amazing, the work is challenging and time consuming but manageable and realistic. I think the staff are pretty good, the teachers make it their business to make sure students are okay and handle certain situation's with the right precautions. I think the students in TYWLS are getting worse as the years increase, but that's simply not the staff that's the YOUTH. I think since I've been in TYWLS I have been offered an amazing amount of opportunities (No. I'm not a top student, I'm an average student like many others, just so you are aware that you do not have to be top in your class to be offered opportunities). These my last comments, from the grandmother of 2004 and 2008. My granddaughter attends her last class today 5/14/10 and thanks to the TYWLS community she has become a beautiful young lady headed into the next chapeter of her life at Emmanuel College in Boston, MA. With the assistance of TYWLS she was accepted to five different colleges and received 3 scholarships. I thank all of the TWYLS staff especially Chris who helped shape her college interest since 2004.

"In 2004 I wrote about my delight in seeing my granddaughter shine at this school. It's 2008 now and I still cannot say enough wonderful things about TYWLS," writes the grandmother from November 2004. "I do not know of many schools that reach out to a parents (via email) when they see things changing with a student. My granddaughter recently began to slip in her school work and one of her teachers reached out to me, coordinated a school meeting with all of her teachers, the principal and guidance counselor. Together we met and discuss her and developed a work plan to get her back on track. This just does not happen in other schools even though it should. Through TYWLS she has attended a special program for young women interested in Science and Engineering at Smith College and a Biomedical Research project at Mt. Sinai during her last two summers. This is what makes TYWLS special."

The Young Women's Leadership School was featured in New York Times Magazine's March 2, 2008 cover story, "Teaching Boys and Girls Separately." Noting the school's reputation as the "birthplace of the current single-sex public school movement," the article goes on to explain, "[t]his position of eminence stems from both its early beginnings and its success; since opening in 1996, every girl in every senior class at T.Y.W.L.S. has graduated and been accepted at a four-year college."
One 7th grader who transferred in from another school says, "I am so happy here. All of the girls try to get along with everyone. There are no cliques like my other school."
A mother who lives in the Bronx says, "I love it! My daughter is happy and that makes me happy."

"My daughter loves her assignments, teachers and overall positive atmosphere," writes a parent. "Her teachers appear to be very knowledgable and genuinely concerned with helping the girls become active learners." This parent notes that there are a number of sports and clubs for students and that the college planning process begins in middle school.

A grandparent writes: "My granddaughter was just admitted into TYWLS after a very disappointing year in another neighbor school. Her entire attitude about learning had been defeated and she didn't really care about school. She felt she couldn't succeed. In just one week I feel like I have a new child. She is excited about learning. She is not overwhelmed with 3-4 hours of homework every night. The majority of learning seems to be done in class and is reinforced by light homework at home. I am so grateful for this school. Last week I had to go and get her because she doesn't want to leave the school."

"In the years my daughter has been at TYWLS I have recognized that the school has a clear mission: to facilitate maximal learning by mid-range students," writes a parent. "It will get them into college by providing a pleasant, comfortable environment with generally dedicated teachers." However, she writes, she does not recommend the school for an academically gifted student. This parent feels that the school does not encourage gifted students to excel.

CPE 2 teachers and families are the highlight of this special school. Families are nurturing, encouraging and active. However, the principal makes it impossible for parents to feel comfortable contributing and participating in their child's education. Teachers are willing to speak with parents, but express concern that the principal will retaliate if she hears that they are working with parents without her knowledge. The principal is a knowledgeable educator but uses aggression and shame throughout her interactions with the children and parents. She has publicly shamed children, targeted specific children, ignored parents emails requesting social and emotional support,  blamed the victim in bullying experiences, and spoke poorly about parents to other parents.  Meetings she runs quickly move from focusing on  school issues and move to her personal gripes with parents, students or other staff. Her unprofessionalism makes it difficult for a child with special needs to get the services they need if she disagrees with the plan. She runs the school through intimidation and fear. Parents, kids and staff are afraid of her. This is not appropriate for a school. Beyond the principal there are wonderful, supportive and smart staff members. The assistant principal is an asset to the school who gets pushed aside by the domineering principal. CPE 2 has so much possibility with its families, teachers and long history. The principal has really made the school a hostile place and we strongly recommend you think before you apply to send your child here.

this school is very Unique and might not be the right choice for every parent, especially if you are looking for traditional educational settings. But if you like to raise creative thinkers in a diverse learning environment this is the place to send you child. The school is a collaboration of the teachers, Students and their families. each child in each grade get so much enrichment like at no other public school: Art weekly, music, birds program, dance, science, trips, you name it. the kids learn in a project base environment, so they also learn how to work in groups which is great since in real life many of us need to deal with working as a team. The school leadership is dedicated and very accessible for questions and discussion. there is a great ratio of teachers- students in each class, so children get the attention they need. most importantly is that our kids are so excited to go to school every mornings, and I think its the case for most kids. there is a very positive and supportive attitude towards the children. the Teachers in the school are Amazing, intelligent, compassionate, dedicated and most of them been there over ten years, which means a lot about the school. 
The issue with the testing is up to you as a parents, the school doesn't encourage you either way, but the kids learn in such a high level that if you do choose for them to test they will be ready. its not a competitive testing environment that can get kids stressed out about school which is good.

In October 2014, twelve New York City public schools, including the Central Park East II, submitted detailed proposals about ways to promote and preserve diversity in their school communities. Nearly a year later, these schools are still waiting on a response from Chancellor Carmen Fariña. Read more here.

The CPE2 community is still one of the best examples I've ever seen of families and educators who bring a great deal of diversity, dedication, and a commitment to keeping arts and music in the curriculum. That said, our family's overall experience has been more negative than positive due to two major problems. First and sadly, influencing and overshadowing everything else, the principal is nearly impossible to work with. Her aggressive, controlling, and disrespectful persona has students, parents, and teachers giving up on contributing to CPE2 or asking for their special needs to be met and just trying to stay out of her way so as not to get yelled at. She publicly shames students and teachers, often for behavior that she arbitrarily decides was unacceptable after the fact. This all by itself is enough for us to have stopped recommending the school to other families and instead to have begun warning them away. But there is a second major problem and this has to do with CPE2's approach to the Common Core curriculum and the introduction of high stakes testing. I share the rejection of high stakes testing but the campaign to force all students into opting out was not well thought out or carried out; instead of reducing stress levels for students we found that students were more anxious, even if they didn't have to take the actual test, because they heard it talked about so much, were falsely led to believe that it would be their own responsibility if their teachers were fired for the school not having high enough test scores, and they were bringing home hours of test prep homework anyway. This is the nucleus of the testing problem in my opinion: the more damaging aspect is not the test itself, but the choice by a school that calls itself progressive to abandon project-based learning in favor of lots of classroom test prep and heavy homework loads based on worksheets the teachers are downloading from the NYS Common Core website. We chose CPE2 because we believe in the progressive philosophy; it is a curriculum which, when done well, is actually more rigorous than mainstream curriculums and which builds students who are better at skills like critical analysis, problem solving, independent research and learning. Our child, however, only participated in one major project, in third grade social studies, in the entire time at CPE2. Otherwise both class time and homework time were taken up by worksheets or timed independent reading (the focus was on number of minutes read in order to "build up stamina" for how long the testing would require instead of on understanding content or engaging in characters and stories) which had no relevant context other than the Common Core standards.
In short, CPE2 has been completely demoralizing for our family and we can't imagine things will get better as long as the current principal is in charge. We certainly wouldn't encourage anyone to enroll here and we suspect the new middle school will be plagued by the same issues.

It's been seven years since CPEII became its own institution, and it's clearly independent. Like any parent of a student anywhere, I've had (and will probably have) issues with the school. when i was in CPEII i loved it there. i was very comfortable with the class size and with talking to the teachers if i had a problem.cpeII was ultra artsy and very creative, from the music class to dancing at art connection, a modern dance class. i'm not completely sure if everything is the way it use to be when i was there but i remember how much fun i had in a school, which is shocking to me. a plus is that central park is just down the block and they have fun trips. the only thing that upset me was that they cut off the grades.it was from pre-k to 8th grade and changed when i was on my first year to pre-k to 5th so i only had 2 years but i had a great 2 years.

I LOVE CPE2! My son is a 1st grader, and has been attending since Pre-K. Enrolling him at CPEII has been one of the best decisions I've made as a parent. After 3 years at CPE2, he enjoys school and is a self expressed and confident learner. The school's progressive philosophy is a great fit for our family. The teachers are awesome, energetic and dedicated to our children's development as learners. The principal, a down to earth administrator, is accessible to each student and family. The parent community is diverse, welcoming and committed to the school's success. The arts and music programs are awesome. This year my son is taking percussion and violin; both programs are superb. The music teacher, Devior is a gem; she is passionate and runs an exceptional after school percussion program, Speaking in Rhythms! The school also offers violin through the renowned, Opus 118! If you are a parent looking for a quality and progressive public school, CPE2 is for you.

My son is a 2nd grader and has attended CPE II since Pre-k. There are many things I love about this school but more than anything I love that my son likes going to school. In this day and age where so many schools teach to test rather than teach to learn I think CPE II provides the proper balance of both. I find the teachers to be very genuine and truly want the children to succeed. I think that the class sizes are very small for public school and this allows for more individualized attention. The teachers and administration are very accessible not only to parents but to students as well. The schools healthy eating policy is a God send, and all schools should follow suit. The swimming, ice skating, visits to Central Park, and offering of after school sports programs lend to this healthy environment as well. I have watched my son flourish in this school and am greatful to have him in such a positive learning community.

CPE II is an intimate yet diverse jewel of a school! The principal, Naomi Smith, knows every child by name and voice. The classes are small (20 kids) with a head teacher, an experienced para and parent helpers. Every semester classes get student teachers from schools like Bank Street. This creates a great teacher/child ratio and infuses the school with energy and fresh ideas. There is a staff librarian, art and music/movement teachers and math, science and literacy specialists. All of whom know every child and can discuss their interests at the drop of a hat. My son started in pre-k and is now in 1st grade. He is happy, confident and enthusiastic about learning. His teachers are all energetic, nurturing and highly effective educators. He reads at at a 5th grade level. He's learning math concepts that make the subject fun and relatable to his experience. In a class that combines kindergarden and 1st grade students every child gets individual attention that is suitable to their level.

Our 1st daughter started with CPE2 in Pre-K 2009 after having visited an upscale private school for 2 years. We had the choice to keep her in that private school for one more year and start with CPE2 in Kindergarten, but after our CPE2 & Lisa's Pre-K class visit we had to admit; the comparison of this school and the expensive private school had a surprising result: besides the obvious plus of saving money, the classrooms were larger, sunnier, the teachers (way) more creative, fresh, attentive and engaged in their job, the parents (way) more involved and interested in their children's school and everyday life, many more regular trips to the beach (once a week in the summer!!) and the ice skating ring in Central Park (once a week in the winter!). there is cooking, baking and animal keeping going on and daily trips to the "backyard", Central Park! the community, music and art program as well as after school offers are amazing! our 2nd daughter will start this fall : ))

Yes the school can come across as a great school, and yes when my daughter was in kindergarden and first grade things were fine, but when my child got to second grade, I was blown away by the fact that she has to share her class with 3rd graders. She was sent home with homework that was not explained in lessons, and then when I tried to voice my opionin about the work, I was shut down by the principal,Ms. Noami can be pushy and very bossy making me feel as a parent that I have no say so whatsoever! There are two grades to a class, one teacher and parent paras. I think with classroom size so large, Ms. Noami should not hire parents to work with children unless they have the experience. If you dont mind your child being singled out, and your concerns for your child put to the side choose CPE 2!

i think this school is a great school for my child Marie Montgomery... i can say that because i too attended this school when i was young when Ms. Vail, Ms. Starskey, and Ms. Beaux were their.. n i think they are very organized... clean .. they pay attention to your child and the teachers are great... i remember when the school only went to 2 grade.. i like now they go to 5th.. with schools closing we have to provide our kids with the best we can to make sure they excel and P.S 36 is the best school for that

"The principal appears to want to help everyone instead of utilizing other staff/resources to help her out," writes a parent. "As a result, she either forgets or is unable to complete the request of the parent, thereby letting the parent down unintentionally."

Principal Cynthia Simmons responds to the comment above: "The hands on approach that has been established with parents at P.S. 36 is a tradition and one that I hope never changes. It is important that parental concerns are immediately addressed. Unfortunately, in the life of a principal, some things will be forgotten. I'm glad to know that the parent mentioned that this was done unintentionally. I would not like to think that my efforts go unnoticed. As far as the staff is concerned, I cannot think of another institution that strives to adhere to the needs of students more. Possibly reevaluating the duties of those who have immediate contact with parents is a suggestion to help to decipher the more important parental issues."

When the Department of Education announced in the fall of 2006 that it was planning to place a new secondary school in the PS 36 building, parents protested. As a result, the DOE has withdrawn the plans, and PS 36 will remain the only school in the building.
For the 2006-07 school year, PS 36 is newly identified by the State Education Department as "in good standing."

"I have nothing but compliments for this school," writes parent Nicola Forde. "My daughter had an amazing kindergarten teacher who continuously pushed and prodded her students to do more; my daughter then moved on to the gifted and talanted class in first grade to an another teacher who equally challenged her especially with her vocabulary words." This parent adds that the school's principal "is always willing to come out of her office to assist with whatever problems the parents may have, and always with a smile and words of encouragement."

A mother whose son transferred to PS 36 writes: "I found the staff to be consistently wonderful." She disagrees with the negative comments about the principal and writes, " The principal comes out of her office, speaks to parents who are waiting to see if she can be of assistance. It was refreshing to go to NYC Public School and see staff that smiled and even though they were busy and were still pleasant. My child, who came in as a special education student, thrived in the environment and is now general ed, thanks to the wonderful, highly skilled staff of this school."

A staff member writes that the school has "simply the best Parent Coordinator!" She writes: "Ms. Flores goes above and beyond to help the parents; if she can't answer you today, she'll get back to you. We only wish that the whole office staff was like her!"

A parent writes in to react to a previous comment indicating that the principal is unresponsive. This parent writes: "That is not true at all. The principal is the greatest and she helps anyone who needs it. I have seen it first hand. The school is a really good school."
I found PS 39 to be an excellent school.

The stats on this schools grossly misrepresent the magic taking place at 46. As a parent, an educator and a member of this community, I can attest to the progress taking place. Up until about four years ago, there were chalkboards and little technology. Teachers transitioned and not the students. There was no bell system. Nonetheless, the school has always been a safe space for students. Former students will declare how much they’ve learned at 46, which made them better prepared for high school. One of the biggest issues impacting this school are the major issues happening in the community and in the homes that impact students socio-emotional, mental and physical well-being. 46 gets a bad undeserved rap and needs more support to help alleviate the depth of issues some students show up witth
PS 46 has been added to the state's list of schools needing improvement under No Child Left Behind because of inadequate performance on the state tests in English.

Teacher Tara Vaughn write: "I was really offended by the remark made about cluster tear teachers being weak. It is just as difficult and in some cases more difficult than being a classroom teacher."  
P.S. 46 was mentioned in a May 21, 2005 article in the New York Sun on Young Audiences New York, a nonprofit organization that places professional artists in public schools. "The students at P.S. 46, an elementary school at 155th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, took their musical talents to Broadway on Wednesday with a performance at the Young Audiences New York annual benefit at the Marriot Marquis.Under a Young Audiences New York program, the students are training their voices with the help of professional artists for 16 weeks.'Having the kids from P.S. 46 was a highlight,' the organization's executive director, Joanne Bernstein-Cohen, said. 'It really brought the entire feeling of what we do at Young Audiences New York into the room.'"

A parent writes that although an unpleasant encounter with a staff member during registration worried her, she is glad she sent her child to PS 46. She writes, "Not only did my child get placed in a talented and gifted class the following year but Mr. Young worked hard to keep the After School Program afloat to continue helping all students. Working with the teachers and principal (Mr. Young) (who knows my child by name), I no longer want to take her out of the school!"
PS 92 is among the schools with the most improved 2017 state English test scores, Chalkbeat reports.

PS 92 has been added to the state's list of schools needing improvement under No Child Left Behind because of inadequate performance on the state tests in English.
According to the city Quality Review Report, "[The school] has seen considerable changes over the past four years... One teacher described the changes since the principal's arrival as a 'miracle.'"

Parent Beverly Greene writes: "My older kids attended PS 92 and they all graduated 6th grade and are now well rounded individuals. I now have an 8-year-old attending PS 92 and she is in Miss Dawn Robert's class. I believe within my heart that Miss Roberts really cares about her kids and this shows in [my daughter's] work on a daily basis. I thank God that she was able to be placed with a teacher who really knows what she is doing and I look forward to working with her to make sure my child is at her full potential in the following months ahead. One last note, before she was in Miss Fields' [class], who is also an exceptional jewel of a teacher. I think if the school had more people like them no child would be left behind." She adds: "Every parent needs to work with their child after school and also keep a dialogue going with the teacher. Working together can bring the school back to where it once was."

"I had to take my children to this school because of zoning," writes Sheree Bethea, a parent. "My son was in 1st grade and my daughter was starting the 3rd grade. When we took my daughter to one class there were only 3 little girls in the class trying their hardest to read a story with one young male teacher, meanwhile there was one group of boys fighting while another male teacher was holding up his "quiet hand". My children and myself broke down in tears we all refused to leave my daughter in that classroom. The next room was calmer, but the teacher was a 19 year-old teacher's aide because the previous teacher had quit. The place is loud and the work my daughter brought home was work she had done in preschool. Needless to say I enrolled my kids on a Monday and their last day was that Friday." She adds, "I had to take a second job to pay for private school."
look that school is the best school in the world so you should have had a meeting with the teacher first before entering your ''kidz'' in class
