I’m very surprised to read such a negative comment about the school and Mr. House. Coinsidently enough, my son was in Mr House’s class this school year. PS 18 is the third school in 5 years that my son has gone to because I have decided to pull him out due to my discontent of the lack of tolerance and understanding of my son’s needs. Thanks to Mr House, my son this year became so much independent at home with his homeworks, my son would be reinforced at school with very positive words such as “ You can do it” or “ You can do your best” which he would repeat at home all the time. My son for the first time ever met the standard math test at his grade level. I think Mr House communicating with me everyday to provide feedback as to how the day was going with my child was very helpful to me on communicating back to my son’s doctors but also helped me find ways on how to improve my son’s behavior in order to help achieve a successful academic year and help him learn. Mr House tries as a team work with the parent to push the child to their fullest potential. I also found the school to be very responsive, cordial and tend to my son’s needs or my request very timely. It seems like all he staff care for the students. I am so happy that I am looking forward to the next few years at PS 18 for my son.
A teacher at PS 18 was fired after asking her class to write down all the reasons they disliked a particular classmate. Read more here.

P.S. 18 is a participant in the Wellness in the Schools Cook for
Kids and Coach for Kids programs. Cook for Kids replaces the traditional
cafeteria menu with a healthy menu based on scratch cooking and fresh
ingredients. WITS places a trained culinary profession in the school cafeteria
to prepare fresh meals from scratch, engage students, and educate families
about the importance of eating whole, unprocessed foods through interactive
cooking demonstrations called WITS Labs. Coach for Kids brings a trained
coach onto the recess yards of public schools to get event the least active
students moving, build self-esteem and teamwork skills, and actively
combat schoolyard bullying. The Coach for Kids program  fosters a sense of
excitement and engagement among children around fitness and exercise. You
can find out more about programming from Wellness in the Schools and see a list
of participating schools online at www.wellnessintheschools.org
Community members raise concerns over a growing number of schools built in potentially contaminated locations. Read more: As City Leases Industrial Sites for Schools, Concern About Safety Builds.
"I'm very happy here," said one parent. "It's a good school, and I'm very happy with the school."
"You're not teaching students," said the school's literacy coach, about the Teacher's College reading and writing workshop model. "You're teaching readers and you're teaching writers."
"I don't just pick anybody," said the principal about hiring teachers. "I'm picky. I'm very picky."
"The kids are so happy here," said one teacher.

"This is a very excellent school," writes a former student. "I had Ms. Bryant who is now Mrs. Gulf in second grade and she made me a excellent student. I had horrible handwriting and did not do homework and did not read and hated Math. She made love Math and now I am very good at it. I read excellently now and do not have problems with many words. My handwriting is very nice and my mom won't stop bragging about it. I also had Mrs. Sharan Rosen and she was an excellent teacher and taught me how to treat others how you want to be treated."

Jamie Lefkowitz, 1st grade bilingual teacher at P.S. 28 Wright Brothers, is one of the 17 recipients of the 2016 Big Apple Award. The Big Apple Award is a citywide recognition program that celebrates the incredible work of New York City public school teachers. Read more here.

Kindergarteners at PS 48 have class in trailers despite the fact that their school building houses unused city offices. Read more here.

Principal Tracy Walsh received a 2007 Cahn fellowship, a 16-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize and develop outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor other principals, while continuing to serve as principal at their schools.
"This school is like a home to me, and the kids are like your brothers and sisters," writes student Delila. "The teachers are like your mom or dad."

A teacher writes: "There is a severe roach problem in many classrooms, as well as evidence of mice in many rooms. In my class during the first week of school I saw three roaches fall out of the cabinet -- and there was no food yet in the room. The school does not allow any type of pest control other than glue traps, which are inhumane for the mice and do not effectively reduce the infestation. Why don't schools fumigate during breaks when the children will be away?"

A teacher writes, "This school has been failing in reading for several years, and the stabs at solutions have been inadequate." She complains that "there is very limited planning to involve and educate parents on how to assist their students at home. Teachers do not attend PTA meetings regularly, if at all." She also describes failed attempts at school reform: "For example, because of failing reading scores, class sizes were supposed to be smaller. But because there was not enough room, a number of teachers are paid full salaries to sit in already full rooms, as extra help for students. ... Call it a lack of training for this model or a lack of interest on the teachers' parts -- but it is not a success." She adds, "Another problem is the special ed program. Many kids are in crisis at this school. Surprisingly, there is no working crisis team or crisis room set up to calm these kids down. ... This has an effect on the entire feel of the school."
Does the school require uniforms?
Yes they do baby blue polo and navy blue pants from 6-7th grade. Navy blue polo and navy blue pants for 8th

The Daily News reports that IS 52 is under investigation as a cancer cluster site after about a dozen teachers in its building were diagnosed with various forms of cancer. The other two schools that are colocated in the same building will also be examined for safety over the summer.

As someone who went to this school during the years of 2010-2013, I can surely say this school has impacted positively in my life. I am now going to college. I had the best time of my life in IS52! I met so many people, learned to network with others and I wrote my college essay about it. I wonder if Ms. Paumig, Ms. Ackert, Ms. Bracie and Mr. Vilson still teach there. This school is definitely a "hidden gem" in New York City. I really miss this school. As for the anonymous that claimed that this is the worst school, I agree with you on one thing only, there are many fights but you'll find that everywhere, literally. I had many fights in that school and it made me evolve into the man I am now. It also gave me insight that life isn't the "Utopian dream" I once thought about. I will always hold this school dearly in my heart. I would really like to speak to Ms. Paumig as I did write my college essay around an event that happened. Anyways, this school is great!!

Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. I.S. 52 Inwood was chosen to host Global Technology Preparatory and The Urban Assembly Institute for New Technologies. Read more here.
Teacher José Lius Vilson explains why students need more black and Latino teachers in an excerpt from his new book, This is Not a Test. Read more here.
IS 52 principal Salvador Fernandez attributes his school's success to its focus on teacher development. Read more here.
Parents and community members are upset about Department of Education plans to move a new career and technical education (CTE) school into the IS 52 building. Read more here.

Its my last year at IS52 and i seriously wouldnt change the last three years of my life. The talent classes, and regular classes are amazing. the teachers are nice, silly and just want to teach us more and more everyday. The principal is such a nice man, he loves walking around and seeing us learn. I graduate in 2014 and I know im going to cry like a baby. You'll meet some amazing people at IS52 and its an experience you cant and wont forget.

Principal Fernandez was awarded the 2013 Elizabeth Rohatyn Prize, which is awarded to a NYC principal who shows innovative ways to increase teacher performance. Fernandez won the school $15,000 for his non-punitive system of self and peer assessment. Read more here.

The District 6 CEC issued a statement on Monday asking the Panel for Educational Policy to cancel a scheduled discussion about the proposed co-locations of IS 52 and PS 192. The plan would place a new six-year high school in the IS 52 building. Read more here.

"The school has made many changes for the better. Please keep in mind that the staff and administration work very hard every single day to educate our children. And they need our support! "I would say that I.s52 is the best intermediate school since the principal Dr. Salvador Fernandez. He changed everything and made the school a more economical and friendly school. the students now have many opportunities to participate in many activities. one of the many improvements oin school are the anual festivals. the students work hard to make every show possible. Now it has white polo shirts and gym uniforms. Lats year he introduced to the school a school hoodie. the most obvious change would be the arrangement of floors. All grades on different floors wich helps us communicate better with students from our ages, although we do miss our academy houses. i was a student in i.s.52 from years 2005-2008. i proudly ammit that this school changed the way i think of things. i learned a lot and im proud to sho off that i was a student at this school. i hope that this school should keep on rising and helping students in the community"

Student Renesady writes that students and teachers in the ALPHA program have a shortage of materials. In the sixth grade they "shared books, sometimes one book for three students," but there were "no materials" in seventh or eighth grade. She adds: "The school's photocopy[ing] policy was bad. Teachers sometimes had to put off lesson plans due to the lack of available materials." But despite having only "four buckets of broken crayons" in art class, Renesady says that the teacher was "always motivating and optimistic."

Lauris Jorge, a student gripes that the school is very rigid and the administration does not trust the students. " We get picked up from lunch, which is nasty, and get picked up from gym. We also don't have any trips or small parties." She adds: "Ms. Bracey and Mr. Rivera are great teachers."

The principal did not respond to the above comment.
"This school is wack," writes student Escarla. "This year they just gave us pizza and we had the worst administrator."
A student, Janelis, complained that students in the Alpha program are sent to detention if they don't wear a uniform, while students in other programs are not required to wear uniforms.

Gabriel, a former student, writes that IS 52 is "one of the best ones you could find in that area." He continues: "Its ESL program is very good, I took it for about 3 months and it helped me a lot, then I passed to regular English. I first attended the Career Prep academy [where] kids used to be mean [to] you and all of that. Then I managed to get transferred to the Humanities Academy, [which] was marvelous; teachers helped you, shared experiences with you and advised you. Later on, my grades helped me to move on to the Alpha Academy. This Academy felt like heaven -- teachers and staff treated you with respect and they always spoke to you in a 'helping' tone which made the academy really good."
Caonely, a 7th-grader, writes: "We are divided into academies... Alpha has a really great staff and it's like we are a little community inside a diversity of communities."
Yaribel, a student, writes: "The school is each day better. I'ms o happy to be one of the students in this school."

A student complains: "The whole school stinks. The classrooms are too small [and] are overflowing. There are hardly any after-school activities for lack of money. Our textbooks, textbooks that we have to share, are all falling apart."
A student writes: "What I dislike most is the Alpha program I'm in. I'm [in] the top class [and] you can tell [the teachers] don't care since they expect us to know everything already."

Jose, a student, writes: "This is a great school with [many] perks. Some kids can be mean but that's is going to happen in every school. I learn a lot but I'm in the Alpha program. I like all my teachers ... I've been in this school since the 5th grade and I love this school."

A parent writes that she visited the Inwood School when she was investigating middle schools for her son, because although she "always heard how bad this school was," she recently heard some comments about positive changes at the school. She writes that her visit led her to agree: "As I passed the classrooms the students were engaged in their work. Bulletin boards [were filled] with students' written essays ... very nicely done. Hallways are light and clean. The whole school was so quiet you can even hear a pin drop." She adds: "I also visit[ed] the Alpha gifted program [and] I was greeted by the director of this program Ms. Weinstein, [a] very nice intelligent lady who made me feel welcome. She was very informative." She notes: "Clara Hemphill [director of Inside schools] says in her book [that] when you are alone you really get a flavor of the school, which is very true. I did get the flavor of the school because I was free to look at different bulletin boards and take my time to absorb everything."

A dissatisfied student complains that "there are roaches everywhere in the lunch room" and that "the teachers are new every year so you learn the same thing over each year." He also writes that older students can be mean toward the 5th-graders.

"That was the worst school I've ever been to," writes a student who left in the middle of the 6th grade. He writes that the teachers weren't patient with the kids and that a lot of the students cut classes.

A student complains that the school "givescheese burgers like every single day" and "they don't take us to trips." He writes, "We really think that they are doing this because some kids do not know how to behave," but he thinks the school should, "only take the students that do know how to behave because is not fair for the rest of the students that do behave. Alpha gives good compliments about the school because they get special treatment, but as for us humanities, Inwood Academy, Career Prep, Excel, and Language Academy get a different treatment."

Because of improvements in its test scores, PS 98 was removed from the state's list of schools needing improvement and is now considered "in good standing" under No Child Left Behind.

A parent describes "a tense atmosphere at the school," as a result of parents who are unhappy with the new administration. This parent believes that parents protesting changes are being disruptive to the school's learning environment, and the new administration "should be given a chance to prove" itself.

Parent Ercilia Alonzo writes that she agrees with previous comments about the lack of distinctions between the "gifted program" and the regular program at this time. She notes that another daughter of hers went to the school five years ago, and she thinks the program and school environment has changed since then. Ms. Alonzo also complains that the new administration does not communicate well with parents and has made changes parents don't approve of. She also writes that the school has been designated as a "Title I school in need of improvement" by the state education department.

"I don't believe that the Gifted and Talented program at this school is a true one," writes a parent. She complains that there is little difference in curriculum and rigor between the general education and gifted classes.

"This school is listed as a gifted school and there is a screening process. However, it is not suitable for truly gifted students," writes a parent. "The above average student may thrive in this school, but if your child is 'gifted' as the term is commonly used in education, then you would be better off trying to get him/her into one of the District 3 schools, they have a more extensive gifted and talented program. PS 98 also has a problem nurturing the highly intelligent and sensitive child. There are/can be serious bullying problems even within the 'gifted' program. While a number of the teachers are very good, I do not believe that they have [all] been trained to teach gifted children at all or to even recognize their needs."
Through the district's participatory budgeting process, PS 132 and Dos Puentes will receive $200,000 to complete a playground installation, DNAinfo reports.

An NY Post editorial chastises the Department of Education for failing to properly repair the bathrooms in the building housing Dos Puentes Elementary School. Read more here.

Parents at PS 132 and Dos Puentes Elementary School are hopeful that funding from the School Construction Authority will be put towards renovating the aging bathrooms in the old school building. Her Majesty Queen Letizia of Spain joined Chancellor Carmen Fariña on a visit to Dos Puentes on Monday, to the delight of students. Read more here.

Beginning fall 2011, PS 115 will share a space with the new KIPP Star Charter School despite neighborhood parents' hopes that the progressive Castle Bridge would open in the space. View the article: Progressive school loses promised space inside Washington Height's PS 115 to charter.

The extra curriculars sound nice.  Are their any extra curricular activities that promote curiosity, creativity and wonder?  More importantly, how is the instruction?  How do students perform on state exams?  Can anyone describe the kinds of curricular activities that extend the classroom?  How does this school's culture compare to that of Castle Bridge's?

Nicole, a PS 128 parent, writes: 
I know that the Pre-K tours will be happening soon so I wanted to give a huge shout out to PS 128 Audubon!! 
My twins Harrison and Olivia are currently attending Pre-K there. I cannot begin to tell you how happy I am with this school. The teachers are FANTASTIC as is the administration! My kids are in two separate classrooms and alternate days for Spanish/English and they absolutely love it. They also have tons of activities (gym, computers, dance, art etc.) 
Beginning January they will go on a school trip weekly. 

What I really love about this school is that there is a very strong social emotional component (as a clinician this is far more important to me than academics). This is also reinforced in the homework. Yes, there is homework but its more about exploring thoughts and feelings and processing the days activities and interactions. PS, I have also learned a few words of Spanish since there will be one kid who will have a Spanish homework assignment and the other an English assignment - cue Google translate and Duolingo!

Anyway, I wanted to post something because it definitely superseded my expectations. If anyone has any questions I am happy to answer them for you.

Hi Nicole, not sure if you are still checking this. I'm a student and live in the area. Principal Rosa Argelia Arredondo wrote Insideschools to share the "many positive attributes that make PS 128 unique and a special place for students to learn" such as "such as winning a Gold at the Finals of the Dancing Classrooms Competition; School Wellness Awards; Mighty Milers Awards, just to name a few."

"We hold a weekly parent workshop through which our parents receive vital information pertaining to instruction;curriculum; grade expectations; demystifying the New York State tests; the Common Core Learning Standards; and using systems, i.e. ARIS and the NYCDOE website, to help their children. Our workshops also provide parents with information and/or training on topics based on a needs assessments, i.e., immigration, health, nutrition, exercise, cultural trips that enhance student learning...Our volunteers assist not only in the cafeteria, but also in classrooms based on their needs and the training we provide."

She disputed Insideschools contention that attendance was poor. "Over the last few years, our attendance rate has been higher than the city’s average, falling a little below this year. Similarly, I clarified that we still experience a problem with students taking extended vacations, as is common to District 6 schools. In terms of lateness, I admitted that this continues to be a problem for us."

P.S. 132 in Manhattan serves 90 fewer students now than it did in 2014, despite extra resources brought to the school by the Renewal program. Read more here.
Through the district's participatory budgeting process, Dos Puentes and PS 132 will receive $200,000 to complete a playground installation, DNAinfo reports.
PS 132 Juan Pablo Duarte is one of 25 schools receiving one thousand books that have been donated to New York City schools by Taylor Swift. Read more here.
A NY Post editorial chastises the NY Department of Education for failing to repair aging bathrooms at PS 132. Read more here.

Parents at PS 132 are hopeful that funding from the School Construction Authority will be put towards renovating the aging bathrooms in the old school building. The bathrooms are separated from the cafeteria by a partition that doesn't stretch all the way to the floor, suffer from exposed and leaking pipes, and have toilets that go un-flushed because they're too difficult for kids to use. Ninety-four low-performing schools are now called “Renewal Schools,”. They will receive increased funds designated for an hour of additional learning time, after-school and summer programs, and teacher training. The principals will also be under review. Read more here.

My child goes to Dos Puentes the school inside PS 132. At PS 132, Ihave never seen children treated with such disrespect. I've seen a teacher say to a child who was touching a radiator in the hall I hope you get burnt you silly little boy!"  I've seen teachers threaten kids by getting in their faces and screaming at them.

The teachers need Non Violent Communication Workshops and the children need a proper playground, respect as humans, and future therapy.

J.H.S. 143 Eleanor Roosevelt is among 40 middle schools selected for an extended learning day pilot with 2.5 more learning hours in the school day for all students, and daily literacy tutoring for high needs students. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

This school has offered me a variarity of after school activities to chose from. I have had the same teachers over the past two school years. Being in the top class gives me the opportunity to take High School courses like Intergraded Algebra and the Living Inviorment. My class has gotten seveenteenth students with 4's on the state math test. The competition in my class is real. Just by ten points the top students is decided. All my teachers are great. They are there when I need them. During my application process Ms. Aquino has guided me step by step. She is there the whole day to help in anything needed.Unfortuanally, chorus has been eliminated as an after school activity and so is art. I have band with Mr. Larios and I play the acustic guitar. I also go to school on Saturday to practice more and to get guitar lessons. I am in the peer mediation team and also help the library as a library monitor. Eight graders are also privileged to leave school at 1:45 PM. I like to stay. I will miss this school when I go to High School.
What became of Mr. Aaron Hasson?
Mr. Hasson retired in June 2010 after teaching at IS 143 for 45 years.

The broken elevator is still causing problems for Ashley Santiago and another wheelchair-bound student, according to an article in the Daily News. Out of service since July, the two students were not able to attend the first two and a half weeks of classes, a source of utter frustration to Ashley's mom.

"The good thing about 143 is the friends," writes 8th grader Elizabeth. "I will never forget the friends I met here.The teachers are so amazing. They are fun and they make your classes easy to learn."

"In this school you learn so much more than your average Math, ELA, SS,and science subjects," writes recent graduate Marieliza. "Kids there are able to learn so much more than that, thanks to many amazing teachers. You can learn life lessons if you absorb it well and dont get caught up in chaos. It was not only my school it was like my home away from home. The staff is great."
"It's good, because I feel safe," says an 8th grader.
"The teachers are neat," a student says. "They're like your friends."
"The teachers always help you. They help you after school," says a student. "They're always there to help you."
"I used to be bad, but now I behave good," says one student. "I'm learning things."
"It's good. The teachers are great. They always help you," says a student.

In response to the below comment, Principal Pappas explains that during Fall 2005, there was no announcement from the Department of Education as to who would become the principal, which created anxiety in some teachers. "Some people left because nobody knew who would be principal," she said. "Some teachers felt a little concerned and scared." She adds that there are no fights, and student whom we spoke with on our visit confirmed her statement. "It's good, because I feel safe," said an 8th grader.

An official who works at the school writes that Principal Pappas "is working hard to meet the needs of these very high risk youth," but some problems remain. "Much of the seventh grade did not have a science teacher for the last half of the last school year and some 8th graders did not have a math teacher! Several teachers quit in the middle of the year last year, presumably due to the fact that some of their students were too 'challenging,'" this person writes. "The number of fights seems to be on the rise again this year."
"I'm going to miss this school so much," write graduating senior, Franchesca. " The teachers are great. You can really trust them with your problems."
Kimberly, who left the school in 2004, writes: "I miss IS 143 so much. I love the school. They treated me so good, and my friends, too."

Darlene, a 2004 graduate writes: "I think that IS143 is a great school. ... I had the best teachers and I made alot of great friends." She adds: "One thing 143 can improve is that fact that there are no lockers available for the students."

"My son is in the 8th grade and three months into the year he is yet to have a science teacher," a parent writes. "If science is such an important subject which he must pass to be able to graduate then why doesn't he have a science teacher?" This parent says the administration has been unresponsive. "Bottom line is this school is just getting worse and worse and nobody cares," the parent concludes.

Arlyn, a student, writes: "I like this school ALOT. I know I'm going to miss this school and my friends. I also do agree with [former commenter] Katherine P. We should get lockers! There are lots of cool teachers and students at IS143."
"You should have lockers in the school so kids don't get to tired going up and down the stairs," writes Katherine P., a student.

A student complains that teachers and other students can be short-tempered, and says that "one of the only things I like about IS 143 is that you find great friends. I know that when I graduate this year I'll be crying because I'll miss them so much!"
Through the district's participatory budgeting process, PS 152 and MS 178 will receive $500,000 to upgrade the playground, DNAinfo reports.

School Administration: At PS 152M we have a strong community.  Our parents and staff went out and collected hundreds of signatures and attend countless community board meetings to ensure that our school receives these types of updates.  Through our parents and staff, we have received many grants and have collected funds for many initiatives.  Currently, we're proudly working on our new project, our school auditorium.  We will eventually collect enough funds to make all necessary updates to our auditorium.

Count my family as one of those fleeing this school as fast as possible.  I brought my daughter, a bright and very pleasant 10 year old girl to this my childhood elementary school simply because it was a treasure chest of fantastic memories as well as a stellar education.  No longer the case by far, the students now receive about one half hour of homework possibly four times weekly.  Need I say more.

This August our daughter will begin anew at a prestigious charter school downtown and why.......... because her parents care.

This review is outdated. The school is on a steep decline. At least six teachers have left the school this year alone due to stress, lack of support, harassment and lack of physical and emotional safety. Morale is INCREDIBLY low. When I visited, I saw teachers literally crying in front of students. I saw them being berated, scolded and micromanaged in front of their classes. Teachers were NOT willing to tell me personally that they were having a rough time, but they weren't able to tell me that they were full of joy. 

Each of the programs highlighted in the review has become diluted to the point of becoming meaningless. There is no PEACEBUILDERS' program any more, there is no LIBRARY!!!, no Arts Intensive Institute, no art teacher, and due to the high attrition rate, cluster teachers are covering classes and students are missing out on the few arts and enrichments that are left. There are no current partnerships with HSA or other cultural institutions, as far as I could see. 

The political climate at this school has become so divisive and nasty that the children are the last thing on administration's minds. Three false arrests for the person questioning (albeit poorly worded queries) misallocated funds? 

Teachers and parents are fearful for their positions and scared that the retaliation will affect their children. Parents are concerned about class size, school safety, teacher support and wellness, and high stakes testing. There is no tutoring, no disciplinary system to speak of, and the teachers are within a wide range of emotional stress and burnout. They clearly love and care about the students but cannot give them what they need in this climate of data walls and the curriculum that doesn't seem to be developmentally appropriate for any but the highest achievers. 

There seems to be some seriously shady business. Questions are evaded. Parents aren't allowed in the classrooms unless there's a scheduled event taking place like a publishing party. I am used to an open door policy in which parents are welcomed in to the classroom at any time for volunteering or special projects, and teachers I've talked to seem eager for the support and community building as well. 

All in all, I think the teachers at 153 are doing their best with the constraints put on them, but I wouldn't send my kid there.

A teacher writes that the arts have suffered mightily under Principal Dawn Boursiquot. "Our pottery kilns haven't been turned on in years; the Suzuki violin program has been reduced from five to two days a week; the dance studio continues to remain empty as the principal never posted an opening for a dance instructor (Principal Boursiquot rents the dance studio to outside community groups)." This teacher also writes that the arts are no longer a part of academic work; for example, this teacher writes, Boursiquot "decreed" that 3rd-grade literacy units should no longer include art components and student writing on lined paper should be the only thing posted on bulletin boards. This teacher also notes that the "hands-on" and "well liked and respected" interim assistant principal was fired without consulting the staff or School Leadership Team.
For the 2006-07 school year, PS 173 is newly designated by the State Education Department as "in need of improvement."

The New York Post reported on Oct. 17, 2006, about tensions between school administrators and parents at PS 173. The article describes how one mother, co-president of the District 6 Community Education Council, was expelled from the building -- and forcibly removed by police and paramedics -- after trying to bring her daughter a sandwich. Principal Dawn Boursiquot told the Post, "She is a CEC co-president, but she is a parent of this school and all parents are treated the same - with respect - and they are to follow the rules," which include not being in the building without approval. Another parent quoted in the article said that "parents have not felt welcome" since a long-time after school program was cut earlier this year, despite parent protests.

A teacher reiterates the comments of the teacher below. "Staff members are leaving this school exactly for the reasons the departing teacher outlined, primarily because we feel unsupported by the administration. In the year and a half that Principal Boursiquot has been at our school, she has made very little effort to get to know her staff. She is rarely available for staff or parents to speak to. She is never to be found in a classroom and rarely in her office. Staff morale is extremely low and many more teachers left over the summer."

A former teacher writes that she left after four years because she felt the administration was unsupportive of teachers' development. She continues: "The literacy consultants that were brought in were not qualified, and teachers were rarely given opportunities to attend other professional development meetings... This year I know of at least six additional teachers who are leaving due to the lack of professional and positive leadership."

Principal Dawn Bourisquot dismisses the comment above. She writes: "Teachers who have left this year either retired, had commuter hardships, or were advised to do so by their supervision and administration program advisors so as to broaden the type of schools they had experience in."

A father comments that his child has had "an excellent kindergarten teacher and a very good 1st grade teacher" at the school, but adds that "with the exception of our kindergarten teacher, a lot of kindergarten teachers [in general] don't teach kids how to read."
A mother says that classes are still tracked, and children who perform above grade level are grouped together.
A student says, "my favorite subject is gym."

The Department of Education announced in August 2005 that the city plans to convert the space at 4111 Broadway to a pre-kindergarten annex for PS 173 when the Twenty-First Century Academy for Leadership vacates that building.  The annex, which will allow PS 173 to expand its pre-K program, is currently slated for completion in the fall of 2008.

A dissatisfied parent writes: "My son entered this school for the first time and already there [is] lots of gossiping going on, from the [administration] to the parents association. What I see I don't like and I believe my son won't be attending this school next year." She continues: "I believe that a good environment is a good education. My son's teacher is an okay teacher, not the very best but she is trying, especially when she has 29 kids who [don't] listen and [are] always misbehaving."

Yvette, a former student who currently attends Mott Hall, writes: "In my family, many of us have gone to PS 173, including my mother. ... I currently do community service at the school and believe that the school's environment has changed. Many kids are failing and the staff is not as caring as it used to be, although I do see the effort from some of the [older] teachers. ... All I hear is complaints from anyone." She adds that fewer students have been going on to attend Mott Hall, which she sees as a bad sign.

The mother of 3 children who attended the school said, "I like this school. It's in a nice neighborhood." However, she complained that her graduating 5th grade daughter was unfairly barred from going to the graduation party. "She felt humiliated," the mother said. School administrators told this parent that they had sent her a letter informing her that her daughter would not be allowed to attend but the mother said she "never received it" and that her daughter arrived at the school dressed up for the party and was not allowed in, despite the mother's pleading.

Principal Deirdre Budd received a 2011 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor an aspiring principal while continuing to serve as principal at their school.

Parent Maria Herrera writes: "I think the most notable thing about PS 178 is the well crafted balance between nurture and discipline. She and her vice principal Pat Sanchez, as well as our parent coordinator, are very open to ideas from parents. My only regret is that the school only goes through second grade. "The Academy opened with its first kindergarten class in September 2004, and will add one grade per year to become a K-8 program. While most of the program's seats are reserved for families from the 178 zone, some seats are available for children from other parts of District 6."

Since Inside Schools still has my comment from 7 yrs. ago on this posting I guess I can feel uninhibited in offering an update, with two kids now graduated from 187.  Shawn: Your stats on spec. hs. applications are wrong.  There are NOT fewer kids from 187 applying to specialized high schools and high schools of choice, there are more.  This year's graduating class actually has four acceptances at HSMSE at City College, six at La Guardia, one at Bklyn Tech, 5 going to Beacon, with one turning it down in favor of full scholarship to Berkshire Boarding School, one to NEST, two or three to Museum School, and, as stated below, by one of my fellow parents, others to NYC iSchool, Frank McCourt, and Hunter College Math & Science, to name a few.  Within this same group of students, who started in the same kindergarten year, seven left for Columbia Secondary School after fifth grade, and four left for Hunter High after 6th grade.  Those are also specialized high schools.  You do the math.  How many other schools of comparable size, with an 8th grade that includes a special education class and large number of ELLs have stats like that?  
 
Moreover, and I say this less with pride than with practicality:  the biggest factor in my sons' acceptances to LaGuardia and Beacon High Schools were their parents' level of involvement.  Private music lessons for five years were essential, as were the tutor I hired for one son in 7th grade math.  Without it he wouldn't have made Beacon.  This is no different than it would be in any other middle school in the city of New York so disabuse yourself of that notion right now, if you're set on the specialized high school path for your child.  Parental input, from day one, is the biggest predictor of educational success, almost everything else being equal.
 
The discussions below are, once again, covering too many different threads.  Discipline issues have always been a topic of dispute at 187.  Some teachers at 187 seem to follow an authoritarian model that some parents feel is set by the administration.  Some of those authoritarian teachers are excellent instructors at the same time they are loud and demanding. Others are loud and not as good at teaching--or can only teach a certain type of learner well.  There are intermediate school teachers who are very lax and friendly.  There are elementary school teachers who are innovative and creative.  There are others who are very traditional in their approach.  Each of them reaches different children differently and any parent will tell you that.
 
Parents who dislike the quiet lunches or the silent passings in the hallway, and who have the means to find alternative schools to choose from, do so.  I don't see that aspect of school life heavily affecting the child's academic success, unless there is extreme unhappiness on the part of the child.  The public school system is wrought with variety in the methods of classroom management and teaching methods used, in every school, and in every classroom.  
 
In terms of actual effect, the administration can do just so much.  In 187, where one hears that discipine is tight, there are individual students who have behavioral problems so acute that they disrupt the functioning of the school in its entirety.  The administration's hands are tied on how to deal with these problems, as they are in many schools of different types.  Only private schools can eject students for their behavior.  In my nine year experience at 187, on balance, I've found it has been easier for the school to remove a problem teacher than a problem student.  Several teachers were moved out of the classroom during my time.  No problematic students were.  
 
And I dispute the assertion that there are no problem students.  Public schools are the one mandatory gathering place for all of our society's young people--the indigent, the troubled, the homeless, the disabled, the gifted, the recently emigrated, the parentless, the abused--all the ones that the private system safely excludes.  Can there be a system that smoothly and satisfactorily educates all these children to the same level of competence?  Is there enough money in the world to do it right?
 
187 does not suffer from any more or fewer difficulties than any other similar elementary or middle school.  There are less competent teachers everywhere and to brand them all "excellent" is as simple-minded as branding them all tyrants.  The only thing parents can do, in this horribly underfunded, overcrowded public educational climate, is fight battles on the most basic classroom level, for their own children, while trying their best to support systemic changes within a school that are realistic, democratic, fair, and thoughtful.  Fortunately, 187 has a lot of parents who are doing just that.
 
Ruth Lilienstein-Gatton

Only one half of the kids here are on level, and the school got an A?  What is wrong with us, people?  How can the DOE award an A when only ONE HALF of our kids are PASSING????

You should be thankful that the school teaches your child about rules, boundaries, and limitations. I am proud that character skills are valued and taught.  Why should anyone have to teach a child how to behave appropriate socially if their parents/guardians are doing their jobs in raising their children?  Then we these things do not occur we become outraged that schools are doing what you won't.  You should be fortunate that this system and not the Dept of Corrections are providing a context for learning.

I second that Glee! I went to this school and it is pure rules & regulations, I hated it while I was there but it instilled in me a passion & respect for learning that has stayed with me even after years of graduating. I am now a college graduate in a Masters program and I thank 187 for showing me that it is possible and that going to college was not an option. All my teachers were what WE Latinos call White and I never felt discriminated against. Instead I felt loved and respected and cared for. when i was in ps 187, i hated it... but it actually set a good standard for me to follow. im currently writing from auburn new york, since i left to college after leaving ps 187 and graduating from highschool.
"Excellent teachers and staff. Each teacher is interested in the intellectual development of each student. I have peace of mind knowing that my children are safe at IS/PS 187."

Parent Ruth Gatton writes: "Since your tour the school has registered another incoming kindergarten class for Sept. 2005. She continues: "The elementary library has received a huge grant and become fully automated (on-line catalog and circulation). The school itself, along with Principal Aravena, has recently garnered a number of awards. Hudson Cliffs is becoming a 'school of note' throughout the city."
"It's organized, it's not chaotic. The teachers work together. It works. If it didn't, I'd send my kid to a private school," said Denny Chern-Falk, a parent who also attended the school as a child.
Jenny, a recent graduate, writes: "I miss [PS 187] so much. I like high school but I think I have too much freedom. When I was in 187, I was with a teacher at all times."

Myranda, a 7th-grader who has attended the school since kindergarten, writes: "187 is great. They help me when I need it and they're always there for me or any one else. It's my home! It's nice how you can go to a teacher and know them, them know you, and trust them with whatever you tell them."

Corinne, an 8th-grader, writes: "The teachers at 187 have been helpful and caring. My little sister is currently at this school and she enjoys it very much. ... It transformed me to a wonderful person with manners."

"I just graduated from I.S 187 and I am not afraid at all to move on to High School because 187 thought me everything I needed to know about succeeding in life," writes Jatnna V., a former student. "I think 187 is a great school because it has great teachers that teach us as much as they could daily and the rules and expectations seem silly but in the end pay off because they help for high school and maybe even college. I really miss 187 and I will always remember it as my second home and as one of my main educators in my life so far."

I think that all that was said in that video is very true about the school. I got the chance to attend P.S. 189M (wow just remembered how i used to write this every morning on my heading haha) and it was the best public school experience/education (later on my mom would put me in catholic school) I ever had. I was also a part of NDI and this program does work wonders for students. The interaction that we had with each other and the idea that we all were working for a common goal, which was to have fun & also impress our parents, teachers & fellow peers when we got to perform at laguardia high school at the end of the year, really built a feeling of companionship. NDI really got me to break out of my shell and I felt like i benefitted from it tremendously. Prior to 4th grade my mother had my twin brother and I attending a school in the bronx where we were beginning to perform under par academically. When getting to this school in 4th grade my brother and I excelled because of the great teachers and staff and also the emphasis they had for the arts. My brother and I loved drawing so it was a great fit.

I hope I am not making this school sound so much like an art school because it really is not but compared to others it really raises the bar for the arts. I stressed on talking about NDI because it had a positive influence in me as a student. Teachers here were committed to their students and loved having a positive influence in them unlike other public schools I had been in back in the Bronx. One teacher in particular was my 4th grade teacher Ms. Thomas who treated all of her students as if we were her sons in daughters. She got to know us on a personal level and really brought out the best in us. If there are any parents reading this in hoping to sign up your kids at 189 I recommend they encourage their kids to take advantage of all the extracurricular opportunities they have at the school like joining the band or orchestra (my brother and i were in the band i was taught how to play the trumpet and he the clarinet by Mr. Palmer :-)) because being a part of these programs and activities made school more appealing for me. When attending P.S. 189 M school was no longer a boring and stressful demand for me anymore, instead it was a place where I would look forward to coming back to after each weekend.

I am now going to be a senior at Syracuse University double majoring in Neuroscience & Psychology. I leave my email here in hopes that I can get in contact with any teachers or fellow peers who remember me haha. 
Harly J. Rodriguez
Class of 2002 at P.S. 189 M
hjrodrig@syr.edu

This was our 3rd choice school based on location for my daughter to attend pre-k. We received the acceptance letter and I gave a call to the school on 2 occasions to ask general questions and I was given a cold response. I didn't even get a good morning back or a your welcome on my thank you. 

I still decided to give them the benefit of the doubt and went to the school to visit. I walked into the office and was not greeted and when I told her I was here to register the woman did not even look up. She said come back on a later date. 
On my 2nd visit, the security guard said they stopped registering for the day. I didn't understand because they said up to 11am and it was only 9:30am. I was allowed to call up to the office to ask if it was possible to be seen being that she said 11am and she "no, I have tons of things to do and do not have time for pre-k registration." I asked her than what the schedule was and she said "whatever the paper (D.O.E. acceptance letter) says." The letter only says the dates of registration. She said to come back the next day at 8am. I told her I have an older child whom was graduating from another school and I couldn't do that time and she said "IT'S NOT MY PROBLEM.'

This was obviously not the school for us. I could only imagine the nightmare in attending a school in which the administration is rude and inconsiderate. I don't know the teachers so I am not commenting on them. Best of luck

The principal describes her philosophy of education in an interview with SchoolBook. http://www.nytimes.com/schoolbook/school/271-ps-192-jacob-h-schiff/principal
Update the Parent Coordinator information.
A teacher writes that about 20 teachers left after Principal Daryle Young's first year before Young was "petitioned out by parents and teachers."

A parent writes: "I have been a parent at PS 192M for the past four years and during this time I have seen the school administration three times. In the past, parents always felt welcomed." This parent complains that under the current administration, "the "culture" in the school has changed for the worse. Parents DO NOT feel welcome. In the past, we always had "Learning Leaders", a volunteer organization that helps train parents to work in the classrooms with teachers and in other areas within the school community [but] parents no longer volunteer in the school." She continues, "This past year we have lost a total of 32 teachers, 19 of them classroom teachers. These teachers left PS 192M due to the uncooperativeness, lack of support," from the administration."

A teacher describes the school's atmosphere as "disheartening." This teacher writes of the administration: "There is a need to listen to staff suggestions or complaints without a retaliation, intimidation, isolation and even fired by administration. There is only a one way communication -- a key factor in leadership is communication. I am tired of administration hiding behind the phrase "in the best interest of our students," when there is another agenda."

A parent praises Principal Young's administration, writing: "I have known her for 20 years and have found her to be a diligent and dedicated educator. Those who are not fully committed themselves to creating a vibrant, effective, and progressive environment for the students and parents will find Ms. Young's administrative style overwhelming. I believe her focus is to find team-playing professionals who are exception at what they do and give students hope for their futures."

An employee at PS 192 writes: "It is very disheartening to read all these negative messages. ... I have many positive things to say about the school and new administration. There have been a lot of changes. Improvement does not take place from one day to the next; it takes approximate 3 to 4 years for change to take place. We as employees need to give this new principal, Ms. Darylé A. Young, an opportunity to show us what she is capable of doing ... . She is trying really hard. The building has even improved in its physical appearance. Office staff has been very helpful and more welcoming ever since the new administration. There is a parent coordinator that is accessible to answer questions. A wonderful group of new teachers that you are able to observe that they are willing to go that extra mile to assist the children in their academic achievement and guidance counselors that work very hard in providing services to our children. What we need to do is continue to work collaboratively so that our efforts are combined in the best interests of our children."
A parent writes that there are some "situations [at the school] that need to be fixed but the school is not the horror place that many are trying to portray."

"This school is in need of a continuous and constant review by the Department of Education," writes a teacher. She writes that there is tension between the administration and teachers, and thinks that the administration ought to be reviewed.

A teacher writes, "PS 192 is mired in unproductivity, miscommunications, and lowered expectations for students and teachers alike. The administration has no viable connection with teachers, who receive very little support. At least one fourth of the staff are leaving the school, mostly the young, talented teachers." She attributes the loss of staff members to a "threatening atmosphere" at the school, and says the students have little contact with the administration.

An article in the New York Daily News reports of a violent incident between a parent and a security guard that occurred on school grounds at dismissal time. The parent became irate upon being asked for ID before leaving the school, and the guard was unable to defuse the situation. A parent who witnessed the brawl commented, "They are trained to handle things differently. ... They make you feel like they are doing you a favor to let you in the building."

"The atmosphere here at PS 192 is one of low morale, fear, and isolation," writes a teacher. "Our questions and comments are frowned upon." This teacher writes that the school's leadership is dictatorial. "The situation is so bad that many of our wonderful teachers are seeking employment elsewhere. There are always teachers who retire or move out of the city, but teachers are looking to transfer out of this school to another city school" because of the new administration. "This has always been a challenging but rewarding place to work," this teacher writes, but now things have changed. "The staff, which includes teachers, paraprofessionals, and school aides are so unhappy."

"Discipline is no different here than anywhere else. As a matter of fact, we are always complimented about how quiet our school is for such a large population," writes Assistant Principal Maureen Guido. She believes that our review of PS 192 does not present an accurate picture of the school. She continues, "Yes we have problems in our school like any school in corrective action. However, we have a terrific staff of teachers, working very hard everyday to implement all the new initiatives, deal with students, many with unfortunate homelives and your article doesn't come close to all the wonderful things happening at PS 192."

"As a former teacher and assistant principal of PS 192 I can attest to the fact that the faculty, staff and parent communities worked together to provide quality instruction to the children," writes a former staffer. "There was always an atmosphere of excitement in the school due to the number and diversity of programs made available to students and parents. Teachers were frequently seen working late in the building. She continues, "I am shocked and dismayed that this report has been published with no mention of the positive effects of the former administration."

A parent writes: "The school has now landed on the list of failing schools. It will undergo restructuring sometime this year, however no details of this plan has been provided [to parents] as yet." She finds this very troubling. Still, she writes, "I would like to point out that my children have received what I consider a top notch education at 192 and have succeeded because of good and caring teachers like Mr. Gordon (K), Ms. Fontnel (K), Ms. Mazin (1st grade), Ms. Crisostomos (3rd grade) and others like them. They nurtured my children and my children learned and have grown academically in spite of the school's present status." She continues, "I support Ms. Young's efforts and desires to change things, however, parents at this school tend to be factious and disruptive with one another and not at all united."

6th grade ICT teacher, Raya Sam, is a recipient of the prestigious Big Apple award, which recognizes "exceptional success in instruction, impact on student learning, and overall contributions to school communities," as reported by Chalkbeat.

We were selected as the NYC DOE's Showcase School for Culture! Only three schools were selected in the category and we were the lone middle school in the entire City! Collaborative Problem Solving, a restorative approach that we use as an alternative to detention and suspension, will be the primary component of our work that we showcase when other schools visit next year.

And in even bigger news... A couple of weeks ago New York State released it's accountability measurements for each school in the State, all 4,771 of them (the five boroughs account for about 1,700 of those schools). This is arguably the most important ranking that any school is subjected to because these rankings, based on a school's annual progress and using State Exam scores disaggregated by subgroups (students with disabilities, black, hispanic, English language learners, economically disadvantaged, etc.) are what determines which schools are making adequate progress and will avoid state intervention, which are not making adequate progress and will come under state control, and which schools the state will close. A small number of schools will even be identified as "reward schools" across two categories, "Performance" and "Progress," and will be used as models for other schools throughout the state to replicate because of their success. Those honored for Performance are more numerous than those honored for Progress, precisely because it is so difficult to make giant gains in progress, and easier to keep performing well when you have a cohort of students already scoring at levels 3 and 4 on the State exams. Whether recognized for Performance or Progress, these schools will be eligible for approximately $75,000 in grant monies to lead this work across the state. 

I've never dreamt that we would be honored as a reward school - in fact, I had no idea there was such a thing before this year, but we did it! I don't think I can convey exactly how exclusive this club is any better than if I just lay out the numbers:

4,771: Schools in NYS (public and charter)
1,700: Schools in NYC  
185: Schools statewide that met the requirements to be honored as Reward Schools in New York State
10: Schools statewide that met the requirements to be honored as a Reward School for Progress in New York State (the other 175 schools were honored for Performance)
2: Schools from the NYC DOE honored as Reward Schools for Progress
1: Middle Schools (grades 6 - 8) in ALL OF NYS to be honored for Progress

That one middle school, is ours. We are literally one of two schools in the City, Elementary and High Schools included, that made the gains necessary to be honored by the State. But even more impressive, WE WERE THE ONLY MIDDLE SCHOOL (6th - 8th grade) IN NEW YORK STATE THAT MADE LARGE ENOUGH GAINS TO BE HONORED AS A PROGRESS SCHOOL. Congratulations to the Hamilton Grange Middle School community!
Please check our website at www.theHamiltonGrangeSchool.org

Hamilton Grange Middle School students made the most progress of all district 6 middle schools in 2016 in moving students out of level 1 and into levels 3 and 4 in the math state exam, and when compared to all other district 6 middle schools, Hamilton Grange students made the second most progress in moving out of level 1 and into levels 3 and 4 on the ELA state exam.

Some of the teachers are great but the administration needs A LOT of work.  My son is Afro-American and was being bullied by his peers about his complexion in 1st, 2nd, and 3rd grade.  Instead of addressing the issue of tolerance in the school, the principal ignored it and the school's counselor told me I should take my son to another school with 'his own peers.’ My older son also experienced racism in the school but was more able to tolerate it.  He tells me that students who are of different backgrounds (Mexicans, etc) are constantly teased about their backgrounds and race.  I brought this to the attention of the principle, gave her contact information of a diversity coordinator who volunteered (free) to help her with incorporating diversity in the curriculum and she ignored it.  She didn't seem too concerned about addressing an issue that has such a huge impact on children and how they interact with society.  I have to say that I am highly disappointed in the way the principal (the wife of an assemblyman- I expected so much more) sweeps significant issues under the rug.  As far as language goes, the program is not set up for non-Spanish speakers and so I feel that the school should be called bilingual, instead of dual-language.  Spanish is 3 days per week, and English is only 2 days, as opposed to alternate days.  This school is not as advertised. Huge disappointment.

This school continues to be enriched by a committed educational leader (principal Evelyn Linares), high quality teachers, and a rapidly diversifying student population.  Unfortunately, the school is suffering under the current high-stakes testing environment which does not reward schools with a curricular focus in dual language development.  The English testing-based promotion requirements are placing great stress on teachers and families starting in the early grades.  Overall, the school has a lot of positives (including a caring environment and beautiful facility), and has a lot to share, but it is struggling withing the current accountability-obsessed DOE educational model.

"As a kindergarten teacher who believes in developmentally appropriate practice, integrated curriculum and a strong foundation for reading, writing and math, I have found PS 210 to be an oasis and a wonderful home," writes teacher Melissa. "In the school community, there is a deep respect for children. There is also an appreciation for the work teachers do. Creativity and innovation is encouraged and appreciated. There is room for children to be children, and there is a committment to academic growth."

The Department of Education announced in August 2005 that the school will move to a $37.5 million building currently being erected at 152nd St. and Amsterdam Ave., when the building opens in September 2007. In the new building, which will feature air conditioning, a library, and a rooftop playground, the school's capacity will expand to 500 students.

I graduated from Mott Hall back in 2016, and I honestly have a hard time recommending the school to anyone who wants to go there. Many of the students show little to no respect for each other, and the staff isn't much better either. The students were often rude and disrespectful to each other and showed little care for the work. Other students like myself who actually wanted to be there would often get lumped in with the rest of the class as the teachers were very fond of group punishment. Very frequently it would only be a handful of students who were misbehaving, but the teachers would just hand out a whole classroom detention during lunch. The staff would use any excuse to take away a students lunch period, from frankly BS class detentions to putting someone aside because there was a tiny amount of white on their 95% black sneakers. Many of the teachers loved to scream at the students for ten to twenty minutes, and would frequently hold up the class over the most menial things. The dean in particular actually wore out her vocal cords because she would scream so much during the lunch period, and was so loud that I could hear her fits from the floor below. 

The environment here is very toxic and doesn't encourage learning in the slightest. Any student who goes in hopeful about the school will quickly have their mind changed by how bad some of the students and staff are. There are some teachers here that I've absolutely loved, but I can't say that I liked the majority of them. I don't know how the administration is these days, but when I was there, the principal and vice principals were always getting switched around, and that made things quite difficult for the teachers as well. I won't be surprised if this school fails.

My daughter is currently at this school and I have to say, thankfully, she has not experienced the issues you describe (except for the yelling Dean at lunch).  The teachers and most of the students are kind and serious about the work and although there are students who are disrespectful, I feel most of the teachers have worked hard to make sure that the disruptions are managed and the students who are there to work are given support and attention.  I also really like the principal.  So far my daughter is thriving.

It’s a school that even with its current administration may crumble down—mainly to the student’s fault. Unfortunately the school is decline because of lack of leadership. Many good teachers have left because of the current and previous administration. There are wonderful hard working students and teachers that deserve better. The principal is not responsive to parents with legitimate complaints. Let's face it, the students of The Mott Hall School for the most part have parents that value education and have a good handle on what it takes to accelerate students. The new principal lacks imagination and treats parents with contempt. Often takes advantage of language barriers to shun and dismiss parents. When she got to the school her only way of solving problems with students was suspensions and detentions violating students and parents rights to due process. She doesn't have a grip on supervising teachers or good pedagogical understanding. The new superintendent was on point with the quality review. This is not a good grade for what once use to be a gem, not only of the district, but of the entire city. In order to return the school to it's past glory it is in desperate need of a principal that understands gifted education, and cares about their futures. This is not the present case. Although she has a PhD. in education it is not reflected in her practice, communication, strategic planning or vision for the school. The Mott Hall School has become a rudderless ship.

Mott Hall is a good school overall. But like all other schools, there are ups and downs. Some good things about this school is that a lot of teachers are really great. For example, Ms. Burke (she left this year), Ms. Brandes, Mr. Fernandez,Ms. Boros, and many others. They are open to tutoring or extra help during lunch hours or after school, and are very supportive in raising your grades. Also, you can make friends very easily. Our school is mostly a bully free environment, and if there is a problem, it can be cleared up pretty quickly. Another good thing is that we are learning on a very high scale. In sixth grade, you are learning on a seventh grade scale, seventh grade on an eighth grade scale, and eighth graders, on a ninth grade scale. For some children, this is two fast paced. In sixth grade, we kind of skipped the basics, so I fell back a bit. The key to achieving in Mott Hall is too stay organized, keep color coded notebooks, and sections in your binders, and have a good format for taking notes and studying. The other key element is doing you're homework. Yeah, its hard, but deal with it. If you start your year not doing any homework, you will not do well. Some things that need to be improved in this school is some of the faculty problems, some teachers do not respect the students. In one instance, a certain teacher, who I wrote a letter in french for (one of our assignments), called it trash, and gave back everyones papers calling them disgraceful. Also we have a small gym, and small classrooms. A lot of times it is either WAY too hot, or WAY to cold in the classrooms. Another downside is that the special ed kids run around the halls and banging on doors and screaming in the staircases. I am a current eighth grader at Mott Hall and going through the high school process, and I have to say that the guidance counseler and teachers are really helpful and supportive in helping you in any way. When I graduate, I will be very sad too leave, and miss everything. If you are thinking about going to this school, you will have a great experience. It will be tough at times, but when you get through them, it will be great.
Sadly mr.ferny left this year

The Mott Hall School is quite the advanced academic school in the city of New York. But this school has some flaws and some goods. 

The Good

1. Above average standards for this school.

The Curriculum provided is considered above the BOE's standards, and we are considered a gifted and talented school.

2. Teachers, teachers, teachers,

While they may be a nuisance at times, the Teachers are nice (mostly) and they provide guidance to students if needed. Some honorable mentions I like to make are teachers like Ms.Torres, Ms.Whyman, Ms.Boros, Mr.Fernandez, Ms.Burke, and Mr.Vigrass. I personally think these teachers are the building blocks of the school. (Unlike there more superior counterparts) *cough the assistant principal and principal cough*

3. Somewhat extracurricular activities.

6th graders are offered the choice of 5 activities they can do twice a week during 8th period.Activities rotate every 3 months.1 is the most preferred and 5 is the least. I believe the 5 are rotational chess, permanent chess (6 months, god knows what they were thinking when naming that), stock market, collage and film producing. Speaking of chess, there is a club that goes from 2-4 pm on Mondays and Wednesdays. They go to junior nationals every year and have free snacks during their sessions. 

4. The Chess Club

A follow up to the chess club, they raise the funds by selling chocolates for $1. After nationals, no more. Pretty sure the school's budget funds part of the trip, but kids who wish to go must pay their airfare ticket or whatever. Usually $150-$250.

The Bad

1. The small space disadvantage.

Space is limited, especially since there is no auditorium and gym. Also the gym teacher Ms.Molina teaches most her lessons in the yard, she locks the equipment when it is not appropriately used (reasonable), and lastly she seems nice inside, but is a real pitbull when you pull her trigger. Additionally we have to walk to another school (mainly A.Philip Randolph and P.S. 129) to have things like ceremonies, ndi performances, and general announcements. 

2. The true "call of the wild"

The special ed kids are mostly bad. They are loud, bang on the doors of teachers during instructing in classes, and they are most responsible for the lockup of sports equipment at recess. 

3. The bathroom battle
The situation is considered bad because with the girls bathroom, girls would be texting and using their cell phones and the boys bathroom is usually trashed.

4. THE LOCKER SITUATION

Oh the horror of this situation i'm about to present.

Indeed, since there isn't enough spacing provided in the building we are forced to share lockers. Sounds reasonable? Wrong, because a locker is shared with 4 people in a cramped spacing. It is considered hallway horror when the 7th and 8th graders make there daily rounds in their lockers.

5. No sports clubs (pretty self explanatory)

6. The french teacher is mean and annoying. Only god knows why that old bag ended up teaching here. She deserves to teach in one of those really bad schools. Maybe that's why we're here.

7. Fighting and the common use of profanity.

There would be fighting once in a while and there would be general disruption and unrest. Meanwhile profanity would be commonly used, but teachers let it slide.

The Verdict

While this school has one of the best academic standards in the city of New York, leadership and a serious staff should put fixing this school as a first priority. This school doesn't have all the potential it used to have 29 years ago. Now if you ask me, we can either fix this as a community or let it all go down the drain. An okay school in general, but it really needs to shape up.

The school is a very safe environment.  When school is in session you can hear a pin drop.  The academics are very rigorous.  It's the only middle school that offers all of it's students the opportunity to take two HS Regents with a 98% pass rate.  Other middle schools are select the students they think will pass.  The egalitarian environment is unmatched in other middle schools including in the elite school districts.  It also has a high acceptance rate to specialized HS.  The academics are demanding but yet supportive.  My daughter is very happy at Mott Hall.

When we first started thinking about schools several years ago we didn't even know 278 existed.    But lo and behold here was this rising, well-respected school right in our area, and we chose it over several other options.  We've been very happy with our experience so far. 


The school is now quite popular in its zone (one of the only schools in all of Upper Manhattan to have a waitlist) and for good reason.  Wonderful teachers, attentive administration, diverse programs including plenty of art and music.  The shared cafeteria and gym with PS 18 do present some challenges but the combination of the two schools also works positively for things like the alternate "wellness in the schools" menu and the unusually good auditorium (complete with stage and theatre lighting). 

If you are considering attending here and want to learn more than you've seen on the school tour or on the DOE website, don't sit on 219th or 220th St and focus on the industrial surroundings and bare schoolyard.  (The outside of the school is admittedly less attractive than many.)  You won't see any of the kids on those blocks outside of school hours.  The actual heart of the school on evenings and weekends is Isham Park, which is in the middle of the school's zone and where many of the students play off-hours.  (Second local hang-out for spotting 278 kids -- the top-notch Indian Road Playground in Inwood Hill Park).  Given that much of the school year is in winter or rainy weather, the plain yard is less of an issue than you might think during the school day and the spacious and well maintained inside of the school is very much up to par.

Being at a zoned school certainly has its advantages when you consider the minimal "commute" (walking 10 minutes instead of a long bus ride)  and the fact that you run into schoolmates everywhere in the neighborhood.   Afterschool options are many (at the school, at the Y, at Bread & Yoga all very popular) and also in the neighborhood. 

The school does have traditional elements like homework and uniforms, but if you like that sort of thing you will be very pleased.  Our child seems to be doing well academically and we're looking forward to next year.
Stephen Jackson, a Science teacher at PS/IS 278, was one of ten teachers to win Big Apple Awards for excellence in teaching in NYC schools. Read more here.

My son is currently attending second grade in this school. He entered at Kindergarten level with an IEP and had to overcome his challenges due to his having ADHD. 
Even in times where schools are facing crippling budget cuts, this school and its dedicated staff and principal have worked so hard to make every student succeed. 
My son is the living proof of that. He is working hard and has turned out to exceed expectations in every subject. He loves going to school and is very proud of his success. 
I'm intensely grateful for the incredible teaching staff and highly appreciate being part of an incredible parent community. Our PTA is outstanding and I feel privileged to know them and volunteer time whenever possible. 
I am very pleased with our school and extremely happy to have made the right decision in enrolling my son.

This is my third year as a parent with a child in PS/MS 278.  Each year, I am more and more thankful to call this school home to my son (and next year for my daughter)!  The kids learn in a safe, caring environment with a staff that dedicates themselves 100% to their craft.  Ms. Guido does an excellent job.  She is approachable on the simplest of subjects to the more advanced ones. I have never seen her door closed. Also, Ms. Reyes the assistant principal, takes great pride in her job and it shows with her hands on method being involved with each and every child at the school.  I could go on and on about the wonderful programs offered by our school and the amazing teaching staff.  I look forward to many years of involvement  with the PTA and it's members who are a majority of working parents making this school the best place in the neighborhood.
