This review is 6 years old!! It would be very helpful to all of us parents to have an updated one. How about sending someone over to the school to get an updated report? Thanks!
Our new review was just posted!
Thank you very much!!! This is very helpful.

I am the visual arts teacher at the school (for the entire school). Thank you for attempting such a thorough review of our school. I look forward to reading your updated review when you visit, as we have evolved much.

It would have been great if, in visiting, you also took the opportunity to talk to the teachers about what makes our school special, as we take a lot of pride in our work and our students, and this is evident in our school, the students who love going here, and the number of alumni who continue to visit us even throughout college to let us know how they are doing.

While you have made remarks about our "progressiveness" and some lack there-of, please note also that we are a Department of Education public school, not a charter school, and therefore are required to mold our educational practices around their expectations and guidelines. We are an A school, we have primarily been an A school, and a School in Good Standing since we have opened, and that is due to our educational practices, which earned us a high proficient mark on our Quality Review in 2011-12.The remarks you made regarding our high school selection process were a little offensive - truthfully, all of us who work with the 8th graders take much time and care in helping them select high schools, and find the best schools possible. You were also incorrect about the specialized high schools, we have had 3 students at LaGuardia, and another just got into City College high school this past year. I have 8th graders enter into Fashion Industries and Art and Design High School every year - while these are not "specialized", these are audition schools, and indicate the level of talent and dedication of our students - and their teachers. In general our students have attended a lot of wonderful high schools in the city - the specialized high schools are not the only good schools that exist, and are often over-crowded and do not allow for more intensive one-on-one attention that other schools do.You should also be specific about the population that we serve, as one of our amazing features is our cultural diversity, and our attitude towards celebrating all cultures' unique features. We have only grown more diverse since our last visit, and it is something that all of us at PS/MS 278 embrace and value.Our parent participation has much evolved since your visit in either our 2nd or 3rd year of opening (as we opened in 2004, also not noted in your review), our PTA is a super active presence in our school. They have done an amazing amount of fund-raising in the past 4 years, are now incorporated as a non-profit, and make an effort to make every year better than the last.

P.S. 278 is a participant in the Wellness in the Schools Cook
for Kids program, which replaces the traditional cafeteria menu with a
healthy menu based on scratch cooking and fresh ingredients. WITS
places a trained culinary profession in the school cafeteria to prepare fresh
meals from scratch, engage students, and educate families about the importance
of eating whole, unprocessed foods through interactive cooking demonstrations
called WITS Labs. You can find out more about programming from Wellness in the
Schools and see a list of participating schools online at www.wellnessintheschools.org

I am very happy with PS 278, my son is in II grade and doing excellent! The school has a rich curriculum, an art and music program and a warm environment. As a parent, I believe success in  your children education is a 50/50 effort and I found in PS 278 the tools I need to provide a safe and stimulating environment for my son. I am mostly grateful for the tireless effort of the parents involved in the school and Ms Guido whom I think is a wonderful and dedicated Principal. PS 278 is a real gem in our neighborhood.

Maureen Guido, Principal

The review above is 6 years old and a bit dated.  It would be great if Insideschools could visit again.  
What's special:  The school doesn't have opera and ballroom dancing, but does have an amazing arts program.  This includes an intensive music program and dance program in the lower grades (via grants for "Music & the Brain", a room of 25 piano keyboards for lower grades and instruments for orchestra and band for higher grades, as well as a collaboration with the 92nd Street Y).   For the upper grades, the debate program does well.  The school also offers Schoolwide Enrichment Model (SEM) which clusters students across grade levels by topics of interest.

The downside:  small play yard and gym


When looking for a school for my son (now a first grader), I looked at the standard schools of choice (lottery) in District 6 (Amistad, Hamilton Heights, Muscota, and Washington Heights) as well as PS 278 (one of our zoned schools).  PS 278 stood out for its emphasis on standards and how happy faculty and parents were with the principal.  It is not a parent-run school, but the principal has an open-door policy and focuses on solving problems.  The student body is not as affluent as that of the schools of choice, but the school does well with getting grants to provide extra funding.   Parental involvement has increased in the last couple of years (see the PTA website at:  http://www.psms278.org/).

My 2 kids are in this school and doing great.  Our school is a community school and parents and teachers work as a team to ensure that our kids learn and love school.  When one of my kids was falling a little behind in his reading skills, the teacher worked with me and made great recommendations for us.  We immediately acted on the teachers suggestions.  The teacher even provided material for us to build on.  Next thing we knew our child not only caught up but even surpassed the reading level that was expected of him in his grade.

It takes a village...

There is a percentage of high school kids who read and write on the third or fourth grade level, at best, yet receive 90s in ELA. Ditto for math, where they are far behind other kids and schools. Plagiarism is accepted, and perhaps encouraged. The grammar spoken and written by some of the teachers is atrocious. State tests? Who knows! It's hard to believe the posted scores, and makes one wonder if tests aren't altered. The administration and Ms. Drysdale cast a blind eye towards these 'anomalies'. What, exactly, is CCAA preparing these kids for? If the spelling and grammar of the comments from those who have graduated is an indication, certainly not college or the real world.

As graduates, (and being in the school for middle and high school), one of the main problems that need to be addressed is professionalism with relationships. (The principal) clearly has a couple of students that she gives perks to, whether or not they deserve it. There have been several occasions in which students who do bad things are not penalized when reported just because the faculty likes said student. In addition, her priorities are all over the place; (uniform enforcement above organization in general) 

 the ASSISTANT PRINCIPLES,  have very tight schedules and do not give student the time and consideration that is needed for classes, tutoring, and etc.. They want us to do better (which is appreciated), yet they do not provide assistance in it. The assistant principles and the main principal need to have better communication within themselves. 

{as for the} COUNSELOR mostly involved with the upperclassmen, it's very hard to say that she helps students in difficult situations. She belittles, doesn't provide answers, is quite impatient/misunderstanding, and victimizes the people when they come to her for help. Although she is supportive in some situations, its pretty easy to say that she forces her opinions on people (she doesn't hold back in telling you that the decisions you are making for your future are wrong, in her opinion).

Moving on to the TEACHERS, they definitely care about the students, although it must be said that some are biased leaning towards their favorites.

The teachers don't discipline the students that need to be disciplined; for example, if a student is doing or saying something inappropriate towards another student, and said student "tattle tells", teachers will and have said "nobody likes a tattle tale."

The STUDENTS: the middle school and high school have different issues that need to be addressed. First, middle school and high school are two very different things and experiences, therefore, they should be kept separate. 

MIDDLE SCHOOLERS are young, vulnerable, and naive. Times are changing, and so are the kids. Some are meaner, some are maturing way earlier, and the rules need to be better enforced to make sure that no kid is belittled and ridiculed by other kids. It's impossible to stop it all, but it can definitely be controlled and reduced by a landslide.

As for HIGH SCHOOL, kids are more mature and they need to be better informed on general knowledge. For example, health classes need to be taken more seriously.It is important that young adults are informed of risks, illnesses, and alternatives that life has to offer in a general sense. Drugs, alcohol, and sex are things that need to be thoroughly addressed.

In addition, high schoolers influence the middle schoolers tremendously.... Cursing, fighting, bullying, and etc is different for middle school and high school. There should be different rules for both, but due to the lack of our own building, there is no space, time, or separation between the different grades. There are territorial issues between the THREE SCHOOLS. I repeat, THREE SCHOOLS in one 5-floor building, of which we only own 1 and a half for over 500 students in just 1 of the schools. No one has enough attitude or authority to fight for the space that is rightfully ours at certain times, and within requested scheduling.

Overall, things just need to be more professional.

Last but not least, the general SCHOOL is not diverse, nor united. There are little to no activities (dances, assemblies, clubs, sports). The school is still trying to bear its ground, but at almost a decade old, it's safe to say that things are moving way too slow. It's time to develop good structure, good organization, and fix the school overall.

Despite all the REALISM (or what you might consider negativity), it must be said that the academics are really great. Generally, students get the help they need, and the program really makes sure no one gets left behind in education. Looking at the big picture concerning education, the curriculum is great.

It is interesting to see the growth of the school, but very sad, having observed the school for a long time and knowing students and staff personally, that the school was never intended to be in the IS 218 building longer than one year.  In addition, many students never receive special education services, ESL services, and the lack of organization is giving students a lesser education.  While CCAA obviously shines above the rest of the schools in the area, by a long shot, it looses many of its best and brightest in 8th grade to better high schools.  In addition, its staff turnover is a huge indicator that, though the school has great potential, it does not have the infrastructure to support a core of teachers whom want to stay for the long term.  Any successful school (and there are many) has a core of teachers (at least 60%) who stay every year because they feel that they are able to make a difference, that their curriculum ideas are valued (not imposed) and that students who wish to take college courses are guided properly in that direction with excellent instruction.  The school has been in existence for eight years and for a parent, these are now a non-negotiable:
1. a building that houses only the school (this is Washington Heights, not midtown, we have room to either occupy an existing space or build!)
2. a website which properly advertises whom the staff are, what they teach, what the school schedule is and how we can get involved with upcoming trips, events, etc...
3. a tutoring program which is also advertised on said website
4. students whom are behavior problems are taken care of, or asked to leave, they aren't kept on because of the financial gain they will bring.  If this is a great school there should be a waiting list and it should be utilized
5. A diverse student population must be recruited, but in order for that to happen organization and administrative know-how must be evident.  Simply stating that students are going to receive up to 60 college credits is not enough to have a diverse student population willing to commute long distances, students need to feel that the school has a culture of success, cooperation and has cast off the ghetto feel of many of the surrounding public schools
6. Parents need to feel that they can contribute to their child's education as a partner, but this cannot happen if a school that is supposed to deliver so much is still set-up as a half-way house and disorganized.  

These have long been issues since the school started and I'm hoping that someone, with enough political power, will make this all move forward.

Teachers and staff at CCAA work tirelessly to ensure the success of the students. While it is a new school, and as with any new enterprise, there are glitches that are encountered and need to be worked out and worked around. However, one would be hard pressed to find a teacher who does not have the students' best interests at heart. The administration does its best to ensure that both staff and students feel welcome, supported and are happy. During the 2008-2009 school year, the school once again received an "A" on the NYC School Report Card, due largely to the many strides the students have made in both Math and ELA. Students come to CCAA to learn in a safe, nurturing and academic environment.

CCAA is a safe, vibrant, innovative school. In 2007-08, our middle school students made some of the greatest gains in ELA and math in the city. Several teachers have pioneered an interdisciplinary reading program with City College professors. We offer a new strings music program, a new track team, and after-school enrichment and tutoring for all students. We recently elected a strong new union rep, and in the DOE's school survey, 87 percent of responding teachers said we felt supported to a great extent by our principal. Our school is still growing and improving, and I'm happy to teach there.

"The administration at this school is extremely manipulative. The union rep never has elections and runs to the administration whenever a teacher talks to him about the exploitation. Students are not treated fairly. Some students are punished while others are allowed to roam the halls. Parents should be aware that their child is going to receive some very traditional learning methods with nothing more than lip service paid to struggling learners. In fact, in many cases the admin does all they can to push students out of the building so that there are more students with "3's" and "4's." Beware!!!"

The school's frequent tests and quizzes received applause from one student. "I like the tests because I like to time myself and test my speed," he said.

"In our school the kids are the focus, and making them excited about learning is what we're trying to do," said Principal Bernadette Drysdale.

This is my last year at Amistad. I'm in 8th grade and I really like this school. My teacher are very supportive and they help us all they can. It is a very small school with two classes per grade. The middle school and elementary school are separate and rarely have contact, unless there's something concerning the whole school. Almost everyone in my year are like my second family, most of us have known each other since kindergarten. Me on the other hand, I came to the school in 4th grade after a very tough move across the country. It was very hard for me to adjust to this city but with the support of my teachers and friend, who are like my family now, I had a very good first year. The atmosphere of the school is very friendly and everyone is accepted. However there are a few problems one being issues with the speech classes. My younger sister who is currently in 5th grade changed the school because she felt like she wasn't challenged enough. She can't say her 'r's, 'th's and 's's, so when it came time for her to read to improve her reading level the teaches never really changed it because of her speech impediment. Our parents tried to get her speech classes but they never took her because it wasn't directly affecting her grade. But despite all of that I've never really had a problem with the school. There are 3 after school programs in the school, CUNY in the heights, FYI (for MS only), and Little Red Rocket (for elementary only). There's also the BOOST program which is a program for middle school student to go on educational and cultural field trips. There is also a regents class for those who want to take the 8th math regents. I really love my school, my teachers, and friends. I'm very glad I came to this school because it is like a family.

The other school in the building, Muscota, tends to have an even longer waiting list as it isn't dual language.

My older child attended Amistad from 3rd-5th grades and my younger, now in 5th, has attended since Kindergarten. I've spent many hours volunteering in classrooms, at school-wide events, at PTA fundraisers and social functions, and on class trips (including an overnight!) I feel confident in saying that Amistad's teachers are completely dedicated to their kids, thinking about each one's skills, abilities and needs. The curriculum is pretty much the same as most other DOE schools, but in my opinion, Amistad distinguishes itself in two ways: most impressively (to me), the students learn in two languages! I've seen students from English-only and Spanish-only households make great strides in both languages; second, while Amistad maintains a safe and secure feeling through the staff's excellent classroom management skills, it also feels very cozy and relaxed. Also, with only 2 classes per grade and around 20 students per class, it is intimate and all staff know all the kids.

Our daughter, now in 5th grade, has attended Amistad since kindergarten. She enjoys a variety of creative and challenging assignments in all subjects, and has bonded well with most of her teachers.

Principal Miriam Pedraja received a 2008 Cahn Fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and continue serving as principal at the school.

A parent writes that her children attend Amistad and her family is "very happy with the school": "My oldest is in 4th grade and her written and spoken Spanish is beautiful. The school has nurtured her sense of intellectual curiosity while making sure she gets a solid education. My son is in 1st grade and is flourishing as well. He started school with a serious aversion to reading and writing, but now looks forward to these subjects, and reads above grade level." She adds: "The school has a very strong music and movement program that is integrated into the curriculum, and uses nearby Inwood Hill Park as the basis for much of its science curriculum. Although the school is open to the entire district, it truly has a community feel to it and parental involvement is welcomed and encouraged. The student body is diverse and the children learn about and value the many different cultures represented in the school."

My child was incessantly bullied at Muscota and the administration would do nothing to help, first ignoring my request for help and then suggesting that my child enjoyed being the target of that behavior. I wish I had gone above their heads to the DOE, but after an extremely difficult final two years there, I began to discover several other families who had pulled their children out of the school because of the bullying and the administration's non-response. I wish we had left earlier. If your child is here and is being bullied, just get out. The admin will not work with you at all and there are so many other schools in the district that really care. My child is extremely happy now and I wish we had left earlier.
Through the district's participatory budgeting process, DNAinfo reports that Muscota New School and Amistad will receive $100,000 to upgrade bathrooms and plumbing.

As a parent of a 1st grade Muscota student, we are extremely happy with Muscota.  The school has rich arts programming, including dance, art, music and drama.  The teachers are bright and compassionate, really caring about each student's individual needs and customize lessons accordingly. The school has done a great job evolving to the common core standards while maintaining a progressive philosophy and traditions.  There is a town meeting every Monday morning where each class takes turns presenting and parents are always welcome.  The looping structure for K-1 really helped the kids establish a foundation that enabled them to start first grade off without skipping a beat.  We really enjoy the other traditions as well, including family breakfasts in the classroom twice a year, the annual Candlelight night program and the many other activities led by the very active parents association.  My son is excited to go to school, which says a lot for him, and he is consistently improving in his studies and social skills.  I am excited to send my daughter to Muscota next year for Kindergarten!

As a veteran Muscota staff member, I believe Muscota is one of the greatest places educators and students can come together to learn and grow.  Thank goodness changes have taken place over the past 5 years under Camille Wallin's leadership. Our doors stayed open, thanks to her vision to sharpen, rebuild and refresh the schools mission.  Teachers are given many opportunities to grow at MNS.  Staff members moved on, but that shouldn't be a reflection of what MNS has "lost."  The staff members who stayed are steeped in good work and refining our practices, always going back to the drawing board to see how we can improve our teaching for the benefit of all students.  New staff members are bright, eager and ambitious, and have brought a wealth of knowledge and dedication to their classrooms and collegial environment.  The entire Muscota staff is devoted to putting children first and making our school vision a reality for all children.  Our administration couldn't be more supportive.  Staff is encouraged to come to the table with input and new ideas. Doors are always open if there is a need for discussion and guidance.  It is all this and more that makes Muscota is a very special place!

While it is true that Muscota's academics have improved in recent years, parents who understand progressive education and seek a progressive education for their children would do well to look elsewhere. In recent years, Muscota has done away with most of its practices that were hallmarks of the progressive philosophy, such as mixed-age groupings, designing units of study based on the students' interests, and many of the school's community-building traditions, such as gathering by grade to sing together and the traditional Candlelight Night, in which members of the school community presented self-selected, and self-rehearsed performances by candlelight.  My children have been given frequent tests and pop quizzes, sometimes graded in red ink. And for the coming year, the school will do away with looping except in kindergarten and first grade. The homework load in my kids' and my friends' kids' grades is very heavy, with a strong emphasis on publisher-created worksheets. The school's former emphasis on social justice and on educating the whole child has faded in the pursuit of higher test scores. Also troubling is that most of the school's teachers of color have left and have been replaced with white teachers, undermining the school's former emphasis on diversity and inclusion. It is still a great school that welcomes parent participation, it is just no longer the progressive school it once was.

Inside schools teacher
As a veteran educator that has witnessed the history of Muscota, I’ve seen it undergo a transition that took them from turmoil to
success.  They were in danger of closing down and change was imminent. Muscota has become more academically rigorous in
recent years but they have maintained their progress values., Teachers pride themselves with holding onto progressive values while meeting the demands of the new common core learning standards. While collaboratively planning, they find interesting ways to make the content more engaging with a real-world application and focus on project based learning.

We are proud that the school outperformed the city without
compromising our values and our belief on how children learn best. I’ve noticed that curriculum has become interdisciplinary, focused on integrating all content areas around big questions. Students engage in inquiry and help develop the guiding questions they are studying. Students have many opportunities to ensure their voice is heard and advocate for themselves. This is evident in our weekly Town Meetings where the whole school community comes together to sing, dance and share our work. Students make announcements in front of the whole school community and help run the Town Meeting. Our Talent Show which is hosted
by the 5th graders is also a great example of students choosing what
they want to showcase and creating original pieces to share with the
community.  

I am honored to be working so closely with my colleagues and
would like to address a comment that was posted about the teaching staff not being diverse. The hiring committee is composed of parents, administration and teachers who all have voices in the hiring of the new staff members. When hiring new staff members, it is a lengthy process to ensure that we find the best candidate for our school. Of course we try to mirror the diversity of our neighborhood but also ensure we have the most qualified candidate for the position.  We are a small staff of only
12 classroom teachers. Within these small numbers, teachers come from various ethnicities and bring forward a variety of different experiences.

Proud Muscota Parent

Hmm, “look elsewhere.” It was not easy to find Muscota, but when I did, I couldn't be happier. Most progressive schools required families to pay tuition to have their child attend. Muscota does not.  My first impression of this school was during a tour. I had spent months researching progressive schools around the city and visited those I thought would be a good fit for my daughter. 

During the tour at Muscota, no matter the classroom I entered, I could hear students engaged in conversations, working independently, or involved in collaborative play. It didn’t have the feel of a traditional school. Students seemed enthusiastic and engaged in their own learning.  There was a warm feeling across the school that I had not seen in other schools I’d visited. I saw evidence of student work products displayed around the room or hanging from lights.  I knew immediately that this was the place I’d want my daughter to attend.

In the end, unquestionably, Muscota was my first choice. The school offered a balance of academics, social and, more importantly a progressive philosophy. 

Since then, my daughter has flourished. She is receiving a well rounded education, that shows her academic as well as her artistic growth.  She is assigned projects based on interest, that we work on at home. She once expressed that she loved her school and didn’t know why anyone would ever want to be absent. The homework she was doing at night prepared her to take state assessments. There was limited evidence that suggested she was being instructed on how to take a test. They read books as a class that engaged my daughter in wanting to read more books by the author. Regardless of what others believe about Muscota’s progressive philosophy, I know that my daughter will be well prepared to meet the demands of the 21st Century.

As a parent of a 1st grade kid at Muscota, I must say that Muscota's academic standards are not lacking in any way. The school is looking to improve, yes - because the teachers are caring professionals. Why would they look to stay the same? Of COURSE the school only wants to get better and better.

Happy parent of a 1st grader.

This year one of our daughters graduates from Muscota as the other starts her journey there in kindergarten. That we have another six years at Muscota gives us great comfort, since it feels like a second home. 



I am writing because, between researching elementary schools seven years ago and spending the last two years researching middle schools, I have spent hundreds of hours talking to parents, researching websites, and touring over twenty schools. I am inspired by how parents share information. We are all in the same boat. Every NYC family has to navigate the treacherous waters of school choice. It makes this big city feel like a small town. We should take solace that college admissions will be a breeze compared with finding the right kindergarten for our children. While there is not one right school for all children, once you find the right school for your child, and your family, you will know it. We are so fortunate and grateful that we found the right school for our daughter and for our family, and that it is a seven minute walk from our home. 



We are not yet authorities on middle schools, but we do know Muscota inside and out, because that's the kind of school it is. It WANTS families to know it, engage with it, and grow with it. A school is only as strong as its inhabitants and Muscota is a thriving community of love, learning, and discovery. We wish Muscota could extend to high school because it offers the kind of education that has finally made it to the front covers of every newspaper and teaching journal in the world. It is progressive, rigorous, responsive, diverse, and child-centered. It is WHOLE. 



Muscota has forever shaped the way our daughter sees, investigates, and reflects the world. Some of its trademarks include: 



THE ARTS. At Muscota students learn about the world THROUGH the arts. The arts are not an appendage, but are rather the heart of the school's rigorous and creative collaboration. Sasha teaches sculpture, perspective, self-portrait, architecture, 2D design, and doll/puppet making by connecting each to texts the students are reading, concepts they are grappling with in math and science, and buildings in their neighborhood. In Megan's music class students compose songs about human anatomy and celebrate Mayan, Irish, Chinese, and Dutch culture through songs (sung in their native language). In Heather's dance class students explore world history through gumboot dances, tutting, and solo/partnering choreography. Students start playwriting in kindergarten with Dayna and graduate to fully produced self-written and Shakespearean plays by fifth grade. The students' understanding of character, dialogue, conflict, context, figurative speech, and plot is extraordinary, thanks to drama with Dayna. 



COMMUNITY. Muscota values community. Rituals and traditions are scheduled weekly and monthly to celebrate and extend classroom learning into the entire school and Inwood/Washington Heights community. Events include Monday morning town meeting, Inwood Park hikes, Family Breakfast, Mad Hatter's Ball, Candlelight Night, Winter Ice Skating Trip, State Fair, Talent Show, Pi Day, Eco-Fest, Spring Shakespeare Production, Spring Auction, Field Day, Mini Mall, Fifth Grade Overnight Adventure, Moving On, and Curriculum Nights. Students visit the nearby Bronx Zoo, Botanical Garden, Dyckman Farmhouse, as well as head downtown to the Joyce Theater, Tenement Museum, Juilliard, and the Museum of Natural History. 



PARENTAL INVOLVEMENT. Parental involvement is encouraged and essential to the thriving environment. Parent-led initiatives were behind a playground upgrade, cafeteria overhaul, state of the art auditorium sound system, science program, yoga program, garden plot, and countless other enrichment opportunities. Parents work closely with teachers and the administration. Communication is clear and comprehensive, accomplished through backpacked written correspondence, e-mail, the website, phone and in person through monthly meetings with Principal Camille Wallin and the Parents' Association. Parents are included in their child's learning through conferences with teachers. Evening and weekend workshops include topics such as nutrition, the arts, literacy, science, math, testing, and parenting support.



RIGOR. We love what our daughter comes home with each night. Her homework is challenging and engaging. She reads a novel a week independently, suited to her interests, as well as a novel/non-fiction book a month with her class and yet another in her after-school program. Her math homework keeps our entire family on our toes and entertained. She has learned math concepts through Mancala, Chess, card games, and the Salvadori program. This year her teacher Lauren's Culture of Proof tenet: "convince yourself, convince a friend, convince a skeptic" has changed the way we talk at the dinner table and the way I teach in my college classroom. We cherish the looping that Muscota is known for. Students, or "scholars" as Principal Camille calls them, stay with each teacher for two years. Muscota's teachers know, honor, respect, and celebrate how each student learns. Recently our daughter's classmate taught the class about rainforest deforestation through an interactive Minecraft presentation. 



The school day spans from 8:30am to 3:10pm and offers early drop off as well as outstanding after-school programs. Partnerships with the nearby Bread & Yoga, Uptown Sports, and Nagle YM&YWHA also provide families with flexibility and enrichment. The school is safe, the kids are safe, and bullying simply does not exist. 



Muscota is responsible, in great part, for how our daughter thinks, problem solves, communicates with friends and family, and engages with the world. It is a gem of a school.

February 2014
NYC Parent

I took many tours as I was searching for a school that was a right fit for my child. Believe me when I say no two schools were alike.

If you are looking at this, then you probably have done your homework and know that Muscota is not a traditional school. 

Confidence, Self Assuredness and Strength of Character are elements of a Muscota child. Where else would a strange parent visiting a child's second home be greeted by an eloquent 5 year old who welcomes and invites them into his classroom?

In today's day and age most people communicate via text and email. Every day, I encounter adults with a lack of socialization skills that is key in this global society. Muscota children have a nurturing environment to facilitate in building key interpersonal skills and emotional intelligence, skills that you can't learn from a textbook.

Muscota's foundation is its community. Strong family involvement is key to its founding and continued vision.

Muscota is one of the few schools that wants parental involvement and input. From the first encounter during a tour with Principal Camille Wallin, I was impressed by the human and personal approach of the faculty and administration. "Do you have a moment? I want to hear your thoughts on the tour? What could we have done better? What did you like?" I was shocked that a principal of an urban public school would want the feedback of a person she just met.

It is important to note high family involvement is the key at this school. It's not required but Muscota follows Mayor DeBlasio's tenet, parents are stakeholders in the school system and have a serious say on things that affect their child.

Now that doesn't mean that you can complain or pick and choose what you want for your child but they have an ear open to the parents. The administrative staff have their hands full balancing the ever-changing focuses of the DOE while fighting to retain the philosophy and vision of the founding parents and administration. this dance is not an easy one but with the support of parents and families, the staff work hard to maintain Muscota's character and beliefs.

Parents should come to the administration and faculty with constructive solutions or ideas that will enhance not only their child's experience but also the other children in the community.

Muscota is a small school with a big heart. It is not only your child(ren) who will be enrolled but also your family who will be welcomed into the Muscota home. Its a lasting relationship well past the years of attendance.

In December 2011, Muscota New School Principal Camille Wallin was profiled by local news source DNAinfo.com as a Principal of the Week: http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20111219/washington-heights-inwood/muscota-new-school-principal-camille-wallin-builds-community-inwood

In the article, Principal Camille Wallin shares what makes Muscota New School PS 314 such a great school. She talks about the progressive teaching environment and Muscota's focus on a holistic approach to learning and the sense of community it provides for the students and their families.

I am the proud parent of 2 Muscota kids, a 3rd grader 
and Kindergartener.  My love for the school has grown each year.  The 
teachers are some of the most committed individuals I have ever met and 
are truly committed to the social and emotional development of every 
child at the school.  

Our principal Camille Wallin, in her 2nd year at 
Muscota, has embraced our progressive philosophy and raised the bar for 
academic excellence.  She was also instrumental in securing a technology grant this year that will bring new laptops, smartboards, and other needed technology resources to our school.

What makes the school really special is the
 level of involvement of our families.  Parents are encouraged and have 
the opportunity to contribute in meaningful ways to the school's daily 
life.  Parents collaborate with teachers to augment classroom 
instruction, participate in hiring committees for new staff, and 
organize events like Eco-Fest and Mad Hatters Parade that embody the 
school philosophy.  I hope that one day we can grow into a K-8 school!

I appreciate the comments made by the Muscota parent, "Good Fortune" and am so glad that they feel the school is doing very well under Camille Wallin's leadership. I couldn't agree more. 
There are some things I would like to correct, however. First, the Muscota founding director was Leslie Alexander; it was she and the founding staff and parents who crafted Muscota's original vision and mission.  Most recently, Camille and the staff have carried it forward with the able assistance of the Muscota School Leadership Team, Parent's Association and the current loyal and very involved parent body.  
I will also add that I recently retired from Muscota after 13 years but, when I have visited,  I have felt welcomed and get a feeling that the Muscota we created in 1993 is alive and well.  As I walked through class rooms just last week, I saw students and teachers engaged and excited; there was a calm, well organized, purposeful and safe environment throughout and ample evidence of the school's progressive values and teaching practices.  In my experience, Camille makes it clear that she has high expectations; that she values teachers' input and counts on their experience to make Muscota the best school it can be. 

 I want to reiterate that it's not gone; it is alive and well and can be felt in the kids, the staff and in the learning at Muscota as evidenced by the school's day to day activities and also by the many Muscota traditions that are also alive and well.

Always,
Louisa

Its been a long time since I read on this site yet, I was glad to see that a Muscota parent was compelled to post a comment. 

I am very proud and happy to say that I chose to spend most of my years as a NYC public school teacher at this amazing school. In my experience, Muscota always strove to balance its progressive philosophy with the external demands of the educational systems it was accountable to; never an easy task.When walking through the school, these days, there is clear evidence that the Muscota staff and administration still place a great value on being the kind of school community that has children and families' best interest at heart; that children's well being and learning BOTH are at the heart of the matter at Muscota.The comments in this recent post make clear that this Muscota parent feels this is still true. This is extraordinary, given Muscota's recent history and the many changes it has endured through the years. This is a testament to the strength of its original mission; to the communal values this small community works so hard to preserve.Last year, with the advent of a new administration, I felt that I could once again focus on honing my craft. I felt that my ideas were greatly valued; my contributions welcomed, and, that my role as an experienced teacher was highly respected. After years of turmoil, I once again had the opportunity to devote my energies to the work of teaching, to the growth of my students, my involvement with their families and the further development of Muscota's hard working professional community.It was a long awaited change that I welcomed.As a parent and educator, I know that while change is never easy, it is essential for growth. I am very grateful that the Muscota community continues to grow and evolve, even in the current climate that breeds so much uncertainty.Irrespective of the current state of affairs in education, I am ever hopeful because there is a Muscota New School and am thankful for all the forces that helped make possible its continued clear vision and strength of purpose.NYC Public School Teacher

As a long time parent who has had both kids go to Muscota, I am very pleased with the new Principal, Camille, and with the new staff.  There was a large turn over this year and we lost a lot of great teachers.  It is early to predict how Muscota will change, grow or evolve with so many new teachers, but I have to say it has been going very well.  The school feels different, no doubt.  The former identity as a Progressive school and the mission of the founding parents and Director, Judi Menken, is long gone.  Change was bound to happen due to the cookie cutter/teach to the test or you will be closed mentality of the DOE.  "Conform or be shut down"is the message and Camille is trying her best to keep us open and please, to a certain point, the DOE.  To do that- you need high test scores.  Sigh.  Oh well.
Camille is very serious about the student's success and making sure they are focused on, safe and engaged.  She has a great presence with the parents, but I am guessing the staff (especially the old staff) find her to be a bully- but that is conjecture.I am beyond please with the organization, the great hires and her ability to get things done.  I will always love this school and give it credit for nurturing and empowering my children.  This is a great neighborhood school with an amazing Parents' Association.
GrowNYC awarded 29 NYC schools a Grow to Learn grant for creating garden classrooms.

"The learning process at Muscota differs from many other schools," writes Chelsea, who graduated in 2004. "Instead of following what some textbooks said, you take a trip to the park and study the leaves there, or learn about animals while your at the aquarium, and the study differed from grade to grade. At Muscota, you know all the other students, and teachers were called by their first names. It's very safe and comfortable school."

"Muscota creates and nurtures a truly non-competitive, safe atmosphere that enhances creative learning and social development," writes parent Emily Horowitz. "The teachers are wonderful, caring, and involved, and the hands-on administration is responsive to parental concerns and, more importantly, to the needs of children." This parent notes that Muscota is a "small, intimate, and unusual place where parents can observe and participate in class activities at any time."

"My children have taken trips connected to mathematics, social studies, science, geography, theater, music, dance, and art. Every trip fosters and extends their learning beyond what could be acquired in the classroom setting," writes parent Courtney Retzler. "I especially like how Muscota teachers take great care to integrate trip experiences into the mathematics, reading, and writing lessons. For example last year one of my children's classes visited local zoos as part of their mammal study. Not only did children gather information for animal research on these trips, they also created graphs and maps about animals and their habitats, read non-fiction such as: brochures & field guides, and wrote stories about their favorite mammal."

Teacher Victoria Dallas-Stephenson writes: "I can honestly say that Muscota is a terrific place to work, and a true learning community. Teachers take the initiative to seek out and participate in professional development that helps them grow as educators. The NYC mandate requires two afternoons per month for staff meetings/professional development - at Muscota the staff insists on weekly meetings (from 3:30 until 5:15) after school, weekly business meetings, staff development retreats, and reviews of staff/children's work. Math is definitely taught. Beginning in kindergarten, children look at the patterns in shape and number. By third grade, they automatically seek patterns to help them solve math problems. This sophisticated algebraic thinking is a Muscota hallmark." The teacher adds that children go outdoors, and "taking the time to build and maintain a community is at the core of what we do. This does not preclude children being taught to do math, read, or write. Children are encouraged to help each other in their learning, and to learn to be team players. Muscota kids find out that we are all learners and teachers, and that we share this responsibility as well. Most classrooms have a forum for dealing with the problems that inevitably arise when more than twenty children get together. Students are given peer and teacher support to help them articulate their particular difficulty and to find solutions that don't condemn anyone, but strive to keep community members feeling safe and heard."

A parent writes: "I urge parents to get as much information about this school as possible before sending there kids there. There is absolutely nothing traditional about this school. Kids are never tested and for the first three years at this school the kids spend too much time on play time, snack time, drama time, outside time. Also, lets not forget the fact that they go on about 60 trips a year. They spend WAY too much time out of the classroom."
"I like that they send reports here instead of just report cards," said parent Alex Heredia. "They really keep you up to date."

Teacher Francesca Weiss responds to a complaint about bulling posted below: "I would like to clarify the way in which issues between children are resolved. In the incident mentioned by a parent about bullying, the victim was not asked to confront the "bully" in front of the class. The child was asked to share her story (with the support of the teacher) with the class. The "bully" was asked to accept responsiblility for her actions within the community of her peers and teacher; a setting that is safe to tell the truth and where both children could come together with a stronger friendship and regard. The actual strategy and full group conversation is too extensive to go into here but I can say that both children became fast and steady friends. It is also inappropriate to label a 5 year old child as a "bully" if one does not know the child well. The behavior was unusual for the child mentioned and did not occur again. When there is a "secret" amongst children that is revealed and discussed, the power of the "bully" is greatly diminished by the revelation and the ensuing conversation. It is a shame that an individual used such an important forum to malign innocent children and to characterize a conversation that was not witnessed first hand. There is not a problem with bullying at Muscota but rather the normal problems of children acting on their fears, vanities and needs in ways that are sometimes inappropriate, sometimes hurtful but as often as possible acted upon by the teachers in the school in a supportive and safe manner. We want all our children to grow. Even the 'bullies.'"

 There is most definitely a problem with bullies at Muscota," writes a parent, who adds that she is unhappy with the way such situations are handled by the school. . I am not happy that my 5 year old has to be told that she had to stand in front of the classroom and confront the bully as a method of resolving this."

I recall this situation, believe it or not I just saw this response.  I am the parent. MY child did NOT feel comfortable standing in front of the classroom and stating her feelings. Adults as caregivers must  validate that we indeed hear a a child's fears and insecurities, this absolutely  VITAL for trust. If you don't approach the child and ask how she/he feels stating her feelings in front of a group, then it is both invalidating her fears and magnifying them, in front of an audience, and leaving her open for judgement and criticism by her peers which can lead to more issues.

"I can say with confidence that we manage to keep children at the center of all of our curriculum and decision/policy making," a Muscota teacher writes. "We do have structure which varies from teacher to teacher (we are not all doing reading at 10:00 am) but it is fair to say that not every child is right for this school. We work hard to keep our classes small (K/1-25 with one para) and no more than 30 in the upper grades (2-5). We utilize student teachers from several reputable colleges (Bank Street, Sarah Lawrence, and CUNY-Queens and City) in order to maximize adults in the classroom. Recently our school has moved the upper grades to a looping model (meaning that 4th and 5th grades are no longer mixed) allowing for more intense structure and curriculum delivery. These 4th graders stay with the same teacher for two years allowing the maximum time to develop and nurture relationships with students. Our students are accepted into all of the best middle schools due to our hardworking staff, parent coordinator, guidance counselor, and principal." Finally, she adds: "I have sent both of my children to this school (my eldest is now applying to high school, and my youngest is currently in kindergarten) without reservation. It is a safe place for children to play, learn, and grow without feeling all the pressures and constraints that are often needlessly put upon them by this current 'test-taking' administration."

A parent writes: "This school doesn't fully adhere to the philosophy used to sell parents on placing their child there. They insist their approach makes allowances for each individual child. That is definitely not the case. There is serious lack of basic structure needed as building blocks for any child." She writes that the school has a take-it-or-leave-it attitude towards parents. On several occasions, she was told by an administrator: "If you don't agree with our curricular methods then you can just find another school." She writes, "Other parents have had similar experiences. I don't think I was being overzealous when I asked why my child only had 10 pages of homework in 1st grade while other children in the same district/grade had over 200. For three years now we have never had to study for any tests. This in a school system where tests are very necessary for passing the grade. I think 3rd grade is too late to build test taking skills." She writes that she also has concerns about safety and bullying at the school.

This school isn’t bad. I will say this: it will change you. A lot. You’ll see what fairness and injustice is. You’ll see what sticking up for yourself means. You’ll see what it’s like to feel like nothing. You’ll see who’s real and fake. The principal, brags so much. He shows injustice. The teachers are mostly nice. The halls are usually okay. Sometimes packed. We get WALKED to class because teachers don’t trust us. There are fights. The uniform can be annoying but after the first week you get used to it. We do share a building with three other schools. We stay on the right side. There’s recess once a week sometimes two. Lunch is 7th period except for 8th graders where it’s 8th period. Back to the principal. He thinks he’s funny and knows student but he really doesn’t. He just brags his kids and does nothing about problems. If you get beat up, instead you get suspended. If you finna get jumped, he does nothing. He acts like he’s nice but he’s not unless you’re lucky. Dudas nice. Faulkner’s nice. Colina nice.
He still isn’t. He’s always bragging.

Principal Ysidro Abreu received a 2009 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor an aspiring principal while continuing to serve as principal at their school.
MS 319 has been added to the state's list of schools needing improvement under No Child Left Behind because of inadequate performance on the state tests in English.

According to the city Quality Review Report, "[The school] has started to look at gender based issues having identified that its numbers show a gender bias towards boys which it feels may be partly because of that named specialists areas of 'math, science, and technology.'"
Principal Ysidro Abreu said: "If we ask a child why we come here, it's all to perservere, achieve, and excel."
He always said that
This is my school

MS 322 is among 40 middle schools selected for an extension of the Middle School Quality Initiative, a program that increases professional development with Common Core-aligned literacy strategies and gives targeted funding for literacy training and materials. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

I wanted to take the time to give my opinion to worrying parents of soon to be middle schoolers. This is my child's first year and I can tell you that it was honestly not my first choice but we went with it. 

My child has improved tremendously since attending ms322. The teachers are great and are always available. My child can email. text or call if he comes across any difficulties with his homework. They have a great system where parents and students can log in everyday and check grades, upcoming homework, behavior and attendance. The teachers update it daily. As a parent, your always "in the know."
My son has art, health and clubs. 

The Children Aid Society offers free after-school. All three schools mix in to join. 

The children are average pre-teens. You have some good and some who need extra attention. My son has made friends with good honest kids and I am happy. He hasn't had a problem as far as bulling or fighting. 

The principal is great. If you have any problems she is fast to resolve. She always asks if you need anything and I like that she is in control of everything. There is an assistant principal for each grade and they are wonderful as well. I see them interacting with the children and give advice as mentors.  

The only downfall I see in this school is lack of communication and parent participation. It surprises me that for meeting and workshops parents are a no show. Of course, I understand many work and I can see where meeting should be held on some evenings, but this has to change. I see no reason for this school not to get the support it needs from its parents to make it a top school. We need to join together as a community and maybe with the new strong parent coordinator ( previous one resigned) and a stronger PTA it can happen.
what tis the uniform for ms 322 ny, ny 10034

6 and 7th grader's wear a grey shirt with a school logo which they sell at the school for $12. 8th graders were a blue one. They wear khaki pants and shoes or sneakers of your choosing. On gym days they are to wear black or grey sweatpants with their cotton uniform shirts. ~new parent to incoming 6th grader

im a current student at this school. I will inform you that the dress code has changed due to schools merging. the uniform is the 6th and 7th grade wear a maroon shirt with the logo or a polo shirt colored maroon. 8th graders wear a dark blue shirt with the school logo or like I mentioned before a dark blue polo works fine as well. all students must wear khaki pants or grey sweatpants.

MS324 is a wonderful school! Our son, Luke, was homeschooled for grades K-6 and entered MS324 in the 7th grade. Our initial questions and concerns about putting him in public school were quickly answered by Ms. Heller, the Principal and his teachers--the teachers MS324 are STELLAR! They engage the students in positive, productive ways and they also gave Luke personal attention to his specific needs. He also had the opportunity to participate in a special math and computer science program. These were/are fantastic opportunities. We cannot thank the Teachers, Ms. Heller and the staff at MS324 enough!
MS 324 students are able to play with dogs in an innovative program designed to develop compassion for animals. Read more here.

This is my sons last year at 324.  He has been very happy at this school and we are sad to be leaving, time has gone by so fast.  First impressions last and the school has a friendly vibe and the hallways and classrooms are light, airy and full of projects and paintings done by the students.  My son and I spent some time in the classrooms observing when we were considering the school and all of the children were eager to tell us just how great their school was and how much they loved their teachers.  I had the wonderful opportunity of spending time with some of the teachers at a camping trip and got to see first hand just how enthusiastic, energetic and dedicated they are to their craft.  They draw out the best in every child with endless encouragement and understanding of every childs needs. The Principal, Ms. Heller is very approachable and passionate about the school as are all of the staff and I have never had a problem communicating with the school or the staff as needed.  My sons education has exceeded our expectations and helped him to grow into a responsible and mature young man over the past 3 years.  We have never had a problem with bullying or safety and I would highly recommend this school to all.

I graduated from MS324 in 2010. I love this school unconditionally and I know that when I have my children someday, this is the school I would send my children to. I just graduated high school and many say that high school are the best years of your life, but to me, middle school (MS324) were the best years of my life. In 2007, all incoming 6th graders were shy and scared - which makes sense after going to a whole new school and atmosphere than the previous school you attended, in which you were there for 6-7 years. The school welcomed me and everyone else with open arms. The way that you had at least one staff member who was your friend was a great feeling, and you grew to become very close to your teacher too. I met my best friend in middle school and now we're going to the same college in the Fall! Literally every staff member cared for every single student at 324, and I know that it seems like I'm just writing it just because, but they really did. If there was an issue, they would hold you after class and ask what's going on and see if there was any way they could resolve the issue. They also knew when someone was getting bullied in school or at home, when the student wouldn't physically tell anyone, and they would act on it by helping or calling someone who could help (although there was NEVER any bullying whatsoever at 324). There was always cool events that the school like small dances to raise money for other trips so students would either have to not pay or pay a minimal price, and had and at least one field trip was happening every month. I don't know if they still have this program at 324, but 324 was part of this program called Project BOOST, which rewarded high achieving students with really cool field trips (I was part of this program during my 8th grade year), examples include trips to see Broadway plays, restaurants, games, movies, and even taking us to Barnes and Nobles and buying us a book! The school is all about pushing the student to reach their fullest potential. And even then, there is no such thing as complacency in the school by means of, staff members kept pushing you. MS324 takes in students with low standardized test scores and bumps them up to a high level. All the teachers show absolute commitment, which in turn inspires the student to become absolutely dedicated to school work and learning. The Principal, Ms. Heller knew everyone and is the epitome of what a school principal should be. She would take time out of her busy schedule every morning to do line-ups with every class (to check up on every class, give insightful information, to encourage students, etc.), before sending the classes upstairs to get started. During the day, she would visit classes just to see how everyone was and she even helped children herself who were stumped on a topic in whatever subject the class was in (this one time she came into our gym class when we had a substitute teacher and led exercises for us, which was pretty cool, how many people can say that their principal came in and exercised with you during gym?). If a student was upset or sad, she would take time out of her day to be that helping hand. She also was not a push over (definitely not), she is very strict, but in a good way. She would not hesitate to enact disciplinary action when necessary. She became a role model to many students, including myself. The system of having a PACT sheet everyday (a paper in which the class gets graded and rated on overall performance, such as behavior, attention, etc..) also kept the classes in line. 324 is also VERY BIG on college readiness and carrying on the message that all students must go on to college after high school, seeing as in the neighborhood of Washington Heights, there are many high school dropouts who end up not doing anything except freelance. 324 did not want us to become a "statistic" and wanted us to break all barriers that held Hispanics/African-Americans in the dark. The super tight knit community of 324 also helped a great deal in my development as an adolescent; because of this closeness with everyone, it truly felt like a family or a second home. I became so excited and happy to come to school everyday (except test days). This school became such a big part in my development in life and inspired me to achieve so much more, because we actually had people tell us we were champions and could do anything our heart desires, and mean it with the most sincerity. I would recommend this school to ANY and EVERY incoming student. I sure know that on the last day of school, I cried because I did not want to leave. If I had the chance to repeat my middle school years, I wouldn't change a thing because MS 324 is absolutely perfect and amazing in every single way.
i love this school, i am in 8th grade in this school now and i love all the teachers, they are all so nice, i dont think this school would be the way it is now without out principal Ms. Heller

MS 324 has an excellent and committed teaching staff, and they manage to maintain needed control over their student population. The level of science my 6th grader is learning is way beyond what I learned in private school growing up. There are extracurricular activities such as a three day trip to a environmental camp in 6th grade--the cheerleading team made it to Radio City and Madison Square garden. A most unexpectedly wonderful school.
im in this school and is awesome, cool staff and it also makes you feel safe. i love ms. heller and the teachers.

The school overall is decent. I went here and graduated recently. Coming from experience with the school staff, they can be disrespectful (Unnecessary screaming, nasty attitude etc.) including the security which hardly do their jobs, they're more concerned with the students uniform policy instead of looking out for the students and protecting them. Also the deans at the school act like they don't want to be there and don't like working with the students. When my parents come to the school, the staff are disrespectful. Lots of the staff go by their own rules which can be confusing and you can tell they don't even follow their own rules. A lot of the teachers choose favorites and treat them better than the other students (letting them not go by rules but getting other students in trouble for doing the same). Usually, I would have to go straight to the principal for anything if I really need something cause most staff is unhelpful and do what they want. The principal is great, it's just the staff that needs fixing. There are some teachers that actually do their jobs, care about their students and want to help out but alot of the staff treat the students poorly and makes the students react offensively ending in unnecessary punishments. There's alot of unnecessary punishments like being a minute late ends up to be an hour detention after school, the school believes that punishments fix us and helps us but it's extremely unaffective. Lots of the unnecessary punishments ends up with students missing class time which is the point of going to school in the first place and should be a priority. Overall, the school staff has lots of fixing to do, many should be fired for not doing their job efficiently.

On March 15, Chancellor Walcott held a ribbon cutting ceremony for the opening of Community Health Academy of the Heights' new building. While the school had previously been housed in two separate locations, it has now moved into a new building at W. 158th Street that includes an art room, a music room, a computer lab, a gymnasium, special education classrooms, and a science class room with two demonstration rooms and a prep room. In September, the school’s partners, the Community League of the Heights (CLOTH) and the Community Healthcare Network, will also open a health center at the school. Read more here.

I have worked at the school for over a year and it has been nice to be a part of a growing school. I would never describe the school as a dangerous place. In fact, I actually enjoy the population I work with. The community does have needs that other communities may not, but I feel that is my charge when choosing to work at a school like CHAH. Of course the school has its "growing pains" but I get to play a role in building and creating a school with a belief in community health. Administrators have supported me in many areas including allowing me to take on leadership positions in different school committees, providing me with more professional development than I have every received at other schools I have taught at, and opportunities to partner with CLOTH and New York Presbyterian and many other organizations.

It actually saddened me to read any negative comments on this website due to the fact that everyone is working diligently and hard at achieving the school's mission and vision while providing students with a quality, college-bound education. I have been at other NYC public schools and it's easy to complain about copies, "basic" needs, but this school truly does care about kids from teachers, administration and office staff. The school focuses on the social-emotional needs of a child which is also hardly recognized at schools I've taught at. I feel that with the school's growth, yes, there will be some challenges such as space, but the focus is always on helping kids succeed.

The teachers are the best part of the school since they genuinely care. However, the school as a whole is dysfunctional. Teachers are not supported and students get mixed messages since they know that there are no higher consequences for their actions. Teachers are expected to work miracles and are given no support. Although i do not feel in danger at the school, i know of teachers who have been in dangerous positions and the students involved are in many cases just sent to another floor in the school. I have asked myself many times: "what message is that sending to these children?" The sad part is that the school has so much potential to be a great school, but the administration seems to hindering the process. The school leadership has not yet realized  how to make the school work and keep on going from one idea to the next, instead of working on one thing at a time and moving on once that is mastered. Many decisions are taken without too much though; for example, why does a school use so much money to purchase an online program when students do not have access to reliable computers in the classroom? This shows the poor thought that is put into things many times at the school. I hope the school gets better because it would be a shame if it does not.

This is a dangerous environment with a lack of administrative support. CHAH has one of the highest teacher turnover rates in the city because of its inadequate leadership, lack of school structure, absence of educational supplies and tools, and absence of a comprehensive, enforceable behavior policy. Teachers are do not have access to a copy machine, supplies, or support for student discipline problems. Many teachers often spend hundreds of dollars from their own pocket for BASIC needs (pencil, paper, etc.) Students have run of the school without consequences, and advisory programs are essentially babysitting periods. The most redeeming qualities of this school are its dedicated teachers, and its tie to CLOTH. Unfortunately, CHAH completely fails to fulfill CLOTH's vision of engaging with the surrounding community and utilizing a health focused curriculum. The building still has yet to occupy a sufficient space, and the partnership with NY Presbyterian Hospital is minimal.

I am glad I am not working for this school. They called me for an interview and I turn them down. There is alwyas problem in school when there is a high turnover rate and the teachers are leaving and the principal who has no experience in running a school does not implement discipline in the first place. Behavior is the key.

Well, Paul...you not only have an issue with spelling, which makes me feel good that you are not working at our school, but you are also misinformed. WHEELS has some major selling points that aren't highlighted in the write-up:
1) The college office does amazing work.  Students last spring got full scholarships to Williams, Smith, St. Lawrence, DePauw, Hobart and William Smith among others.
2) The music program led my Mr. Johnson is truly exceptional, and begins in the lower grades.  The middle school and high school bands are terrific and students win competitive prizes, play paid gigs, etc.  Johnson's teaching was recognized by the American Academy of Arts and Letters in 2017.  https://artsandletters.org/pressrelease/graham-johnson-awarded-presidential-citation
3) The staff is exceptional (I say this as an educator familiar with multiple New York schools).
WHEELS science teacher Jared Fox was named one of seven winners of the 11th Annual Sloan Awards for Excellence in Teaching Science and Mathematics in New York City Public High Schools, Patch reports.

An 8th grade social studies teacher at WHEELS explains how student led conferences (SLCs) help her students take ownership of their work and stay on track at school. Read more here.

We love WHEELS! Our daughter started in PreK and is now a Kindergarten student & the community is incredible. The teachers & staff have created a brilliant space for our young students to learn & grow. Our lower, middle & upper grades all work together in an innovative & exceptional learning environment. The expeditionary learning aspect is also amazing to witness. The last expedition on corn included a farm to table dance, scientific drawings of corn on the husk & salsa & corn fritters that the students all helped make. WHEELS is true holistic learning & we can't wait to watch our daughter continue to grow.

DO NOT ENROLL YOUR CHILD INTO THIS SCHOOL. 
As an alumni in from this school I can wholeheartedly say that this school is one of the worst schools I have ever come across. I have transferred schools from 4th grade to 10th grade but this is by far the worst school I've attended. The kids here do not care about your feelings and are highly stereoypical with cliques and narrow-minded opinions. They highlight the jocks and if you are in anyway different they mock and look down on you. In fact there have been SUICIDES in this school because of how horrible these kids were towards other children. WHEELS also lies to you AND your child, they will hold them back because they did not pass THEIR requirements even though they have passed the STATE requirements. I have had close friends of mine transfer to another school that would graduate them ON TIME because they had all the state requirements but WHEELS would tell them they'd graduate NEXT YEAR. They've also lied about what colleges look for in students, stating that if you do not have a 85 average you will be rejected from good colleges and have to resort to community college when I've seen COUNTLESS seniors with 70 averages get into John Jay and City College. They pressure students to take classes they don't need also. If your child is a senior, do not be surprised if they have 2 or three classes that they do NOT need for graduation and are only there to drain their GPA and increase stress. The only good thing about this school is how caring some teachers can be, other than that everything is in this school is pure trash. Please stay away if you love your child!

I am currently a 10th grade student and I've been in this school since 6th grade.The fact that students are behaving negatively towards other has nothing to do with the way this school helps students academically. This school provides various student counselors to help students deal with their emotions and their personal lives. Ever since I enrolled, each semester we take one extra class for three days a week (the days we have gym, we don't take it). So no, they do not "pressure students to take classes they don't need". That alternative class is almost always a Spanish class and/or art/music. They do not tell us that unless we have an 85 average we won't attend colleges. They simply tell students that most colleges look for students with an 85 average. They never say that "you will be rejected from good colleges and have to resort to community colleges". The only true thing you wrote down in this overall false comment is that the teachers are caring. Indeed, they are. A year before I entered middle school, a WHEELS student did commit suicide and people believed it was due to her 7th grade's math teacher's bullying. I believe the teacher was looked into and found innocent of these allegations. So no, there have not "been SUICIDES in this school because of how horrible these kids were towards other children". Although the school building is not as big as students would want it to be, Washington Heights Expeditionary Learning Schools is a very good school.

There are now 163 iZone360 schools in NYC, schools that receive funding to try new approaches to education like reorganizing the school day. Read more: An offbeat school gets funds and a push to try something new.

"WHEELS' first year was a tremendous success!" writes Principal Brett Kimmel. "Students completed three Learning Expeditions, participated in three student-led conferences, took part in an Outward Bound four-day trip to Harriman State Park and participated in a talent show and field day. The WHEELS Performance Ensemble--a Latin jazz group--performed several times, including the Region 10 Arts Festival and the New York City Outward Bound Benefit Dinner at Tavern on the Green (for an audience of over 600 people that included Mayor Bloomberg and Chancellor Klein!). Surveys of students, teachers and parents indicated outstanding 'customer satisfaction' with the school and ELA and math test scores and attendance rates were among the highest in all of District 6 middle schools."

A May 22, 2006, article from Business Wire writes about Principal Brett Kimmel's background. "After graduating from the University of Michigan in 1996, Kimmel began his career in education with Teach for America. As part of that program, he spent two years in Houston, Texas as a fifth grade teacher and founded the Garcia Elementary After-School Mentoring Program for at-risk elementary school students. In 1998, he joined the Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation in New York as associate director of programming, developing after-school programs for New York City public elementary and middle schools, and then went on to work with New York University's School of Education as its Project Director for After-School Programs. After receiving his Master of Arts in Education Administration from NYU, he joined IS 143."
