very disappointed to hear that another year will go by in this new building without a gym teacher and a science teacher.  Such a lovely gym not used to it's full potential and students having no practical experience in the beautiful science lab.  2 wasted years.

As the school approaches full capacity (having opened our middle school in September 2014), all of the building's spaces are fully utilized. Students enjoy regular physical education classes in the gym and daily recess in the gym or on one of the school's two play yards. Extracurricular sports include co-ed Basketball and Track & Field. Students at all grade levels also enjoy 2-3 periods of hands-on science instruction in the lower grade Science Room (PreK-Grade 3) and upper grade Science Lab (Grades 4-6). Additional classes and extracurricular programs will be offered as the school expands to include Grades 7 and 8.

The fact that all of the parents who have posted comments feel their
children are doing well at Washington Heights Academy is a credit to the
school’s strong teachers, who have done their utmost for students in spite of
the school’s weak leadership. The school's Learning Environment Surveys reflect
consistently low principal ratings that have steadily declined each year. With
new and improved leadership, there is hope that the school’s outstanding staff
will receive the support that all teachers need and deserve. It is time for our
school community to heal and move forward.

The recent change of leadership (a new principal) is an encouraging signal that Washington Heights Academy is getting back on track with its original goals of high academic expectations, parent involvement and relationships at the center of its day-to-day practice.  We have an exceptional teaching staff, small classes (usually) and the DOE is extremely supportive of the original school mission and vision, including the eventual expansion to a pre-K through 8. I think this is a good place to participate in my child's education.

The school was on the right track and my child is doing really well. The school had all the components mentioned already, the change in leadership is a sign of the failure of our school system to protect children from folks that don't have the best interest of children in mind, but of their own personal agenda. I'm hopeful that my child continues to thrive despite the new leadership and that some people take responsibility for the negative energy they have brought to the school and neighborhood.
NY1 reports that though PS 366 has a state-of-the-art science lab, they don't have the teachers to utilize it. Read the full story: New Science Labs Remian Unused, Without Teachers.

As the school approaches full capacity (having opened our middle school in September 2014), both our lower grade Science Room and upper grade Science Lab are regularly utilized by all PreK, elementary and middle school students, who receive regular hands-on science instruction from designated Science teachers. Grade 4 students receive additional science enrichment from Yeshiva University Project START <https://yuacs.wordpress.com/start/>, a student volunteer program with whom we have partnered for several years. During the current school year, students in the upper grades have also had the opportunity to study Robotics and Computer Coding as part of our Saturday Academy.

My daughter has thrived at Washington Heights Academy, but I'm concerned that the school's original mission and overall performance are eroding.  Yes, we're in a brand new building and the school raised its Progress Report grade last year.  But it only achieved this through a great deal of test prep.  Several talented teachers left in the summer and a haphazard enrollment process led to uneven class sizes this year.  And much to the dismay of many parents, the family involvement practices that made the school unique have languished under the school's current administration.

Our Progress Report grade is an aberration that is at odds with other measures that indicate that Washington Heights Academy is a quality school, including good overall test scores and a positive Quality Review. As a new, small school, our grade rested almost entirely on the state test scores of a small sample in a single grade whose scores could be compared to the previous year. Our teachers and staff are fabulous, and are using the report to focus more resources on areas in need of improvement. For more information, see a letter to the Manhattan Times.
The classrooms are so small.  There’s no room to do anything.
That was years ago
I’ve been able to grow [as a teacher] as the school has grown.
A mom of a 3rd grader who has ADD/ADHD, who is not on medication, said, "Everyone is sensitive to his needs and my voice counts as a parent."
"It is parent oriented. ... There is parent involvement -- no parent gets left behind -- we join together," said a parent.

A parent praised Lynn Herndon, who is the school's community coordinator and one of its founding parents. (Community coordinator is similar to parent coordinator.) "I was a parent freaking out, but her kindness and understanding lead me to my decision to trust my instincts about the school," she said.

"We all get to know each other and are free to discuss and not have to be scared," a parent said. "If they see your child slowing down, they talk to me immediately. We are like a very nice family, other parents are like cousins and the academics and teacher access it good."
One young girl said, "I love it here. Art, dancing and math are my favorite."
"It's wonderful, the best place for a first year teacher to be," said a teacher. "Administration, parent support -- I couldn't ask for more."
The female security guard at the front desk said, "This is a dream compared to where I worked before," a large high school. "It's small and quiet."

Parent Vicky Rueda writes: "WHA has impacted my life and my son's life forever because it is a piece of heaven in our Inwood community. It is a place where our children learn their academics, along with social and life skills. The best part of all is that parents get to join in on the fun."
Parent Jessica Herrera writes that the school made "our kids feel special, and they are all the more closer because of the sense of family created by WHA."

"WHA promises and delivers a unique and rewarding experience," writes parent Marlyn Montalvo. "We as parents always have meetings with the teachers to update us on what's happening in our children's classes, which is very important if we want to be able to help."

"This is a great program, not only for the children but also for the parents at the WHA! There are so many activities, class meetings, and many more that the Washington Heights Acedemy offers," writes parent Virginia Lopez.

this school is failing because a small group of well connected white parents keep trying to colonize the school and devalue the needs and desires of the majority students and families of color.  ala "nice white parents" https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/23/podcasts/nice-white-parents-serial.html

My son is a 5th grader and has been at HHS since 1st grade. It has been a wonderful experience for him.  Classes are small and the teachers are excellent.  While there has been problems with administration in the past, the teachers and families at the school have maintained the the special spirit of the school. We now have a strong, proactive principal in Charles Reilly. Within just a few weeks of his first year he brought in after school programs and this year has coordinated with Boys & Girls Club of Harlem for after school coverage till 6pm.  Our teachers have always been jewels of the school as they have created safe, stimulating classrooms where our kids thrive.  For example, when my son struggled in 4th grade with math early in the year, it was quickly clear that there were social/emotional issues contributing to his struggle and his teacher skillfully came up with plans to address both sides of the struggle. When the social/emotional issues started manifesting outside of school, his teacher and Mr. Reilly were incredibly supportive and made sure my son had the support he needed.  Within just a couple months my son was again thriving socially and emotionally and had raised is math average by 10 points!  This year Mr. Reilly has the two 5th grade classes sharing teachers -- one is teaching math and science, the other ELA and Social Studies -- so the kids switch classrooms, getting a taste of what is to come in middle school. The teachers are excited because they aren't as "overwhelmed" and can dedicate more time and energy developing lessons that are engaging and meet the needs of learners of all levels.  I am so grateful to have found this gem of a school and confident my son will thrive in middle school thanks to the strong, creative education he is receiving here.

A word of caution about this school.  I had a child just graduate from HHS this year.  It was a great school for her and most of the teachers are amazing.  My son, who has special needs, was a first grader last year. HHS was a nightmare for him last year.  I had been expressing concern to the new principal, Charles Reilly, since 12/18 regarding the special education teacher in his class.  Other parents witnessed her making my son sit out of recess for questionable reasons.  He has ADHD and needs to be able to exercise!  My daughter reported observing the same thing. Mr. Reilly continually pushed it off and didn't do anything about my concerns, he even told me I had something personal against the teacher. My son started having nightmares and was acting differently at home. I continually tried to discuss with the teachers and the principal, and was told my son was happy in school. In April, another mom received a call from a staff person in the school to tell her that my son and 3 other kids were being targeted by the SE teacher, the same one I had been complaining about for 5 months. This mom went to Mr. Reilly, who stated that no one had complained about this teacher before and that there was nothing to be concerned about.  5 other parents had already complained! Our children developed anxiety because the Special Education teacher started taking away free time from students for spelling a word wrong or getting a math question wrong. These are first graders!
My only regret is not putting a camera on my son to get proof of the abuse that was happening. The teacher was screaming, humiliating, and pulling on my son's arm forcefully. This is not a school for children with special needs.  I have continually had problems with his services and most of the teachers are not equipped to work with kids with special needs.  HHS has a practice of having kids share paras to save money and don't want to give services because their budget is very small. They will insist that they can serve your child, but I assure you they cannot. Once you are in the school, it is hard to get out or transfer elsewhere, which I learned the hard way. My son was spending hours of his day wandering the halls and I didn't know this until the end of the year, when I had him evaluated for another program which sent a team into observe him. My son now hates school and it's going to take a while for him to ease back in to a new one. I had to constantly explain his disability to professionals who are supposed to be familiar with children's disabilities and the challenges they present. 

I cannot, with good conscience, recommend this school.  The way the situation with my son was handled was terrible.  I know that you think this could never happen to your kid, I didn't either, but it did and I will forever regret not getting recorded proof so that I can prevent this happening to someone else's child. I went through the proper channels to report it but without a recording, there is nothing. Please do your homework, find another place to put your child with special needs!
you can file a complaint https://www.nycenet.edu/offices/osi/CPR_Form/form.aspx

I have two kids at HHS, 4th and 2nd grade. Every year that we've been here I
 have been incredibly impressed with the teachers. Classrooms are joyful
 places, and my kids consistently want to go to school. HHS is small and
 community-focused, like the schools I went to in Vermont. Parents are 
welcomed into the building and the classrooms at any time. There is a 
focus on art and creativity and getting hands dirty. The DOE 
numbers are pretty rotten mostly because the school rejects the 
high-pressure testing -- we have a more than 50% opt out rate. The 
teachers don't teach to the tests, they teach to the kids. I love that.

My daughter is a first grader at Hamilton Heights School. WE LOVE IT! She is flourishing in Math and Reading and it's so exciting to see. I teach at a private school in the city, and we choose to send her here because it's such a wonderful learning environment. We also love that as a first grader she gets dance three times a week, and music twice a week. Arts education is a high priority in our family. Her teachers are caring and the new principal DeDe Budd is terrific. I think she will bring some strong leadership that the school needs. The parents and teachers have carried leadership on their backs when past principals have failed to do so. The way I describe the school to many is feeling like getting a big hug when you walk in the building, but with Math.

My son has been at Hamilton Heights School for three years and we are very happy with the school. It is a small, progressive school, with small class sizes (around 20 students per class), dedicated teachers and focus on the arts ( our students have dance and music two to three times a week). Nearly 50% of our students opt out of standardized tests, and teachers do not teach to the test, but focus on inquiry-based learning instead. What also makes our school unique is also the wonderful parent body. Parents are always welcome in the school, which makes our school a true community.

The minute we walked in the doors at HHS, we knew it was the best school for our daughter-warm, creative, and attentive teachers who know how to foster a love of learning, a welcoming atmosphere, caring staff who pay attention to every child. We especially love that the kids get dance and music twice a week each and that there is a focus on the arts and creative projects and community. She has been attending since kindergarten and is now in second grade. Parents and siblings are welcome in the school and classrooms, especially at Friday morning singalong. I can't wait to send my little boy here when he is old enough!

I am now a seventh grader. I not only met amazing friends and teachers, but I got an amazing education works. The teachers have fun ways of learning and they help you if you don't understand. I would highly recommend this school. Now I go to Manhattan East school for Arts and Academics and would not of made it without HHS. SEND YOUR CHILDREN HERE.
i graduated from this school, its the best elementary school ever I'm in the 6th grade now, I'm on the honor roll every semester thanks to what this school taught me

My daughter had been accepted in a G&T program in another school, but when we visited Hamilton Heights School, we knew that that was the right school for her. She has been thriving ever since. It’s like an entirely new, beautiful side of her personality is flourishing. She has made many new friends, asks for play dates, and always comes home to do her homework and book log. She is more inquisitive, more motivated, and happier than I’ve ever seen her. Her teacher is absolutely wonderful. I also love the racial, social and international diversity of the school, and the way that the school really fosters a climate of camaraderie among its students, teachers, staff and parents. Our “Sing-Along” sessions on Friday mornings are fun and deeply moving: all the students get together with parents and teachers in the cafeteria and sing in unison. We are also very happy with HHS’s afternoon program, where our children learn gymnastics, do art, and where the older ones can sign up to learn Chinese. Last, I really appreciate the parental involvement and passion, and I am happy to be part of a community like the one we are creating together at Hamilton
Heights School.

I have two daughters who attended Hamilton Heights School since Kindergarten -- one currently a 5th grader and one who graduated and is now in 7th grade at an academic magnet school.

Hamilton Heights School is true to its mission and vision statements.  So many schools SAY they are family-friendly, and create caring communities, and treat children as individuals, but they really don't.  At Hamilton Heights, it's all true.  

The tone is busy, respectful, and caring.  There is not silence here, but the quiet buzz of students eagerly going about their work.  

In addition to the items in the review, I want to add that the teachers are loving, thoughtful, and dedicated.  Social justice is a theme that comes up frequently.  A full music program is provided to all students.


I COULD have sent my children to a gifted-and-talented program, but what they have learned here is even more valuable.  They are adequately challenged academically while truly learning to see and value each person's strengths, and feeling their role as vital members of a vibrant caring community.

Hamilton Heights School has been absolutely wonderful for our daughter. There is a special vibe there of caring, community, academic rigorousness, and dedication to students that you will not find elsewhere.

"Honestly the school has a lot going for it - good veteran teachers and young idealistic go-getters, intelligent creative students, and a somewhat supportive administration. But somehow it misses excellence," writes a teacher. "This is partly due to disruptive students, inconsistent classroom management & punishment, and lack of parental involvement/investment. The ESP classes are excellent, however, and the school has amazing extra-curricular programs that benefit the whole school. Yet overall it is an above-average, struggling school."
"I think it's o.k.," said a 7th grader. "I kinda feel safe."
"When there's a problem the assistant principal and the principal take care of it right away," said one student. "They don't wait for something to happen. They squash it right away."
"I mostly love everything," said one 3rd grader.
"I like that the kids are very respectful. They're nice to each other and they respect our stuff," said one 3rd grader.

P.S. 31 was recently praised in the 2007 Blackboard Awards. The school made the honor roll lists for "Quality of Math and Science Instruction," "Integration of Technology in Instruction, and "Respect for Students by Each Other." In addition, one commenter noted that the addition of a new school counselor has made a real difference. "He has made a huge impact on the classroom and learning experience school-wide."

Student Betty writes that "this school has many features that students will like!" For example, "we have many events such as cycles, where you get to learn [about] things you don't learn in school, such as the human body, photography, astronomy, etc... We also have end of the year trips for 5th, 6th, and 7th graders. They get to go to other countries for a week or two," she writes.
"This is an excellent school," writes parent Lisa-ann Gillings. "The only bad thing they are located within two other schools, and the big kids bully the younger kids."

Teacher Dorothy Brown-Tucker writes that PS/MS31 recently adopted a plan to improve professional development for teachers, bring enrichment resources to students, and build connections between enrichment and state standards.
Ms. Tucker is the best teacher that a parent could have to prepare their kids for the future. She is caring and dedicated to the whole child.

"I dislike everything about this school. My child has been acting out every since he has been in this school," writes a parent, who believes "gifted" students receive preferential treatment. "My child has been on both sides and there is a difference in the treatment of the students." The parent adds: "PS 31 added 6th grade and now there are 33 students in three classes with only one teacher per class."
"The gifted and talented program helps those students get into the prep for prep program and other programs like it that lead their students to bigger and brighter futures," writes student Stephanie.
A student writes: "I personally think this is a great school. I have worked harder than I thought I could."
Ileana, a student, writes: "Right now I am in the ESP gifted program and it is very fun. My teacher is great and makes us understand things we don't get."

Vikelia, a former student, writes: "I went to this school from K-6 in the ESP progam. I have became a successful younger student and from all the teachers in that school I have now gone to a great public middle school, IS162." She notes that she still takes part in a gifted education prograqm, and credits PS 31 for her success.

"I went to PS 31 in elementary school from kindergarten until 6th grade," writes Brittany M., a former student in the ESP program. "I thought it was a amazing school. In PS 31 they offer the best education, and the best programs. PS 31 has amazing teachers and an amazing principal Mrs. Russo. This school also has the best scores in that neighborhood. I am going to ninth grade now, but I went to a prestigious middle school and I am going to a prestigious high school because of PS 31. I personally loved PS 31."

"This school has a great curriculum for the ESP or gifted classes but the other classes are not given the proper attention," writes Annette Flores, a parent. She writes of "a huge bully problem in this school" as a result of the fact that "PS 31 shares the building with a [junior high school] and the older kids create chaos and distractions in which seem to difficult for the administration to handle."

"My daughter entered PS 31 in the 4th grade, I was extremely pleased with the school and her teachers," writes Mrs. Francis. "The school overall is an excellent school." Still, she writes, the administration is not accessible to parents or students.

This school has a lot of issues. The building is cramped, oddly structured inside, and outdated to the point where concentration and focus is near impossible. The building has issues with clean water and rats. My daughter has seen several rats and mice. The school has no library or extra curricular activities. If they did, I have no idea about them because the school doesn't communicate very well. There are no sports either. PTA meetings are at 8:45am??? Clearly they don't want engaged working parents to attend, nor do they even try to have a second session in the evening. Other meetings they have are parent cook sessions at 8:45am.....um how about parent student behavior workshops, not a damn cooking class? Majority of the children are very disruptive to the point where the teachers aren't teaching but trying to get the classroom under control. Bright students fall behind because teachers have to focus on those yelling all the time. Nothing is electronic, you can not check on your child's behavior or grades online, and there are no computers. There are no field trips. The school's disciplinary action is a joke. I witnessed a mother upset that her son was bullied and confronted what appeared to be a teacher or aid. The teachers response was that because they didn't see it there was nothing they can do and they need to find the adult that did witness it. He didn't even try to console her or direct her to someone who can actually help her. It was ridiculous! This school would be much better if parents got more involved, children were better behaved and less disruptive, they implemented clubs and activities, improved communication and opportunities to parents, and help students focus through renovations.

After some discussion with other parents and school administrators, the school's policy on recess is changing and children will now have time built into the school day for physical movement and activity. I have to say that the school was responsive to reintroducing recess. We are pleased with this development and hope that it is indicative of parents getting our concerns heard and acted upon.

I think this profile is a bit outdated. At least I don't recognize the school my 4-year-old attends in it. It's now almost February and her pre-K class has yet to take more than one walk around the neighborhood much less visit a farm, museum, or other library. They have no recess, ever (the AP blames the teachers for not wanting to go outside and the teachers assure me that it's actually a school policy; something about not considering the neighborhood safe enough for the kids to be outside! Well, newsflash: we all live here and most of us walk with our kids to school.) And they only have PE once a week. 

They do give the younger kids' families access to the Cool Culture card, which enables us to visit many cultural institutions that would otherwise be too expensive to go to on a regular basis. But we do that on our own time.

The dynamic principal? I don't see that either. My brief interaction with her showed me someone who was entirely condescending and patronizing. She didn't even bother to ask my name before launching into a lecture. And this is in addition to reading my child's name and mistaking her gender because it is not a common English name.

I do find the teachers and staff we interact with on the whole to be caring and engaged (if a tad overly concerned with discipline and arbitrary rules). And I have few complaints about the general vibe in the class. But the school also seems unable to withstand the testing/standards frenzy. My daughter gets homework most days and extra packets to complete over vacation, which to me is ridiculous for kids younger than 8 and defeats the purpose of having a holiday. 

I wish the atmosphere were more lively and that the school resembled the one in the description above more. I'd be a lot happier about her continuing to go to this since it's our zoned school and I truly believe that we need neighborhood schools to be centers of caring communities. But sadly, this school has a long way to go. We are applying to others for next year.
PS 49 has been added to the state's list of schools needing improvement under No Child Left Behind because of inadequate performance on the state tests in English.

Under the supportive guidance of Principal Laura Galloway and Assistant Principal Weeks, the school flourishes. It is a pleasure to be part of something that is so motivated to help our children."

"Everything we need, we get," said 3rd grade teacher Anna Sanchez. "I have billions of books on every level. The principal has a vision and she knows where she is going." "I wish there were 12 grades just to keep you as my principal," two girls, Yasmine and Malaysha, wrote.

The city announced that Mother Hale School, on a state list of “persistently lowest achieving” schools, will most likely be phased out and replaced with new schools, it was reported in The New York Times on June 25, 2010.
According to a July 7, 2008 New York Daily News article, the school will recieve a playground by September 2008.

An Insideschools.org reader writes: "I am a teacher at a school in western Massachusetts. During the spring of 2004 I visited Mother Hale school with my students after reading Amazing Grace and being afforded the visit by Dr. Cruz. She and her staff graciously hosted us -- a large group of comparatively affluent Anglos. What struck my students most strongly was the supportive, affectionate atmosphere. In our school environment, there is little touching, [but] at Mother Hale, we saw students constantly hugged and lovingly supported by the staff." She adds: "Another shock -- the cleanliness and bright colors in the school. It felt like a valued place holding valued children. It was a very positive and powerful experience for all of us. Dr. Cruz and her staff have our admiration for their hard work and for enlightening rather dimly aware visitors."

A father, who said his children are "crazy about going to school" and would rather go to school than stay home, praised the changes put in place by the new administration. "Before, they would come home and they were clueless [about their homework]," he said. "Now, they can explain their homework and do it on their own. They read on their own. They enjoy science and history."

Hi Sarita, My name is Andre Mendez. I too was in that first class. I remember the school was still under construction. Lots of great memories!

I'd like to start out by saying this review needs to be updated. An interview with the new principal would be nice.  The new principal, Ms. Rivera has tried her best to reach out to the parents by encouraging enrollment in the PTA, with "parent's night out" free dinners and Thanksgiving potluck dinners.  

The parent coordinator (who's main job is to be a link between parents and the school) is Ms. Vicente.  She also tries to foster parent involvement which I completely love about her. If I could recommend one person to develop a relationship with in this school for parents, it would be Ms. Vicente. My view of the school staff went up about 100% once I got to know her. 

On the downside, I don't see how there hasn't been an outcry for more serious academics in this school.  The children are barely getting by, in all honesty. "No Child Left Behind" is a joke. 

What I would like to see in this school would be a music program (I wandered into Kipp Academy by accident and saw the music equipment - how is it that the Gehrig children are in the same building but different sections of the school and are not receiving these benefits?)
"This review is four and one-half years old and in serious need of refreshening."

Cordelia, a student, writes: "I think the school is great ... Even though the students can be [obnoxious] sometimes they are really great. I have been going to the school for three years and i really like it."
"I like this school because I can go outside everyday to play," a 6th grade student said. .

Former PS 154 Parent Amanda Martinez transferred her son to a Success Academy Charter School after being unsatisfied with the pace of the Renewal School's progress. Signs of improvement for teachers and students alike are uneven among the Renewal School program schools, as the New York Times Reports.

PS 154 was the top performing Renewal school on the 2016 statewide tests. The results showed that 27 percent of its students were proficient in English and 25 percent were proficient in math. Read the full story here.

P.S. 154 was one of thirty-seven schools chosen to participate in the Showcase Schools program, a program that works to promote effective teaching methods by asking schools to host educators from around the city. Read more here.

This is a good school indeed. The staff are always open for parents. The school is amazing. The teachers are really devoted to their children. They want them to do well and excel. Every time I see a kid leave their school it is with a smile.

Ninety-four low-performing schools are now called “Renewal Schools,” by DiBlasio. They will receive increased funds designated for an hour of additional learning time, after-school and summer programs, and teacher training. The principals will also be under review. Read more here.

Fariña visited P.S. 154's Summer Quest program and observed students preparing to run a farmer’s market featuring produce from the school’s garden and eggs from the small chicken coop next to the school. Read more here.

"The teachers are great," said a mother. "The parents' room is always open. They are welcoming to parents. You don't have to wait for open school night to visit."

A parent whose daughter has been enrolled since Pre-K writes that she has had "excellent academic progress" in an accelerated class offered by the school. "In the past three years my child has had wonderful teachers and I have not encountered any problems with her learning achievements. In fact, my daughter is in the 1st grade and is already reading at a 3rd grade level." She feels that teachers are not solely responsible for children's educations and urges parents to become more involved. Her only complaint about the school is that "the administration can be disorganized about communicating with parents and publicizing school events." .

Assistant Principal Sara Carvajal said she transferred her child to PS 157 from a parochial school because it offered "more cooperative activities" and the chance to "talk a lot," rather than "desks bolted in rows" and a passive form of instruction.

I worked at PS 161, and want to direct my comment to prospective teachers thinking about working here.

I see many of the comments here are about disruptive students. I felt that this behavior was about the same as other schools with high economic need. The children are not the problem at this school.

The biggest issue is administration. The principal is very hands off and lets the APs handle everything, even answering her emails. They are quite disorganized, i.e. sometimes they announce the wrong times for meetings/assemblies, or they say they will provide you some support and then never do it.

Worst of all, one of the APs is a bully who likes to play favorites and abuse her power. Teachers live in fear of getting yelled at and written up for minor incidents. She has a need to control everything: your bulletin boards, your classroom furniture, your lesson plans. UFT knows about this, but she gets away with it because she will argue with everything and twist the contract wording around. She barges in on teachers during their prep/lunch to make them do something. She has even threatened not to recommend tenure for effective-rated teachers. I firmly believe she is the main reason why 161 has high teacher turnover.

Another consideration for candidates is there are charter schools all around 161, so enrollment is constantly dropping. They have lost a lot of funding and will need to let teachers go (even tenured teachers). So if you get a job here, your job could be gone very quickly.

If you read through all of this, please consider this information, for your career and your well-being.
PS 161 now offers free pre-kindergarten for both 3- and 4-year olds.
The dual language program at PS 161 will begin in pre-kindergarten, beginning in 2015.

I am a recently retired teacher. I visited my old school 161 where I was an ESL teacher for two years some years back and met the principle today for about one minute. I'd never met the principle before today and didn't hear her introduce herself--maybe I didn't hear something.  I found Ms. Soto's comment---"you have no reason to visit here"-unfriendly. I had just signed in with security. (The officer, in contrast, was appropriately friendly.) I told her that I would like to greet old coworkers, but she brushed me off. One staff member saw me before I actually left and shook my hand but I already feared Ms. Soto. Did any body ever hear of something called camaraderie? Sullivan and LaSalle were principles when I was teaching there. Fortunately I was in very high spirits and left. I think Mark Weisman was teaching when I was teaching there, but I didn't know he had become an assistant principle and even principle there.

Teaching is a team effort. While all my students have already graduated from elementary school and I wish them the very best, staff camaraderie can go a long way in maintaining school moral. I encourage retiring teachers to maintain contact with  other staff and their students.  Is this just a dream?

DNAinfo profiled South Bronx Prep's principal, Ellen Flanagan, who conducted her doctoral research on the transition from middle to high school while teaching middle school in Tremont. Read more: South Bronx Principal Ellen Flanagan conducts research, cracks jokes

There’s no denying that SBP is
part of my story.


More than 306,000 seconds, 756
days, 5,100 hours, and 7 years of my life have been spent inside the walls of South
Bronx Prep. I’ve been taught by over 20 teachers, taken various exams, and
handed in more homework assignments then I can count.  My days as a student at SBP ended in June 2011
as part of the first 6-12 graduating class. I had the privilege of growing
simultaneously with my school having been one of the very first students of
SBP. 


SBP has been a home to me and
continues to be one for so many students today. The strong sense of community
is comforting and contributes to a welcoming and safe atmosphere. SBP’s teachers
not only educate their students but
many of them act as a vent to the students as well.  It’s always been a priority that students
perform well academically but it’s equally important that they feel comfortable
among their peers and aren’t feeling burdened with life outside of school.  


 But of course, academics are just as imperative.
As a student at SBP I was challenged intellectually and pushed to my absolute
full potential. Not only are students pushed to deliver their best
academically, students are able to seek plenty of one-on-one assistance and
further clarification of in-class material after school hours. 


Not only did I enjoy experiences
multiple teaching styles, but I was able to take advantage of a dependable
support system, make friends, and participate in a variety of clubs and student
organizations. I even had the opportunity to start my own organization that is
still running strongly after 2 years and is currently in its 3rd
chapter.


Because I spoke up abut something
I wanted changed I had the option to start something new at my school. SBP
offers plenty of opportunities for students to speak up, ask for change, and
lead the changes. As such a tightly-knit community I think it’s a very
important aspect that ANY small school should have.


I left SBP feeling prepared for
the real world and its challenges. I walked out with a diploma in hand, an
essence of college readiness, and even left a legacy. Yes, it’s safe to say
that SBP isn’t perfect, and that is why teachers, administrators, and staff
strive to work together as a team to keep moving forward and overcome and improve
the weaknesses in SBP’s system.  But if
you, parent, and your child are willing to grow alongside SBP with all its pros
and cons I believe your student has a place and would be more than content at
SBP.

South Bronx Prep (SBP) is located within a community where the
main freedom from hardships are through education, and with so many people
missing out on the opportunity it makes it harder for statistics to be positive,
but South Bronx Preparatory has made it possible by opening its doors in 2004
with a goal of changing the atmosphere of the once known Elijah Clark and forming
a community of middle and high school students.  Some may think the span of 6th grades
through 12th in one concentrated space may be inappropriate, but the
truth is that it unifies everyone as a whole, and that is not just by the
uniform policy. Interactions of the seven different grade levels give each and
every student the privilege to communicate and break down the barriers of age.
Not only making sure that the community of students are well associated, the
administrators, teachers and staff play their part extremely well. They elicit
a sense of safety and security for the students- even the role of a mentor.

A school is to be the common ground for learning and
success, and with the universal College Board curriculum it makes all students
think, plan, prepare, and eventually initiate the college process when they are
high school seniors. 



Ready or not for college South Bronx Prep will get you ready
for it. As an alumnus of SBP I can attest to the fact that there are no excuses
for any student as to why they are not ready for the next step of their
educational career. Teachers, administrators and staff will be the backbone of
every student the moment they enter and until the day they leave through the
doors of SBP, and it doesn’t end there. Once you commit yourself to SBP it’s a
done deal; consider your educational career a success.



If a support system like the one South Bronx Preparatory
generated is not amazing I do not know what else is. I praise this school for
their continuous strive in making sure that no one is left behind. This school
is unlike others, do not let the smaller scale of students fool you, but it’s
the advantage of my alma mater SBP. And I am proud to say I attended, persevered,
conquered and continued on, and my communication with the school is ongoing. One
cannot forget the assistance from all of SBP in the struggle towards success. I
made it and anyone’s child can too.

I am a student of south bronx prepatory and i can also say this isn't a good school at all. Students always wandering in the halls, Leaving school on school hours in front of security guards without any of them acknowledging any of the administration about it. Academically MAJORITY of the students are not actually "college ready" as it is one of the schools main goals. Alot of teachers cannot control the students from staying in there classes. When visitors are present that is really the only time the issue is pushed to really educate. Attendance is terrible in this school and things are always getting stolen. If you ask ANY of the seniors in this school they will say they wish they never came to this school and chosen another school to go to. There are fights here and there in this school with the projects that are close to the school zone. I HIGHLY wouldnt recommend this school to go to if you really want to be "college ready" and graduate.

This school isn't really great and this is coming from a student. There aren't a lot extracurricular activities, barely any AP classes, there is only one foreign language class, not a lot of team sports and when I asked the seniors about their experience at SBP most said they wished they never chosen this school in the first place. I'm actually regretting my decision right now about going to this school. So parents all I ask is that your kids will not make the same mistake. South Bronx Preparatory graduated 91.2 percent of their eligible students, but only 14.7 percent were ready for college, according to their progress reports for the 2010-11 school year. Read more: At Most High Schools, Fewer Than Half of Graduates Are Ready for College.

South Bronx Prep has been great for my son and me. I can email the principal or the guidance counselor and they promptly return to my email or call. Ms. Flanagan is very involved with the students and has a great attitude. Definitely the best school in the area.
Special Education teacher Victoria Orsi received the NYC Teaching Fellows Award for Classroom Excellence, Chancellor Klein announced.
“I was borderline failing at another school before I came here.  They helped me academically a lot.  Here they don't wait until the last minute to tell you you’re failing.”
“Academically my kids are doing well.  I'm in and out of here all the time.  I am putting this school on the high school application because everyone knows everyone here, even academically.”
“The principal is very accessible.  Parents were reluctant when the new principal came on board, but she has a good rapport with the kids and staff and has won us over.”

Students and teachers at the school are conversing, reading teachers' notes, and accessing homework assignment over the Internet, through the use of eChalk, an online system that creates a virtual school community and enables students to obtain homework assignments, principal notices, and more from any computer - even at home, according to a May 27th, 2008 New York Daily News article. "Sometimes I still have kids come in and say 'I don't have the assignment, I wasn't here.' But that's not an excuse anymore," said Math teacher, Sameh Fakhouri. [...] "It's actually pretty helpful. If I don't finish my project in class, I can take it home and work on it," said student Alan Dennis, 17. "And I can e-mail my teacher if I have questions about it."

A school counselor said "advisories" -- in which teachers and other staff meet daily with a small group of students to talk about any issues that concern them -- make the school special. Staffers help students with social and emotional issues as well as academic ones, the counselor said, adding, "The artificial divorce between teaching and learning and student support doesn't exist here."

"The mission of South Bronx Preparatory is to facilitate learning so that all students can master the challenges of a rigorous curriculum that will guide them to college entrance and successm," according to the school's mission statement. "We are committed to establishing a strong school community of families, teachers, and staff in support of our core mission. Our students will learn to think critically, communicate effectively, and be open to new experiences and ideas as they become lifelong learners," according to the statement posted on the College Board's website.

MS 223 will expand to include a high school, adding one grade level each year, beginning with ninth grade this year. DNAinfo reports that the new class of ninth graders will benefit from a new science lab and will be issued Google laptops. Read more here.

M.S. 223 The Laboratory School of Finance and Technology is among 40 middle schools selected for an extended learning day pilot with 2.5 more learning hours in the school day for all students, and daily literacy tutoring for high needs students. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

This is an excellent. I work in the neighborhood and see the kids who are going to MS223. While they are a "choice" school, they still take kids in the neighborhood. They still work with kids who are scorings 1s and 2s on their tests. The whole process of choosing and being accepted into schools in NYC can be very confusing for even the most involved parents. Even schools don't get to choose every srudent they enroll. MS223 has a dedicated staff, high expectations for all students and is a place where kids can feel safe. 

Students are respected at MS223 and the administration and staff believe that all students can succeed there. Test scores are rising not because of "better test takers," but because of quality teaching, students who want to be there and parents who are involved in the school.

Here is a comment from NYT Article which best sums up the chances for your child to get in:

dc, NYC April 10th, 2011 11:34 pm
"I know a fifth grade teacher at a neighboring south bronx elementary school. I am told that to these fifth graders, MS 223 is highly desirable. Most of them do not get accepted. Who does? MS 223 is a "choice" school (see insideschools.org re: 223 admissions). Like the fifth graders at this local S Bronx elementary school, neighborhood children can request the school, but they don't necessarily get in. So when Mr Gonzalez says he takes them as they walk in the door, if you think that means he must take anyone, that's not true. Most of the children are accepted competitively, from what I understand, that is the definition of 'choice' school when too many 'choose' it. Since too many list 223, at least from this one neighboring elementary school, it has the ability to pick the 'best' of the lot, for the most part, and does (though some students might be assigned there). The better students are chosen, the rest are left to MS 162 or MS 224 or other less desirable middle schools. "Better" is a relative word, particularly in that neighborhood where many barely perform at or below grade level. Nonetheless, clearly due to its popularity and 'choice' admissions, there is some selection over many who apply vs those who are admitted Its popularity, no doubt, is due to Mr Gonzalez in large part."The above is very true. My son and I live across the street from this school, I open my curtains and see this school. MS223 is his zoned school, yet he was not accepted. We attended both the open house and interview. I was told by the female interviewer "his porfolio was excellent (this included teacher recommendations) and that he did very well". When the acceptance letters went out, he was assigned to another District 7 school. When we called MS223 we were told a song and dance story about their process. One of his classmates who didn't bother attending the open house or the interview was accepted (he lives in another district) which goes to show how true the above NYT comment really is. Word of Advice: Don't be fooled by the rising test scores for this school. The scores only rose because they choose students who are better testers. This means that even if your child is an overall great student but gets nervous during testing, they won't even bother looking at him/her as a potential student.If you're a District 7 middle school parent, don't box yourself into thinking MS223 is the only choice because you'll be wasting your time on the open house and interview process. There are plenty of charter schools that are willing to take your child and help them grow as a student, you just have to look for them. There is a new charter school opening in that same building (not sure the date it opens) which means you will have yet another option for your middle school child.

Despite recent citywide budget cuts, students at MS 223 have been endowed with professional art instruction from a grant obtained by the school, according to a May 27th, 2008 Daily News article. '"To be able to feel successful in one part of their day makes them feel engaged and successful the rest of the time," said literacy coach Rose Greco. Sixth-grader Vilma Bermeudez, 11, said she likes her art classes so much that it helps her get through trickier subjects, like math. 'When we do art, I feel like I can express myself through the drawings,' she said. 'I feel good doing it. I look forward to doing something when I come to school."' The new art program is open to all 6th graders, however Principal Gonzalez plans to expand the engaging courses to 7th and 8th graders.

Principal Ramon Gonzalez received a 2007 Cahn fellowship, a 16-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize and develop outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor other principals, while continuing to serve as principal at their schools.

"We have an extremely high attendance rate for our staff," writes principal Ramon Gonzalez. "Our school averages 4 absences per year per teacher over the last three years, one of the lowest in the city and a reflection of our school environment (The Board of Education teacher average per school is over 10 days). And we have one of the highest student attendance rates for a middle school of our size... We have recruited 5 teachers with three or more years of experience out of a staff of 32. We have only lost 1 teacher in the past three school years.

"We have become a model site for literacy and special education with students of high poverty rates in Region 9," the principal writes, adding that the Reading and Writing Project at Teachers College has selected MS 223 as a model for middle schools in high poverty areas. "We recently were selected by Laura Kotch, the deputy to [deputy schools chancellor] Carmen Farina, as a part of the Collaborative Communities of Practice, a small select group of schools with model practices in New York City.

"We have had a Reading and Writing Project staff developer work with our English Language Arts teachers for the last two years. Last year's staff developer, Rose Greco, felt the school had so much potential that she chose to come work with us full-time as our literacy coach after not only working for the project but for notable District 2 schools such as IS 89 in Battery Park and The Salk School of Science in Gramercy Park."

Gonzalez continues: "We recently have been the topic of several articles in the news media about our school and our finance program ('Best in Class', Cornell Alumni Magazine Jan/Feb 2005.'Valuable lessons', NY POST 10/18/2005, 'Innovative School Program Paying Huge Dividend for Students' Bronx Times January 5, 2006, Telemundo International Vivo Rojo 12/13/2005). These articles have cited our school as innovative and our staff as 'out of the box thinkers.'"

The school, which had some students reading at a 1st or 2nd grade level when it first opened, is now attracting stronger students, including many who list MS 223 as their first choice, Gonzalez writes. "Most students now range between 4th to 8th grade reading level. We were ranked 8th in Middle School ELA test score growth in the City in 2005."
"I like this school," writes student Roberta.

"Being at The Laboratory School of Finance & Technology, was like a breath of fresh air, in terms of the excellent educational model being developed at this school," writes Carl E. Reid, President of NYTC, who participated as Principal for a Day at MS 223. "As I participated in a class run by a teacher named Ms. Sobin, I saw young students embrace their school work while being taught a combination of creative writing, public speaking and learning how to encourage each other. Using technology to spur education is apparent in every classroom. Principal Ramon Gonzalez and his energetic professional staff have motivated me to do whatever I can personally and through LISTA to assist in helping MS 223 continue to develop our future leaders."
"All of us are here until 5 p.m. and school gets out at 2 p.m.," a teacher said. "It's almost overwhelming at times, but I'm really passionate about it."
A mother wrote that she was grateful that the principal went out and looked for her son and found him in the neighborhood when he didn't come home one afternoon.

Science School for Exploration and Discovery is being accused of grade inflation after discrepancies found in comparing passing scores in math classes and that of the state math exam. The New York Post reports that 94% of its students received passing marks in their math classes, but only 2% passed the statewide test.

The Daily News reports that Principal Catania will be leaving IS 224 after being accused of denying her black teachers and students the opportunity to teach and receive black history lessons. To fill her position, the DOE says to be working with the community to find a replacement who will better fit the needs of the school.
Pix11 News shows the community protests in response to recent reported actions of the school's administration.
